The  questions  being  very  easy,  the  percentage  of  failures  was  consequently  low.  An  examination  conducted  exclusively  in  writing,  as  we  have  it  at  present,  however,  forms  hardly  n  test  of  the   practical  knowledge  of  a  living  languuge. heading: GERMAN POLAND. "TEACHING" GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN  POLAND.   'TEACHING'  OERHAN.   LONDON,  December  .1.  —  It  is  reported  that  Prussian  schoolmasters  flog  Polish  children  who  are  unable  to  say  the  catechism  and  pray  in  German.  Relatives  who  protest  against  this  treatment  are  arrested.  In  one  case  a  mother  who  protested  against  the  treatment  of  her  child  received  a  heavy  sentence.

heading: GERMAN PRECEPT AND GERMAN PRACTICE.
article_text: GERMAN  PRECEPT  AND  GERMAN  PRACTICE.   The  "Contemporary  Review"  for  July  publishes  a  translation  of  a  pamphlet  Herr  Meyer,  a  well  known  writer,  it  ap  pears,  on  naval  subjects,  which  has  had  it  great  circulation  in  Germany,  and  bubbles  over  with  hatred  to  England,  while  claim-   ing  for  its  writer  an  ample  participation  in  that  "inextinguishable  enthusiasm  for  the  Good,  the  Beautiful  and  the  True,"  by  which  it  is  the  peculiar  privilege  of  his  countrymen  to  be  animated.  His  animosity  to  the  mother  country,  its  people  and  its  institutions  is  so  intense  that  he  goes  out  into  the  street  and  "swears  at  large"  in  order  to  ease  his  mind.  As  to  her  land  forces,  heinforms  us  that  "a  couple  of  French  army  corps  would  suffice  to  drive  the  wonderful  army  of  England,  with  all  her  Indian  and  colonial  troops,  to  the  devil."  Whatever  reputation  it  may  have  wrongfully  acquired  in  former  days  has  van-  ished,  he  tells  us.  "English  incendiarism  in  South  Africa  has  tarnished  the  Iast  re-  mains  of  England's  military  glory,  and  branded  her  name  as  infamous  for  all  time.  It  has  revealed  to  the  world  the  shameless-  ness  of  the  English  character  and  an  un-  "scrupulousness  which  hesitates  at  nothing."  Words  almost  fail  Herr  Meyer,  indeed,  when  he  endeavors  to  express  his  contempt  for  the  British  fleet,  and  his  enormous  ad-  miration  for  that  of  Germany;  while  to  those  who  are  capable  of  holding  up  the  former  as  a  model  for  the  construction  of  the  latter,  he  sarcastically  exclaims,  "Eng-  land,  powerful  at  sea,  and  therefore  on  land  —  the  land  grabber  and  therefore  the  in-  satiable;  England,  unscrupulous  in  her  am-  bition,  and  therefore  breaking  up  in  an  ir-  reparable  decay;  England  is  to  be  the  edu-  cator  of  Germany!  Only  he  who  is  taken  in  by  the  deceptions  conjured  up  by  the  Protean  arts  and  duplicity  of  Britain  can  allow  her  to  be  capable  of  such  a  task."  Finally,  having  exhausted  his  tolerably  copious  vocabulary  of  vituperation  in  ve-  hement  abuse  of  our  countrymen,  Herr  Meyer  winds  up  his  pamphlet  in  these  stir-  ring  words:  —  "Unite,  German  people,  in  the  war  cry  of  Germany,  'Los  von  Eng-  land!'"  —  which  may  be  read  as  a  para-  phrase  of  the  elder  Cato's  memorable  words,  "Delenda  est  Carthage."  Having  listened  to  Herr  Meyer's  Anglo-  phobic  declamation  against  the  "infamous"  conduct  of  Great  Britain  in  the  Boer  cam-  paign,  based,  as  a  matter  of  course,  upon  the  monstrous  fabrications  invented  by  Dr.  Leyds,  and  circulated  through  the  medium  of  the  reptile  press  in  Germany  and  else-  where,  it  is  amusing  to  turn  to  the  very  next  article  in  the  same  number  of  the  "Contemporary,"  and  to  read  Mr.  Auberon  Herbert's  narrative,  mainly  drawn  from  German  sources,  of  the  atrocities  perpe-  trated  by  the  Germans  during  their  occu-  pation  of  France  in  1870-71.  "All  movable  property  was  subject  to  demands  of  German  commanders  to  be  transferred  by  the  horses  and  labor  of  the  inhabitants  to  any  point  directed.  The  penalty  for  imperfect  com-  pliance  was  fine.  To  ensure  payment  of  the  fine  there  was  seizure  of  the  chief  inhabi-  tants  as  hostages.  If  the  village  or  town  de-  fended  its  property  the  penalty  was  burn-  ing  of  the  village.  If  any  German  troops  al-  lowed  themselves  to  be  surprised  in  any  vil-  lage,  penalty—  burning  of  the  village.  For  injury  to  roads,  bridges,  railways  —  penalty,  devastation  of  the  district.  For  wearing  a  not  recognised  uniform  —  penalty,  death."  The  French  freeshooters  and  the  followers  of  Garibaldi  after  their  capture  by  the  Ger-  mans  were  shot  down  like  dogs.  "Every  vil-  lage  in  which  an  act  of  treachery  has  been  committed,"  said  Bismarck,  "should  be  burnt  to  the  ground,  and  all  the  male  in-  habitants  hanged";  and  when  he  heard  of  the  capture  of  1200  prisoners,  many  of  whom  were  freeshooters,  he  angrily  exclaimed,  "Prisoners!  Why  do  they  continue  to  make  prisoners?  They  should  have  shot  down  the  whole  1200,  one  after  another!"  And  yet  our  amiable  critics  in  Germany  stigmatise  our  soldiers  as  little  better  than  barbarians  and  monsters,  because  when  some  of  them  approached  a  farm  house,  the  inhabitants  of  which  exhibited  a  flag  of  truce,  and  saw  their  comrades  shot  down  in  cold  blood,  they  avenged  this  act  of  treachery,  and  pre-  vented  its  repetition,  by  burning  down  the  house  in  which  it  had  occurred.  In  simi-  lar  circumstances  in  France  thirty  years  ago  every  inmate  of  the  habitation  would  have  been  put  to  death  by  the  German  soldiery.

heading: German Militarism.
article_text: German  Militarism.   Most  extraordinary  evidence  was  given  at  the  trial  by  court  martial  at  Readsbur^  of  Sergeant  Franzky,  which  ended  in  the  sen  teoce  of  five  y  eats'  imprisonment  and  degra  dation.  One  thousand  five  hundred  and  twenty  cases  of  maltreatment  of  subordinates  were  proved  against  him,  and  in  a  large  number  nf  ftARPK  lh  WAR  isliniirn  fhgt  lio  \\aA  nnvnnoWot   private  soldiers  under  him  to  lend  him  money  which  he  never  thought  of  returning.  The  same  revelations  were  made  as  in  preceding  trials  of  this  nature,  viz.,  when  the  judges  asked  the  men  how  they  could  put  up  with  Buch  treatment  when  they  had  the  right  to  complain,  they  invariably  replied  that  they  were  afraid  to  take  this  course  owing  to  the  vengeance  that  wonld  be  subsequently  wreaked  on  them.  DuriDE  drill  hours  the  recruits  were  in   mortal  terror,  for  Frnnzky  used  to  6ay  'Now  we  are  alone,'  and  then  maltreated  them  with  every  possible  refinement  of  cruelty.  During  these  periods  he  posted  two  men  outside  the  building  with  orders  to  report  immediately  the  arrival  of  the  lieutenant.  One  witness  said  he  had  been  compelled  to  carry  a  heavy  coalscuttle  for  half  an  hour  rminn  Ann  round  a  warm  mnm  Arwitliat*   was  compelled  to  stand  in  a  bucket  and  then  jump  out  aud  in  again  till  the  sergeant  tired  of  watching.  Another  confessed  to  having  been  beaten  300  times,  perhaps  more.  Another  was  compelled  to  pnlish  a  bucket  on  his  knees,  and  while  in  that  position  was  repeatedly  kicked  by  Pranzky.  He  was  also  ordered  to  go  through  exercises  in  front  of  a  warm  stove  till  he  sank  from  exhaustion.  Medical  ex  perts  say  that  this  witness  will  throughout  hia  life  be  subject  to  fits  brought  on  by  con  stant  and  brutal  maltreatment.  Franzky  spat  in  the  men's  faces  at  will,  struck  them  in  the  face  with  bis  fist  and  beat  them,  preferably  when  they  were  undressed,  with  a  broomstick,  which  he  named  '  King  Frederick  Wilbelm.'  When  thia  broomstick  was  broken  by  long  service  he  procured  an  other,  which  he  christened  '  Frederick  the  Great.'  Another  witness  swore  that  Franzky  made  him  run  his  head  sevBral  times  agaiutst  a  wall,  which,  said  the  man,  '  hurt  him  severely.  Another  soldier  who  Was  compelled   to  perform  the  same  operation  had  a  bucket  of  water  poured  o;er  his  head  afterwards  'to  cure  him  of  stupidity.'  Every  day  the  ruer  were  beaten,  struck,  or  made  to  go  through  the  most  exhausting  and  unnecessary  exer  cise,  merely  evidently  to  gratify  the  sergeant's  depraved  desire  to  witness  another  man's  pain.

heading: GERMAN ASPIRATIONS.
article_text: GERMAN  ASPIRATIONS.      The  Germans  have,  of  course,  a  per-   fect  right  to  enlarge  their  fleet,  and      we  have  none  to  prevent  them  doing  so.  What  we  have  a  right  to  do,  and  what  we  shall  do  unless  we  are  "drowned  in  security,"  is  to  watch  the  naval  developments  of  Germany  with  the  utmost  vigilance,  and  to  note  carefully  the  growth  of  her  as-  pirations  for  world-power  and  sea-  power-aspirations  which  cannot  be  fully  realised  without  involving  the  weakening,  or  in  the  last  resort  the  destruction,  of  the  British  Empire. In  the  struggle  a  warder  was  injured

heading: GERMAN INTERFERENCE.
article_text: GERMAN  INTERFERENCE.   LONDON,  October  18.  —  Dr.  'Morrison,  the  Pe  kin  correspondent  of  the  'Times,'  recalls  that  Germany  in  deference  to  Russia's  wishes  in  1901,  affirmed  that  Manchuria  was  outside  the  Anglo-German  agreement.  Now,  for  the  pur   pose  or  embarrassing  Great  Britain,  Germany  has  persuaded  China  that  if  the  British  treaty  with  Thibet  is  confirmed  as  it  stands  Germany  may  demand  prescriptive  rights  in  Shantung,  France  may  make  similar  claims  on  Yunnan,  and  Japan  on  Fo-kien.  Tang-shao-yi,  the  Chinese  representative  at  Lhassa,  has  been  instructed  to  seek  at  Cal  cutta  a  modification  of  the  treaty  to  save  China's  face.  The  Vienna  correspondent  of  the  'Times,'  says  that  Germany  has  possibly  over-reached  herself  in  exerting  pressure  on  China  at  this  juncture.  Embarrassment,  almost  vexation,  is  felt  at  St.  Petersburg,  at  Germany's  proclaim  ing  at  Pekin  the  solidarity  of  German  and  Rus  sian  interests  in  Asia.  Her  interference  is  intended  to  imply  that  Germany  and  Russia  are  united  in  their  antagonism  to  Great  Britain.  Russia  and  Great  Britain  as  great  Asiatic  Pow  ers  admit  that  they  have  a  mutual  right  to  speak  with  a  view  of  adjustment  of  their  own  differences,  and  both  resent  the  gratuitous  in  terference  of  a  third  Power  having  no  claim  to  speak  as  an  Asiatic  Power.  Russia  has  -informed  the  Court  of  Pekin  of  the  clauses  which  she  considers  objectionable  m  the  British  treaty  with  Thibet,  and  has  stated  that  these  objections  are  not  intended  to  imply  the  slightest  animosity  to  Great  Britain.

heading: GERMAN EXPEDITION.
article_text: GERMAN  EXPEDITION.   A  German  column,  operating  in  the  neigh  bourhood  of  the  junction  of  the  Great  Wall,  some  miles  due  north  of  Pekin,  has  had  a  sharp  engagement  with  a  Chinese  force  at  a  town  twenty  miles  to  the  north-wost  'of  the  junction.   The  Chinese  force  consisted  of  3,000  men,  and  the  Germans  expelled  them  from  the  town,  after  a  light  laBting  several  hours,  killing  or  wounding  200  of  them.  The  Ger  man  casualties  were  only  one  killed  and  four  wounded.  v

heading: GERMAN "JUSTICE."
article_text: GERMAN  "  JUSTICE."   In  contrast  to  the  lenient  punishment  ac  corded  to  Ensign  Huessner,  who  .murdered  an  artilleryman  in  the  street  (and  previously  men  tioned  in  the  "The  World's  News"),  the  case  of  a  soldier  who  has  been  tried  at  Nuremburg  is  worthy  of  notice.   The  man  refused  to  execute  a  trifling  ordef  given  by  a  non-commisioned  officer,  and  was  afterwards  foolish  enough  to  speak  of  the  mat  ter  in  barracks.  In  consequence  he  was  court  martialled,  and  sentenced  to  five  years  and  six  months'  imprisonment,  with  hard  labor.   While  the  average  German  in  conversation  condemns  the  injustice  of  these  sentences,  he  dare  not  object,  and  the  soldiers  themselves  adopt  a  fatalistic  attitude,  and  merely  remark,   "It  must  be."

heading: GERMAN SPREADEAGLEISM.
article_text: GERMAN  SPEEADEAGLEISM.   A  prominent  German  newspaper  baa  opened  oat  with,  another  hysterical  tirade  against  Great  Britain.  This  in  stance  of  spread-eagleism  might  well  be  dismissed,  as  others  have  been,  but  that  it  acquires  special  significance   from  tbe  fact  that  the  journal  in  which  it  appears  is  frequently  the  mouthpiece  of  the  Government  —  which  in  international  affairs  really  means  the  impetuous,  ambitious  Kaiser  —  and  touches  upon  tbe  vital  question  of  what  Power  really  controls  the  destiny  of  European  politics.  Great  Britain  is  warned  not  to  provoke  a  decision  on  the  subject,  because  of  the  world  wide  significance  and  effect  attaching  to  it.  In  other  words  Germany  infer  entially  threatens  that  if  the  issue  is   provoked  Bhe  will  contest  any  decision  adverse  to  her  aspirations  in  that  con  nection.  Tbe  greatest  of  the  Kaiser's  many  ambitions  is  unquestionably  that  Germany  should  gain  that  indefinite,  yet  all  important,  quality  known  as  the  '  balance  of  power.'  Every  move  in  policy,  every  increase  of  the  navy  and  the  army  is  conceived  with  that  objective  in  view;  it  is  almost,  if  not  quite,  an  obsession  with  the  Monarch.  How  far  this  spirit  and  the  prepara  tions  which  How  from  it  can  ba  effec   tive,  must  remain  iu  uuuoi  uum  ??  test  has  been  applied.  In  tbe  interim  Germany  remains  the  cause  of  unrest  amongst  the  nations,  and  because  of  her  strenuousnesss  in  almost  every  part  of  the  world  has  to  be  closely  watched,  even  by  the  smaller  powers.  It  can  well  be  understood  that  a  nation  with  such  ambitions  as  Germany  has  chafes  under  the  '  diplomatic  net  '  which  has  been  woven  around  her,  and  for  which  Great  Britain  has  to  thank  the  late  Lord  Salisbury,  whose  apprecia  tion  of  the  importance  of  the  Empire's  relations  with  the  other  Powers  has  resulted  in  the  creation  of  what  is  ad  mitted  to  be  the  ablest  diplomatic  service  in  the  world.  That  service  has  unquestionably  checkmated  Ger  many,  maintained  Great  Britain's   prestige  and,  by  .the  intervening  of  interests,  made  her  position  more  secure  and  yet  left  an  outlet  for.  the  policy  of  'grand  isolation'  which  Lord  Salisbury  considered  so  essential  to  her  supremacy.  Germany  may  at  tempt  to  capture  the  '  balance  of  power  '  by  a  revolt  against  the  tight  ening  cordon  of  diplomacy,  tbe  con  tinued  increase  -of  her  naval  and  mer  cantile  fleets,  and  her  army.  Bat  how  long  could  such  an  aggressive  nation,  inclined  to  riding  rough-shod  over  obstacles,  maintain  that  power  when  in  the  high  stirrups,  assuming  that  altitude  was  attained  9  Not  for  long,  we  believe.  So  long  as  Great   Britain  maintains  the  two-power  de  fence,  the  balance  of  power  is  likely  to  remain  with  her.  But  at  Germany's  rate  of  battleship  construction  that  position  is  being  jeopardised.  It  is  probably  Great  Britain's  realisation  of  that  fact  which  the  German  semi  official  newspaper  regards  as  provoca  tion  for  testing  the  issue  of  supre  macy,  and  for  the  spreadeaglelsm  in  which  it  indulges  with  reference  to  tbe  capabilities  of  the  army.  Though  hysterical,  however,  the  declaration,  emanating  from  what  is  frequently  the  mouth-piece  of  the  Government,  may  or  may  not  have  official  founda  tion  ;  at  any  rate  it  is  worth  noticing.

heading: GERMAN FINANCES.
article_text: GERMAN  FINANCES.   Herr  Von  Koenneritz  writes   Sir,—In  connection  with  the  "Economist's"  state-   ment  regarding  the  position  of  the  German  finances,   it  may  not  be  without  interest  to  remind  your  readers   that,  compared  with  the  estimates  for  1907,  viz.,  1,187,600,000  marks,  the  Empire's  receipts  during  last  year  totalled  1,201,100,000  marks;  that  is,  roughly  13,500,000  marks,  or  about  1  per  cent  more  than  had  been  anticipated.  Compared  with  1906,  all  sources  of  revenue,  except  two  show  increases,  as,  for  instance,  Customs  duties,  643,000,000  marks,  or  88,400,000  marks  more  than  during  the  previous  year.  Tobacco  and  cigar-   ettes  excise  duties  23,600,000  marks,  or  7,000,000  marks  more,  distilled  excise  duties  112,600,000  marks,  or  7,800,000  marks  more,  brewing  excise  duties  51,100,000  marks,  or  8,200,000  marks  more,  etc.  The  two  excep-  tions  referred  to  are  the  stamp  duties  on  revenue-pro-  ducing  stocks  and  on  Bourse  transactions,  which  together   yielded  22,900,000  marks  less  than  in  1906.  But  against  this  it  should  be  remembered  that  they  had  been  un-  naturally  high  during  that  year.  All  other  sources  of  revenue  together  show  an  increase  of  160,000,000  marks  in  round  figures,  so  that  if  we  deduct  the  lesser  yield  of  the  Bourse  transactions,  there  still  remains  for  1907  an  excess  of  revenue  of  137,000,000  marks  in  round  figures  as  compared  to  the  previous  year.  Moreover,  the  fact  should  not  be  lost  sight  of  that  of  the  new  duties  passed  in  1906,  obviously  none  were  able  to  yield  their  full  measure  of  revenue  in  1907.  This  will  only  be  the  case  in  1910,  and  not  before.  This  much,  however,  may  safely  be  predicted—that  the  expecta-  tions  which  led  to  the  imposition  of  the  new  duties  will  be  fully  justified;  in  fact,  in  some  instances,  the  yield  has  already  come  up  to  the  estimates.

heading: GERMAN COMMENTS.
article_text: GERMAN  COMMENTS.   German  comments  on  the  four  Dreadnoughts  debate  show  a  determin  ation  not  to  recognise  the  necessity  for  British  supremacy  of  the  sea.  The  Liberal  members'  proposals  for  a  limi  tation  of  armaments  are  interpreted  as  an  attempt  to  maintain  supremacy  without  incurring  additional  expendi  ture.
snippet: German comments on the four Dreadnoughts debate show a determination not to recognise the necessity for British supremacy of the sea. The

heading: GERMAN INTENTIONS
article_text: GERMAN  INTENTIONS   The  opinion  formed  by  the  Bishop  of  Salisbury  as  to  the  trend  of  thought  in  Germany  about  war  with  Britain  comes  opportunely  by  cable  for  com  parison  with  the  mail  brought  views  of  some  other  observers  and  critics  of  Germany's  warlike  preparations.  And   it  is  interesting  to  find  that,'  leaving  out  of  consideration  the  question1  whe  ther  there  is  any  -real  desire  for  war  on  the  part  of  the  people  of  Germany,  the  Bishop's  discovery  of  'a  consider  able  desire  for  the  possession  of  such  naval  and  military  supremacy  as  might  enable  Germany  -to  dictate  to  Europe  in  a  crisis,  or,  if  necessary,  to  the   United  States,'  is  very  muchi  in  har  mony  with  what  Captain  Mahan,  an  American  thinker  and  writer  of  accept  ed  authority  on  such  subjects,  recently  addressed  to  his  fellow  countrymen.  In  an  article  in  'Collier's  Weekly,'  Cap  tain  Mahan  calls  upon  Americans  to  give  their  attention  to  the  recent  change  in  Germany's  .  shipbuilding  capacity,  as  revealed  by  the  British  Prime  Minister  and  Admiralty.  He  says  :  'j[  believe  an  extraordinary  situa  tion  ihas  been  created,  and  that  hence  forward,  if  Germany  so  will  and  can  find  the  money,  the  two-Power  '  stand  ard  of  the  Britisk  Fleet,  accepted  by  Liverals  as  well  as  Conservatives,  can  not  be  maintained.  .  -  Few  persons  realise  what  the  appearance  of  such  a  navy  as  that  which  Germany  is  build  ing  means  in  international  affairs.  The  question,  indeed,  as  not  what  she  in-,  tends;  like  other  Governments,  she  may  to  some  extent  live  from  hand  to1  mouth,  though  probably  not  eo  much  so  as  others.  The  question  is:  What  will  she  be  able  to  do  with  such  a  force?  That  is  her  meaning:  the  expediency  of  an  unknown  future,  as  yet  contingent,  and  impossible  to  fore  see.  But  though  contingencies  are  beyond  our  ken,  it  is  perfectly  know  able,  and  absolutely  sure,,  that,  should  they  be  unfavorable,  6he,  with  a  decisively  superior  navy,  will  have  the  whip  hand.'  In  'The  United  Service  Gazette'  Captain  E.  H.  James  deals  with  the  same  aspect  of  Germany's  naval  operations,  and  points  out  that  the  British  policy  ihas  been  to  fight,  'with  absolute  impartiality,  for  or  against  every  great  Power  on  the  continent,  as  circumstances  demanded,'  to  'prevent  any  Power,  or  group  of  Powers,  from  obtaining  domination  over  Europe.''  For,  in  other  words;  'our  sea  supre  macy  depends  upon  our  ability  to  main  tain  the  balance  of  power  in  Europe.'  In  the  'Insurance  and  Banking  Re  cord'  we  find  'Jotter'  advising  those  who  would  understand  the  situation  of  to-day  to  read  Ellis  Barker's  great  work  'The  Rise  and  Decline  of  the  Netherlands.'  After*  pointing  to  the  warning  of  the  fate  of  Holland,  this  writer  says:  'Presently  -we  shall  have  to  tighten  our  belts  and  set  our  teeth  and  go  on  short  commons  to  repel  a  similar  attack  ;  and,  please  God,  with  -the  same  result.  -  .  .  For  the1   great  law  of  the.  gods  is  the  Law  of  the  Survival  of  the  Fittest.  The  gods  give  victory  to  those  who  by  self  denial/  grit  and  a  united  resolution  prove  their  right  to  it.  Heaven  iias  no  favorites,  and  never  had.  And  unless  moral  excellences  go  hand  in  (hand  with  the  qualities  just  mentioned,  moral  excellences  —  if  these,  indeed,  be  ours  —  will  count  for  nothing.'

heading: GERMAN MOURNING.
article_text: GERMAN  MOURNING.   LONDON,  Tuesday  Morning.—  The  Emperor  of  Germany  has  extended  the  Court's  full  mourning  till  March  8,  and  half-mournine  till  April  22.
snippet: LONDON, Tuesday Morning.—The Emperor of Germany has extended the Court's full mourning till March 8, and half-mourning till April 22.

heading: GERMAN DREADNOUGHT.
article_text: GERMAN  DREADNOUGHT.   It  is  announced  that  the  battleship  Bayern,  the  first  Dreadnought  built  by  the  German  Admiralty,  will  be  launched  at  the  Imperial  Dockyard,  Wilhelmshaven,  at  the  end  of  February.  Particulars  regard-  ing  the  construction  of  the  vessel  have  been  kept  secret,  but  it  is  reported  that  the  work  of  building  was  not  begun  until  early  in  1906.  The  ship  will  have  a  dis-  placement  of  18,000  tons,  and  the  guaran-  teed  rate  of  speed  will  be  19½  knots.  The  cost  of  the  ship  when  completed  is  set  down  at  £1,825,000.

Having  explained  that,  the  mo  lasses  used  is  -t.lio  article  in  the  raw  state,  in  which  at  least  fifty  per  cent,  of  sugar  is  to  be  found,  while  the  dust  is  obtained  by  passing  the  ordinary  moss  litter  through  a  disintegrating  ma  chine,  he  proceeds  to  summarize  the  advantages  of"_the  mixture,  in  the  following  succinct  order.  I  1.  It.  is  fifty  per  cent,  cheaper'  than  the  best  fut-pr  educing   food,  and  yet  equal  in  nourish  ment.  2.  It  tends  to  keep  the  animal  in  health,  helps  diges  tion,  and  whets  the  appetite.  3.  It  is  almost  equal  in  nourish  ment  to,,  and  is  a  good  substi  tute  for  bran.  4.  It  prevents  colic  and  other  sickness.  5.  It  gives  a  glossy,  h<  althy  appear  ance  to  the  skin.  6.  When  used  for  fatteniug  it  increases  weight  and  improves  the  flavour  of  moat,  &c.  &e.  On  the  ques  tion  of  amount  to  be  given  to  the  animal,  the  writer  slates  that  iu  order  to  accustom  the  animals  to  molasses  food  give  them  first  for  a-  week  only  a  quarter  of  an  ordinary  ration  (that  is  from  half  a  pound  to  a  third  of  a  pound  daily  ;  in  the  following  week  raise  the  amount  to  about  three  quarters  of  a  pound,  and  the  third  week  to  the  maximum  amount  —  namely,  one  pound  to   a  pound  and  a  hull.

heading: German Blunder.
article_text: German  Blunder.   A  party  of  German  soldiers  by  mistake  got  hold  of  Wang,  President  ef  the  Treasury,  and  proceeded  to  diag  him  through  the  streets.  Wang  vainly  protested,  but  before  the  mistake  was  discovered  the  unfortunate  official  had  been  flogged  with  a  rope,  and  his  nose  broken

heading: GERMAN SHIPBUILDING
article_text: GERMAN  SHIPBUILDING   If  anything  were  needed  to  testify  to  the  really  marvellous  strides  which  have  been  made  by  Germany  in  shipbuilding  cldring  the  last  20  year*,  then  the  despatch  with  which  the  German  shipbuilding  yards  can  turn  out  battleships  nowadays  might  be  mentioned.  Thus,  20  years  or  so  ago,  it  took  nearly  eight  years  to  build  a  battleship  of  the  Sachsen  class  of  7280  tons;  the  Bayern  was  laid  down  in  1874,  and  finished  in  1882;  and  the  Baden  was  laid  down  in  187G,  and  fin  ished  in  '1884,  both  vessels  being  of  7280  tons.  But  at  the  present  day  the  German  yards  can  turn  out  a  battleship  almost  as  large  again  as  those  of  the  Sachsen  class  in  only  a  little  more  than  a  third  of  the  time  taken  in  building  the  battleships  of  that  class.  The  four  battleships  of  the  Braunschweig  class  of  13,'200  tons,  recently  finished,  have  taken  on  an  averuge  36  months  for  their  complete  construction;  thg  IVittelsbach  class,  of  12,000  tons,  took  39  months,  »r,.ietlic  Kaiser  class,  of  11,180  tons,  took  t>s  much  ns  48  months;  and  ths  !*rai.donburg  class,  of  9S40  tons,  to  A  ll.e  same  time. heading: German Animosity.
article_text: German  Animosity.   In  a  recent  letter  to  the  Sydney  Press  Mr.  O.  C.  Beate  gives  a  long  and  interesting  extract  from  a  leading  German  newspaper  which  sets  forth  what  it  calls  the  reasons  that  their  country  should  distrust  Engiand.  The  arguments  are  of  course  terribly  biassed  against  the  British  Empire,  but  they  overlook  one  fact  that  should  make  up  for  all  the  sins  of  England's  committing.  Where  ever  the  English  flag  floats  the  German  colonist  is  as  welcomo  as  the  Britisher;  the  German  merchant  is  given  equal  rights  to  trade  as  the  British  merchant;  his  life  and  property  is  protected,  his  religion  is  respected,  his  freedom  absolute.  When  Britain  opens  up  a  tract  of  country  in  Africa,  China  or  elsewhere,  it  is  a  distinct  gain  to  £.11  the  world.  Can  these  things  be  said  of  Germany  ?  She  owns  a  lot  of  territory  in  various  parts  of  the  world,  but  her  citizens,  as  frugal  as  industrious,  and  as  in-   telligent,  as  any  people  in  the  world,  prefer  to  emigrate  t  o  British  territory.  In  German  colonies  the  German  merchant  is  given  a  preference  over  all  other  nations,  German  goods  are  not  taxed  like  British  goods  are.  When  Germany  secures  a  tract  of  country,  that  territory  is  lost  to  all  the  world,  the  exports  thcreform  go  to  Germany  on  German  ships,  the  imports  thereto  must  come  from  Germany.  The  country  is  administered  not  for  its  own  good  but  to  the  benefit  of  its  master,  much  the  same  as  Britain  used  to  have  India  administered  over  half  a  century  ago.  Britain's  policy  now  is  the  "  Open  Door,"  and  if  all  colony  owing  Powers  worked  en  the  same  principle,  it  would  not  matter  much  who  owned  the  world.

heading: German Sausage.
article_text: German  Sausage.   One  of  two  men  bought  a  German  sausage.  On  the  way  home  his  com  panion  reproved  him  for  such  foolish   ness,  declaring  that  the  sausage  was  made  of  time-expired  cab-horses.  This  the  purchaser  indignantly  denied,  but  that  same  evening,  going  to  his  friend’s  room,  he  apologised.   “You  was  right  about  that  sausage,  Bill,”  he  said.  '   “Ah,  I  Knew  I  was.  But  how  did   you  prove  it?”   “Whv,  I  cut  the  sausage  up  into  five  pieces,  and  set  ’em  out  in  a  row,  one  behind  the  other.  Then  I  pushed  for  ward  the  first  on  the  rank,  and  the  other  four  moved  up!”   You  may  set  it  down  as  a  truth  which  admits  of  few  exceptions,  that  those  who  ash  your  opinion  really  I  wait  yetrr  prai'tfe.

heading: GERMAN SHOOTS GERMAN.
article_text: ?'?  GERMAN  SHOOTS  GERMAN.  .   The  High  Commissioner  reports:—  'Since  the  last  letter  left  general  headquarters  evidence  has  been  re  ceived  which  points  to  the  fact  that  during  the  counter-attacks  on  the  night  of  September  20  German  in  fantry  fired  into  each  other,  the  re   sult  of  an  attempt  to  carry  out  a  dangerous  expedient  of  a  conver  ging  advance  in  the  dark.  Oppo  site  one  portion  of  our  position  a  considerable  massing  of  hostile  forces  was  observed  before  dark.  Some  hours  later  a  furious  fusilade  was  heard  in  front  of  our  line,  though  no  bullets  came  over  our  trenches.  On  the  21st  there  was  a,  little  rain,  and  the  weather  took  a  turn  for  the  better,  which  has  been  maintained.  The  action  was  prac  tically  confined  to  die  artillery,  oui  guns'  at  one  point  shelling  and  driving  away  any  who  were  en  deavoring  toeon.struct  redoubts.  The   Germans  expended  a  large  numoer  of  heavy  shells  in  a  long-range  bom  bardment  of  the  village  of  Oissy.  Reconnoitring  parties  sent  out  dur  ing  the  nights  of  the  21st  and  22nd  discovered  some  deserted  trenches  in  the  woods.  Over  100  dead  and  wounded  were  picked  up.,  together  with  a  number  of  rifles  and  am  munition  and.  equipment.  There  were  various  other  signs  that  por  tions  of  the  enemy's  forces  had  been  withdrawn  for  some  distance.  'The  22nd.  although  fine  and  with  less  wind,'  was  one  of  the  most  eventful  days  the  British  passed  since  we  left  the  Aisne.  There  was  less  artillery  work  on  either  side,  the  Germans,  nevertheless,  giving  the  village  of  Paissy  a  taste  of  war.  The  spot  thus  honored  is  not  far  from  the  ridge  where  some  of  the  most  severe  close  fighting  in  which  we  !have  taken  mrt  has  occurred.  All  over  this  'Roman's  Land'  between  the  lines  bodies  of  German  infantry  are  still  Iving  in  heaps  where  they  have  fallen  at  different  times.

article_text: GERMAN.   (Admiralty.—Per  Wireless.)   LONDON,  Saturday.—  German  offi-  cial:  South  of  the  Somme,  we  with-  drew  our  advanced  troops,  thus  evacu-  ating  Essigny-le-Grand.  The  evening  gained  a  footing  on  the  high  ridges  W.  of  Jouy.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   (Admiralty.—  Per  Wireless.)   LONDON,  Wednesday.  —  German  official:  We  withdrew  from  parts  of  our  salient  lines  near  St.  Quentin,  N.W.  of  Rheims  and  W.  of  the  Ar-  gonne.  The  enemv  obtained  a  footing  in  Ledgehem  (S.  of  Roulers),  but  our  counter-attack  regained  the  eastern   part.  On  the  fifth  day  of  the  Cambrai  battle  we  repulsed  seven  assaults  N.  of  Sancourt,  and  further  south  the  enemy  advanced  beyond  Abancourt,  Bantigny,  and  toward  Cuvillers.  Our  counter-attack  pushed  him  back  beyond  Abancourt  and    Bantigny.  Th  enemy's  xxxx  broke  down  at  and  south  of  Cambrai.  The  enemy  captured  Rxxmilly  and  occupied  St.  Quentin.  We  withdrew  from  the  Vesle,  N.  of  Rheims.

heading: German.
article_text: German.   We  repulsed  partial  attacks  in  the  region  of  Merris  and  astride  the  Ayetts  River  .  The  enemy  strongly  attacked  our  new  lines  northward  of  the  Ourcq  and  on  the  wooded  heights   south-westward  of  Rheims.  We  threw  them  back  inflicting  very  heavy  losses.  Very  heavy  repeated  attacks  against  the  Hartennes-Fere-  en-Tardenois  front  and  also  as  far  as  the  Meunssre  Wood  broke  down  before  and  at  our  lines,  and  some-  times  under  our  counter-attacks.

article_text: German.   A  Berlin  communique  merely  stated:—  "No  change  as  far  as  German  troops  are  concerned.  The  Russians  covered  25  miles  to  Lutsk  in  three  days  through  fortresses  and  marsh  lands,  and  over  battered  de-   fences."

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   A  wireless  German  official  message  says:  Southward  of  Thiescourt  the  enemv  captured  Attich  Farm.  The  enemy  suffer-  ed  heavily  in  the  fighting  for  Lassigny.  We  drove  him  back  six  times  during  the  hours  of  heavy  fighting.  A  German  official  message  on  Sunday  says:  We  repulsed  repeated  attacks  on   both  sides  of  Roye,  extending  northward  as  far  as  south  westwards  of  Chaulnes  and  southward  as  far  as  north  westward  of  Lassigny.  The  enemy  near  Royencourt  gained  ground  in  the  direction  of  Roye.  Our  counter-attack  threw  him  back.  Re-  peated  French  attacks  southward  of  the  Avre  collapsed.  Allied  airmen  have  dropped  bombs  on  Darmstadt,  the  capital  of  Hesse-Darm-  stadt,  in  Germany.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.  An  artillery  battle  has  developed  be-  tween  Zborow  and.  Brzezany.  It  is  also  lively  at  Zwrxyn,  Brody,  and  Smorgon.  A  Roumanian  preparation  for  an  attack  southward  of  Casinu  Valley  was  dispersed  under  our  fire.  The  enemy  is  restless  along  the  lower  Danube.  Massed  Russian  assaults  at  Brzezany  and  between  Zborow  and  Koniuchy  broke  down  heavily.

article_text: GERMAN.   (Admiralty.  —  Per  Wireless.)   LONDON,  Sunday.—  German  official:  We  evacuated  Bruges,  Thielt  and  Kor-  trik.  On  both  sides  of  Vouziers,  the  enemy  established  himself,  on  the  east  bank  of  the  Aisne.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   Herr  Dernburg,  the  Kaiser's  Press  agent  for  America,  and  probably  one  of  the  most  blun-  dering  and  thoughtless  persons  in  the  World,  has  deemed  it  fit  to  deliver  himself  publicly  on  the  subject  of  —  tact!   It  was  at  a  meeting  of  a  league  newly-form-  ed  in  Berlin  with  a  view  to  expanding  German  industrial  interests  in  the  South  American  continent.  Herr  Dernburg,  who  had  been  elec-  ted  president,  said,  according  to  a  Reuter  mes-  sage  from  Amsterdam  received  recently:  —  'Germany  has  only  a  few  friends  in  the  world.  Feeling  in  South  America  is  divided,  and  real  neutrality  in  North  America  is  also  doubtful.  'It  is  not  uninteresting  to  note  how  Lord  Haldane  at  Manchester  explained  to  British  merchants  that  now  a  favorable  opportunity  had  come  to  snatch  away  from  Germany  her  commercial  supremacy  for  ever.  "For  generations  to  come,  we  need  not  fear  competition  abroad,  though,  if  the  present  war  ,.?.'.  Iasts  a  long  time,  commerce  will,  at  last,  be  obliged  to  find  new  outlets,  and  the  recapture  of  the  ground  now  lost  will  become  more  dif-  ficult.  "For  coal  and  iron  South  America  will  be  dependent  on  the  industrial  States  for  a  long  time  to  come,  and,  therefore,  the  investment  of  more  capital  in  South  America  will  be  well  worth  while  for  commercial  reasons,  and  also  in  order  to  regain  lost  ground.  ''Besides  strengthening  our  economic  influ-  ence,  the  obtaining  of  a  certain  intellectual  influence  will  be  of  an  importance  which,  up   till  now,  has  been  greatly  under-estimated.  "We  have  not  understood  the  soul  of  the  South  Americans,  and  not  of  them  alone.  For  this  reason,  we  find  few  friends  among  neu-  trals.  This  is  largely  the  fault  of  the  Ger-  mans,  who  must  learn  to  understand  foreigners  and  introduce  German  achievements  in  science  and  art  with  more  discretion  than  heretofore.  "Only  too  often  the  German  merchant  shows  an  absence  of  that  friendly  feeling  towards  merchants  abroad  which  is  of  special  weight  with  Southern  people."

heading: German [?]
article_text: German  Ideas  of  Peace   By  D.  Thomas  Curtin   It  is  a  mistake  to  suppose,  when  reading  of  peace  talk  in  Germany,  that  the  topic  is  a  new  one  there.  It  is  not.  I  heard  the  German  people  talking  peace  a  month  after  the  outbreak  of  war—of  a  peace   to  be  sure  which  Germany  would  dictate  and  keep.  When  the  Fatherland  was  winning  I  heard  no  discordant  note.  That  was  owing   to  the  general  belief  in  and  eager-  ness  for  certain  victory  and  vast  annexation  which  prevailed  then.  To-day  the  Germans  —  with  the  exception  of  a  minority  of  extreme  Social  Democrats  —  are  no  less  united  in  their  desire  to  get  all  they  can,  but  they  are  not  all  united  in  their  opinions  as  to  how  much  they  can  get.  Hence,  after  the  French  definitely  blocked  the  German  of-  fensive  at  Verdun  and  the  British  Fleet  grip  more  and  more  tightly  the  economic  life  of  German,  a     bewildering  variety  of  Kriegsziele  (war  aims)  was  discussed  by  all  classes  of  people.  The  National  Liberal  Party  in  Germany,  as  I  have  already  in-  dicated  in  a  previous  article  on  submarines,  is  backing  a  gigantic  and  aggressive  plan  for  German  world-domination  through  a  colossal  organisation  and  expansion  of  Ger-  man  commerce  and  industry.  The  great  captains  of  industry  who  con-  trol  the  party  believe  in  the  em-  ployment  of  the  German  Army  and  Navy  to  further  their  ends  —  i.e.,  to  secure  permanently  for  Germany   the  mining  regions  of  Northern  France  and  the  coal  and  shipping  of  Belgium  ;  and  to  cripple  rival  commerce,  not  only  as  a  means  of  winning  the  war,  but  also  of  limit-  ing  competition  against  them  after  wards.  These  are  the  men  behind  Tirpitz,  and  they  are  working,  and  will  continue  to  work,  to  restore  him  to  power.  Dr  Stresemann,  one  of  the  most  influential  National  Liberals,  is  a  dynamo  of  energy  in  German  com-  mercial  plans.  His  eyes  sparkling  with  zeal,  reddish  hair,  a  clear,  metallic  voice,  he  is  a  heavy  man  physically,  wielding  a  tremendous  and  growing  power  in  Germany  to-  day.  He  has  a  controlling  interest  in  a  recently  organised  combination  of  some  two  thousand  manufactur-  ing  firms,  and  is  practically  dictator  of  the  Sachsische  Handelsgesell-  schaft  and  the  Deutsch-Amerikan-  ische  Wirthschaftsverband.  He  became  one  of  theChancellor's  most  out-spoken  enemies  at  the   time  of  the  Danish  concessions  to  America,  and  his  fiery  advocacy  of  relentless  submarine  warfare  has  earned  him  a  reputation  for  fright-  fulness,  even  in  Germany.  He  be-  longs  to  the  Western  School  of  pre-  sent-day  Germany  —  the  school  which  believes  in  placating  Russia  (to  be  followed  by  a  peaceful  pene-  tration  of  that  country)  and  the  smashing  as  far  as  possible  of  Britain  and  France.  As  his  utter-  ances  in  the  Reichstag  plainly  show,  he  is  passionately  anti-American  in  general  and  anti-Wilson  in  par-  ticular.  Since  he  is  one  of  the  foremost  Germans  in  the  great  campaign  against  Great  Britain  both  during  and  after  the  war,  Dr  Stresemann's  views  should  be  of  particular  in-  terest.  His  most  recent  utterances  agree  in  the  main  with  those  he  made  in  an  interview  which  he  gave  me,  and  which  I  duly  communi-  cated  to  American  newspapers  through  the  Wilhelmstrasse.  There  are,  however,  some  important  dif-  ferences  which  I  shall  point  out   later.  "How  seriously  do  German  in-  dustrial  circles  regard  the  Paris  Economic  Conference?"  was  the  first  question  I  put  to  Dr  Strese-  mann.  "If  one  is  to  attach  great  import-  ance  to  the  words  of  the  political  economists  of  the  Entente,"  he  be-  gan,  "then  we  must  agree  that  we  might  have  considerable  anxiety  and  alarm  about  our  industrial  fut-  ure;  but,  as  a  matter  of  fact,  Ger-  man  industrial  circles  view  these  endeavors  of  our  enemies  with  calm-  ness  of  indifference.  "Russia  cannot  emancipate  her-  self  from  German  industry.  As  for  France,  she  may  look  to  a  boy-  cott  of  German  wares.  Yet  that   will  make  no  appreciable  difference  in  our  world  trade,  even  though  here  and  there  we  may  drop  a  few  million  marks.  We  have  but  to  consider  France's  tremendous  losses  in  relation  to  her  already  falling  birthrate  before  the  war  to  realise  that  France  must  inevitably  sink  to  the  rank  of  a  third  rate  Power.  "After  the  war  Great  Britain  will  probably  stand  united  against  us,  politically  and  economically,  but  we  fear  her  just  as  little  as  we  fear  Russia  and  France.  We  rely  first  of  all  upon  the  peerless  quality  of  our  goods  —  just  think  of  our  chemical,  textile,  and  toy  monopo-  lies,  and  the  like  —  and,  secondly,  we  rely  on  our  unsurpassed  mar-  kets  for  consumption.  "In  1913  we  imported  for  ex-  ample,  from  Great  Britain  and  her  colonies  2,109  ,000,000  marks  (£105,450,000)  worth  of  goods.  Do  you  for  a  moment  believe  that  our  rival  is  going  to  sacrifice  such  a  tremendous  volume  of  business  for  the  sake  of  a  personal  spite?  Any  tariff  war  which  is  waged  against  us  can  injure  us,  but  it  is  bound  to  injure  the  side  just  as  much.  That  will  be  realised  all  the  more  in  England,  since  these  threats  drive  us  into  a  closer  trade  and  industrial  relationship  with  our  allies,  thus  affording  us  a  greater  extent  of  united  industrial  territory  to  oppose  the  industrial  chicaneries  which  our  enemies  have  developed  during  the  war.  In  this  we  shall  undoubtedly  be  successful  at  the  Peace  conference.  "With  the  United  States  we   shall  resume  trade  immediagelyafter  the  end  of  hostilities.  The  war  has  caused  both  of  us  to  become  un-  comfortably  short  in  some.  com-  modities.  Consequently,  the  first  demands  after  our  resumption  of  trade  will  restrict  free  competition,  since  both  sides  must  limit  them-  selves  at  first  to  importing  the  most  necessary  commodities.  You  will  need  dyestuffs,  for  example  ;  we  must  have  certain  raw  materials.  "To  be  sure,  trade  rivalry  will  be  keen  in  other  markets,  especially  in  South  America.  It  is  there  where  immense  capital  is  necessary  for  extensive  undertakings,  and  we  fully  realise  your  advantage  over  us  for  the  present  in  this  respect,  for  it  is  you  who  have  made  the  greatest  economic  gain  out  from  the  world  war,  a  gain  which  puts  millions  upon  millions  of  ready  money,  while  bleeding  Europe  will  emerge  from  the  struggle  economi-  cally  weakened.  "We  Germans  would  not  dispute  your  legal  right  if  you  would  balance  the  munition  deliveries  to  our  enemies  with  raw  materials  and   foodstuffs  to  us."  Dr  Streseman  then  went  on  to  explain  that  America  did  not  really  understand  Germany  because  she  looked  at  her  through  the  "dis-  torted  eyeglasses  Of  Reuter."  "It  is  only  in  British  fancy,"  he  said,  "that  we  are  going  to  wage  war  against  Brazil  or  other  South  American  States  in  order  to  establish  colonies.  "You  look  calmly  on  while  Britain  rules  half  the  world,  while  she  militarily  controls  the  gates  of  the  world  in  Egypt,  India,   Cape  Colony,  Canada,  and  Gib-  raltar.  In  your  opinion  that  is  all  right  ;  but  if  in  peace  time  Ger-  many  indicated  that  she  wished  a  coaling  station  or  two  to  protect  her  vast  trade,  then  half  the  press  of  the  universe  rose  in  an  outcry  against  the  German  lust  for  'con-  quest'  and  the  'world  domination'  she  wished  to  establish.  We  stand  second  in  world  trade.  In  exports  we  are  only  300,000,000  marks  (£15,000,000)  behind  England,  and  we  surpassed  her  by  more  than  3,000,000,000  marks  (£150,000,  000)  in  exports,  if  we  exclude  British  exports  to  her  own  Colonial  Emgire,  which  buys  4,000,000,000  marks'  (£200,000,000)  worth  of  goods  from  her  annually,  she  would  long  ago  have  been  defeated  by  Germany  in  free  world  competition  —  defeated,  however  not  by  unfair  methods,  but  by  the  superior  qual-  ity  of  German  goods."'  In  the  "Through  German  Eyes"  column  of  ''The  Times"  recently  is  discernable  a  more  anxious  strain  in  Dr  Stresemann's  remarks  concerning  the  Paris  Economic  Conference.  Russia,  in  particular,  seems  to  have  considerably  dis-  mayed  him.  The  meeting  of  the  Russo-British  Chamber  of  Com-  merce  at  the  Savoy  Hotel,  at  which  Count  Benchendorff,  the  Russian  Ambassador,  presided,  should  prove  further  unpleasant  news  in  the  Fatherland.  Note  that  Dr  Stresemann  now  says:—  'We  do  not  yet  know  the  end  of  the  struggle.  We  know  that  we  are  military  invincible.  But  wherever  an  economic  heel  of  Achilles  shows  itself  England  will  make  every  attempt  to  bleed  us  to  death.  The  peace  must  include  the  restoration  of  free  competition  in  face  of  the  resolution  of  the  Paris  Conference.  When  free  com-  petition  is  restored  nothing  can  frighten  us,  because  we  know  that  in  this  freedom  Germany  can  win  the  victory."—  "The  Times."
snippet: It is a mistake to suppose, when reading of peace talk in Germany, that the topic is a new one there. It is not. I heard the German

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   (Admiralty  -  Per  Wireless.}   LONDON.  Thursday.—  German  offi-  cial:  English  attacks  this  evening  against  Marquion  and  Havrincourt,  and  the  canal  sector  failed.  LONDON,  Friday.  —  German  offi-  cial:  Renewed  English  attempts  be-  tween  the  Arras-Cambrai  and  Peronne-  Cambrai  roads  failed.  The  Franco-Americans  attacked  at  the  St.  Mihiel  bend.  The  fighting  continues.
snippet: LONDON, Thursday.—German official English attacks this evening against Marquion and Havrincourt, and the canal sector failed.
from_newspaper: The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times (Tas. : 1899 - 1919)

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   (Admiralty  —  Per  Wireless).   LONDON,  Monday.—  German  offi-  cial:  North  of  Montdidier  we  with-  drew  from  the  W.  bank  of  the  Avre,  and  Dombrook.  We  also  withdrew  to  the  north  bank  of  the  Vesle  before  a  strong  attack  near  Fismes.

heading: German.
article_text: German,   LONDON.  Wednesday,  6.50  p.m.—"The  French,  by  a  strong  thrust,  in  the  direc-  tion  of  Pinon,  and  southward  of  the  Laffaux-Chavignon  road,  temporarily  penetrated  our  lines,  but  our  counter-   thrust  drove  them  back."   LONDON,  Thursday,  12.10  a.m.—  "The  Anglo-French  attacked  on  a  wide   front  from  Havrincourt  Wood  to  the   Somme.  Counter  attacks  are  progressing.  The  enemy  penetrated  our  centre  be-  tween  Hargicourt  and  Emignon  Brook.  Elsewhere  the  attacks  failed."

heading: German.
article_text: German.   LONDON,  Wednesday,  1.45  a.m.—  "We  captured  English  and  Portuguese  positions  northward  of  the  La  Bassee   Canal.   "We  threw  the  enemy  back  across  the  Oise-Aisne  Canal  between  Coucy  le  Chateau  and  Brancourt."   LONDON,  Wednesday,  12.50  a.m.—  "We  captured  Quincy,  Landricourt,  and  Coucy  le  Chateau  (south  of  La  Fere)."
snippet: LONDON, Wednesday, 1.45 a.m.—"We captured English and Portuguese positions northward of the La Bassee Canal.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   Herr  Dernburg,the  Kaiser's  Press  agent  for  America,  and  probably  one  of  the  most  blun-  dering  and    thoughtless  persons  in  the  world,  has  deemed  it  fit  to  deliver  himself  publicly  on  the  subject  of—  tact!  It  was  at  a  meeting    of  a  league  newly-form-   ed  in  Berlin  with  a  view  to  expanding  German  industrial  interests  in  the  South  American  continent.  Herr  Dernburg,  who  had  been  elec-  ted  president,  said,  according  to  a  Reuter  mes-  sage  from  Amsterdam  received  recently:  —  'Germany  has  only  a  few  friends  in  the  world.  Feeling  in  South  America  is  divided,  and  real  neutrality  in  North  America  is  also  doubtful.  'It  is  not  uninteresting  to  note  how  Lord  Haldane  at  Manchester  explained  to  British  merchants  that  now  a  favorable  opportunity  had  come  to  snatch  away  from  Germany,  her  commercial  supremacy  for  ever.  'For  generations  to  come,  we  need  not  fear  competition  abroad,  though,  if  the  present  war  lasts  a  long  time,  commerce  will,  at  last,  be  obliged  to  find  new  outlets,  and  the  recapture  of  the  ground  now  lost  will  become  more  dif-  ficult.  'For  coal  and  iron  South  America  will  be  dependent  on  the  industrial  States  for  a  long  time  to  come,  and,  therefore,  the  investment  of  more  capital  in  South  America  will  be  well  worth  while  for  commercial  reasons,  and  also  in  order  to  regain  lost  ground.  '  ''Besides  strengthening,  our    economic  influ-  ence,  the  obtaining  of  a  certain  intellectual  influence  will  be  of  an  importance  which,  up  till  now,  has  been  greatly  underestimated.  'We  have  not  understood  the  soul  of  the  South  Americans,  and  not  of  them  alone.  For  this  reason,  we  find  few  friends  among  neu-  trals.  This  is  largely  the  fault  of  the  Ger-  mans,  who  must  learn  to  understand  foreigners  and  introduce  German  achievements  in  science  and  art  with  more  discretion  than  heretofore.  'Only  too  often  tho  German  merchant  shows  an  absence  of  that  friendly  feeling,  towards  merchants  abroad  which  is  of  special  weight  with  Southern  people.'
snippet: Herr Denburg, the Kaiser's Press agent for America, and probably one of the most blundering the thoughtless persons in the world, has deemed it fit to deliver himself publicity on

heading: GERMAN [?].
article_text: GERMAN  PASTORS.   In  the  Legislative  Assembly  yester-  day,  the  Minister  for  Education  (Hon.    H.  F.  Hardacre)  informed  Mr.  Carta  that  German  pastors  were  given  the  same  facilities  as  other  ministers  of  re-  ligion  in  regard  to  religious  instruction  during  school  hours.  No  discrimination  had  been  made,  no  complaints  had  been  received  from  German  pastors  in  regard  to  such  religious  instruction,  and  the  de-  partment  had  no  desire  to  make  any  discrimination.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   Koenigen  Luise,  mine-layer,  10.735  tons.  Built  1896.  Sunk  by  the  British  destroyer  Lance  near  the  mouth  of  the  Thames,  4th  August.  Torpedo  boat  exploded  and  sunk  in  Baltic,  5th  August.   U15  submarine.  Sunk  by  British  cruiser  Birmingham  in  North  Sea.  Spindhaven,  steamer,  on  Lake  Ny-  assa.  Captured  by  British  steamer.  Kaiser  Wilhelm  der  Grosse,  auxiliary  cruiser,  14.350  tons.  Sunk  by  British  cruiser  Highflyer  off  the  African  coast,  27th  August  Magdeburg,  cruiser,  4.550  tons.  12  4-inch  guns.  Built  1810.  Ran  ashore  in   Baltic  Sea  and  destroyed  by  Russian  warships,  27th  August.  Goehen,  battle  cruiser,  23.000  tons  10  11-inch  and  12.6  inch  guns.  28\  knots.  Built  19110.  Took  refuge  in  Dardanelles  and  sold  to  Turkey.  Breslau,  cruiser,  12  4-inch  guns.  28  knots.  Built  1910.  Took  refuge  in  Dardanelles  and  sold  to  Turkey.  Mainz,  light  cruiser,  4.300  tons.  12  4-inch  guns.  20  knots.  Built  1905.  Sunk  in  engagement  Heligoland  Bight,  21st  August.   Koln,  light  cruiser,  4.350  tons,  12  4-  inch  guns.  26  knots.  Built  1908.  Sunk  in  Heliogoland  Bight,  21st  August.  Ariadne,  light  cruiser,  2.650  tons,  10  4-inch  guns,  21  knots.  Built  1897.  Sunk  in  Heligoland  Bight,  21st  August.  Cap  Trafalgar,  auxiliary  merchant  cruiser,  sunk  off  South  America  by  Car-  manin,  14th  September.  Spierwald,  auxiliary  merchant  cruiser  3.899  tons.  Captured  North  Atlantic  September  20.  Two  destroyers,  numbers  not  given.  Sunk  in  Heligoland  Bight,  21st  August.  Hela,  small  cruiser,  sunk  by  sub-  marine,  September  16th.
snippet: Kocnigen Luise, mine-layer, 10,735 tons. Built 1896. Sunk by the British destroyer Lance, near the mouth of the Thames, 4th August.
from_newspaper: Maryborough Chronicle, Wide Bay and Burnett Advertiser (Qld. : 1860 - 1947)

heading: GERMAN
article_text: ^GERMAN   The  pocket-book  of  an  officer  of  a  Saxon  regiment  has  been  found  to  contain  particulars  of  outrages  by  his  own  troops.  A  German  cyclist  at  one  village  pretended  to  have  been  shot  at.  For  this  tho  village  was  lired,  and  all  the  inhabitants  were  thrown  into  the  flames.  At  Leppes  200  civilians  were  killed,  the  writer  stating  that  the  commander  who  was  responsible  could  have  prevented  the  pillaging  and  destruction.
snippet: The pocket-book of an officer of a Saxon regiment has been found to contain particulars of outrages by his own troops.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.  The  following  German  ships  were  put  out  of  action.  BATTLESHIPS  AND  CRUISERS.  Two  Dreadnoughts  sunk.  One  of  Deutschland  type  (13,200  tons)  sunk.  Battle  cruiser  Lutzow  (28,000  tons)  sunk.  Dreadnought  severely  damaged,  pro-  bably  failed  to  reach  port.  Battle  cruiser  (ditto).  LIGHT  CRUISERS.  Five  light  cruisers  (one  of  large  size)  sunk.  DESTROYERS,  ETC.  Six  destroyers  sunk  (possibly  nine).  One  submarine  sunk.
snippet: The following German ships were put out of action. BATTLESHIPS AND CRUISERS. Two Dreadnoughts sunk.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   (Admiralty—  Per  Wireless.)   LONDON,  Friday.—  German  official:  The  enemy  has  captured  Havricourt.  Fresh  enemy  attacks  between  Moe-  uvres  and  Gouzencourt  were  repulsed.  In  anticipation  of  an  attack,  the   evacuation  of  the  St.  Mihiel  salient,  which  has  been  under  consideration  for  years,  was  commenced  a  few  days  ago.  The  French  advanced  to  the  heights  E.  of  Maas,  and  were  repul-  sed.  We  temporarily  lost  the  Com-  bres  height,  but  it  was  recaptured  by  the  Landwehr.  Austro-Hungarians,  S.  of  Combres,  by  their  strong  resist-  ance,  assured  the  retreat  of  our  divi-  sions  at  St.  Mihiel.  The  enemy  gain-  ed  ground  neair  Triacourt.  The  eva-   cuation  of  the  salient  was  completed  at  night  undisturbed.  LONDON,  Saturday.—  Official:  Our  advance  and  the  enemy  advances  led  to  violent  fighting  about  Moeuvres  and  Havrincourt.  Enemy  attacks  be-  tween  the  Ailette  and  the  Aisne  fail-  ed.  The  enemy  felt  his  way  forward  E.  of  Combres  and  N.W.  of  Thiaucourt  (in  the  St.  Mihiel  salient).
snippet: LONDON, Friday.—German official: The enemy has captured Harricourt. Fresh enemy attacks between Moeuvres and Gouzeucourt were repulsed.
from_newspaper: The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times (Tas. : 1899 - 1919)

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.  SUNDAY  NIGHT.--We repulsed  English  local  attacks,  which  entered  our  foremost  lines  westward  of  Locon.  We  repulsed  enemy  attacks  on  Dom-  miers  and  Villes  Cotterets.
snippet: SUNDAY NIGHT.—We repulsed English local attacks, which entered our foremost lines westward of Locon. We repulsed enemy attacks on

heading: German.
article_text: German.   A  Berlin  communique  reports:  —   ''General  Hindenberg  continues  to  storm  the  forfeited  bridgehead  at  Leunewaden,   north-west,  of  Friedrichstadt.   "The  Russians  north-west  and  west,  of   Vilna  attempted  to  stop  our  advance,  and  failed  with  heavy  losses.   "Our  troops  near  Grodno,  by  means  of  a  quick  action,  succeeded  in  crossing  the  Niemen  and  occupied  Grodno  town  after  street  fighting.  Four  hundred  prisoners   were  taken.   "General  von  Gallwitz,  on  the  road  to  Alekszyee,  south  of  Adelsk  Wiloz,  broke   down  the  resistance  of  the  Russian  rear-   guard,  taking  over  3000  prisoners  and  18  machine  guns.   "General  von  Mackensen  has  reached  Jasiolda,  near  Sjelec.   "General  von  Bothmer  is  approaching  the  south  district,  in  Galieia,  and  is  fighting  without  interruption."   Another  Berlin  communique  states:—   "We  stormed  the  bridgehead  and  road,  taking  3325  prisoners.  The  enemy  on  both  sides  of  the  Vilna  has  abandoned  800  pri-   soners,  besides  dead  and  wounded.   "The  whole  fortress  and  forts  at  Grodno  are  in  German  hands.  The  Russians  are   retreating  fast,  and  are  being  pursued.   We  captured  six  heavy  guns  with  2700  pri-   soners.   "The  enemy  evacuated  his  positions  on  the  Niemen  south  of  Grodno.   "Prince  Leopold  is  fighting  for  the  swamps  and  narrows  north  and  north-oest.  of  Brzezanv,  in  Galicia."
snippet: A Berlin communique reports- "General Hindenberg continues to storm the forfeited bridgehead at Leunewaden, north-west, of Friedrichstadt.

heading: GERMAN [?]
article_text: GERMAN  FEARS.   News  of  the  proclamation  of  a  Rhenish  republic  caused  much  agitation  in  Berlin  and  fears  for  German  unity.  Herr  Leinert,  one  of  the  German  peace  delegates,  to  Versailles,  says  he  attributes  the  Hano-  verian  movement  to  British  diplomacy,  as  Great  Britain  desires  to  gain  a  foothold  in  the  seaport  of  Bremen.
snippet: News of the proclamation of a Rhenish republic caused much agitation in Berlin and fears for German unity. Herr Leinert one of the German peace delegated to

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   {Admiralty.  —  Per  Wireless.)  .   LONDON,  Sunday.  —  German  offi-  cial:  Everywhere  along  the  battle-front  we  are  in  our  new  positions.  South  of  the  Peronne-Cambrai  road,  the  ene-  my  attempted  to  approach  them,  and  our  rearguards  yielded  to  a  numeri-   cally  superior  enemy,  and  repulsed  vio-  lent  attacks  W.  of  Gousaucourt,  Epehy  and  Templeux.  South  of  the  Ailette  River,  the  ene-  my  reached  our  line  B.  of  Vauxaillon.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   (Admiralty—  Per  Wireless.)   LONDON,  Tuesday.—  Official:  We  repulsed  attacks  W.  of  Chaulnes  and  N.W.  of  Roye.  We  repulsed  French  attacks,  after  bitter  fighting,  between  Bouvraignes  and  the  Oise;  also  between  Carlepont  and  Souvron.  LONDON,  Wednesday.—  German  offi-  cial:  The  French  attempted  to  break  through  our  line  between  the  Oise  and  the  Aisne.  The  first  assault  broke  down  in  our  battle  positions  after  a  bitter  struggle.
snippet: LONDON, Tuesday.—Official: We repulsed attacks W. of Chaulnes and N.W. of Roye. We repulsed French attacks, after

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   (Admiralty  —  Per  Wireless.)  LONDON,  Friday.—  German  Offi-  cial:  We  repulsed  partial  attacks  E.  of  the  Meuse,  the  Austro-Hungarians  specially  distinguishing  themselves.  The  Franco-Americans,  advancing  W.  of  the  Aisne  and  E.  of  the  Ar-  gonne,  employed  numerous  tanks.  Our  advanced  posts,  in  accordance  with  orders,  retreated  fighting  to  their  allotted  defence  lines.  The  enemy  reached  the  heights  N.W.  of  Tahure  and  Fontaine-Notre-  Dame,  where  our  reserves  stopped  the  enemy's  local  attempt  to  break  through.  The  enemy's  attacks  between  Aub-  erive  and  S.E.  of  Semmeny,  also  northward  of  Cernay,  broke  down.  Between  the  Argonne  and  the  Meuse,  the  enemy  reached  Mont  Blainville.  Montfaucon  and  the  bend  in  the  Meuse,  N.E.  of  Mont-  faucon,  where  he  was  brought  to  a  standstill  by  our  reserves.  Fresh  battles  are  imminent.
snippet: LONDON, Friday.—German Official: We repulsed partial attacks E. of the Meuse, the Austro-Hungarian specially distinguishing themselves.
from_newspaper: The North Western Advocate and the Emu Bay Times (Tas. : 1899 - 1919)

article_text: GERMAN.   LONDON,  Monday.—  German  offi  cial:  Sunday's  fighting  resulted  in  complete  success  for  the  Germans.  Enemy  attacks  S.W.  of  Soissons  and  S.W.  ot  Hiirteunes  broke  down.  Wo  threw  back  tho  enemy  N.  of  Ville  -liontoire,  and  we  defeated  an  assault  astride  Oulchy-le-Chateau.  Strong  enemy  attacks  N.  and  N.E.  of  Chateau-Thierry  broko  down  with  heavy  losses.  Wo  sanguinarily  repulsed  Anglo  French  attacks  between  the  Marne  and  Ardre  Rivers.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GRAMAN   The  social  which  was  held  in  aid  of  the  Tennis  Club  was  a  marked  success.  Although  the  weatber  was  very  threatening  about  thirty  couples  were  present.  During  tbe  evening  a  presentation  was  made  to  the  worthy   secretary,  Mr.  W.  L.  O'Brien.  Mr.  A.  Lowe  mads  the  presentation,  and  in  a  few  fitting  words  said  that  the  Club  was  indebted  to  Mr.  O'Brien  for  his  untiring  efforts  in  furthering  its  interests.  Mr.  M.  Robson  endors-  ed  the  last  speaker's  remarks,  and  said  be  hoped  that  although  Mr.  O'Brien  was  not  actually  in  harness  he  hoped  the  CIub  would  not  lose  one  of  its  most  energetic  members.  Mr.  O'Brien  in  responding,  said  he  tried  to  do  his  best  in  the  interests  of  the  Club,  but  through  pressure  of  busi-  ness  he  was  unable  to  do  it  justice,  so  he  thought  it  better  for  the  Club  if  he  allowed  some  one  else  to  fill  his  place.  He  again  thanked  the  mem-  bers,  and  said  he  would  continue  to  do  his  utmost  to  advance  its  interests.  A  tennis  match  was  played  between  Bannockburn  and  Gratnau  last  Satur-  day.  The  game  was  very  evenly  and  keenly  contested,  and  was  won  by  Bannockburn  by  the  narrow  margin  of  4  games.  We  have  experienced  several  frosts  during  the  last  few  weeks,  and  of  course  everybody  is  wishing  winter   over,  and  the  nice  warm  days  in  its  stead.  Last  Thursday  at  the  School  at  9  a.m.  it  was  32  degrees,  a  record  for  this  year  up  to  the  present.  By  the  way,  the  local  school  garden  at  the  present  is  looking  in  tip  top  order,  although  it  cannot  boast  of  a  garden  equal  to  "Andersons"  it  will  in  the  near  future  eclipse  many  so-  called  gardens.  At  the  present  time  the  local  school  is  half-time,  but  it  is  to  be  hoped  that  before  long  it  will  be  made  into  a  provisional.          REX.
snippet: The social which was held in aid of the Tennis Club was a marked success. Although the weather was very threatening about thirty couples

article_text: GERMAN.   LONDON,  Friday.—  German  official:  We  repulsed  attacks  on  the  front  on  both  sides  of  Ville-Mont-Soire,  as  far  S.  as  Hartennes.  Strong  Franco-British  forces  attacked  from  a  line  N.  of  Grand  Rozoy  and  Fere-en-Tardenois,  and  their  tanks  on  both  sides  of  Brug-  neux  crossed  our  front  lines,  and  reached  the  heights  N.  of  Brugneux,  but  were  ultimately  shot  to  pieces.  We  sanguinarily  repulsed  infantry  attacks.  Enemy  attacks  N.  of  Cierges  also  failed.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.  Germany's  luck  has  been  out.  To  understand  this  we  want  to  read  history.  Had  there  never  been  a  great  Empire  of  Germany,  then  possibly  there  would  now  be  a  great  German  Empire.  We  want  to  realise  that  the  old  German  Empire  was  one  made  up  of  nations,  and  that  some  of  these  did  great  pioneerlng  work  which  circumstances  linked  with  their  individual  selves.  If  Australia  were  to  take  all  New  Guinea,  and  England  approved,  it  would  be  an  Imperial  work,  and  our  language  being  the  same,  the  latter  would  stand  even  though  ultimately  we  separated.  Some  of  the  work  of  Spain  was  done  as  part  of  the  old  German  Empire:  that  is  to  say,  the  King  of  Spain  was  also  the  German  Emperor.  The  old  German  Empire  came  too  soon  in  last,  albeit  it  did  last   in  one  form  and  another  for  ages.  Permanent  Empire  is  dependent  on  rapid  transit  and  quick  intercommunications.  Without  the  stcemboat  and  the  telegraph,  and  also  railways  in  conjunction,  the  present  British  Empire  would  be  as  impossible  as  was  the  former  one.  1t  is  forgotten  that  there  was  an  Anglo-French  Empire,  even  though  not  that  the  thirteen  American  Colonies  dissolved,  the  Anglo-American  one  to  the  extent  that  they  were  responsible  for  the  title.  German  is  the  vernacular  of  a  territorially  small  section  of  the  world's  surface.  It  is  filled  in  solid  in  the  little  map.  German  is  read  or  spoken  to  some  extent  in  the  shaded  sections,  for  the  following  reasons—  in  parts  through  old  control  and  the  continued  virility  and  influence  of  the  strain,  and  over  all  through  present  Germany's  commercial  and  flinancial  relatlonships.  To  these  we  may  add  strain  derivations,  no  matter  of  what  date,  and  the  face  that  German  has  been  responsible  for  a  great  literature.  Nevertheless  partial  use  is  not  sufficient.  Partial  use  in  Germany's  case  means  that  in  many  spheres  the  language  is  merely  classical.  There  is  no  domain  for  the  vernacular  to  establish  itself  outside  of  Europe  and  spread.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   Messrs  T.  Boss-Walker  Ltd.,  of  Hob-  art,  have  received  from  the  Inter-  nationale  Frucht-Import-Gesellschaft,  in  Hamburg  details  of  the  sale  of  their  shipments  of  Tasmanian  apples  ex-  R.M.S.  Comorin  and  Narkunda,  tran-  shipped  from  London.  A  portion  of  the   fruit  suffered  somewhat  from  detention  in  London  and  in  the  course  of  tran-  shipment;  but  taken  as  a  whole  the  shipments  were  delivered  in  very  fair  order.  The  best  of  the  fruit  sold  as  under,  other  parcels  and  portions  of  parcels  inferior  in  quality  or  condition  or  of  "plain"  grade  or  under  2¼  inch,  realised  from  m.  6.25  to  m.  17.40,  four  cases  wasty  m.  400  and  three  cases  very  wasty  down  to  m.  3.000.  The  mark  is  worth  about  11¾d.

heading: FORMERLY GERMAN.
article_text: FORMERLY  GERMAN   An  "  advance  copy  of  the  mandate  granted  to  the  Commonwealth  Gov  ernment  for  the  administration  of  .  former  German  territory  in  New  Guinea  and  the  former  German  Is   lands  in  the  Pacific  lying  south:of  the.  .equator,  has  been  received  by  the,  Prime  Minister.  It  follows  closely  the  main  provisions  of  Article  22  of  the  Covenant  of  the  League  of  Na  tions,  but  differs  slightly  in  its  lang  uage.  The  mandatory  is  to  have  full  power  of  administration  and  legisla  tion  over  the  territory  as  an  integral  part  of  the  Commonwealth  of  Austra  1  Jia,  and  may  apply  to  it  the  laws  of  |  the  Commonwealth,  subject  to  such   local  modifications  as  circumstances   I  require.  The  mandatory  must  pro  j  mote  to-the  utmost  the  material  and   moral  well-being  and  the  social  pro  gress  of  the  inhabitants,  .must;  see  |  that  the  slave  trade  is  prohibited,  and  !  no  forced  labor  permitted  (except  for  |  essential  public  works  and  services,   !  and  then  only  for  adequate  remunera  !  tionj,  and  must  also  see  that  traffic   in  arms  and  ammunition  is  control   [  led.  The  supply  of  intoxicating  |  spirits  and  beverages  to  the  natives,  I  and  the  military  training  of  the  nat  !  ives  other  than  for  tho  purpose  of  in  j  ternal;  peace  and  local  defence,  1b  pro-;  hibited,  and  no  naval  or  military  I  bases  are  to  be  established  or  fortifi  j  cations  erected  in  the  territory.  The  !.  mandatory  .  must  ensure  freedom  of   conscience  and  the  free  exercise  of  all  forms  of  worship,  and  allow  all  missionaries  and  nationals,  of  any  member  of  the  League  of  Nations  to  enter  into,  travel,  and  reside  in  the  territory  for  the  purpose  of  prosecut  ing  their  callings.  An  annual  report  is  to  be  made  to  tho  Council  of  the  League  of  Nations,  whose  consent  is  required  for  any  modification  of  the  terms  of  the  present  mandate.  If  any  dispute  should  arise  between  the  man-;  datory  and  another  member  of  the  League  of  Nations  relating  to  the  in-,  terpretation  or  the  application  of  the  provisions  of-the  mandate,  if  it  can  not  be  settled  by  negotiations,  it  must  be  submitted  to  the  permanent  court  of  International  Justice.   JAPAN'S  DECLARATION   An  official  copy  of  the  declaration  made  by  the  Japanese  Government  on  the  occasion  of  the  settling  of  the  mandates  in  regard  to  all;  the  man   dates  in  class  "C"  (German  South-,  west  Africa,  German  Samoa,  Nauru,  the  New  Guinea  territory,  arid  the  is  lands  north  of  the,  equator)  .has  also  reached  .  Mr.  Hughes.  It  .is  as  fol  lows  :-"From  the  fundamental  spirit  of  the.  League.  of  Nations,  and  the  question  of  interpretation  of  the  Cove  nant,  his  Imperial  Japanese  Majesty's  Government  has  a  Arm  conviction  in  the  justice  of  the  claim  it  has  hitherto  made  for  the  inclusion  of  a  clause  concerning  the  assurance  of  equal  op   portunities  for  trade  and  commerce;  in  "C"  mandates.  But  from  a  spirit'  of  conciliation  and  co-operation  and  its  reluctance  to  see  the  question  set*  tlod  any  longer,  it  has  decided  to  ag  ree  to  the  issue  of  the  mandate  in  its  present  form,  Thet  decision,  however,  should  not  be  considered  as  an  ac  <mieeceace  on  tho  part  of  his  Imper  ial  japaueaQ  Majesty's  Government  .:n  the  BubmiSsieil  of  Japanese  sub  jects  to  a  discHffiinatoiy  aiid  disad   vantageous  tr6atiii6nt  in  the  iiiah-  1  dated  tcirriiorifes.  Nor  lias  it  tiifireby  discarded  Its  filaiih  that  th6  rights  and  interests  enjoyed  by  Japanese  subjects  in  these  territories  in  the  past  should  be  fully  respected."  The  mandate  conferred  on  Japan  in  re  spect  to  the  former  German  posses  sions  north  of  the  equator  is  in  the  same  terms  as  that  for  the  New  Guinea  territory.

heading: GERMAN BRAG.

heading: GERMAN REBELS.
article_text: GERMAN  REBELS.  Herr  Lipinski,  an  Independent  Social  Ist,  who  is  Saxon  Minister  of  the  Inter  jor,  made  a  remarkable  speech  in  the  Diet.  He  declared  that  there  were  several  notorious  anti-Republican  organisations.  These  were  financed  by  the  Saxon  indus  trialists  to  promote  a  conservative  Pan  German  Government.  One  organisation,  known  as  the  Brethren  of  the  Rock,  he  declared,  was  operating  in  Eastern  Sax  ony.  Another  was  called  the  Ilohenzol  lern  Knighthood.  Its  headquarters  were  at  Leipzig,  The  authorities  confiscateu  700,000.marks,  which  had  been  collected  by  these  organisations,  whose  functions  included  a  secret  fighting  organisation,  and  a  court  to  punish  and-even  sentence  to  death  those  obstructing  the  work.
snippet: Herr Lipinski, an Independent Socialist, who is Saxon Minister of the Interior, made a remarkable speech in the Diet.
from_newspaper: Newcastle Morning Herald and Miners' Advocate (NSW : 1876 - 1954)

heading: GERMAN OUTRAGE
article_text: GERMAN  OITRAGE  The  railway  bridge  at  Duren,  in  Rhen  ish  Prussia,  was  blown  up  by  bombs  a  few  minutes  before  the  Brussels-Cologne  express  was  duo  to  pass.  Scnegalese  soldiers  warned  the  driver,  who  stopped  the  express  in  time  to  avoid  disaster.
snippet: The railway bridge at Duren, in Rhenish Prussia, was blown up by bombs a few minutes before the Brussels-Cologne express was due to pass.

heading: GERMAN CRUELTIES.
article_text: SGERMAN  CiRUELTIES.  The  hearing  of  the  evidence  of  Mritlsh  war  prisoners'  who  were  unable  to  attend  at  Lelpsig  in  respect  of  the  chargee  against  the  Germans  of  cruelty  in  prison  camps,  began  yesterday  at  Bow-streee,  when  German  lawyers  attended  to  cross  exnamine  the  witnesses.  The  first  charge  was  against  MIuller,  commandant  of  the  Flavelemartel  prison  camp,  of  cruelties  practised  in  April  and  June,  1918,  where  there  were  500  dases  of  dysentery  In  a  month,  with  an  average  of'six  deaths  a  day.  The  evidence  of  the  witnesses  showed  that  there  was  no  doctor  at  the  camp,  and  the  'naccused  habitually  rode  through  the  camp  scattering  the  prisoners,  whom  he  photographed  in'  their  agonies.  Dr.  Stewart  Melghen:  ex-chaplain,  and  a  war  prisoner,  stated  that  90  sick  Brit  ish  prisoners  arriver  at  Stondahl  oamp  in  June,  1918,  from  Flavelemartel.  They  were  terribly  emaciated,  were  verminous,  and  had  undressed  sores.  A  number  of  them  died.  Another  witness  stated  that  *between  50  and  60  of  those  died  from  lack  of  food  and  from  ill-treatment.
snippet: The hearing of the evidence of British war prisoners who were unable to attend at Le[?]psig in respect of the charges against the Germans of cruelty in prison

heading: GERMAN SHIPBUILDING.
article_text: GERMAN  SHIPBUILDING.   ?  The  capture  by  a  Swedish  yard  of  the  order  for  a  -motor  tanker  by  the  Hamburg  dm  of  Albreclits  was  a  very  bitter  pill  for  German  shipbuilders  to  swallow,  for  with  their  experience  in  the  construction  of  this  type  of  vessel  they  have  been  very  successful  in  se  curing  Scandinavian  orders,  and  cer   tainly  did  not  expect  to  lose  the  con  tract  for  an  8500-ton  ship  for  native  owners.  The  Swedish  Government  is  willing  to  grant  a  certain  amount  of  assistance  to  yards  building  for  foreign  owners,  (tut  not  nearly,  so  much  as  when  the  ships  are  Tor  native  firms,  while  the  rate  of  interest  Is  much  higher.  The  German  Government  is  now  being  persuaded  to  grant  additional  benefits  to  shipbuilders,  with  the  recent  order  as  the  basis  of  campaign.
