heading: GERMAN SETTLERS.
article_text: GERMAN  SETTLERS.   Sir,-According  to  Press  reports,  Ger-  man  agriculturists  desire  to  resume  migration  to  Australia.  It  is  said,  a  number  of  them  possessed  of  capital  from  one  thousand  to  three  thousand   pounds  each,  are  ready  to  come,  pro-  vided  Australia  is  willing  to  receive  them.  It  is  to  be  sincerely  hoped  that  the  Federal  Government  will  not  miss  the  opportunity  of  securing  as  many  as  possible  ol  those  industrious  people.  For  if  we  do  not  secure  them,  Canada  or  Argentina  will  gladly  welcome  them  to  their  shores.  Few  people,  I  think,  will  deny  that  the  German  settlers  of  former  years  proved  themselves  second  to  none  as  pioneers  of  Australia.  Their  activities  were  not  confined  to  one   crop,  or  one  district.  They  spread   themselves  throughout  the  land,  and  embiaced  all  branches  of  the  agricul-  tural  industry.  As  citizens  tliev  were  honest  and  law-abiding.  Australia  has  everything  to  gain  by  welcoming  that  kind  of  migrant  in  thousands  at  all  times.  Because,  In  spite  of  all  tariffs  that  may  he  given  to  our  secondary  Industrie.1!  it  will  still  remain  for  the  primary  industries  to  pull  Australia  out  of  the  financial  bog  which  she  is   in  to-day.   -I  am,  sir,  &c.   1  W.  BATES,  ,   Olive-street,  Nundah,  February  2.

heading: GERMAN ARMY
article_text: GERMAN  ARMY   The  biggest  manoeuvres  held  since  the  war,  which  Germany  officially  describes  as  "the  turning  point  in  the  history  of  the  German  Army,"  are  being  carried  out.   The  manoeuvres  at  Luneburg  and  Hanover  will  include  combined  Army  and  Air  Force  exercises  designed  to  stem  and  throw  back  an  advancing  enemy  of  double  the  strength  of  the  army  taking  part. heading: GERMAN HAND
article_text: GERMAN  HAND   KISCH  SEES  IT  IN  BAN  BY  FEDERAL  GOVERNMENT   ADELAIDE,  Sunday.  —  Declaring  he  was  convinced  that  the  Hitler  Government  was  responsible  for  the  Federal  Government's  decision  not  to  allow  him  to  land  here,  Egon  Kisch,   Czechoslovakian  author  and  lecturer,  who  passed  through  the  Outer  Har  bor  in  the  Strathaird,  said  it  was  significant  that  Australia  was  now  attempting  to  re  -open  trade  channels  with  Germany.  When  the  ship  reaches  Melbourne  he  intends  to  jtry,  through  the  Con  sul-  General  for  Czechoslovakia,  to  have  the  ban  removed.  He  said  that  unless  this  was  done  he  intended  to  disclose  In  his  future  writing  the  treatment  meted  out  to  him  by  the  Federal  Government.  He  was  not  an  agitator,  but  was  a  pacifist.  BISHOP  LENDS  WEIGHT  TO  PROTEST  MELBOURNE,  Sunday.—  The  pro  test  against  the  exclusion  from  Aus  tralia  of  Herr  Kisch,  the  novelist,  and  the  New  Zealander,  Mr.  Griffin,  dele  gates  to  the  All-  Australian  Congress  of  the  Council  against  War  and  Fas  cism,  is  supported  by  the  Bishop  of  Goulburn,  Rt.  Rev.  E.  H.  Burgmann.  He  has  sent  a  statement  to  the  Kisch  reception  committee.  "I  understand  that  these  men  were  to  speak  at  an  anti-war  meeting  at  Fort  Melbourne,"  says  the  Bishop.  "If  this  is  the  reason  why  permission  was  refused,  It  is  an  altogether  inadequate  one.  deputation  to  minister  The  Minister  for  Defence,  Mr.  Parkhlll,  told  a  deputation  at  the  week-end  that  he  would  refer  its  protest  against  Herr  Egon  Erwin  Klsch's  exclusion  to  the  Minister  for  the  Interior,  Mr.  Paterson.

heading: GERMAN DEMANDS
article_text: GERMAN  DEMANDS   HISTORIANS  in  years  yet.  to|   come,  when  they  will  be  in  a  position  to  look  back,  and  make  a  fair-  ly  unbiassed  review  of  the  War,  and  its  consequences,  may  conclude  that  the  Treaty  of  Versailles  can  rank  with  the  Treaty  of  Vienna  a  century  earlier,  as  indicating  a  total  absence  of  under-  standing.  No  doubt  a  great  part  of  the  muddle  was  due  to  the  insistence  of  President  Wilson  that  the  adjust-  ment  of  conditions  must  be  delayed  until  his  own  special,  fad  was  dealt  with.  Certainly  that  insistence  was  responsible  for  the  hasty  creation  of  the  League  of  Nations,  but  since  America  at  once  repudiated  the  under-  takings  of  her  President,  nothing  was  gained.  The  history  of  the  world  since  has  been  a  sad  one.  Some  of  the  clauses  of  the  Treaty  of  Versailles  have  been  ignored,  and  the  financial  clauses  of  this  and  other  treaties  have  been  changed,  and  changed  again,  un-  til  they  are  unrecognisable.  And  now  Germany  is  in  a  condition  of  practical  revolt  against  the  conditions  of  the  Treaty  limiting  her  right  to  arma-  ments.  For  this  spirit,  we  arc  sorry  to  say,  France  has  some  responsibility.  In  spite  of  the  fact  that  Germany  has  been  left  practically  helpless  for  ag-  gression,  France  refuses  every  sugges-  tion  for  a  substantial  reduction  of  armaments.  Perhaps  this  consistent  refusal,  and  the  examples  of  chauvin-  ism,  are  more  directed  against  Italy,  but,  in  order  to  avoid  complications,  Germany  is  held  up  as  the  potential  enemy.  There  has  been  much  adverse  comment  as  to  the  failure  of  Great  Britain,  through  the  League  of  Na-  tions,  or  otherwise,  to  bring  about  a  settlement.  This  criticism  is  not  just.  Great  Britain  has,  during  and  since  the  War,  pulled  so  many  chestnuts  out  of  the  fire  for  others,  all  of  whom  were  ungrateful,  thal  suggestions  of  further  burning  of  fingers  in  the  cause  of  al-  truism  are  not  welcomed.  If  France  really  reduced  armaments,  probably  Germany  would  not  make  any  demand  for  equality.

heading: GERMAN CREDIT
article_text: GERMAN  CREDIT   OWING  to  the  total  failure  of  all   efforts  to  make  arrangements  with  Germany  for  the  payment  of  pri-  vate  debts,  the  Lancashire  cotton  mill-  ing  companies  have  decided  definitely  that  they  will  not  expoit  any  more  of  their  goods  to  that  country.  This  means  a  serious  interruption  to  an  old  established  trade.  But  the  manufac-  turers  are  faced  with  a  difficult  posi-  tion.  Already  there  is  a  great  deal  of  money  owing  for  goods  supplied,  and  the  German  Government  has  not  only  authorised  but  has  practically  com-  pelled  repudiation  of  the  debts.  It  must  be  noted  that  this  has  nothing  to  do  with  the  public  debt,  whether  owed  to  Governments  or  to  private  in-  dividuals  or  companies.  It  is  purely  a  matter  of  private  obligations  incurred  as  between  trading  concerns.  German  merchants  have  bought,  at  prices  fixed  by  mutual  consent,  quantities  of  cotton  goods  from  manufacturers  in  Lanca-  shire,  who  have  paid  for  the  raw  ma-  terial,  the  wages  of  the  persons  em-  ployed,  and  other  incidental  charges  Their  customers  are  men  with  whom   they  have  had  dealings  for  many  years,  j  and  there  has  not  been  any  suggestion  of  doubt  as  to  their  ability  and  willing-  ness  to  meet  their  obligations.  Now  these  are  set  on  one  side,  and  it  has  not  been  possible  even  lo  secure  the  pro-  mise  of  an  arrangement  for  future  payment.  In  the  circumstances  there  can  be  no  other  course  than  to  refuse  further  business.  But  the  position  is  extremely  serious.  Wholesale  repudia-  tion  by  a  nation  of  its  public  and  pri-  vate  monetary  obligations  tends  to  shake  the  whole  foundation  of  inter-  national  credit.
snippet: OWING to the total failure of all efforts to make arrangements with Germany for the payment of private debts, the Lancashire cotton

heading: GERMAN GIRLS
article_text: GERMAN  GIRLS   Every  German  girl  must  in  the  future  "serve  the  people"  for  a  year.  Hitherto  only  those  engaged  in  certain  occupations  were  liable  for  labor  service.  Now  the  order  is  extended  to  all  unmarried  girls  under  the  age  of  25,  which  affects  300,000  to  400,000  annually,  who  may  be  employed  in  industry,  agriculture  or  household  work.  The  measure  is  due  to  labor  shortage,  which  is  also  leading  to  the  compulsory  closing  down  of  small  shops  and  unprofitable  factories.

heading: GERMAN SHEEP.
article_text: GERMAN  SHEEP.   Germany's  flocks  of  sheep  have  been  increased  by  a  third  in  the  past  three  years  in  the  great  drive  for  economic  self-sufficiency.  An  official  census  shows  that  Germany  now  has  4,400,000  sheep,  which  is  1,100,000  more  than  at  the  time  of  the  1932  census.  The  increase  is  due  to  the  Government's  efforts  to  free  the  country  as  much  as  possible  from  dependency  upon  imports,  a  goal,  however,  which  experts  doubt  can  be  ever  attained.  How  far  Germany  has  progressed  along  the  road  to  general  self-sufficiency  has  been  shown  by  recent  official  figures,  which  showed  that  the  value  of  food  imports  had  declined  from  3,900,000,000  marks  (£325,000,000)  in  1929  to  1,100,000,000  marks  (£91,700,-  1  000)  in  1934.  It  is  further  announced  that  Germany's  requirements  of  grain,  flour,  meat,  potatoes  and  milk  can  be  almost  entirely  provided  by  home  production  this  year,  while  87  per  cent  of  the  butter  demand  can  also  be  riiet.
snippet: Germany’s flocks of sheep have been increased by a third in the past three years in the great drive for economic self-sufficiency.

heading: GERMAN COMMENT.
article_text: GERMAN  COMMENT.   BERLIN,  Dec.  8.—  With  reference  to  Sir  Samuel  Hoare's  speech  in  the  House  of  Commons,  -  the  'Berliner  Tageblatt'  declares  that  the  British  Government  is   laying  the  foundations  of  a  strong  and  second  post-war  England.  'The  first,'  it  says,  'was  dominated  by  the  Poincare  in  fluences,  which  are  now  ended.  Britain  is  taking  not  only  her  own  future  but  that  of  Europe  in  hand,  hoping  to  settle  her  relations  with  her  neighbours  before  the  storm  breaks  out  in  the  Far  East'

heading: GERMAN REARMAMENT
article_text: GERMAN  REARMAMENT  While  it  appears  to  overlook  the  provocation  under  which  Germany  laboured  before  she  reached  her  recent  decision  to  undertake  com  aplete  W'earnmament  in  defiauce  of  the  provisions  of  the  Versailles  Treaty,  the  article  written  by  the  British  Prime  Minister,  Mr.  Ram  say  MacDonald,  and  published  in  the  National  Labour  Party's  maga  zine,  in  Which  he  declares  that  Ger  many  has  "broken  up  the  rnad  to  peace'  is  entitled  to  be  read  with  particular  respect  and  attention  be  cause  the  .writer  is  and  has  heen  for  many  years  the  world's  foremost   pacificist,  and  he  could  only  make  such  a  declaration  out  of  the  bitterness  of  his  heart,  induced  by  the  situation  into  which  Germany's  action  has  plunged  Europe.  Mr.  .MacDonald  Went  on  to  say  that  Germany  was  the  most  secure  nation  in  Europe  until"  she  aroused  sus  picion  by  her  own  demands,  in  cluding  an  army  which  would  be  the  greatest  in  Europe,  an  air  force  already  equal  to  that  of  Bri  tain  and  a  navy  equal  to  that  of  France  and  superior  to  the  Italian  navy.  The  Germans  were  asking  too  much  when  they  expected  acceptance  of  their  objects  and  methods  without  fear  and  suspicion,  in  the  face  of  ominous  revelations  of  the  ultimate  intentions  and  spir:it  animating  them,  and  Germany's  military  expansion  must  inevitably  force  the  sound  and  pacific  prin  ciple  of  general  collective  security  into  the  dangerous  form  of  military  alliances.  Coincidental  with  this  pessimistic  outburst  from  a  statesman  who  is  the  very  antithesis  of  a  militarist  or  alarmist,  interesting  information  has  been  published  concerning  the  actual  significance  of  the  state  ment  made  by  the  German  Presi  dent-Chancellor  (Herr  Hitler)  to  the  British  Foreign  Secretary  (Sir  John  Simon)  during  the  Berlin  conversa  tions  recently,  that  Germany  had  already  achieved  air  parity  with  Britain.  This  was  perhaps  gener  ally  assumed  to  mean  that  the  Ger  man  establishment  of  military  air  craft  was  equal  to  that  maintained  in  the  British  Isles-a  total  of  about  480  machines,  but  it  is  now  statged  on  apparently  relialle  authority  that'  Germ?rny's  strength  in  the  air  is  equivalent  to  that  of  the  British  Empire,  or  a  total  of  about  1020  first-line  'planes,  thus  placing  Britain  herself  in  an  in  feriority  of  more  than  two  to  oe.  During  the  Great  War  Germany  was  the  initiator  and  principal  ex  nonent  of  the  policy  of  air  fright  fulness  against  the  civilian  popula  tions  of  the  countries  of  her  enemies,  and  even  after  nearly  twenty  years  there  are  still  a  sufficient  number  of  Britons.  particularly  Londoners,  alive,  who  well  renimember  the  Ger  man  air  raids,  when  bombls  were  dronpnd  ruthlessly  on  the  great  metropolis,  with  no  distinction  be  tween  strictly  military  and  ourely  nonr-military  obiectives,  for  the  dis  b.losuire  of  Germany's  preient   superiority  to  produce  an  irrestist  able  demand  for  muc'h  greater  ac  :eleratiou  of  Britain's  aerial  arman  rnment  than  was  provided  for  in  the  recently  passed  Estimates.  The  German  demand  for  a  navy  ,:iuivalent  to  that  of  France,  or  approximately  one-third  the  size  of  the  British  Navy,  will  also  be  very  hard  for  Britain  to  accept,  for  in  addition  to  the  fact  that  as  the  whole  of  Germany's  war-time  naval  strength  was  surrendered  at  the  close  of  the  war  and  then  scuttled  at  Scapa  Flow,  thus  ensuring  that  any  new  German  navy  will  consist  entirely  of  the  most  modern  ships,  whereas  most  of  the  units  of  the  British  Navy  date  from  war  or  pre  war  years.  Britain's  naval  craft  are  so  distributed  over  the  seven  seas  that  the  force  sought  by  Ger  many  would  approximately  give  her  Iarity  with  Britain  in  the  North  Sea.  As  Germany  has  no  colonies,  and  a  comparatively  short  coast  line,  it  is  difficult  to  see  that  she  has  any  legitimate  claim  to  a  navy  as  big  as  that  of  France  with  her  extended  coastline  on  two  oceans  and  her  somewhat  spread-eagled  African  colonies.  When  Britain's  sufferings  at  the  hands  of  German  aircraft  and  sub  marines  during  the  Great  War  are  rmemembered,  it  will  not  be  surpris  ing,  in  view  of  these  disquieting  trends  of  German  rearmament,  if  the  Prime  Minister's  declaration  about  Germany  having  "broken  the  road  to  peace"  meats  with  a  re  sponse  from  the  British  public  which  will  materially  stiffen  Britain's  attitude  towards  Europe's  pressing  security  problem.  Germany  appears  to  have  a  strong  case  for  a  substan  tial  measure  of  rearmnament,  but  failing  an  early  and  authoritative  secaling  down  of  her  present  demands  in  that  direction,  she  will  have  her-'  self  to  blame  if  she  finds  practically  her.  Britain  has  been  her  best  friend,  and  she  is  rapidly  alienating  British  sympathy

heading: GERMAN DIPLOMACY
article_text: GERMAN  DIPLOMACY   Sir,  —  In  his  letter  on  the  causes  of  the  Great  War  Mr.  Jones  has  made  many  inaccurate  statements.  He  said,  for  instance,  that  the  Kaiser  aban   doned  the  policy  of  Bismark,  which  stood  for  European  concentration,  friendly  alliance,  and  prevention  by  diplomacy  of  alliances  between  other  countries.  On  the  contrary,  ihe  Bis  markian  policy  was  one  of  deliberate  and  ruthless  conquest.  His  famous  de  claration  was  that  the  destinies  of  Germany  were  to  be  worked  out  not  by  notes  and  speeches,  but  by  blood  and  iron.  His  three  successful  wars  in  six  years  earned  for  him  the  name  of  'The  Iron  Chancellor.'  Mr.  Jones  says  that  during  the  Spanish-American  war,  the  Kaiser  ap  proached  England  with  regard  to  op  posing  the  United  States,  and  that  England  stood  by  America.  But  Mr.  Usher,  in  his  book,  asserts  that  the  Spanish-American  war  was  instigated  by  England  in  order  to  prevent  Ger  many  from  acquiring  the  Spanish  colonies.  Both  statements  may  be  wrong.  Again,  Mr.  Jones  says  that  during  the  Boer  War,  Germany  made  over  tures  to  France  and  Russia,  suggest  ing  combined  action  against  England,  but  that  they  refused.  According  lo  historians  Russia  and  France  were  pre  pared  to  intervene  on  behalf  of  the  Boer  Republic  if  Germany  would  join,  but  she  refused  to  do  so.  In  1899  the  London  'Daily  Mail'  was  full  of  praise  of  Germany.  The  Kaiser  was  hailed  as  'a  '  friend  in  need,  and  a  gallant  gentleman  whose  word  is  bet  ter  than  many  another's  bond.1',  Mr.  Jones  refers  to  General  Bern  hardi's  book  as  proof  of  Germany's  guilt,  A  book,  exactly  parallel  to  General  Bernhardi's,  entitled  'L'Of-   fensive  Contre  Allemagne'  has  been  written  in  France  by  Colonel  Boucher.  Another  correspondent,  Mr.  Watson,  mentioned  the  Agadir  incident,  m  1911  French  and  Spanish  troops  had  all  leir  spheres  marked  out  for  them  by  '  the  secret  articles  in  the  Anglo-French  agreement.  France  took  the  lead  in  threatening  war.  Germany  sent  'The  Panther'  to  Agadir  as  a  protest.  Why  Mr.  Watson  should  see  in  the  building  of  the  Constantinople  —  Bagdad  railway  more  evidence  of  ihe  German  qloven  loof  when  the  whole  world  is  hunt  ing  for  railway  concessions  is  beyond  my  comprehension.—  I  am,  sir,  &c,  Morningside.  -  F.  MALETZ

article_text: German's  Record   ROME,  July  15.—  The  German,  R  Harbig,  won  the  800  metres  run  from  the  Italian,  M.  Lanzi,  in  lmin  46  3-5  sec.  This  beats  Wooderson's  1938  re  cord  by  1  4-5sec.

heading: GERMAN MANOEUVRES.
article_text: GERMAN  MANOEUVRES.  METZ,  July  6.-The  German  army's  summer  manoeuvres  in  the  Siegfried  Line  region  have  begun.  Artillery  and  machine  gun  fire  can  be  heard  throughout  the  day  and  the  Saar  Valley  is  being  lit  by  search  lights  at  night  time.  Hundreds  of  planes  have  been  heard  near  border  towns.
snippet: METZ, July 6.—The German army's summer manoeuvres in the Siegfried Line region have begun. Artillery and machine- gun fire can be heard throughout the day

article_text: GERMAN  CHAMPIONSBH.  BERLIN.  Nov.  12.-W-alter  Neusel.  deleated  C.  Koelblin  on  points  in  Berlin  today.  The  match  decided  the  heavyweight  championship  of  Germany.

heading: GERMAN'S
article_text: GERMAN'S   LONDON,  Thursday.—Evidence  is  accumulating  that  fear  of  a  British  landing  In  Europe  is  be-  coming  a  nightmare  to  some  Ger-  man  staff  officers,  whose  preoccu-  pation  is  shown  in  story  after  story  coming  uncensored  from  neutral  correspondents  in  Berlin,  where  it  seems  to  be  taken  for  granted  that  the  visit  of  General  Marshall  to  London  concerns  the  completion  of  final  details.   A  despatch  from  the  "Daily  Mail"  correspondent  at  Stockholm  links  the  appearance  of  a  Hitlerite  peace  tout  in  Sweden  with  the  German  success  at  Vichy  as  evidence  of  German  mis-  givings  for  the  success  of  the  Spring  offensive  against  Russia,  and  stresses  that  those  activities  aim  at  securing  Hitler's  rear  against  a  British  crea-  tion  of  a  second  front.   The  peace  envoy  was  a  wealthy  Cologne  banker  of  Jewish  extrac-  tion.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   I  WISH  to  support  the  protest   against  the  use  of  German  ai   a  recent  public  Jewish  function.  The  occasion  was  a  concert  organis  ed  by  Jewish  youth  in  Melbourne  on   Sunday  night  in  aid  of  the  Israeli  appeal.  I  do  hot  think  our  young  people  —  and  particularly  its  more  intellectual  wing  —  ought  to  coun  tenance  any  truck  with  the  German  tongue.  They  ought  to  be  among  the  first  to  recognise  that  the  Jew  ish  people  desires  no  association  with  German  ‘kultur’  in  any  of  its  man  ifestations,  and  particularly  should  they  recognise  that  use  of  the  Ger  man  tongue  is  calculated  to  arouse  associations  that  are  .  painful  in  the  extreme.  If  there  are  people  that  use  the  language  in  private  that  is  their  business,  but  we  want  none  of  it  in  our  organised  official  life.  The  time  has  come  for  a  determined  stand  on  this  matter.  I  think  it  true  t  '  say  that  the  feelings  of  the  over  whelming  majority  of  Jews  are  out  rageu  by  public  Jewish  use  of  Ger  man.  That  seems  to  me  one  good  test  of  where  the.  proper  course  of  conduct  lies  here.

heading: GERMAN.
article_text: GERMAN.   fWUULU  ask  the  Jewish  -Stud   ents’  Study  Group  not  to  feel   that  I  have  been  severe  with  them  in  the  matter  to  which  I  referred  last  week  and  about  which  they  have  written  their  letter  in  this  issue.  I  thought  I  had  dealt  with  the  ques  tion  quite  moderately.  I  do  not  want  to  labour  the  point,  but  in  view  of  the  correspondence  this  week  per  haps  another  word  or  two  may  be  permitted.  The  further  arguments  adduced  do  not  throw  any  fresh  light  on  this  controversy.  One  can  not  altogether  escape  the  feeling—  I  may  be  quite  wrong  about  this—  that  the  students  are  defending  a  position  into  which,  willy-nilly,  they  have  been  forced.  I  want  to  say  to  them  a‘s  gently  as  I  can  that,  outside  a  tiny  minority,  they  will  find  no  support  for  their  views  anywhere  in  the  Jewish  world.  The  logical  arguments  with  which  for  the  most  part  defenders  of  German  must  make  do  cut  no  ice.  It  is  a  fact  which  anybody  may  ascertain  for  himself  that  Jewish  public  opinion  wanted  no  countenance  with  anything  German,  whether  it  be  the  culture,  language,  or  anything  else.  Against  that  justifiable  sentiment  all  the  ar  gument  in  the  world  will  not  avail.

heading: GERMAN TALES IN GERMAN
article_text: GERMAN  TALES  IN  GERMAN   THE  enterprise  of  the  Melbourne  University  Press  in  publishing  "Five  German  Tales,"  intended  as  "attractive  reading  matter  for  pupils  '  who  have  studied  the  language  for  at  least  one  year,"  is  praiseworthy,  especially  in  war-time.  The  tales  chosen  are  "from  among  the  most  charming  Marchen  in  German  literature,"  but  it  is  questionable  whether  they  make  a  suitable  text-book  for  the  readers  the  editor  has  in  mind.  German  fairy  tales  are  full  of  obsolete  words  and  archaic  constructions  that  may  be  attractive  for  the  educated  German  reader,  but  are  difficult  for  even  well-advanced  students.  Moreover,  German  style  has  changed  greatly  since  the  time  of  the  Brothers  Grimm.  The  stark  vigour  of  Luther's  prose,  the  Gallic  rococo  of  the  early  eighteenth  century,  the  classic  solidity  of  Goethe  and  Schiller,  and  even  post-war  German,  differs  widely   enqugh  to  be  almost  a  different  language.  The  sentence  of  seven  lines  (page  78)  is  characteristic  of  the  time  of  Schiller  and  Goethe,  but  no  intermediate  pupil  in  Germany  to-day  would  be  allowed  to  write  in  such  a  style,  any  more  than  a  modern  English  child  would  be  encouraged  to  write  in  the  language  of  Johnston  or  Goldsmith.  We  think  that  text-books  for  beginners  should  make  the  student  acquainted  with  the  living  rather  than  the  dead  language  by  interesting  him  in  stories  of  contemporary  life.  In  practice,  too,  it  would  be  better  if  the  help  provided  at  the  end  of  the  book  (notes,  vocabulary,  etc.)  were  spread  through  the  book  at  the  head  of  chapters  or  at  the  bottom  of  the  page.  Five  German  Tales.  By  Professor  A.  Lodewyckx.  Melbourne  University  Press.  Price  2/3.

heading: German Commander's Death GERMAN ADMISSION
article_text: German  Commander's  Death   GERMAN  ADMISSION   London,  Feb.  21.—  After  having  -  stated  yesterday  that  Stemmer  man,  commander  of  the  German  Eighth  Army,  had  been  awarded  oak  leaves  to  the  Knight's  Cross  for-  having  broken  out  of  the  Red  Army's  trap  at  Kanev,  Berlin  radio  admitted  to-day  that  Stemmerman  had  died  'a  heroic  death'  inside   the  Russian  ring.  The  radio  said  that  Stemmer  man's  death  was  announced  to  pressmen  by  his  successor.'  Russian  reports  yesterday  told  how  Stemmerman's  body  had  been  found  lying  alone  in  the  snow.

heading: GERMAN BROADCAST. Anti-German Propaganda.
article_text: GERMAN  BROADCAST.   Anti-German  Propaganda.   LONDON.  August  2S  —  A  voice,  speaking  in  German,  broke  Into  broad  casts  from  a  Deutscbland  sender  sta  tion  last  night  with  anti-German  pro  paganda.  The  voice  was  heard  to  sav:  'Against  Hitler  stands  the  world's  greatest  Industrial  power—  America,  the  greatest  sea  power—  Britain  and  the  greatest  land  force—  Russia  How  now,  can  Hitler  hope  to  win.  Hitler  will  bring  nothing  but  sorrow  to  you.  Destroy  Hitler  and  make  the  end  of  this  senseless  war.  Germany  cannot  sund  a  two  front  war.  Tou  were  told  Germany  was  immune  from  air  raid  ing,  but  enemy  planes  are  over  Ber  lin.  Rblneland  factories  have  been  transferred  to  Slovakia  and  Austria.  There  will  be  no  peace  for  the  Ger  man  people  while  Hitler  is  in  power.'

heading: GERMAN JEWS AND GERMAN CULTURE
article_text: GERMAN  JEWS  AND   GERMAN  CULTURE   By  ARNO  WITTEN   The  Jews  ai’e  endowed  with  sur  prising  spiritual  gifts.  There  is  one  domain  of  their  own,  the  pro  vince  of  religious  and  moral  ethics  where  the  great  deeds  of  this  small  people  have  shaped  the  human  history  of  millenniums.  The  spreading  of  the  idea  of  the  one,  spiritual  and  •  invisible  God,  the  creation  of  the  Bible,  the  mo  rals  and  teachings  of  Moses,  Christ,  Spinoza  and  Marx  have  in  fluenced  mankind  more  than  the  art  of  the  Egyptians,  the  geogra  phical  explorings  of  the#  Vikings,  the  laws  of  the  Romans,’the  war  deeds  of  Alexander  or  of  Ghengis   Khan.   Although  a  people  that  has  formed  the  shape  and  idea  of  human  life  throughout  the  civili  sed  world  has  certainly  fulfilled  ■the  task  which  history  has  laid  •  on  it  the  Jews  have  over  that  pro  •duced  miracles  also  in  the  sphere  •  of  general  human  culture.  And  .specially  so  in  Germany,  the  coun  try  that  to-day  denies  them  every  valuable  quality  of  mind  and  soul.   Their  contributions  to  art  and  .science  are  almost  inconceivable.  The  more  so  if  we  consider  that   they  have  been  kept  away  from  any  collaboration  with,  and  even  from  the  admission  to,  almost  any  form  of  cultural  life  since  ,  time   immemorial.  No  one  would  expect  people  who  had  been  forced  to  live  in  open  country  and  to  whom  the  doors  have  suddenly  been  opened  to  rush  into  the  building,  to  pull  down  immediately  the  old  walls  and  to  erect  better  ones.  They  must  first  find  out  their  way  in  the  new  surroundings  and  to  accomodate  themselves.  (It  is  •only  a  little  more  than  a  centi.ry  •since  the  Jews  have  been  permit  ted  to  join  the  European  life  with  equal  rights—and  that  indeed  only  formally,  not  even  practic  ally—-and  this  permission  has  al  ready  been  revoked  again,  It  is  instructive  to  remember  that  cruel  fact.  We  sometimes  forget  it).   Besides  that,  there  is  another  reason  why  all  those  achievements  must  be  classified  in  the  highest  ranks  of  human  successes.  For  also  after  their  admission  to  the  European  dinner-table'  they  were  not  served  the  same  dishes.  as  their  fellow-beings.  If  the  Jews  made  the  most  valuable  •  contribu  tions  to  the  welfare  of  the  civi  lised  society  it  was  not  certain  at  all  that  the  .  contributions  were  appreciated  as  they  infallibly  would  have  been  with  their  fellow  scientists  and  fellow-artists.  If  the  Jews  received  any.  rewards  of  their  endeavours  at  all  then  there  was  almost  always  connected  with  it  some  humiliatins.  Although  they  may  have  been  winners  of  the  Nobel-prize  or  they  may  have  gained  the  admiration  of  the  whole  civilised  world,'  as  for  in  stance  Einstein,  who  changed  the  human  outlook  on  eternity,  or  Freud  who  opened  new  perspec  tives  of  men’s  cognition,  they  were  not  regarded  as  digniifed  enough  to  become  ordinary  tea  chers  at  the  university.   But  in  spite  of  those  handicaps,  which  proved  only  that  anti-Jew  ish  feelings  never  had  practically  ceased  to  exist,  the  Jewish  fight  ers  for  the  development  of  man  kind  gave  the  best  of  their  hearts  for  the  benefit  of  the  human  so  ciety,  imbued  with  the  ardent  de  sire  to  further  the  progress  of  the  human  race.  And  it  Is  almost  in  credible  how  marvellously  they  succeeded  in  nearly  every  cultural  province.   At  first  thought  it  may  seem  not  worth  the  while  to  remember  what  the  Jews  have  achieved  in  Germany  and  for  Germany.  In  deed  the  wheels  of  history  will  not  be  turned  into  any  other  direction  by  the  statement  how  much  the  Jews  have  added  to  the  benefit  of  German  name  and  German  fame.  But  it  will  buttress  the  proud  and  the  certain  feeling  of  the  Jews  themselves  that  one  day  when  the  waves  of  hatred  will  have  been  .  calmed  down  Jewish  accomplishments  will  be  recognis  ed  again  and  that  the  world  will  give  the  Jews  that  place,  in  the  council  of  peoples  for  which  they   .  are  entitled  to  claim.   When  the  Jews  in  the  beginning  of  the  19th  century  were—ac  least  formally—admitted  as  equal  to  the  community  of  free  men  in  Germany,  it  was  as  if  a  bulwark  had  been  broken  down  and  the  water  dammed  up  behind  it  had  fallen  like  a  torrent  into  the  open  land.  So  powerful  was  the  mental  energy  that  became  free  and  ru  shed  down  into  every  district  of  spiritual  activity.  Impossible  to  count  down  every  Jew  who  has  added  stones  to  the  edifice  of  Ger  man  art  and  science.  We  can  give  only  a  few  names  out  of  thou  sands.  But  we  can  appraise  the  real  significance  of  that  powerful,  stream  of  spii’itual  fructification  only  if  we  consider  that  the  Jews  comprising  but  1  per  cent  of  the  German  population  at  once  took  part  in  the  building  up  of  the  cul  tural  life  by  contributors  out  numbering  10  or  even  20  times  their  actual  proportion  of  the  po  pulation.  An  example  may  make  it  clear  how  this  miraculous  fact  turned  out  to  be  of  almost  in  credible  .  effects:  The  Jews  for  in  stance  brought  forth  9  remarkable  composers  in  a  little  more  than  one  century;  the  Germans,  in  or  der  to  keep  pace  should  have  had  to  muster  900  (!)  equivalent  ta  lents  or  take  another  example:  About  25  per  cent  of  the  German  Nobel-prize  winners  were  Jews,  equal  to  five  .times  more  than  their  proportion.  And  so  it/-  was  in  nearly  every  district  of  cultural   life.   At  the  beginning  of  that  “Pe-  ,  riod  of  Enlightenment”,  stands  the  venerable  figure  of  the  poor  hunch  backed  office  clerk  and  great  philosopher  Moses  Mendelssohn,  the  friend  of  Lessing.  He  was  still  deep-rooted  in  Jewish  feelings  and  it  was  but  in  his  adult  years  that   he  learnt  to  write  German.  Pro  found  was  his  influence  on  Ger  man  philosophy.  (The  fate  of  his  children  is  significant;  it  shows  how  quickly  by  the  way  of  assi  milation  large  and  valuable  parts  of  Jewry  have  been  absorbed  by  the  German  people:  Two  of  his  sons,  baptized,  became  the  found  ers’  of  one  of  most  famous  Euro  pean  Banks.  His  daughter,  also  baptised,  was  renowned  for  her  literary  salon  and  played  an  im  portant  part  in  the  history  of  Ger  man  literature.  His  grandson  Felix  Mendelssohn-Bartholdy,  baptised,  was  one  of  the  greatest  German  composers.  And  many  of  his  des  cendents  are  reputed  as  artists  and  scientists).  Besides  Mendel  ssohn  there  were  many  more  Jew  ish  philosophers  as  for  instance  Salomon  Maimon,  Otto  Liebmann,  Herman  Cohen,  Gustav  ^  Simmel,  Gustav  Landauer  etc.  Although,  they  were  not  the  great  lonely  stars  they  influenced  largely  thoughts  and  ideas  in  Germany.   In  the  discipline  of  Physics,  Mathematics  and  Physics  near  to  the  province  of  Philosophy,  scores  of  Jews  excelled.  The  one  Einstein  would  suffice  to  procure  the  Jews  a  place  of  honour  in  the  history  of  Science.  Only  the  coming  cen  turies  can  judge  fully  his  import  ance.  But  he  seems  to  be  a  genius  the  like  of  whom  mankind  pro  duces  only  every  some  centuries  to  be  placed  in  line  with  men  like  Ptolemy,  Galileo,  Giordano  Bruno  and  Newton.  And  there  are  many  others  whose  names  can  keep  the  field  also  besides  Einstein.  Hertz  (theory  .  of  electric  waves),  J.  Frank  (theory  of  atoms),  David  sohn  (electro  motor),  Marcus  (petrol  motor),  Berliner  (micro  phone),  Haber  (nitrogen),  Frank  (Kali),  Caro  (dyes),  Willstaetter  (Chlorophyl),  Bayer,  the  son  of  a  Jewish  mother  and  the  founder  of  the'  mighty  German  Dye  concern  (indigo)  and  practically  thou  sands  of  famous  names  more.   Jews  have  always  been  prepon  derant  physicians  and  that  may  partly  explain  the  fact  that  there  was  nearly  no  inventive  medical  achievement  without  Jewish  guid   ance  or  at  least  Jewish  assistance.   It  is  almost  impossible  an  under  taking  to  enumerate  the  names  of  the  countless  medical  pioneers  and  only  a  few  ones  may  therefore  be  mentioned  who  acquired  wide  pub  lic  fame.  So  Meyerhof  (transfor   mation  of  energy),  Zunz  (physio  logy),  Ehrlich  (Salvarsan),  Was  sermann  and  Morgenroth  (both  diagnosis  of  syphilis,  Freud  (psychoanalysis),  Adler  (indivi  dual  psychology),  Minkowsky  (diabetes),  Boas  (stomach  di  seases),  Zondeck  (internal  di  seases),  Asehheim  (pregnancy  diagnosis)  etc.   ,  But  how  much  soever  all  these  contributions  have  added  to  the  famous  reputation  of  German  cul  ture  the  public  in  general  knew  and  appreciated  better  the  Jews,  who  worked  in  the  sphere  of  the  arts.   In  the  first  line  it  was  the  Jew  ish  musicians  who,  even  in  the   land  of  music  proper”  attracted   the  eyes  or  rather  the  ears  of  their  contemporaries.  There  •  are  the  composers  Mendelssohn,  Mey  ei’beer,  Offenbach,  Moscheles,  Ru  binstein,  Joachim,  Mahler,  Schoen  berg,  Korngold,  there  are  the  con  ducted  Walter,  Klemperer,  Klei  ber,  there  are  the  countless  prac  titioning  musicians'  of  world-wide  fame  like  Schnabel,  Horowitz,  Ser  kin,  Hubermann,  Kreisler,  Morini,  Tauber  and  scores  of  them  more.   In  the  art  of  painting  it  was  Liebermann,  Israels,  Lesser  Ury,  Chagall,  Feinger,  Marees  (a  half  Jew)  etc.  who  helped  to  develop  German  artistic  reputation.  That  seems  to  be  indeed  a  very  surpris  ing  fact.  For  since  the  Jews,  pre   (Continued  on  page  6)   GERMAN  JEWS  AND  GERMAN  CULTURE   (Continued  from  page  4)   vented  by  religious  prohibitions,  had  never  excelled  in  the  field  of  painting  it  was  all  the  more  mir  aculous  that  they  could  hold  their  own  without  any  existing  artistic   tradition.   Always  have  the  Jews  been  bear  ers  of  a  deep  inner  conscience  and  masters  of  the  word.  Since  the  days  of  the  Prophets  they  have  been  the  proclaimed  and  propa  gators  of  teachings,  doctrines  and  convictions.  That  may  be  the  ex  planation  of  the  immense  part  played  by  Jews  in  the  German  literature.  The  way  leading  from  Heinrich  Heine  to  Stephan  Zweig  is  short  in  time  but  overcrowded  by  writing,  composing,  teaching  and  admonishing  Jews:  Boeme  and  Weininger,  Wassermann  and  Werfel,  Kaffka  and  Heimann,  Schnitzler  and  Hofmannsthal,  Bu  ber  and  Mombert,  Toller  and  Weissi,  Brod  and  Arnold  Zweig,  Doeblin  and  Beer-Hoffmann  are  only  a  few  names  casually  picked  out  of  the  innumerable  spiritual  Jews  who  have  influenced  the  thoughts  and  feelings  of  the  Ger  man  people.   It  is  practically  impossible  even  if  the  limited  space  would  not  prohibit  it—to  mention  every  do   main  where  the  Jews  had  a  share  in  the  shaping  of  German  culture.  Industry  and  economicsi,  sociology  and  agriculture,  film  and  theatre  dance  and  architecture,  journal  istics  and  playwriting,  charity  and   art-donations  were  but  a  few  ones  of  the  vast  provinces  of  Jewish   collaboration.   How  is  it  possible  that  in  spite  of  all  this  cultural  work  done  by  Jews  the  terrible  outbursts  of  cruelty  against  the  German  Jews  could  happen  ?  Probably  because  the  people  did  not  know  how  great   the  share  of  the  Jews-  in  all  those  cultural  achievements  had  been.   For  however  magnificent  the  Jewish  accomplishments  were  they  did  not  reach  the  bulk  of  the  people.  The  ideas  of  the  Jewish  writers'  were  too  elaborate,  too  high-brow,  to  be  understood  by  the  masses.  They  became  the  spi  ritual  food  of  the  intelligentsia  with  the  exception  of  Heine  whose   poems  are  recited  and  sung  by  the  whole  of  Germany,  .  but  .  mostly  without  any  knowledge  who  wrote  those  deeply  touching  songs.  And  again  the  composers  although  some  of  thefn  being  pacemakers  of  new  musical  ways  did  not  pene  trate  into  the  people’s  hearts,  be  side  Mendelssohn  whose  songs  went  straight  to  the  people’s  feel  ings.  And  even  men  who  achieved  the  most  practical  successes  like  Haber  who  saved  Germany  from  losing  the  world  war  in  its  first  year,  or  Ehrlich  who  released  the  world  from  one  of  its  deadliest  plagues,  were  not  popular  because  the  simple-minded  maxi,  could  not  conceive  their  complicated  con  structive  work.   Shall  we  wonder  about  it?  No,  for  not  even  the  Jewish  ^masses  knew  it.  Even  now  after  the  last  years  of  Jewish  persecution  and  reawakening  of  Jewish  conscious  ness  a  French  Jew  with  whom  I  conversed  recently  had  no  idea  that  Bergson  and  Andre  Maurois   were  Jews  and  Anatole  France  half  of  Jewish  parentage.   Must  we  therefore  assume  that  all  the  cultural  work  done  by  Jews  has  been  in  vain?  Certainly  not.  Material  values  can  be  lost,  money,  houses,  diamonds  can  be  destroyed  but  spiritual  values  that  have  been  produced  remain..  Books  which  have  been  printed  can  be  burnt  but  their  contents  cannot  be  burned.  Heads  can  be  cut  off.but  thoughts  which  they  had  spoken  out,  the  songs  which  have  been  sung,  cannot  been  drowned,  smoth  ered,  hanged.  The  cultural  achive  ments  the  Jews  have  produced  in  Germany  will  be  remain  alive  and  there  will  be  again  a  time  of  peace  when  all  that  Einstein  and  Freud,  Mendelssohn  and  Heine  have  thought,  said,  written  and  sung,  will  again  be  heard,  read  and  sung,  and  when  again  will  be  thought  of  with  deep  and  kind  feelings  of  thankfulness  those  men  who  have  served  the  progress  of  man  with  the  best  of  their  lives.   But  something  more  will  come  out  again  of  the  marvellous  riches  of  Jewish  spirit.  Those  riches  which  have  survived  the  centuries   of  prosecution  will  remain  in  the  same  way  alive  in  spite  df  the  new  pains  that  have  come  down  over  Jewry.  The  men  who  have  pro  duced  all  those  miracles  of  their  spirits  have  had  to  go  again  on  their  new  travels  throughout  the  world.  They  had  to  leave  behind  them  their  fortunes,  their  money,  even  their  clothes.  But  they  have  taken  along  with  thentselves  their  unbroken  spirit.  That  spirit  wher  ever  the  Jews  will  be  driven  out   and  wherever  they  ‘  will  settle  afresh  will  fructify  again  mankind  for  the  benefit  of  the  human  race  and  to  the  honour  of  the  Jewish   name.

heading: Russo-German War GERMAN LOSSES
article_text: Russo-German  War   GERMAN  LOSSES   London,  May  20.—The  Moscow  "Izvestia"  states  that  the  Wehr-  macht,  in  the  first  three  years  of  the  Russo-German  war  lost  70,000  tanks  on  the  eastern  front  and  an  additional  10,000  before  the  end  of  the  war.  At  the  outbreak  of  the  war  the  Red  Army  had  fewer   tanks  than  the  Wehrmacht,  which  then  possessed  14,000,  but  the  Rus-  sian  tank  production  increased  eightfold.  The  Red  Air  Force  during  the  first  three  years  of  war  destroyed  60,000  Luftwaffe  planes.  Russian  fighters  during  the  whole  of  the  war  carried  out  3,000,000  battle  flights.  The  speed  of  the  Russian  fighters  increased  150  per  cent.  dur-  ing  the  war.

In  the  discipline  of  Physics,  Mathematics  and  Physics  near  to  the  province  of  Philosophy,  scores  of  Jews  excelled.  The  one  Einstein  would  suffice  to  procure  the  Jews  a  place  of  honour  in  the  history  of  Science.  Only  the  coming  cen  turies  can  judge  fully  his  import  ance. And  there  are  many  others  whose  names  can  keep  the  field  also  besides  Einstein.  Hertz  (theory  of  electric  waves),  J.  Frank  (theory  of  atoms),  David  sohn  (electro  motor),  Marcus  (petrol  motor),  Berliner  (micro  phone),  Haber  (nitrogen),'  Frank  (Kali),  Caro  (dyes),  Willstaetter  (Chlorophyl),  Bayer,  the  son  of  a  Jewish  mother  and  the  founder  of  the  mighty  German  Dye  concern  (indigo)  and  practically  thou   sands  of  famous  names  more.   Jews  have  always  been  prepon  derant  physicians  and  that  may  partly  explain  the  fact  that  there  was  nearly  no  inventive  medical  achievement  without  Jewish  guid  ance  or  at  least  Jewish  assistance.  It  is  almost  impossible  an  under  taking  to  enumerate  the  names  of  the  countless  medical  pioneers  and  only  a  few  ones  may  therefore  be  mentioned  who  acquired  wide  pub  lic  fame.  So  Meyerhof  (transfor  mation  of  energy),  Zunz  (physio  logy),  Ehrlich  (Salvarsan),  Was  sermann  and  Morgenroth  (both  diagnosis  of  syphilis,  Freud  (psychoanalysis),  Adler  (indivi  dual  psychology),  Minkowsky  (diabetes),  Boas  (stomach  di  seases)  ,  Zondeck  (internal  di  seases),  Aschheim  (pregnancy  diagnosis)  etc.   But  how  much  soever.  all  these  contributions  have  added  to  the  famous  reputation  of  German  cul  ture  the  public  in  general  knew  and  appreciated  better  the  Jews,  who  worked  in  the  sphere  of  the  arts.   In  the  first  line  it  was  the  Jew  ish  musicians  who,  even  in  the  land  of  music  proper,  attracted  the  eyes  or  rather  the  ears  of  their  contemporaries.  There  are  the  composers  Mendelssohn,  Mey  erbeer,  dffenbach,  Moscheles,  Ru   binstein,  Joachim,  Mahler,  Schoen  berg,  Korngold,  there  are  the  con  ducted  Walter,  Klemperer,  Klei  ber,  there  are  the  countless  prac  titioning  musicians  of  world-wide  fame  like  Schnabel,  Horowitz,  Ser  kin,  Hubermarin,  Kreisler,  Morini,  Tauber  arid  scores  of  theni  more.   In  the-  art  of  painting  it  ’  was  Lieberinarin,  Israels,  Lesser  Ury,  Chagall;  Feinger,,  Marees  (a  ,half  Jew)  etc.  who  helped  to  develop  German  artistic  reputation.  That  seems  to  be  indeed  a  very  surpris  ing  fact.  For-since  the  Jewa,  -pre  vented  by  religious  prohibitions,  had  riever  excelled  iri  the  field  ;of  painting  it  was  all  the  mrir^.ihir.,  acuious  that  they  .could  hold  their  own  without  ’any  existing1  artistic  tradition.  **  /■V   v  (Continued  6n  page  ‘t   GERMAN  JEWS  AND  GERMAN  CULTURE   (Continued  from  Front  page)   Always  have  the  Jews  been  bear  ers  of  a  deep  inner  conscience  and  masters  of  the  word.  Since  the  days  of  the  Prophets  they  have  been  the  proclaimed  and  propa  gators  of  teachings,  doctrines  and  convictions.  That  may  be  the  ex  planation  of  the  immense  part  played  by  Jews  in  the  German  literature.  The  way  leading  from  Heinrich  Heine  to  Stephan  Zweig  is  short  in  time  but  overcrowded  by  writing,  composing,  teaching  and  admonishing  Jews:  Boerne  and  Weininger,  Wassermann  and  Werfel,  Kaffka  and  Heimann,  Schnitzler  and  Hofmannsthal,  Bu  ber  and  Mombert,  Toller  and  Weiss,  Brod  and  Arnold  Zweig,  Doeblin  and  Beer-Hoffmann  are   only  a  few  names  casually  picked  out  of  the  innumerable  spiritual  Jews  who  have  influenced  the   thoughts  and  feelings  of  the  Ger  man  people.   It  is  practically  impossible  even  if  the  limited  space  would  not  prohibit  it—to  mention  every  do  main  where  the  Jews  had  a  share  in  the  shaping  of  German  culture.  Industry  and  economics:,  sociology  and  agriculture,  film  and  theatre  dance  and  architecture,  journal  istics  and  playwriting,  charity  and  art-donations  were  but  a  few  ones   of  the  vast  provinces  of  Jewish   collaboration.   How  is  it  possible  that  in  spite  of  all  this  cultural  work  done  by  Jews  the  terrible  outbursts  of  cruelty  against  the  German  Jews  could  happen  ?  Probably  because  the  people  did  not  know  how  great  the  share  of  the  Jews  in  all  those  cultural  achievements  had  been.   For  however  magnificent  the  Jewish  accomplishments  were  they  did  not  reach  the  bulk  of  the  people.  The  ideas  of  the  Jewish  writers'  were  too  elaborate,  too  high-brow,  to  be  understood  by  the  masses.  They  became  the  spi  ritual  food  of  the  intelligentsia,  with  the  exception  of  Heine  whose  poems  are  recited,  and  sung  by  the  whole  of  Germany,  but  mostly  without  any  knowledge  who  wrote  those  deeply  touching  songs.  And  again  the  composers  although  some  of  them  being  pacemakers  of  new  musical  ways  did  not  pene  trate  into  the  people’s  hearts,  be   side  Mendelssohn  whose  songs  went  straight  to  the  people’s  feel  ings.  And  even  men  who  achieved  the  most  practical  successes  like  Haber  who  saved  Germany  from   losing  the  world  war  in  its  first  I  year,  or  Ehrlich  who  released  the  world  from  one  of  its  deadliest  plagues,  were  not  popular  because  the  simple-minded  man  could  not  conceive  their  complicated  con   structive  work.   Shall  we  wonder  about  it?  No,  for  not  even  the  Jewish  masses  knew  it.  Even  now  after  the  last  years  of  Jewish  persecution  and  reawakening  of  Jewish  conscious  ness  a  French  Jew  with  whom  I  conversed  recently  had  no  idea  that  Bergson  and  Andre  Maurois  were  Jews  and  Anatole  France  half  of  Jewish  parentage.   Must  we  therefore  assume  that  all  the  cultural  work  done  by  Jews  has  been  in  vain?  Certainly  not.  Material  values  can  be  lost,  money,  houses,  diamonds  can  .be  destroyed  but  spiritual  values  that  have  been  produced  remain.  Books  which  have  been  printed  can  be  burnt  but  their  contents  cannot  be   |  burned.  Heads  can  be  cut  off  but   thoughts  which  they  had  spoken  out,  the  songs  which  have  been  sung,  cannot  been  drowned,  smoth  ered,  hanged.  The  cultural  achive  ments  the  Jews  have  produced  in.  Germany  will  be  remain  alive  and  there  will  be  again  a  time  of  peace  when  all  that  Einstein  and  Freud,  Mendelssohn  and  Heine  have  thought,  said,  written  and  sung,  will  again  be  heard,  read  and  sung,  and  when  again  will  be  thought  of  with  deep  and  kind  feelings  of  thankfulness  those  men  who  have  served  the  progress  of  man  with  the  best  of  their  lives.   But  something  more  will  come  out  again  of  the  marvellous  riches  of  Jewish  spirit.  Those  riches  which  have  survived  the  centuries  of  prosecution  will  remain  in  the  same  way  alive  in  spite  of  the  new  pains  that  have  come  down  over  Jewry.  The  men  who  have  pro  duced  all  those  miracles  of  their  spirits  have  had  to  go  again  on  their  new  travels  throughout  the  world.  They  had  to  leave  behind  them  their  fortunes,  their  money,  even  their  clothes.  But  they  have  taken  along  with  themselves  their  unbroken  spirit.  That  spirit  wher  ever  the  Jews  will  be  driven  out  and  wherever  they  will  settle  afresh  will  fructify  again  m  inkind  for  the  benefit  of  the  human  race  and  to  the  honour  of  the  Jewish   name.

heading: GERMAN FEARS.

A  traveller  from  Berlin,  who  ar  rived  recently  in  Sweden,  says  that  ?75  per  cent,  of  diplomats  and  high  er  Nazi  officials  in  Berlin  fear  a  Gorman  collapse  within  two  months. heading: TEACHING GERMAN
article_text: TEACHING  GERMAN   Sir,-I  have  read  that  educationists  do  not  support  Professor  Osborne's  state,  ment  "that  the  study  of  French  li)  schools  was  waste  of  time,  and  that  German    should  be  taught  instead,  because  it  was  much  more  easily  appreciated  and  consequently  its  literature  was  available  to  a  greater  number."  It  is  good  to  find  that  there  is  a  leaning  away  from  Germany    in  the  realm  of  education,  in  spite  of  the  professor's  contention.  We  appreciate  good  Germans  and  fine  lateral  ture,  but  the  beastliness  in  Europe  makes  even  the  name  of  German  something  to   be  pitied  and  condemned Yours,  &c.   ONLOOKER. heading: GERMAN BARBARISM
article_text: GERMAN  BARBARISM   With  tumors  of  peace  feelers  by  the  Germans  being  widely  circulated  in  both  hemispheres,  and  questions  arising  concerning  the  political  future  of  Germany,  It  is  timely  that  official  revela  tions  should  have  been  made  of  the  Blmost  unbelievable  barbarity  that  has  been  openly  practised  by  the  Germans  In  countries  which  their  armies  have  overrun.  Such  disclosures  will  also  serve  to  counter  any  misplaced  pity  that  may  be  felt  at  the  increasingly  heavy  bombing  of  Berlin,  nerve-centre  and  core  of  the  whole  vile  creation  of  Naddom.   The  Polish  authorities  have  already  unearthed  evidence  J'  abundance  of  the  wholesale  slaughter  of  civilians  in  that  desolate  country.  Stories  of  trainloads  of  men,  women  and  children  setting  out  for  'murder  centres,'  there  to  be  deliberately  and  ruthlessly  machine-gunned  or  forced  into  lethal  chambers  and  gassed,  have  been  told  repeatedly  by  escapees  and  others.  Such  stories  are  too  persistent  and  factual  to  be  doubted.  They  be  token  an  attitude  towards  human  life  and  suffering  that  Is  alto  gether  foreign  to  British  civilisation—  a  foul  philosophy  of  sadism  which  appears  to  permeate  the  whole  German  nation.  Now  the  special  Russian  committee  which  is  Investigating  Nail  atrocities  in  the  Donets  Basin  has  brought  to  Ugbt  a  series  of  atrocities  equally  as  appalling,  and  entirely  In  keeping  wltn  the  German  practice  in  occupied  countries.  The  bodies  of  thou  sands  of  civilians  have  been  dug  up  from  coal  pits  and  quarries,  where  they  were  buried  by  the  Germans,  while  no  fewer  than  25,000  Russians  were  found  buried  near  the  Stalino  prisoner  of  war  camp.  Horrible  stories  of  torture  have  also  been  told,  and  the  Bnsslan  committee  has  ascertained  the  names  of  90  military  officers  and  Gestapo  officials  who  win  be  held  responsible  for  these  crUnes,  Equally  appalling  are  the  revelations  that  have  just  been  made  by  the  Inter-AIIied  Information  Committee  concerning  the  German  treatment  of  women  in  occupied  countries.  Women  nave  been  reduced  to  the  level  of  slaves.  The  Gestapo  never  hesitates  to  use  its  -expert  tortures  in  an  effort  to  make  women  lncriminate  their  menfolk,  states  the  report.  Trilling  offences  are  made  an   excuse  for  Imprisonment  and  deportation,  ana  sms  ««  abducted—a  systematic  policy  of  the  German  authorities.  Not  only  has  the  German  nation  for  the  second  Ume  this  century  plunged  the  world  Into  a  terrible  war,  eosting  millions  ;  of  lives  all  told,  but  It  is  waging  the  ore  sent  fa^11?lthAt^^ar  Yt  ™  that  outclasses  even  that,  of  the  celebrated  Hun,  AttiU.  It  dlffl-olt  not  to  sympathise  with  views  being  expressed  by  repre  sentatives  of  occupied  nations  at  their  discussions  in  tonaon  tbat  Germany's  position  as  a  major  economio  power  should  be  destroyed  for  all  time.  Whatever  Is  done  In  this  direction,  how  ever,  there  must  be  no  flagging  In  the  re-olve  of  the  Cnited  Nations  to  bring  to  book  all  Germany's  war  criminals,  against  whom  evl  denoe  ha,  £en  piling  up,  and  try  them  at  the  scene  of  'heir  crimes,

heading: GERMAN LEAFLETS
article_text: GERMAN  LEAFLETS   Leaflets,  signed  by.  General  von  Folkenliorst,  the  German  General  commanding  in  Norway,  and  dropped  on  Norwegian  villages  near  the  Swedish  frontier,  announce:  "The  German  troops  intend  to  defend  Norway  against  the  Western  Powers.  The  Norwegian  Government  has  refused  to  co  operate.  Therefore  the  Norwegian  people  must  decide  their  own  fate."  And  in  order  to  assist  the  Norwegian  people  in  coming  to  a  decision  adds  the  sinister  warning:—  "Every  resistance  will  be  met  with  the  most  ruthless  measures.  War  tribunals  will  be.set  up,  and  anyone  found  with  arms  will  be  immediately  shot,  Nothing  will  happen  to  those  who  are  quiet."

article_text: GERMAN  MORALE   One  of  the  most  encouraging  developments  of  recent  weeks  has  been  tne  increasing  reference  to  the  decline  in  (iern.au  morale. It  comes  from  such  authoritative  a  source  as  Dr.  Josef  Goebells  himself. Though  the  Russian  victories  have  frustrated  a  German  victory,  they  have  not  yet  insured  a  German  defeat.  In  fact,  the  German  retreat,  which  started   much  earlier  than  Napoleon's,  has  ap  parently  saved  .their  armies  intact.  They  still  seem  prepared  to  put  up  a  strong  defence  at  their  chosen  line.  They  have  been  working  on  their  "East  Wall"  for  years.  Their  occupa  tion  of  Bulgaria,  coupled.  with  increas  ing  terror,  not  only  in  the  conquered  lands,  but  also  at  home,  is  further  evi  dence  of  their  -  determination  to  con  tinue  to  fight.  In  that  light,  the  re  treat  in  Russia  is,  indeed,  part  of  the  new  German  strategy,  which  the  Ger  mans  now  admit  has  been  dictated,  in  part  at  least,  by  the  collapse  of  Italy,  and  which  compels  them  to  mass  forces  against  the  Allies  in  the.  west.  —   N.Y.  "Times."

heading: GERMAN GOVERNMENT
article_text: GERMAN  GOVERNMENT  With  the  formation  of  Dr.  Adenauer's  right-wing  coali  tion  Government,  the  West  Gernman  Federal  Republic  has  now  been  launched  and  the  Occupation  Statute,  which  de  fines  the  rights  of  the  western  Allied  Powers  pending  the  con  clusion  of  a  peace  treaty,  has  simultaneously  come  into  force.  The  new  republic,  founded  on  the  democratic  parliamentary  principles  of  the  Bonn  Consti  tution,  is  not  yet  a  fully  sove  reign  State,  for  it  is  subject  to  discretionary  Allied  control.  Nor  is  the  structure  of  the  Re  public  complete,  for  it  has  not  been  possible  to  include  the  Russian  zone.  But,  within  those  limits,  a  self-governing  Ger?jp  State  has  been  brought  into  being  by  the  Western  Powers.  It  is  a  fateful  experiment.  The  willingness  and  capacity  of  the  German  people  to  make  a  re  presentative  parliamentary  sys  tem  work,  which  has  already  failed  once  in  the  destruction  of  the  Weimar  Republic  by  Hitler's  Nazism,  is  again  being  put  to  the  test  in  a  very  difficult  post  war  stage.  The  outcome,  politically  and  economically,  will  have  a  profound  influence  on  the  future  of  Europe  and  the  task  of  Dr.  Adenauer  as  the  first  Chancellor,  is  one  of  the  gravest  responsibility.  The  return  of  germany  to  a  proper  place  in  the  European  and  world  community  has  been  facilitated  by  the  Western  Powers.  But  there  will  be  need  for  sound  evidence  of  German  attachment  to  peaceable  demo  cratic  practice  and  of  a  genu  inely  cooperative  spirit  to  justify  the  next  step,  which  would  presumably  be  admis  sion  to  the  Council  of  Europe.  The  greatest  danger,  as  always  in  German  politics,  must  come  from  the  lack  of  any  ingrained  parliamentary  tradition  and  the  struggle  of  extremists  on  the  right  and  the  left  to  overthrow  the  moderate  democrats  and  seize  authoritarian  power.  A  stabilising  factor,  however,  is  that  the  two  major  parties-the  Christian  Democrats  in  office  and  the  Social  Democrats  in  opposition-stand  firmly  for  constitutional  and  democratic  principles.  The  Christian  Democrats,  although  the  larg  est  party  in  the  Federal  Lower  House,  have  only  139  seats  out  of  402.  Under  Dr.  Aden  auer's  leadership  they  de  clined  to  seek  a  Government  with  the  Social  Democrats  (131  seats)  because  of  deep  divisions  on  economic  policy.  Dr.  Aden  auer  therefore  looked  to  the  smaller  parties  on  his  right  and  he  has  formed  a  coalition  with  the  conservative  .  Free  Democrats  and  the  strongly  nationalist  German  Party.  It  is  a  coalition,  however,  which  has  an  extremely  narrow  ma  jority.  Dr.  Adenauer's  pro  blem,  in  which  the  Western  Powers  have  an  acute  and  ap  prehensive  interest,  will  be  to  resist  dictation  from  the  right  and  to  hold  in  check  the  re  vival  of  nationalism  which  was  so  strongly  marked  in  the  elec  tion.

article_text: GERMAN  ELECTION   LONDON,  September  16.-In  the  German  local  elections  Hamburg  Independents  topped  the  poll  in  the  British  stone  with  947,751  votes  followed  by  Social  Democrats  470,  962,  Christian  Democrats  378,134,  Centre"  Party  41,061,  Free  Demo-   crats  40,366,  and  Communists  16,018.   Social  Democrats  are  leading  in  the  American  zone  and  Christian  Democrats  in  the  French.zone,  in  each  of  which  Communists  polled   the  least  votes.   The  following  were  the  final  re-  sults  in  the  Russian  zone:  Social-  ist  Unity  820,600  Christian  Demo-  crats  359,038,  Democrats  238,387.
snippet: LONDON, September 16.—In the German local elections Hamburg Independents topped the poll in the British stone with 947,751 votes

snippet: The High Altar of St. Paul Cathedral laid low by a German bomb. heading: GERMAN REPARATIONS
article_text: GERMAN  REPARATIONS   LONDON,  Sunday.-Many  questions  arc  being  asked  in  Loudon  as  to  the  precise  -meaning  of  the  reparation  proposals,  says   tho  "Times"  diplomatic  correspondent.  Allied  experts  in  assessing  tho  amount  of  equipment  to  bo  removed  have  to  decide  ,  ?what  is  German  peace  economy  and  what   is  thc  average  European  standard.   It  seems  that  German  economy  and  in-  dustrial  production  will  bo  reduced  below  thc  1927-29  level.  When  tho  intensive  in-  dustrial  development  during  Hitler's  four  year  plan  is  recalled,  and  the  no  less  in-  tensive  drive  during  thc  war,  it  is  seen  that  a  considerable  part  of  thc  existing  equipment  will  be  removed.   Tho  Soviet  authorities  arc  anxious  to  rebuild  from  thc  eastern  zone.   Gorman  industry  will  not  be  completely   shipped,  and  the  German«  will  be  left  with  enough  lo  work  their  way  forward  in  peace.
snippet: LONDON, Sunday.—Many questions are being asked in London as to the precise meaning of the reparation proposals, says the "Times" diplomatic correspondent.

article_text: German  Report   London,  .June  5.—  A  Berlin  communi  que,  states:—  'British  counter-attacks  in  North  Africa  have  been  repulsed.  'We  captured  an  order  of  the  4th  British  Tank  Brigade  stating  that  prisoners  .  must  not  be  allowed  food,  water  or  sleep,  or  receive  facilities  or  concessions  of  any  kind,  unless  they  have  been  interrogated  by  the  appro  priate  authorities.  The  German  High  Command  therefore  orders  that  from   noon  to-morrow  British  troops  taken  prisoner  in  the  course  of  the  present  battle  are  not  to  receive  food  or  drink  until  this  despicable  and  inhuman  order  is  revoked,  and  the  revocation  brought  officially  to  the  notice  of  the  German  High  Command. heading: GERMAN REPORT
article_text: GERMAN  REPORT   London,  June  2.  —  The  Berlin.  radio  says  that  the  mopping-up  operations  are  continuing  in  Crete  according  to  plan.  Remnants  of  the  British  units,   under  the  pressure  of  Italian  and  German  troops,  are  trying  to  leave  the  island  by  any  available  means.  'German  troops,  operating  on  the  south  coast,  are  witnessing  drama  tic  scenes  as  British,  Australian  and  New  Zealand  troops,  in  their  wild  flight,  are  trying  to  get  away  in  small  schooners,  fishing  boats  and  rowing  boats.  Only  a  small  number  could  be  taken  on  board  the  British  warships,  which  were  forced  to  leave  the  waters  around  the  island,  be  cause  of  the  incessant  bombing  at  tacks.  Numerous  fishing  boats,  car  rying  British  soldiers,  had  to  return  to  Crete  and  gave  themselves'  up,'-'

heading: GERMAN TACTICS
article_text: GERMAN  TACTICS   London,  Sept.  12—  The  'Daily  Herald'  correspondent  in  Moscow  describes  the  street  fighting  tactics  the  Germans  had  to  employ  to  take  Novorossisk.  'The  Germans  advanced  in  small  rushes  with  the  nervous,  crouching  gait  of  men  seeking  imaginary  safety  under  fire,'  he  says.  'The  Germans  did  not   leave  a  aoorway  oenma  witnout;  toss  ing  in  a  volley  of  grenades  or  search  ing  stairs  and  rooms  with  a  prelude  of  tommy-gun  fire.  Occasionally  despite  this  caution,  a  German  figure  would  crumple  with  a  bullet  in  the  back  from  a  Red  army  soldier  concealed  in  a  house  which  the  Germans  had  passed.'

heading: German Reports
article_text: German  Reports   London,  July  29.—  A.  Berlin  com  munique  states:  'The  Germans  on  several  parts  of  the  Orel  salient  throughout  yesterday  were  en  gaged  in  heavy  defensive  battles.  They  repelled  all  Russian  attempts  to  break  through  and  inflicted  con  siderable  losses.  The  Russians  in  one  sector  north  of  Orel  alone  lost   100  tanks  and  303  planes.  There  were  only  local  Russian  attacks  on  the  remaining  sectors  of  the  front,  which  were  repelled  in  hard  fightr  ing.  A  total  of  186  Russian  tanks  were  destroyed.'  London,  July  30.—  A  Berlin  com  munique  states:  'In  the  Orel  area  we  again  repulsed  fierce  infantry  and  tank  attacks.  The  Russian  offensive  south  of  Lake  Ladoga  has  further  slackened.  Local  Russian  attacks,  strongly  supported  by  tanks  and  fighters,  were  repelled  with  losses  for  the  enemy.  Our  naval  forces  again  shelled  enemy  positions  on  the  Mius  front.'

heading: GERMAN CLAIMS
article_text: .  GERMAN  CLAIMS   London,  Oct.  4.—  The  Berlin  radio  states  that  German  landing  forces,  which  attacked  Kos,  had  captured  all  military  installations  by  yesterday.   The  German  newsagency  to  night  claimed  that  German  forces  attacking  from  landing  craft  had  captured  all  important  military  in  stallations  on  the  island  of  Kos.  It  added:  'Over  200  British  troops  have  been  captured  and  a  number  of  others  killed.  Part  of  the  British  forces  fled  to  the  mountains.  Re  sistance  was  encountered  at  only  a  few  points.'  .  ~

heading: GERMAN MIGRATION GERMAN MIGRATION
article_text: GERMAN  MIGRATION   OPPOSED  BY  E.C.A.J.  CONFERENCE   GERMAN  MIGRATION   In  his  address  about  German   migration  to  Australia,  Mr.  £in   feld  stated  that  the  Committee   of  Management  has  continued  its  representations  to  the  Gov  ernment  in  opposition  to  the   continuous  intake  of  Germans  as  favoured  migrants  to  Aus  tralia.  It  is  regretted  that  the  Government  seems  determined  to  continue.  with  this  policy,  and  it  is  distressing  to  learn  that  2638  Germans  have  been  admitted  to  Australia  in  the  first  quarter  of  1954.   I  have  learnt  that  the  Gov  ernment  expect  approximately  9000  Germans  .  who  are  to  be  skilled  artisans  to  come  to  Aus   tralia  during  the  next  twelve   months.   In  regard  to  German  migra   tion  we  had  been  told  that  no  more  than  3,000-4,000  Germans  would  be  admitted—but  accord   ing  to  the  report  the  position  has  changed,  as  the  Government  will  bring'  9,000  Germans  to  this  country.  What  are  the  plans  of  the  Committee  of  Management?  Are  you  going  to  acquiesce  or  should  we  do  something  about  this  new  situa  tion.'We  want  an  objective  as   sessment  of  the  situation  and   guidance  for  our  policy.   The  delegate  from  S.A.,  Mr.  Hines,  expressed  the  desire  that  the  immigration  of  some  unsuit   able  elements  of  other  nationali   ties  (Poles,  Lithuanians,  etc.)   should  also  be  included  in  the  orbit  of  our  attention.   Mr.  H.  B.  Newman  (N.S.W.)   defended  the  policy  pursued  by  the  Committee  of  Manage  ment  in  this  delicate  political   issue.   Mr.  Wolfensohn  referred  to   the  fact  that  inquiries  were  made  on  the  point  raised  by  Mr.  Hines,  but  no  answer  has  come  from  the  competent  authority.   An  interesting  debate  de  veloped  on  the  discrimination  inflicted  on  a  company  which  wanted  to  deal  with  $audi  Arabia  and  invoked  the   E.C.A.J.  intervention  with  the   Australian  and  British  Govern   ment  against  such  discrimina  tion.  The  prevailing  opinion  was  that  an  approach  to  the   Crown  should  be  made  only  it|.  a  matter  of  vital  policy.   Answering  Mr.  Ben  Green,   Mr.  Einfeld  stated  that  the  Committee  of  Management  was  not  idle,  but  has  repeatedly   intervened  with  the  Govern*   ment  from  September,  1953,  on  this  issue  and  it  has  finally  been  settled  by  the  combined  efforts  of  N.S.W.  and  Victoria.'   As  to  the  dissatisfaction  re,   German  migration,  Mr.  Einfeld  said  with  emphasis:  “I  d<?n’t  know  of  any  new  method  how  to  fight  German  migration!  If  you  will  show  me  such'  new  method,  we  shall  apply  it  in  our  effort  to  stem;  the,  influx  of   Germans.”  '  i  .'i':

heading: GERMAN MIGRATION
article_text: GERMAN  MIGRATION  A  chronic  difficulty  in  Aus  tralia's  immigration  and  de  velopment  programme  has  been  to  obtain  a  sufficient  pro  portion  of  skilled  agricultural  workers.  This  is  an  import  ant  factor  to  be  reckoned  with  in  the  urgent  and  complex  problem  of  revitalising  food  production.  Even  if  Britain  were  not  herself  engaged  in  a  vigorous  drive  for  more  out  put  from  the  land,  the  com  petition  from  other  overseas  countries  is  such  that  Austra  lia  would  still  have  to  turn  to  Europe  for  agricultural  mi  grants.  There,  too,  post-war  rehabilitation  has  reduced  the  small  proportion  which  farm  workers  represent  in  the  pool  of  potential  migrants.  But  there  is  a  surplus  of  landless  farming  people  in  West  Germany  for  special  rea  sons  emphasised  by  the  mem  bers  of  the  West  German  Federal  Migration  Board  now  visiting  Western  Australia  on  an  exploratory  mission.  The  Commonwealth  Govern  ment's  move  towards  accept  ance  of  a  quota  of  selec  ted  Germans  under  a  negotia  ted  migration  agreement  like  that  with  Italy-gives  Australia  a  chance  to  recruit  agricultural  workers.  For  West  Germany  it  offers  some  relief  in  the  problem  of  pro  viding  for  an  influx  of  nearly  10,000,000  people  who  are  either  victims  of  Communist  expulsion  from  the  Russian  dominated  territories  or  fugi  tives  from  Communist  terror.  Nothing  but  prejudice  need  stand  in  the  way  of  working  out  an  arrangement  for  mutual  advantage.  If  we  have  to  go  outside  Britain  for  population  we  naturally  look  first  along  the  Western  European  seaboard  for  assimilable  racial  stock  most  akin  to  our  own.  In  the  aftermath  of  the  war  there  have  been  great  changes  in  Germany  and  also  in  the  Western  attitude  to  the  Ger  man  people  and  their  future  in  the  free  world.  An  at  tempt  is  being  made  to  build  up  a  friendly  and  peaceful  cooperation  and,  at  the  same  time,  circumstances  have  pro  duced  a  new  period  of  Ger  man  readiness  to  migrate.  In  South  Australia,  particularly,  there  is  experience  of  how  an  earlier  generation  of  German  settlers  showed  a  capacity  to  identify  themselves  with  the  life  and  institutions  of  their  adopted  country.  Any  German  migration  now  could  amount  to  only  a  micro  scopic  percentage  of  the  Australian  population  and,  should  any  political  or  other  undesirables  slip  through  the  screen,  they  could  always  be  sent  back  on  proof  of  subversion  or  misconduct.  There  would  be  no  need  for  costly  land  settlement  ven  tures.  Concentration  on  Ger  man  farmers  or  farm-workers  willing  to  take  agricultural  jobs-perhaps  under  some  limited  contract-would  im  pose  a  minimum  strain  on  housing.  Employed  on  farms  they  could  gain  experience  of  Australian  conditions  and  work  towards  small  farms  of  their  own.
snippet: A chronic difficulty in Australia's immigration and development programme has been to obtain a sufficient

heading: GERMAN PROBLEMS
article_text: GERMAN  PROBLEMS   Despite  the  grant  of  wide  self-governing  powers  and  economic  aid  to  Western  Ger  many,  it  is  doubtless  too  much   to  expect  that  relations  be  tween  this  and  other  Euro  jpean  States  should  be  con  sistently  harmonious.  British  policy  and  British  actions  have  I  often  been  unjustly  criticised  by  the  Adenauer  Government.  Upon  Britain  has  fallen  the  brunt  of  the  attack  relating  to  the  Allied  policy  of  disman  tling  certain  German  indus  tries.  Most  of  the  industrial  plants  marked  for  demolition  were  in  the  British-controlled  zone;  and,  as  fresh  cases  of  violence  this  week  have  I  shown,  German  workers  threatened  .  with  unemploy  iment  are  inclined  to  ascribe  I  their  troubles  to  those  near  at  hand.  |j  In  the  matter  of  disman  tling,  however.  Western  Ger  Ijmany  has  not  been  treated  liwith  undue  severity  by  the  II  Allies.  In  the  past  year,  de   molitions  of  major  plants  have!  seen  curtailed.  Some  observers.!  indeed,  feel  misgivings  overj  :he  decision  to  raise  the  an  nual  ceiling  for  German  steelj  production  to  eleven  million  |  :ons.  Such  unemployment!  roubles  as  face  the  Adenauer  Government,  are  due  chiefly  :o  the  waves  of  refugees  trom  :he  cast.  Latest  official  figures  show  that  there  are  now  8,500,000  registered  (and  many  unregistered)  refugees'  in  Western  Germany,  com  pared  with  1,558,469  unem-j  ployed.  Density  of  popula-l  tion  in  the  State  having  been  increased  by  30  per  cent.,  in-i  iustry  simply  cannot  absorb!  the  labor  available.  I  Even  so,  conditions  in  Western  Germany  have  enor  mously  improved  through  the  help  of  Marshall  Aid;  and  it  is  hardly  surprising  that,  apart  from  dismantling,  there  is  now  'little  sign  of  popular  disaffection,'  but  rather  a,  feeling  that  life  is  'returning!  to  normal.'  This  internal  pro  gress  seems  to  have  raised  hopes  that  the  country  can  achieve  greater  equality  with  her  neighbors,  and  perhaps  strengthen  herself  against  threats  from  the  east.  Dr.  Adenauer,  with  his  long  ex  perience  as  administrator  of  Cologne,  has  actively  en  couraged  the  idea  of  closer  German  collaboration  with  the  French.  In  view  of  the  re  cent  clash  over  the  Saar  coal  mines,  and  the  difficulties  met  in  drafting  a  trade  agreement,  however,  it  seems  scarcely  timely  for  Dr.  Adenauer  to  propose  a  Franco-German  union.

heading: German Peace
article_text: German  Peace   The  war  with  Germany  is  expected  to  be  formally  ended  this  week  by  Britain,  France,  and  the  United  States.   The  Diplomatic  Correspon  dents  of  several  London  Sun  day  newspapers  say  an  Order  m  Council  will  be  promulgated  m  London  tomorrow,  and  simi  lar  action  will  be  initiated  in  Washington  and  Paris.
snippet: The war with Germany is expected to be formally ended this week by Britain, France, and the United States.

Later  the  Land  Commissioner  Rgreed  to  receive  a  five-man  dele  gation.  Allied  sources  in  Berlin  said  Communists  had  been  Instructed  to  provoke  clashes  wherever  pos  sible  between  West  Germans  and  the  occupation  authorities. heading: GERMAN COURSE
article_text: Evidence  of  the  growing  influence  of  the  German  community  in  South  Aus  tralia  was  provided  by  the  announcement  this  week  that  a  new  German  course  is  to  be  introduced  at  Adelaide  University.   This  step  is  being  taken  “because  of  the  large  number  of  people  want  ing  to  learn  German  there.”   As  indicated  in  our  columns  from  time  to  time,  there  has  been  a  concentration  of  German  migrants  in  and  around  Adelaide. heading: GERMAN OPINION.
article_text: GERMAN  OPINION.   BERLIN.  'Mar.  4  (A.AJ3.).  West  Berlin's  Mayor  (Herr  Ernest  Reuter),  once  a  col-  laborator  of  Stalin,  said  to-day  that  the  Russian  leader's  death  would  provide  the  Western  world  with  a  big  chance  for  Dew  diplomatic  moves  toward  the  Soviet  Union.  Herr  Reuter,  Who  abandoned  Communism  in  1921.  said  of  Stalin:  "I  never  liked  bim."   Herr  Reuter  said  that  the  end  of  Stalin,  "which  we  can  presumably  expect  in  a  few  days  or  at  the  outside  a  few  weeks,"  will  signal  the  begin-  ning  of  a  big  change.  It  will  also  provide  a  big  chance  for  the  Western  world  to  use.  "I  mean  this  in  the  sense  of  pro-  viding  a  new  political  climate  favouring  the  West  in  which  a  new  diplomatic  offensive,  or  some  new  approach  to  solving  the  global  problems  of  Korea,  Germany,  Austria  and  the  Far  East  could  be  launched,"  he  said.   Herr  Reuter  joined  the  Rus-  sian  revolutionaries  after  his  release  from  a  World  War  One   prison  camp  in  Russia.  In  1918  and  1919,  as  Soviet  Commissar  for  the  German  Volga  Repub-  lic,  he  was  in  close  touch  with  Stalin.
