heading: GERMAN “PROPOSALS.”
article_text: GERMAN  “PROPOSALS.”   rgnHE  West  German  Chancellor  has  JiL.  been  vocal  again,  not  without  some  effect.  The  world’s  press  has  given,  over  much  space  to  comment  on  Dr.  Adenauer’s  plea  that  Ger  many  should  be  strengthened  again  to  serve  as  a  buffer  between  the  West  and  Russia.  Somewhat  less  space  to  these  important  matters  has  been  given  in  the  Australian  news  papers  where  pre-occupation  with  other  issues  has  crowded  the  German  news  out.  The  impudence  of  German  “statesmen,”  boundless  as  always,  permitted  Adenauer  to  insinuate  into  his  plea  the  suggestion  that  a  re  established  Germany  could  “avert  an  otherwise  inevitable  explosion.”  It  is  good  to  see  that  for  the  most  part  Adenauer’s  proposals  have  been  re  jected  with  contumely.  The  Christian  Science  Monitor  said  that  to  rearm  Germany  would  simply  place  in  Ger  man  hands  the  balance  of  power  in  Europe,  an  arrangement  which  might  suit  diabolical  German  plans  very  well,  but  which  would  effectively  destroy  any  prospect  of  world  peace.  The  warnings  against  these  German  manoeuvres  must  be  sounded  from  one  end  of  the  world  to  the  other.  Germany  still  remains  the  greatest  menace  to  world  peace,  said  Lord  Wavell,  whose  lamented  death  oc  curred  only  a  fortnight  ago.  We  should  do  well  not  to  forget  this  great  soldier’s  warning.   *  *  *
snippet: THE West German Chancellor has been vocal again, not without some effect. The world’s press has given, over much space to comment

heading: German Elections
article_text: German  Elections   Tire  points  of  view  any  of  us  may  hold  will  tend  to  colour  our  appreciation  of  the  significance   of  the  results  of  the  recent  German  elections.   The  resounding  defeat  of  both  Communist  and  Neo-Nazi  forces  in  open  election  may  mean  noth  ing  more  than  a  distrust  of  extremism  at  this  stage  of  national  resurgence.   .  It  may  also  mean  a  more  deepseated  opposition  to  dictatorship  and  all  its  works  born  of  the  ex  perience  of  past  decades.   There  is  almost  endless  room  for  speculation  about  it.  But  one  thing  is  clear,  it  will  not  mean  the  «nd  of  Neo-Nazi  activities,  but  may  mean  in  stead  a  stepping  up  in  force  of  the  political  ma  chinations  of  the,  new/Hitlerite  brigade.   .  .  .Whatever  is  underground  will  continue  the  whiteanting  process,  whatever  is  aboveground  will  continue  propaganda  in  an  endeavour  to  win  ad  herents  and  through  them  power.   What  emerges,  then*  is  the  warning  against  complacency  or  taking  the  results  of  last  Sunday’s  election  to  mean  that  democrats  can  sit  back  in  ease  because  Nazism  is  a  spent  force.  There  never  has  been  a  time  when  vigilance  could  be  relaxed  with  safety,  and  this  applies  here  as  much  as  else-i  where,  because  of  the  large  number  of  Nazi-in  doctrinated  people  who  have  come  to  these  shores.   •Vigilance  must  be  maintained  at  high  pitch  against-  any  form  of  dictatorship  encroachment,  because  whatever  may  be  the  political  slogan  used,  dictatorship  itself  is  the  scourge  of  the  peoples  of  the  world,  the  slogans  serving  but  to  camouflage  the  fact  that  unscrupulous  men  gain  power  over  other  men,  and  are  determined  to  keep  that  power,  even  using  murder,  and  assassination  to  do  so.

heading: GERMAN MIGRANTS
article_text: GERMAN  MIGRANTS  A  large  party  of  German  migrants  has  arrived  in  West  ern  Australia  and  its  members  are  bound  to  be  wondering  what  kind  of  reception  they  will  be  given  in  this  large  and  remote  part  of  the  Bri  tish  Commonwealth.  And  although  West  Australians  have  become  accustomed  to  European  migration,  doubt  less  many  of  them  will  be  a  little  curious  about  these  new  Australians  whose  homeland  has  altered  the  course  of  world  history  and  may  do  so  again.  There  need  be  no  misunder  standings.  Australia  is  not  exactly  an  earthly  paradise  but  the  Germans  who  have  come  to  our  shores  are  fortunate  people  and  we,  in  turn,  should  be  glad  to-have  them.  We  can  afford  to  forget  past  animosi  ties  and  Hitler's  misdeeds  but,  if  we  cannot  completely  .erase  them,  we  should  take  a  broad  view  of  history  and  recollect  that  Wellington  prayed  for  Blucher's  arrival  at  Waterloo.  Australia,  after  all,  is  not  so  remote  from  the  world's  great  populations  and  if  it  is  to  accept  the  challenge  of  the  new  Asia  it  will  have  need  for  the  German  qualities  of  indus  try,  fortitude  and  discipline.  In  our  factories,  mines  and  laboratories  and  on  our  farms  there  is  also  a  place  for  Ger  man  intelligence  and  in  genuity.  South  Australia  has  good,  reason  to  be  thankful  to  its  early  German  settlers  and  it  should  be  our  hope  that,  in  years  to  come,  we  shall  be  able  to  look  upon  a  comparable  German  contribution  to  the  vr..n?ress  of  Western  Aus  tralia.
snippet: A large party of German migrants has arrived in Western Australia and its members are bound to be wondering

heading: EAST GERMAN
article_text: EAST  GERMAN   HATRED  OF  REDS.   Berlin,  Wednesday:  Russian  tanks  patroled  East  Berlin  tonight,  restoring  order  after  the  two-day  riots,  which  cost  four  lives  and  left  60  people  injured.   Unrest  has  spread  to  other  East  German  cities  -^Magdeburg,  Halie,  Erfurt,  and  Leipzig-where  discontent  pt  the  actions  of  the  Communist  Govern-  ment  is  growing.   Soviet  tanks  tonight  had  sealed  all  the  main  ap-  proaches  to  East  Berlin  from  .the  West.   Five  tanks,  their  guns  pointin»  toward  West  Ber-  lin,  took  up  positions  in  Un-  ter  Den  Linden,  to  reinforce  lorry  loads  of  steel-helmeted  machine-gunners.  *   Two  anti-tank  guns  were  also  deployed  in  Unter  Den  Linden,  facing  the  British  sector  through  the  Bran-  denburg  gate.   Battalions  of  East.  Ger-  many's  barracked  police  force,  which  is  trained  and  equipped  like  an  army,  guarded  the  entrances  to  East  'Berlin  and  barred  everyone  without  an  East  Berlin  I  identity  card.   Two  of  the  four  dead  in  the  riots  were  run  over  .  by  Soviet  tanks.   A  21-years-old  man,  shot  in  front  of  an  East  German  Government  building  died  in  the  West  Berlin  Hospital.  The  fourth  man.  killed  was  a   West*  Berliner,  who  was  shot   in  the  head.   Earlier  some  40,000  angry  East  Berlin  workers  .hurling  stones,  smashing  windows,  starting  fires  and  yelling  dé  nuhciatfons  bf  the  East  Ger-  man  Communist  Leaders  marched  through  the  streets.  They  demonstrated  in  front  of  the  Government  buildings  and  party  headquarters  and  outside  the  prisons,  calling  for  the  release  of  political  prisoners.   All  German  Affair   It  had  become  an  all-Ger-  man  affair  throughout  yes-  terday,  when  the  strikers  ,  forced  the  East  German   ¡Government  to  withdraw  an  .  iprder-  to  do  more  work  for   Çkie  same  pay.  After  this  Victory  the  temper  and  size  .of  the  demonstration  grew.   It  was  directed  against  the  East  German  Govern-  ment  and,  on  the  advice  -of  ¿he  workers*  leaders,  avoided  any  attack  on  the  Soviet  jragime.   Soviet  soldiers  at  first  stood  by,  but  the  East  Ger-  man  police  were  powerless.  (Twenty  police  were  tramp-  led  down,  in  Unter  Den  Linden.   Then  thc  Russians  has-  tily  dug  in  round  the  Go-  vernment  quarter  and  or-  dered  tanks  and  armored  cars  into  action.   The  serious,  bloody  events  have,  again  made  Berlin  a  flashpoint.   Revelations  of  the  serious  .unrest  may  influence  Rus-  sia's  :  pl?.  #  ;  about  the  unifi  ,,  cation  of  Germany.   The  Soviet  authorities  tiave  put  1,800,000  people  under  martial*  law,  imposing  «  curfew  from  9  p¿m.  until  6  a.m.  Public  assemblies  ol'  more  than  three  people  have  been  banned.   Changes  are   Likely   London,  Wednesday:  It  is  felt  political  .  changes  ni  East  Germany  are  ceiTtiin   following  the  rioting.  The   Vital  fact  emerges  that  Rus-  sia  can  no  longer  be  certain  that  the  East  German  Com-  munist  ¡Party  can  keep  East  Germany  subservient  to  the:   Kremlin's  will-still  less  that  it  could  dominate  an  all-German  Government.   The  East  Berlin  riots  came  shortly  after  a  series  of  riot-  ing  in  Czechoslovakia:  also  on  the  basis  of  the  workers'  economic  condition.   Political  observers  in  West  Germany  believe  that  the  riots  will  almost  certainly  lead  to  an  end  of  the  East  German  Government  as  at  present  constituted.1-^   The  West  German  Chan-  cellor  (Dr  Adenauer)  told  the  Bundestag  in  Bonn  to-  day  that  his  Government  "feels  with  the  women  and  men  of  East  Berlin,  who  have  expressed  their  desiro  for  liberation  from  oppres-  sion."  ^   He  said  events  in  East.  Berlin  found  a  strong  echo  in  West  Germany  and  thc  entire  world.   Tlae  Chancellor  reiterated  requests  recent!"  made  bv  the  Bundestag  for  free  elec-  tions  in  all  Germany,  for-  mation  of  a  free  all-German  Government,  a  freely  nego-  tiated  peace  treaty  with  a  united  Germany,  the  settle-  ment  of  all  "remaining  fron-  tier  problems,  and  freedom  of  action  for  an  all-German  Government.  "  !

heading: German Migrants
article_text: German  Migrants   Sir,-In  reply  to  Mr.  W.  S.  Kent  Hughes,  M.P.  ("Herald,"  Feb.  23),  I  wish  to  state  clearly  my  views  on  the  question  of  Ger   man  migration.   I  have  never  condemned,  nor  would  any  other  sane  person  con-  demn,  a  whole  race  on  account  of  the  excesses  of  a  few.  As  my  brother  surely  knows,  12  million  (some  put  the  figure  as  high  as  20  million)  in-  nocent  people  cannot,  even  with  Nazi  efficiency,  be  massacred  by  a  few;  even  so,  it  has  never  been  a  question  of  condemning  the  whole   German  race.   1  and  others  who  are  opposing  this  plan  to  bring  100,000  young  Ger-  mans  to  this  country  in  the  next  four  years,  do  so  because  they  will  be  the  ones  who  received  their  whole  education  under  Hitler-the  disastrous  effects  of  which  I  saw  as  early  as  1936  and  1937-and  so  would  be  a  threat  to  our  Australian  democracy.   I  wonder  what  Mr.  W.  S.  Kent   Hughes's  reaction  wouldj  be  if  the  proposal  was  to  bring  100,000  young  Japanese  to  this  country?   When  a  new  generation  has  arisen  in  Germany,  free  from  Hitlerism,  then  it  will  be  time  enough  to  re-  open  the  question  of  German  migra-  tion.  To  date,  there  has  been  no  effective  de-nazification  in  Western  I  Germany.   (Miss)  M.  KENT  HUGHES.  Rose  Bay.

heading: German cake
article_text: German  cake   One  lb.  flour,  ¼  lb.  sugar,  ¼  lb.  butter,  3  eggs,  cup  milk,  ¼  teasp.  cinna-  mon,  ½  teasp.  salt,  lemon  essence,  cup  yeast,  little   mace,  currants  and  sul-  tanas.  Mix  flour,  sugar,  cinnamon,  salt  and  mace  together,  then  add  melted  butter  and  milk,  slightly  warmed  and  well  beaten  eggs.  Add  currants  and  sultanas  well  washed  and  dried,  and  lastly,  the  yeast.  Knead  well  and  put  away  to  rise.  Roll  out  about  ½  inch  thick  on  a  greased  baking  sheet  and  let  rise  again.  Brush  over  with  melted  butter  and  put  top  on  it,  prepared  as  follows:  Half  lb.  flour,  ¼  lb.  sugar,  ½  teasp.  cinnamon,  ¼  lb.  1  butter,  little  mace.  Crumble  all  with  the  hand  and  sprinkle  thickly  on  cake.  Bake  15  to  20  minutes  in  good  oven.

heading: German Migration
article_text: German  Migration   Percipient  members  of  the  Australian  Jewish  community  were  not  surprised  by  the  statements  in  the  press  that  the  Minister  for  Migration  (Mr.  Holt)  had  signed  an  agreement  with  the  West  German  Government  for  the  mass  migration  of  ten  thousand  Germans  a  year.   The  sign  has  been  in  the  sky  for  a  long  time,  despite  protestations  to  the  contrary,  and  statements  suggesting  that  Australian  necessity  made  the  practical  implementation  of  a  paper  scheme  impossible  of  realisation.   Now  the  sign  is  growing  larger  than  the  warning  hand.  The  ABC  news  session  on  Wednesday]  morning  reported  Mr.  Holt  as  stating  that  he  examined  the  screening  system  in  Germany  and  he  was  very  happy  with  it,  it  was  function  ing  perfectly.  He  had  seen  the  files  on  Nazis  and  their  completeness  astonished  him.   Mr.  Holt  did  not  state  whether  the  screening  of  migrants  was  based  on  the  weeding  out  of  Nazis*  or  other  people.  It  is  one  thing  to  have  the  files,  another  to  use  them  against  Nazis.   However,  he  went  on  to  say,  or  is  reported  as  having  done  so,  that  the  Dutch  would  make  the  more  desirable  migrants.   Why,  then,  is  he  allocating  first  place  to  Germans?  The  filing  system  he  praised  so  highly  would  surely  list  only  the  outstanding  workers  for  Nazism*  the  gauleiters  and  the  smaller  fry  who  bossed  the  towns  and  villages.   This  filing  system  surely  did  not  list  all  those  Noting  people  who  had  been  taken  by  the  Nazis  and  moulded  to  Nazi  doctrine  during  their  most  impressionable  years...  people  who  are  now  of  the  eligible  age  group  to  come  here.   Nor  would  any  screening  system,  however  efficient,  be  able  to  cope  thoroughly  with  so  many  applications  that  would  involve  the  acceptance  of  ten  thousand  a  year,  and  at  least  a  token  rejection  of  a  few  besides.   What  will  the  Executive  Council  of  Australian  Jewry  do  now,  to  acquaint  the  general  community  with  the  dangers  involved,  and  the  need  for  constant  vigilance  if  the  demo  cratic  institutions  We  have  evolved  out  of  much  tribulation  are  to  be  transmitted  to  our  successor  generations?

heading: German apology
article_text: German  apology   BONN,  Thursday.  —  The  W  est  German  Government  has  apologised  to  the  French  High  Commissioner  for  a  re-   cent  "war  vindication"  speech  by  J  ustice  Minister  Thomas  Dehler.  In  another  peace  gesture,  Chancellor  Adenauer  ap  pealed,  to  German  party  lead  ers  for  calm  and  patience  on  the  Saar  question.  The  French  protested  that  Dehler's  speech  was  "shock  ing"  and  "amounted  to  a  justification  of  Adolf  Hitler's  policy  at  the  expense  of  France."  Dehler  had  said  it  was  un  true  that  Germany  was  guilty  of  starting  all  aggression  in  the  last  200  years.  '  v  He  said  that  Hitler  was  to  a  great  extent  the  result  of  the  Versailles  Treaty  and  the  pusillanimity  of  France.  —   AAP.

heading: German Rearmament
article_text: German  Rearmament   The  whole  question  of  rearmament  after  1945  seems  to  be  overshadowed  by  the  chan  ges  contained  within  the  heart  of   warfare.  •   Captain  Liddell  Hart,  a  world  authority  on  military  strategy  and  tactics,  in  a  recent  article  drew  attention  to  the  futile  pre-occu  pation  with  manoeuvres  and  armies  that  con  tinues  as  though  nuclear  fission  had  never  been  harnessed  to  the  destructive  spirit.   He  emphasised  the  stupidity  of  organis  ing  Commands  and  headquarters  when  a  hydrogen  bomb  dropped  within  a  few  miles  of  the  target  and  not  necessarily  at  the  bull’s  -eye  will  lay  waste  yast  areas  through  the  explosion  and  the  resultant  fall-out  of  radio   active  material  from  the  skies.   In  the  light'  of  this,  it  may  seem  just  as  stupid  to  protest  against  German  rearmament  as  belonging  to  something  of  another  era.   We  differ  from  this  view.  With  all  sides  possessing  stock-piles  of  atom  bombs,  no  one  will  dare  to  use  them,  just  as  no  one  dared  to  use  poison  gas  or  bacterial  bombs  during  the  1939-45  war.   But  the  influence  of  the  psychological  type  now  cartooned  as  the  Prussian  officer  is  a  menace.  This  influence  is  not  confined  to  study  of  out-of-date  military  tactics.  For  decades  it  has  been  imbued  with  lust  for  power,  and  in  recent  times  it  has  thrown  in  its  lot  with  Nazism.  Hitler  may  be  dead  but  his  spirit  goes  marching  on.   Jews  must  protest  against  what  this  means  for  humanity!  The  ’rearmament  of  the   —rTufcstttt^'tqnm"*ter,~  one  rrattgnt  •   with  grkve  danger  for  European  civilisation.   It  ie  significant  that  the  youth  represen  tatives  atlthe  Victorian  Board  of  Deputies  were  the  most  vehement  in  denouncing  it  at  last  Monday’s  meeting.

heading: German Ships
article_text: German  Ships   GERMAN  ships  are  ex  pected  to  resume  regular  services  to  Singapore,  Djakarta,  Hong  kong  and  Japan  this  month.  The  services  were  stopped  at  the  beginning..  of  the  Second  World  War,  14  years  ago.  News  ships  of  the  Nord  hure-Amerika  Lines  will   initiate  the  services,  which  will  be  three-weekly,  ana  conducted  by  four  ships  of  each  company.  The  services  will  be  pri  marily  for  the  carriage  of  cargo,  but  limited  passenger  accommodation  will  be  pro  vided.  This  accommodation  will  be  increased  next  year. heading: GERMAN OPERA
article_text: GERMAN  OPERA   Australian  baritone,  Ronald  Jackson  (winner  of  the  first  "Mobil  Quest"  in  1919),  has  signed  a  12  months  contract  with  the  Kiel  Opera  House,  Germany.   Under  the  contract,  which   takes  effect  on  August  1,  he  will  sing  all  leading  baritone  roles  as  lyric  and  character  baritone.   It  is  believed  that  Jackson  has  prospects  of  a  similar  con-  tract  with  another  German  Opera  House  when  the  Kiel  contract  expires.

Three  Western  High  Commissioners  of  Germany  to-day  in  a  letter   to  Vladimir  semeonov,  Soviet  High  Commissioner,  have  asked  the  Soviet  Union  to  agree  to  a  joint  abolition  by  the  four  occu  pation  Powers  of  all  inter  zonal  passes  for  Germans  travelling  between  East  arid  West  Germany. heading: GERMAN TREND
article_text: GERMAN  TREND  Dr.  Adenauer's  con  duct  of  the  foreign  policy  of  the  West  Ger  man  Federal  Republic  has  been  supported  be  yond  expectations  by  the  results  of  the  elec  tions  in  Bavaria  and  Hesse.  These  were  elec  tions  to  the  respective  State  Parliaments  and  affect  the  Federal  Par  liament  only  indirectly  in  the  sense  that  the  Bundesrat  (the  Federal  Upper  House)  is  made  up  of  State  nominees.  The  notable  gains  made  in  the  two  States  by  parties  supporting  the  Federal  coalition  Gov  ernment  have'  demon  strated  a  strong  public  trend  towards  ratifica  tion  of  the  London  and  Paris  agreements  for  the  rearming  of  a  sov  ereign  West  Germany.  The  outlook  for  accept  ance  of  a  Sarr  ar  rangement  with  France  is  also  more  promising.  Should  it  be  held  that  ratification  of  these  vitally-important  inter  national  agreements  re  quires  a  constitutional  amendment,  the  Aden  auer  Government's  pros  pects  of  obtaining  a  two  thirds  majority  in  both  Federal  Houses  have  been  strengthened.
snippet: Dr. Adenauer's conduct of the foreign policy of the West German Federal Republic

heading: GERMAN ARMY
article_text: GERMAN  ARMY   HANOVER,  Monday  (A.  A.P.).  —  The  first  100-man  unit  of  West  Germany's  new  Territorial  Army  was  formed   in  Hanover  yesterday.   The  force  is  planned  to   reach  50,000  by  1966.  Its  members  will  do  less  than  30  days'  training  a  year  and  will  not  be  under  NATO  con-  trol.

heading: GERMAN "ERROR"
article_text: GERMAN  "ERROR"   Bonn,  Monday  (JTA):  A  three  hundred  million  dollar  “error”  in  West  German  resti  tution  payments  to  Nazi  vic  tims  has  been  discovered,  in  dicating  that  Jewish  pension  ers  have  suffered  serious  losses.   The  irregularities  were  dis  covered  by  a  young  half  Jew  ish  German  Government  em  ployee  "who  very  carefully  checked  calculations  which  prove  (as  some  parliamentar  ians  now  agree)  that  income  tax.  has  been  deducted,  despite  exemption  of  .  restitution  pay  ments.  Also  increments  were  unpaid,  and  in  many  cases,  payments  were  illegally  round  ed  off,  downwards.   The  discoverer  took  his  case  to  the  Finance  Ministry  who  denied  the  irregularity,  but  disciplinary  action  was  re  portedly  instituted  against  the   discoverer.  ■   Indirect  confirmation  is  seen  in  the  new  Government  decree  to  raise  pensions  'by  twelve,  to  fifty  per  cent',  retroactive  to  September  1,  19G5.

heading: German measles
article_text: German  measles   Sir,  -  I  am  writing  a?  a  member  of  a  group  of  parents  of  deaf  children,  a  proportion  of   whom  are  deaf  as  a  result  of  maternal  rubella  (or  german  measles).   We  feel  that  attention  should  be  drawn  to  the  fact  that  there  appears  to  be  an  epidemic  of  german  measles  in  Canberra  at  the  present  time,  and  we  Would  like  to  give  publicity  to'  the   harmful  effects  of  this  disease.   If  contracted  by  a  woman  in  the  first  few  months  of  her  preg  nancy,  there  is  a  definite'  risk  that  her  child  will  be  born  han   dicapped  in  one  or  more  ways.  These  include  deafness,  blind  ness,  mental  retardation  ,  and  heart  lesions,  or  a  combination  of  some  or  all  of  these.   If  a  pregnant  woman  in,  the  early  stages  comes  into  contact  with  someone  suffering  from  this  otherwise  mild  complaint,  she  can  be  given  some  protection  by  her  doctor  against  actually  developing  the  disease  herself.  The  earlier  in  pregnancy  that  the  disease  actually  develops,  the  more  serious  may  be  the  con  sequences  to  the  unborn  child.  So  we  suggest  that  all  women  who  do  contract  german  measles  and  who  may  be  pregnant   should  consult  their  doctor  im  mediately.   We  would  also  suggest  that  parents  of  children  with  german  measles  take  care  to  keep  their  children,  while  they  know  that  they  are  infected,  away.  from  public  places,  shops,  buses,..etc,  where  chance  meetings  with  pregnant  women  arc  possible.   We  have  a  hearty  respect  for  the  rubella  virus  and  the  effects  it  has  had  on  children,  and  we  hope  that  the  numbers  of  Child  ren  handicapped  by  it  will'  not  be  unnecessarily  increased'  by  ignorance  or  apathy  towards-  it.   (Mrs)  ELEANOR  EVAN..  Watson.   Loiters  to  tice  Editor  ..iiould  be  signed  and  carry  the  full  ad  dress  of  the  writer.  A  Post  Office  box  is  not  sufficient  address.  In  exceptional  circumstances  a  -pen  name  may  be  accepted  for  pub  lication.  Correspondents  ,,.ar«   asked  to  keep  letters  as  shorj  »   possible.

heading: German drama
article_text: German  drama   GA,S  chambers,  gau   leiters,  guilt  and  conscience  provide  a   theme  for  the  German  language  contemporary  play  Die  Flucht,  to  be  presented  by  Kam  merspiele  Sydney  at  Canberra  Playhouse  this  Saturday,  Novem  ber  26,  at  8.15pm.   Written  by  Ernst  Wald  brunn  and  Lida  Winiewicz,  the  play  examines  the  dil  emma  of  an  Austrian  haunted  by  the  guilt  of  a  decision  made  just  after  the  fall  of  the  Third  Reich.   In  the  tradition  of  Arthur  Miller's  After  the  Fall,  this  drama  makes  use  of  flashbacks  to  examine  the  past,  and  attempts  to  show  that  we  all  are  guilty  and  victims  at  the  same  time.   A  half-Jewish  actor  (played  by  Jaro  Klugcr)  acccpts  wartime  protection  from  the  Gauleiter  (Hans  Farkash);  at  the  end  of  the  war  the  actor  protects  the  Nazi,  whose  hands  are  soiled  with  the  blood  of  thousands.  The  question  is:  what  would  you  have   done?   Directed  by  Professor  Gerhard  Felser,  the  Kam  merspiele  drama  group  is  actively  associated  with  the  Independent  Theatre  of  Sydney.
snippet: GAS chambers, gauleiters, guilt and conscience provide a theme for the German

heading: GERMAN SHADOWS
article_text: GERMAN  SHADOWS   The  purge  and  counter-purge  in  the  Ger^  man  extreme  nationalist  N.D.P.  follow  logic-!  ally  from  developments  in  Germany.  The  party,  never  was  a  unified  group,  it  was  de  fined  by  what  its  members  were  against.  no  less  than  by  what  they  were  for.   The  N.D.P.  made  particular  headway  dur  ing  the  uncertainties  which  '  arose  out  of  the  crisis  inside  the  coalition  and  ruling  party,  and  from  what  many  considered  excessive  com  pliance  towards  the  United  States.   The  new  coalition  government,  which  ;  gives  every  appearance  of  governing,  and  has   adopted  a  firm  foreign  policy,  is  believed  by  many  observers  to  have  won  back  much  of  the  public  confidence  its  predecessor  had  lost.   As  a  result  the  N.D.P.  itself  faces  a  .  dilemma.   Should  it  try.  to  win  support  by  adopting  an  even  more  extreme  stance,  and  thereby  risk  alienating  potential  support  and  even  provoking  a  ban?  *   Or  should  it  try  to  modify  its  extreme  appearance  in  order  to  attract  more  support  from  conservatives,  from  small  farmers  who  are  suffering  from  a  decline  in  protectionism,  and.  from  the  small  shokkeeper  and  business  man  who  may  be  doing  badly  or  feel  that  he  is  over-taxed?   This,  issue  has  split  the  N.D.P.  with  the  moderates  suffering  a  defeat.  If  the  result  is  to  produce  a  smaller  and  even  more  violently  extreme  group,  all  concerned  will  need  to  re  appraise  their  attitude.  Will  the  new  party  be   more  dangerous  or  le^p  so?   Will  the  weight  of  considerations  for  or  I  against  banning  be  altered?  Where  will  the   minority  and  its  supporters  go?  These  ques  tions  should  be  answered  by  the.  events  of  1  the  next  few  weeks.   In  the  meantime  there  can  be  no.  doubt  that  responsible  circles  in  Germany  are  watching  developments  closely  and  are  aware  that  the  outside  world  is  watching  them,  too.

heading: German Civilisation
article_text: German   Civilisation   ]%flOST  people  were,  I   think  appalled  bv  a  news  item  in  the  daily  papers  last  week,  in  which  it  was  reported  that  a  group  of  German  students  in  tended  to  underline  their  protests  against  war  by  burning  a  dog  alive.  This,  they  explained,  was  to  chrystalise  the  idea  of  suf  fering  and  transfer  it,  from  the  dog,  to  human,  beings.   This  sickening  idea  is  a  true  flowering  of  the  Ger  man  soul,  of  the  kind  that  gave  us  the  death  camps  and  medical  experiments.  This  is  what  makes  German  cruelty  different  to  the  cruelty  of  other  peoples;  they  need  to  have  some  pseudo-scientific  or  psycho  logical  rationale  for  their  beastilness.  Which  is  not  to  suggest  that  all  Germans  are  eager  to  rush  around  burning  dogs.  Nevertheless,  it  is  an  ugly  symptom  of  something  which  v.  e  hoped  had  died  out  before  the  post-war  generation  had  grown  up.   It  was  suggested  to  me  that  these  “idealists”  might  do  better  to  burn  one  of  their  own  number—a  volun  teer  of  course—instead  of  some  poor,  helpless  and  wholly  innocent  dog.
snippet: MOST people were, I think appalled by a news item in the daily papers last week, in which

heading: JEWISH GERMAN
article_text: JEWISH  GERMAN   miring  the  Middle  Ages  Jews  in  Germany  spoke  the  langu  age  of  the  place  and  period.  When  they  migrated  to  Poland  and  eastwards  they  took  their  language  with  them,  and  added  to  it.  It  was  known  as  Judisch  Deutch  or  Jewish  German,  and  later  as  Yiddish.   I  nave  many  times  m  my  life  wished  l  could  speak  Yiddish.  I  understand  very  little,  but  have  had  to  pretend  at  times  that  I  understand  a  lot.  On  the  other  hand,  1  know  people  who  understand  quite  a  lot  and  pretend  they  under  stand  only  a  little.   In  this  roundabout  way  I  am  gradually  getting  to  the  point  I  wanted  to  make.  My  objection  to  speeches  in  Yid  dish  is  based  on  no  grounds  other  than  simple  utilitarian  ism.  If  I  take  the  trouble,  along  with  other  non-Yiddish  speaking  Jews  (and  even  Gentiles)  of  going  along  to  a  meeting,  the  least  the  speakers  can  do  is  direct  their  re  marks  to  the  greatest  number.   Yiddish  is  a  dying  language.  Yiddishists  will  not  like  me  for  saying  this,  but  really  it  is  not  my  fault..Even  Sholem  Aseh's  son  cannot  read  his  father’s  writings  in  the  original  Yiddish.   If  speakers  insist  on  addressing  audiences  in  Yiddish  it  is  virtually  an  admittance  that  they  address  themselves  to  a  generation  on  the  way  out.  If  their  English  is  not  good  enough  then  they  should,  for  a  formal  speech,  arrange  for  translations  to  be  circulated  for  the  benefit  of  those  of  us  who  really  want  to  know  what  they  are  saying.   The  risk  is  that  some  of  the  best  speeches  do  not  look  too  good  in  print.
snippet: During the Middle Ages Jews in Germany spoke the language of the place and period. When they migrated to Poland and eastwards they took their language with them, and added to it. It was known as Judisch Deutch or Jewish

heading: GERMAN MEASLES
article_text: GERMAN  MEASLES   (Contributed  by  the  N.S.W.  .  Dept.  of  Public  Health)   Popular  names  for  in  fectious  diseases  are  sometimes  misleading.  'German  Measles'  for  In  stance,  may  be  confused  with  ordinary  measles.  While  both  diseases  at  tack  children,  rubella  —  the   medical  term  for  'German  Measles'  —  can  inflict  last  ing  damage  on  babies  be  fore  they  are  born,  if  it  at  tacks  the  expectant  mother.  Although  ordinary  meas  les  appeared  in  England  as  far  back  as  1517,  rubella  was  often  mistaken  for  measles  or  scarlet  fever  un  til  1881.  Normally  a  mild  |  disease,  rubella  is  a  serious  menace  to  the  expectant  j  mother.   The  danger  to  her  is  greatest  during  the  first  four  months  of  pregnancy.  Besides  affecting  the  bear  ing  of  the  developing  child,  rubella  can  damage  the  baby's  sight,  too.  Facing  such  serious:  consequences,  each  expectant  mother  should  take  special  precau  tions  against  the  disease.  If  a  member  of  the  house  hold  develops  rubella,  the  expectant  mother  should  place  her  unborn  child's  safety  above  all  other  con  siderations.  She  must  avoid  direct  and  indirect  contacts  with  the  patient.  Infection  is  spread  by  droplet  spray  —  coughing  and  sneezing  —  as  well  as  by  freshly-soiled  towels,  handkerchiefs,  cups  and  other  articles.  Unlike  or  dinary  measles,  rubella  is  most  cominon  among  adults.  Let  a  doctor  see  the  patient;  he  can  decide  whe-  '  ther  the  trouble  is  ordinary!  measles  or  rubella.  It  is  important  to  remem  4.1  ?  J-  ?  ?  _  i.1  ?  i_  '  -   wci  viuxv  an  aiftacK  01  or  dinary  measles  gives  no  pro  tection  against  rubella.  If,  despite  her  care,  a  preg  nant  woman  develops  ru-l  bella,  she  should  go  to  bed  and  obey  her  doctor's  in  structions.  Her  baby's  safe  ty  demands  that  such  pre  cautions  be  taken.  If  a  child  is  suffering  from  German  measles,  he  should'  be  excluded  from  school  attendance  for  three  weeks  from  the  onset  of   illness,  or  until  a  doctor  certifies  him  to  be  free  from  liability  to  convey  in  fection  —  the  minimum  period  of  exclusion  is  8  days.  Contacts  need  not  be  ex  cluded  from  school.  j  Further  information  about  Rubella  is  contained  in  a  pamphlet  available  from  the  Publicity  Officer,  Health  Department,  52  Bridge  St.,  Sydney.

heading: GERMAN TREES
article_text: GERMAN  TREES   DUESSELDORFF,  (JTA):  A  fund-raising  campaign  for  180,000  trees  to  be  planted  in  Israel  as  symbols  for  German  Jewish  vicitims  of  the  Hitler  regime  was  launched  here  yesterday.   The  campaign,  under  ,  the  auspices  of  the  Jewish.  Na  tional  Fund,-called  for  rais  ing  2,500,000  deutschmarks.   The  trees,  symbols  for  the  180,000  German  Jews  killed  in  concentration  camps,  will  be  planted  near  the  road  from  Jerusalem  to  the  arm  istice  line.  '   Dr.  L.  H.  Famborough,  honorary  president  of  fee   Jewish  National  ;  Fund  in  Germany,  speaking  at  the  Duesseldorf  .House  -  of  the  Sciences,  described  the  pro  gramme  as  a  sign  of  forgive  ness  as  a  symbol  for  the  determination  of  the  Jewish   people  never  again  to  play  the  role  of  martyr.   Dr.  M.  Taver,  Counsellor  of  the  Embassy  for  the  Is  raeli  Mission  in  Cologne,  said  the  programme  represented  Israel’s  determination  not  to  be  .  pressured  by  the  Arab  States.  He  described  the  forest  as  the  last  martyr  forest  in  Israel.   ’  Present  at  the  meeting   were  the  /North  Rhine-West  phalian  State  Rabbi.  Dr.  L.  Saloinonowicz,  Dr;  Heinrich  Grueber,  Provost  of  the  Evan  gelical  Church  in  Berlin,  and  leading  Municipal,  State  and  Federal  officials.
snippet: DUESSELDORFF, (JTA): A fund-raising campaign for 180,000 trees to be planted in Israel as symbols for German Jewish vicitims of the Hitler regime was launched here yesterday.

article_text: X  •  GERMAN  ENSEMBLE   ei  me  uerman  drama  ensem   e  ble  Die  Bruecke  will  make  a  -  short  tour  of  Australia  be   tween  August  13  and  Septem  ber  1. Schedule  for  the  Australian  tour:  Adelaide,  Union  Theatre,  I  August  13,.  15  and  16;  Sydney,  i  University  Theatre,  Kensing  ton,  August  23  to  27  inclus   ive;  Melbourne,  Comedy  nie  atre,  August  29  and  30;  Can  berra,  The  Playhouse,  Can  berra  Theatre  Centre,  August   Enquiries:  Sydney  211-5055,  Adelaide  23-1079,  Melbourne  63-3407  or.  63-6531,  Canberra   7-1486.   *  .  ■  *  *■   The  next  attraction  at  the  Comedy  Theatre,  following  the  return  season  of  Les  Bal  lets  Africains,  will  be  “An  other  Evening  with  Joyce  Grenfell.”  which  will  play  from  Wednesday,  August  31,  to  Saturday,  September  17   One  of  the  most  versatile  of  England’s  great  actress  comediennes,  she  is  famous  for  her  stage  roles,  motion  pictures,  television  perform  ances,  broadcasts  and  record   ings. This  was  annoum  by  the  Manager  for  the  A  in  Victoria,  Mr.  E.  Whiteley.   .Mr.  Jones  replaces  Mr.  Adrian  Bendall,  who  retired  earlier  will  year. He  has  played  in  the'  Melbourne  Symphony  Orchestra  ,  on  several  occa  sions  in  relieving  capacity.

heading: German Zionism
article_text: German  Zionism   It  was  certainly  a-  develop-  i  ment  never  anticipated  by   him  when,  during  World  War  !  I  and  later,  he  played  a  lead-  I  ing  part  in  the  Zionist  Feder  ation  of  Germany,  and  especi  ally  in  the  Zionist  newspaper  the  “Juedische  Rundschau.”  In  friendly  co-operation  with  Leo  Hermann,  he  wrote  article  upon  article—all  anonymous,  of  course;  as  a  foreign  Jew,  he  could  not  then  write  under  his  own  name—but  every  Zion  ist  in  Germany  was  aware  of  his  activity  and  felt  that  a  new  note  sounded  in  his  words.   I  cannot  say  that  I  always  agreed  with  the  articles  writ  ten  or  inspired  by  him.  He  was  a  faithful  adherent  of  Poalei  Zion.  The  influence  on  him  of  Borochov  and  the  very  gifted  and  original  Nach  man  Syrkin  was  clearly  notice  able.  In  “Der  Jude,”  he  wrote  on  various  topical  questions  under  the  name  R.  Zalman.   Zalman’s  connection  with  Jewish  socialism  stems  from.  Russia.  In  Germany,  he  had  some  first-rate  scholars  for   teachers.  The  studies  ,  he  be  gan  in  Leningrad  were  con  tinued  at  the  Universities  of  Freiburg,  Strasbourg  and  Ber   lin.   In  Berlin,  he  met  the  man  of  whom  he  still  rightly  says  tliat  he  was  the  greatest  Jew  ish  editor  he  ever  knew,  Dr.  Joseph  Bloch,  of  the  “Sozial  istische  MonaWhefte.”  That  man  never  wrote  a  line  him  self,  but  everything  published  in  the  ‘‘Monatshefte’’  through  out  the  years,  was  checked,  controlled  and  directed  by  him.   Zalman  knew  German  Zion  ism  in  all  its  ramifications,  and  it  seems  to  me  that  his  stay  in  Berlin  has  been  of  lasting  benefit  to  him.  He  :  lodged  at  Rose  Struck’s  pen   sion,-  together  with  his  friend  Kitain.  I  think  that  he  un  derwent  a  marked,  spiritual  development  in  those  years.   I  will  confine  myself  to  what  I  know  at  first  hand  and  of  which  I  believe  that  it  will  help  to  characterise  the  man.

heading: German frontiers
article_text: German  frontiers   THERE  IS  something  sen  iously  wrong  with  the  map  of  Europe  printed  on  page  3  of  your  supplement  of  July  24.  In  saying  this  I  am  not  pri-   marily  thinking  of  the  fact  that  you  have  omitted  Luxem  burg,  although  that  is  bad.  My  objection  concerns  the  way  the  map  depicts  —  or  rather  overlooks  —  the  fact  of  the  two  German  States  and  your  denial  of  the  border  separating  the  two  German  States  as  being  a  proper  state  frontier.  Surely  you  are  aware  that  the  West  German  authorities  do  not  accept  the  postwar  borders  in  Europe  and  that  they  want  to  change  the  status  quo.  By  denying  that  there  is  a  proper  frontier  between  the  two  German  States  they  act  ually  intend  to  anticipate  any  future  aggression  on  their  part  as  an  "internal"  affair.  That  is  in  fact  anticipated  aggres  sion.   Gertrude  Salomen,  Berlin.   Tribune  regrets  that  on  the  map  the  two  States  and  the  border  were  unsatisfactorily  marked.  There  was  no  political  significance  in  this  oversight.  —  ED.
snippet: THERE IS something seriously wrong with the map of Europe printed on page 3 of your supplement of July 24.

heading: GERMAN QUESTIONS
article_text: GERMAN  QUESTIONS   The  Central  verein  der  Juden  in  Deutschland  (Organisation  of  Jews  in  Germany)  has  celebrated  its  tenth  anniversary.   When  the  war  ended,  it  seemed  inconceivable  that  within  such  a  short  time  a  new  Jewish  community  would  re-establish  itself  in  the  graveyard  of  its  illustrious  predecessor.   After  the  Spanish  Inquisi  tion  the  Jews  did  not  return  to  Spain  for  centuries,  and  in  the  case  of  Germany  the  in  habitants  seemed  to  be  infin  itely.  greater.   Nevertheless,  some  German  Jews  have  returned,  many  of  them  elderly  people  who  were  unable  to  strike  roots  else  where,  though  the  majority  of  the  Centreleverein  members  did  not  live  in  Germany  at  all  before  1939.   The  Germans  themselves  are  .likely  to  be  more  impres   sed  T>y  a  feeling  of  reserve  towards  them  by  Jews  rather  than  by  eagerness  to  partici  pate  in  their  country’s  fin  ancial  prosperity.   From  a  Jewish  point  of  view  the  only  justification  for  the  resumption  of  an  organ  ised  Jewish  community  in  Germany  would  be  that  it  in  sisted  upon  a  probity  of  living  that  exemplified  the  highest  traditions  and  reputation  of  Jewry.   CRITICISM   These  sentiments  should  not  be  understood  as  a  reflection  on  the  sincerity  of  the  Fed  eral  Republic  in  its  desire  to  atone.   It  is  precisely  because  these  efforts  are  recognised  that  some  recent  cases  of  judicial  lenience  bordering  on  con  criticism  must  be  made  of  donation  towards  war  crim  inals.   Statements  by  judges  that  the  killing  of  innocent  persons  by  shooting  is  neither  murder  nor  cruel,  and  their  unwil  lingness  to  accept  the  testi  mony  of  surviving  victims,  show  an  unregenrate  attitude  that  is  inconsistent  with  the  avowed  beliefs  of  Western  Germany’s  present  leaders  and  gravely  impairs  the  good  name  of  the  new  Germany   abroad.   Incidents  such  as  these  lend  added.  point  to  the  abhor  rence  which  is  widely  felt  among  the  British  public  at  large  and  among  Jews  in  par  ticular  at  the  reports  of  pos  sible  stationing  of  German  troops  in  Britain  under  NATO  arrangements.   However  logical  this  step  may  be  from  the  point  of  view  of  defence  arrangements  (though  so  far  no  convincing  reason  has  been  made  pub  lic)  logic  is  not  everything  and  sentiment  too,  must  be  taken  into  account.   While  considerations  of  se  curity  must  be  paramount,  the  misgivings  strongly  felt  by  wide  sections  of  the  Brit  ish  public  should  be  given  most  serious  consideration  by  the  Government  before  a  final  :  decision  is  taken.—  (JCFNS).  -  .  ‘

heading: GERMAN CHAMPION
article_text: Star  womaq  athlete  at  the  r«cent  German  Light  Athletic  cham  pionships  in  Hamburg  was  Jutta  Heine,  above.   The  21-year-okl  stu  dent  of  political  economy,  shown  at  the  start  erf  the  100  metres,  gained  three  champion  ships.   She  won  the  100  metres  against  a  head  wind  in  11.6  seconds,  the  200  metres  in  23.8  seconds  and  with  three  other  runners  of  the  Cologne  Athletic   Association  won  the  four  time  100  metre  relay  race  in  46.4  seconds.   Altogether  20  new  German  champions   emerged  from  the  Ger  man  Light  Athletic  Championships.   Manfred  Germar,  with  his  victory  in  the  200  metres  (21.0  seconds),  became  Ger  man  champion  for  the   18th  time.   Helmut  Janz  de  fended  for  the  fifth  time  his  title  in  the  400  metre  hurdles.

heading: GERMAN STUDY
article_text: GERMAN  STUDY   FRANKFURT,  (Germany),  (UPI):  The  Frankfurt  State  prosecutor  last  week  said  his  office  will  study  the  notes  written  by  former  Nazi  leader  Adolf  Eichmann  in  his  Israeli  prison  cell  for  evidence  of  war  crimes  by  other  persons.   Prosecutor  Heinz  Wolff  said,  that  the  Israeli  Government  already  had  sent  a  4,000-page  copy  of  Eichmann’s  notes  at  his  request,  and  that  the  Is  raeli  Government  had  granted  a  Frankfurt  Prosecutor  per   mission  to  attend  Eichmann’s  war  crimes  trial  as  an  ob   server.   The  trial  is  scheduled  to  begin  April  11.   Wolff  said  a  list  of  suspects  also  sent  to  him  by  the  di  rector  .  of  "Historical  doc  umentation  for  the  research  of  Nazi  war  crimes”  In  Haifa  contains  47  names,  all  known  to  West  German  police  of   ficials.   MAN  HUNT   He  said  some  of  those  on  the  list  were  dead;  and  some  executed,  with  one  now  in  prison.  A  police  manhunt  is  underway  for  the  rest,  he   said;  •   Wolff  said  .  the  files  on  Eichmann  have  been  closed  in  Frankfurt  since  he  was  capt  ured  in  Argentina  and  spirit  ed  to  Israel  by  secret  agents  last  year.   •But,  he  said,  his  office  would  use  Eichmann’s  notes  in  an  effort  to  track  down  Eiehmann’s  aeco  m  p  1  i  c  e  s,  whose  location  may  be  brought  out  during  the  trial.   '  He  said  Hermann  Erumey,  one  former  Eichmarin  sub  ordinate,  and  other  persons  accused  as  war  criminals,  are  in  jail,  awaiting  trial  next  year  on  charges  they  deported  about  400,000  Hungarian  Jews  to  death  camps.

heading: German measles
article_text: German  measles   Sir,  -  May  I  write  in  support  of  the  letter  by  Mrs  Eleanor  Evans  (Aug  ust  20)  with  regard  to  the  incidence  of  german  measles  in  Canberra  at  present?  I  feel  sure  most  people,  unless  they  have  had  personal  experience  of  the  ravages  of  this  dis  ease,  are  not  aware  of  the  severe  handicaps  that  can  be  caused  to  their  child   ren.   The  end  result  arising  from  a  woman  in  preg  nancy  contracting  this  dis  ease  at  the  critical  time,  without  any  medical  safe  guard,  not  only  entails  a  severe  handicap  for  the  Child  but  eventually  affects  all  members  of  the  family.  Anxiety  and  strain  aro  common  and  the  parents  have  less  time  to  spend  with  other  children  in  the  family.   As  Mrs  Evans  has  said,  we  have  a  hearty  rcspcct  for  the  rubella  virus.  It  is  to  be  hoped  that  even  a  little  knowledge  will  help  others  to  perhaps  avoid  the  effects  of  it.  Please  mothers,  don't  depend  on  first  having  to  see  a  rash  or  other  symptom  before  seeking  medical  advice,  more  especially  if  you  have  been  or  are  likely  to  be  in  contact  with  other   riih#»11n   M. article_text: German   crisis   BONN,  Wednesday  (AAP-Reuter).-The  coali  tion  partners  in  Chancellor  Ludwig  Erhard's  Govern  ment  failed  yesterday  for   the  second  time  in  24  hours  lo  resolve  crucial  dif  ferences  over  budgetary  policies.   The  future  of  the  coali  tion  between  Dr  Erhard's  Christian  Democrats  and  the  minority  Free  Demo  crats  was  in  the  balance.   The  Free  Democrats  have  threatened  to  quit  the  coalition  if  tax  increases  are  imposed  to  plug  an  ex  pected  $900  million  deficit  in  next  year's  budget.   They  think  the  Govern  ment  should  rely  on  re  duced  subsidies  and  remo  moval  o£  tax  concessions  as  well  as  cuts  in  Govern  ment  spending.

heading: A GERMAN NOTEBOOK
article_text: A  GERMAN  NOTEBOOK   By  WILLIAM  FRANKEL   (The  first  of  too  articles).   if  lie  possesses  any  sensitivity  at  all,  a  Jew  visiting  Germany  for  the  first  time  must  undergo  an  intensely  emotional  ex  perience.   He  looks  coldly  and  almost  apprehensively  at  the  German  men  and  women  in  the  street:  were  they  among  the  persecutors?  Of  the  Germans  with  whom  he  comes  into  closer  contact,  the  Jew  won  ders:  is  the  hand  I  am  shaking  the  hand  of  one  of  the  butchers?   Naturally,  the  intensity  of  this  reaction  is  blunted  after  a  while,  but  there  remains  a  residue  very  near  the  surface  that  colours  every  moment  of  the  stay  in  Germany.   So.  of  course,  the  relation  ship  between  German  and  Jew  Is  bound  to  be  an  ab  normal  one.  Nearly  all  the  Germans  I  met  during  my  visit  felt  it  necessary  to  make  some  expression  —  from  the  eloquent  to  the  hesitant  —  of  their  sense  of  guilt  for  the  Nazi  past,  and  to  add  some  words  explaining  their  own  innocence.  Many  of  them  were,  undoubtedly,  both  truth,  ful  and  sincere,  but  yet  I  felt  that  to  some  extent  even  they  resented  being  reminded  of  something  they  would  much  rather  forget.   For  my  part,  at  each  of  these  encounters  I  could  not  avoid  a  feeling  of  some  dis  comfort  at  being  the  cause  of  shame  and  embarrassment  on  the  part  of  these  apparent,  ly  decent  Germans.  Yet  I  know  that  I  would  have  taken  amiss  the  absence  of  their  expression  of  guilt  and  of  explanation.  I  cannot  but  feel  that  this  reaction  of  German  and  Jew  will  continue  through,  out  the  lives  of  the  genera  tion  who  was  involved.   NO  TRADITION   The  present  abnormality  in  the  relationships  between  Germans  and  Jews  was,  therefore,  responsible  for  a  certain  tension  during  my  visit  But  Germany  (like  Is  rael).  is  a  country  in  which  a  great  deal  is  going  on,  and  the  interest  in  observing  this  regeneration  overlays  though  it  never  entirely  displaces,  the  I  sense  of  discomfort   Certainly,  the  Wirtschafts  wunder  —  the  miracle  of  German  economic  recovery’—■  is  all  nervading.  Shops  are  not  only  full  of  expensive  merchandise,  they  are  busily  selling  it   Innumerable  and  varied  eating  establishments  dispense  gargantuan  servings  of  whole  some  food  to  portly  diners.  New  construction,  skyscrapers,  houses,  public  buildings,  trans  form  derelict  bombed  sites.  The  men  and  women  in  the  street  are  patently  well-fed  and  well-clothed.   TENSION   This  abundant  prosperity  has  obvious  implications  for  the  prospect  for  democracy  in  Germany.  So  long  as  it  lasts,  the  German  man-in-the  street  will  be  content  with  the  Government  which  pro  vides  these  benefits.   But  Germany  has  no  tra  dition  of  democracy.  Its  citizens  have  been  condition  ed  to  respond  to  authoritar  ian  leadership.   One  of  the  many  everyday  examples,  is  the  exaggerated  difference  still  accorded  to  uniforms  and  titles.  I  have  no  doubt  that  the'  present  administration  has  a  sincere  desire  to  establish  a  soundly  based  democratic  system  in;  Germany  and  today’s  pros  perity  is  helping  to  achieve   it.   But  should  there  be  a  serious  economic  or  political  crisis,  a  new  type  of  total  litarianlsm  might  very  well  emerge.  As  a  leading  trade  unionist  put  •  it  to  me.  “I  would  not  put  my  hand  in  the  fire  for  German  democ  racy.”   It  is  a  pity  that  many  who  understand  the  fragility  of  German  democracy  try  to:   protect  it  by  over-emphasis  upon  the  fight  against  former  Nazis.  Undoubtedly  their  re  tention  in  positions  of  ap  parent  influence  exercises  a  harmful  effect  on  public  opinion.-A  new  totalitarian  ism,  however,  can  be  brought  about  by  a  wave  of  emotion  alism  and  anti-rationalism  that  may  flare  up  In  a  crisis.  The  new  right  vsdng  radical  parties  are  the  ones  to  watch.  By  diverting  energies  to  the  proscription  of  old  Nazis  (who  will  not  be  the  new  Nazis)  the  real  sources  of  the  future  danger  may  be  ignored.   EDUCATION   What,  therefore,  can  be  done  so  that  a  new  Germany  does  not  ever  again  become  militaristic,  nationalistic  and  racist?  The  education  of  the  rising  generation  in  democ  ratic  ways  and  to  a  realisa  tion  of  the  crimes  of  Nazism  is  not  a  complete  Insurance  against  another  recession  into  savagery  (nothing  is),  but  it  is  an  aspect  than  can  only  be  neglected  at  the  nation’s  peril.   I  believed  the  German  educationists  who  told  me  what  they  were  trying  to  do,  for  they  were  enlightened  and  Intelligent  people.  Ideal  cur  ricula  are  drawn  up  but  they  might  never  be  applied  in  practice  because  of  opposi  tion  by  parents  and  teachers  who,  naturally,  want  to  avoid  the  discovery  of  their  own  guilt  to  the  children.   As  the  opinions  I  heard  of  the  effectiveness  of  the  schools  programme  were  so  varied,  I  decided  to  make  my,  own  test   Without  anyone  else  being  present.  I  met  the  top  classes  of  two  schools.  One  was  a  grammar  school  and  the  average  age  of  the  boys  was  17.  They  all  had  a  fairly  good  knowledge  of  the  origins  and  rise  of  Hitlerism.  They  knew  something  about  the  causes  of  the  war  and  of  Hitler’s  invasion  of  neutral  countries  (though  they  thought  it  was  justified  in  a  “total  war”).  And  they  knew  about  the  persecution  of  the  Jews,  (the  reason  —  they  were  ter  i  ribly  rich  and  Hitler  wanted   their  money  to  start  a  war),  though  not  of  other  minor  ities.   NAZIS   Most  of  their  parents  had  been  Nazis,  but  had  explained  their  membership  to  their  children  as  having  been  due  to  economic  reasons  such  as  employment  and  getting  school  places.   In  the  second  school,  which  approximates  more  to  our  secondary  modern,  I  spoke  to  the  top  class  of  boys  who  were  about  15  year  old.  They  knew  very  little  about  Hitler  and  the  war  but  they  all  knew  the  figure  of  six  mil  lion  Jews  who  had  been  killed.  I  gathered,  however,  that  they  had  learned  this  from  television  and  not  from  school.   The  Cologne  swastika  smearing  of  December,  1959,  came  as  a  profound  shock  to  liberal  elements  in  Germany  and  the  repercussions  are  by   no  means  ended.   One  was  a  recognition  that  the  educational  programme  had  been  allowed  to  drift   almost  into  stagnation  Educ  ation  is  a  responsibility  of  the  Laender  not  the  Federal  Government  “Controversial”  issues,  like  the  teaching  of  Germany’s  past,  are  suscept  ible  to  local  pressure,  and  that  Is  one  of  the  reasons  why  more  has  not  been  done.  Ef  forts  have  been  unsuccessful  to  establish  a  Federal  Minis  try  of  Education  which  might  be  expected  to  tackle  the  sub  ject  with  greater  vigour.  Since  this  is  unlikely  to  come  about  for  political  -  and  practical  reasons,  there  ought  to  be  some  effective  system  of  school  inspection  to  ensure  that  the  syllabus  approved  bv  enlightened  Ministers  of  Education  is.  in  fact,  applied  in  lessons  and  that  teachers  do  not  plead  lack  of  time  in  stopping  the  teaching  of  Ger  man  history  at  1914.   (To  be  concluded.)   (Copyright,  Jewish  Chron  icle  Feature  &  News  Service.)

heading: Student's German fellowship
article_text: Mr  Brooks   Student's  German  fellowship   I  Australian  National  Uni  versity  student,  Mr  Christopher  Brooks,  26,  will  go  io  Cologne,  West  Ger  many,  next  year  °n  an  un  usual  fellowship.   The  German  Government  has  awarded  him  the  Lud  wig  Leichhardt  Fellowship  so  he  can  continue  work  on  the  rubidium  strontium  age  technique.   The  fellowship  is  awarded  to  only  one  Australian  each   year.   Mr  Brooks,  a  Tasmanian,  has  been  studying  at  the  Institute  of  Nuclear  Chem  istry  for  the  past  two-and-a  half  years.   He  will  complete  his  doc  toral  course  this  year,  and  will  complete  a  two-month  "crash"  course  in  German  before  he  begins  work  in  Cologne.

heading: East German Accusations
article_text: East  German  Accusations   BERLIN,  Friday  (A.A.P.).  —  The  East  German  Com  munist  Party,  in  a  report  published  yesterday,  accused  Communist  China  of  advo  cating  a  split  in  the  interna  tional  Communist  Movement,  British  United  Press  said.   The  report,  made  last  week  by  the  Politburo  to  the  partys  Central  Committee,  said  an  article  in  official  Chinese  party  journals  on  Febraury  4  appealed  directly  for  a  split  in  the  movement.   It  denounced  the  article  as  being  the  vilest  attack  ever  made  by  the  Chinese  on  Rus  sia  and  on  Mr.  Khrushchev.   Published  in  today's  offic  cial  party  newspaper  Neues  Deutschland,  the  report  also  accused  the  Chinese  of  break  ing  an  agreement  to  refrain  from  public  attacks  on  other  Communist  parties.

heading: GERMAN GARDEN CITY
article_text: GERMAN  GARDEN  CITY   The  baroque  style  of  gardening  can  still  be  seen  in  Harrenhausen,  near  I   Hanover,  the  capital  of  Lower  Saxony,  in  Western  Germany.  I   Hanover  is  known  as  the  city  of  trees  and  gar   dens.  Tlie  Great  Garden  of  Herrenhausen  (above)  is  the  only  baroque  garden  which  has  remained  un   altered  in  Germany  and  has  all  the  characteristics  of  its  period,  the  18th  cen  tury.   The  garden  is  laid  out  on  strictly  geometrical  lines  with  artistically  cut  trees,  box-wood  pyramids,  neatly  trimmed  hedges  and  regular  gardens.   The  Great  Garden  is   only  one  of  the  wide  spreal  gardens  and  parks  in  Hanover  which  to   gether  cover  an  area  of  over  2,000  acres  and  pro   ?   vide  the  city  with  the  green  open  spaces  it  needs.

heading: German measles vaccine
article_text: German  measles  vaccine   WASHINGTON,  Friday  1   (AAiP).  —  Two  American  '  doctors  have  developed  what  appears  to  be  the  iirst  safe  vaccine  offering  long  term  protection  against  Ger  man  measles,  the  Washing   ton  Post  reported  last  night.  1   Credited  with  developing  the  vaccine  wefe  Doctors  Harry  M.  Meyer  and  Paul  D.  Parknian,  research  pedia  tricians  at  the  division  of  biologic  standards  at  the  National  Institute  of  Health.   They  said  the  vaccine  was  still  being  evaluated,  but  preliminary  tests  on  humans  showed  significant  results.   German  measles  —  or  rubella  —  is  a  mild  disease  when  contracted  by  child  ren,  but  when  contracted  by  women  during  early  preg  nancy  the  rubella  virus  can  kill  or  cripple  the  unborn   child.

heading: German home units
article_text: A  German  idea  for  using  blocks  of  pre-fabricated  home  units.  See   story  below.   German   home  units   ^  EUROPEAN  com   petition  for  the  best  pre-fabricated  liv  I  ing  units  was  won  bv   young  German  archi  tect  Jochen  Brandi,  against  3.128  entries.   Brandi's  design  for  four  rooms,  bath,  kitchen  and  closet  can  be  used  as  a  single  home,  or  in  block   such  as  shown  in  the  draw  ing  above  in  which  terraces  take  the  place-  of  gardens,  or  in  the  rows  on  a  single  level.   Brandi's  advanced  con   ception  begins  in  the  archi  tects's  office  where  the  mat  erial  is  chosen  before  the  design  is  settled.  Despite  the  design  being  for  pre  fabricated  units,  a  number  of  variations  are  possible  according  to  taste  and  available  funds.   The  units  are  built  into  a  supporting  steel  framework.   According  to  Brandi's  carefully  conceived  plan,  only  a  few  days  are  needed   to  erect  each  home.   Neither  the  heating  units  —  Brandi  foresees  nuclear  energy  as  an  inexpensive  heating  source  —  nor  the  water  connections  are  hound  to  a  certain  location.   The  rents  in  one  of  the   complexes  —  such  as  that  shown  —  will  be  consider  ably  lower  than  similar  liv  ing  space  in  a  conventional  style  building,  it  is  claimed   Competitors  were  from  53  countries  and  the  winner  received  a  prize  of  $20,000.   Extensive  use  of  steel  was  a  condition  of  the  competi  tion.

heading: German exercise begins
article_text: German  exercise  begins   BONN,  Monday  (AAP-Reuter).  —  The  controversial  Black  Lion  exercise  by  West  Ger  man,  American  and  French  forces,  originally  scheduled  to  be  staged  along  the  Czechoslo  vak  border,  began  today  in  southern  Germany.   The  West  German  Gov  ernment  decided  before  the  Warsaw  Pact  invasion  of  Czechoslovakia  to  move  the  battle  area  95  miles  westward  to  avoid  increasing  tension  in  East  ern  Europe.   But  many  officials  and  politicians  in  Bonn  felt  the  exercise  should  have  been  cancelled  altogether.   Three  West  German  divisions  and  support  units  totalling  42,000  men  are  being  joined  by  an  American  Seventh  Army  tank  brigade  and  a  French  reconnaissance  regiment  in  the  exercise.   The  exercise  calls  for  a  powerful  "red"  invader  to  be  repelled  by  "blue"  de   fence  forces.   Final  preparations  to  day  coincided  with  a  call  by  Mr  Hans-Dietrich  Genscher,  Deputy  Leader  of  the  Opposition  Free  Democratic  Party,  for  more  effective  West  Ger  man  conventional  arma   ments.

heading: Insulted German officer
article_text: Insulted   German  officer   London  (JCNS).  —  A  19  year-old  Jewish  student  in  Poland,  Berl  Lenczner,  is  shortly  to  stand  trial  in  Wroc  law,  for  calling  a  high-rank  ing  East  German  officer,  a  “German  swine,”  according  to  a  report  from  a  reliable  tourist,  who  just  returned  from  Warsaw.   About  two  months  ago,   Lenczner  and  a  fellow  stud  ent  met  the  officer,  who  was  accompanied  by  a  Polish  and  a  Czech  colleague,  in  the  street  of  Lignice  (formerly  Leignit),  during  the  Warsaw  Pact  manoeuvres  held  nearby   there  at  the  time.   Facing  the  trio  Lenczner  addressed  the  German  officer  with  the  words  “Du  Deutsch  er  Schwein,  Raus.”  (“You  German  swine,  out  with  you”).   The  Polish  officer  promptly   arrested  both  students  and   took  them  to  the  police  sta  tion.  The,  local  prosecutor  released  them,  but  the  Sec  urity  Police  had  Lenczner  re  arrested  and  brought  to  War   saw.   Lenczner  is  known  locally  as  a  brilliant  student  and  had  been  admitted  to  the  Cracow  University,  which  has  now  suspended  him.

heading: German History Regulations
article_text: German  History   Regulations   BONN  (JTA):  Regulations  recently  laid  down  by  education  ministers  of  West  German  Laender  for  both  the  teaching  of  history  and  for  history  text  books  have  now  been  published  in  the  official  Federal  German  Gazette.   One  of  the  primary  tasks  of  teaching  history  in  schools  will  be  to  make  pupils  acquainted  with  contemporary  history  and,  in  view  of  Germany’s  present  political  position,  with  Nat  ional  Socialism.   International  organisations  and  alliances  should  be  dealt  with  properly,  and  the  struggle  between  democratic  and  totalit  arian  systems  be  dearly  ex  plained,  thereby  describing  the  resistance  movements  aiming  at  freedom.   Any  glorification  of  war  and  totalitarianism  ought  to  be  omitted,  according  to  the  regu  lations.

heading: EAST GERMAN DISSATISFACTION
article_text: EAST  GERMAN  DISSATISFACTION]   The  equivalent  of  seven  companies  of  sol  diers  and  People's  Police  have  fled  to   West  Germany  from.  Ulbricht's  Communist  East  Zone  since  August  13,  1961.  Their  average  age  is  19  to  20.  Many  of  them  were  forced  to  serve  in  the  People's  Army  and  to  guard  the   frontier.  Because  of  the  inhuman  orders  they  re  ceived—shoot  to  kill—  and  the  continual  poli  tical  indoctrination,  they  deserted  to-  West  Berlin.   The  photo  shows  a  group  of  East  German  soldiers  on  the  square  in   front  of  the  Branden   burg  Gate  in  East  Ber   lin.

heading: GERMAN LIBRARY OPENED
article_text: GERMAN  LIBRARY  OPENED   A  GERMAN-language  library  has  been  opened  by  Bankstown  Council  as  a  special  service  to  its  many  migrant  ratepayers.  The  new  library  forms  part  of  the  Bankstown  Municipal  Library,  Chester  Hill  branch.  It  contains  1,000  books,  ranging  from  novels  to  tech  nical  and  travel  books,  carefully  selected  over  a  period  of  three  years,  at  a  cost  of  over  £3,000.  The  library  was  opened  recently  by  the  First  Secretary  to  the  Embassy  of  the  Federal  Republic  of  Germany,  Dr.  B.  Richter.  Also  at  the  ceremony  were  the  Austrian  Consul,  Mr.  G.  Felser  and  Mrs.  Felser,  the  German  Consul,  Mr.  H.  H.  Hamburger,  the  Mayor  of  Bankstown  and  Ald.  D.  B.  Carruthers.  Dr.  Richter  said  that  the  new  library  would  be  of  help  to  the  many  German-speaking  settlers  in  the  district.  Catering  for  them  by  providing  books  in  their  own  language  was  not  a  retrograde  step,  he  said.  It  would  help  to  keep  many  people  bi-lingual,  and  that  was  an  economic  and  cultural  asset.  The  Chief  Librarian,  Mr.  B.  Churm,  said  that  the  library  had  been  an  immediate  success.  Migrants  constituted  about  25  per  cent  of  the  population  in  the  Bankstown  area.  LEFT:  Shown  looking  over  the  selection  of  books  on  opening  day  are  three  German  migrants  from  nearby  Villawood  hostel.  They  are  Mrs.  Henny  Schulze  (left),  Mrs.  Katherina  Scheibe  and  Mrs.  Rosemarie  Reinsch.

heading: GERMAN OFFICIALS SUSPENDED
article_text: GERMAN   OFFICIALS   SUSPENDED   DUSSELDORF  (JCNS).—  Twenty-four  officials  in  the  State  of  North  Rhine-West  phalia  were  suspended  from  their  posts  during  the  past  15  months,  it  was  disclosed  here  by  German  Trade  Union  circles.   The  officials  had  been  accused  of  criminal  activi  ties  during  the  Nazi  regime  and  legal  proceedings  initiated  against  most  of  thein.   For  several  years,  trade  unions  have  been  fighting  for  the  demoval  of  former  SS  officers  from,  police  posts  in  this  state,  but  the  auth  orities  always  declared  that  charges  against  these  per   sons  were  unfounded.   Many  arrests  in  recent  months,  including  several  high-ranking  CID  officials,  had  shown  that  public  criti  cism  was  fully  justified.   As  a  result  the  authorities  had  changed  their  personnel  policy.   In  future,  leading  police  positions  would  be  given  only  to  persons  who  had  not  been  members  of  the  Nazi  SS,  Gestapo  or  Nazi  Security   Service.

heading: German Visitor Unwelcome
article_text: German  Visitor  Unwelcome   TORONTO  (JTA):  An  official  of  the  Canadian  Jewish  Congress  said  that  protest  demonstrations  of  a  “massive  character”  will  be  staged  here  if  Adolf  von  Thad*  den,  head  of  the  extremist  West  German  National  Democratic  Party,  comes  to  Toronto  on  a  scheduled  visit  this  month.   It  was  reported  that  Thadden  would  come  to  Toronto  on  Janu  ary  29  to  address  a  public  meet  ing  and  to  appear  on  Toronto   television.  However,  it  was  not  learned  what  group  he  would  address  and  no  local  television  station  has  admitted  asking  him  lor  an  interview  appearance.  The  External  Affairs  Department  of  the  Federal  Government  in  Otta  wa  said  it  was  looking  into  the   matter.   In  announcing  ihe  plans  for  a  demonstration,  Meyer  Gasner,  chairman  of  the  CJC  central  region,  said  support  for  the  pro  test  would  be  sought  among  all  sections  of  the  community,  in  cluding  veterans’  groups,  the  trade  union  movement,  ethnic  groups  and  youth  organisations,  as  well  as  from  public  leaders  generally.   Mr.  Gasner  added  that  whether  or  not  the  NPD  leader   comes  to  Canada,  support  will  be  sought  for  a  Canadian  protest  demonstration  against  the  growth  of  the  NPD,  which  he  said  had  the  “colouration  of  a  neo-Nazi  movement,”  represent  ing  a  threat  not  only  to  Ger  many  but  to  the  entire  free   world.

heading: The German view
article_text: The  German  view   So  far,  Mr  Wilson  has  avoided  spelling  out  other  than  in  the  most  general  terms  his  future  plans  for  Britain  beyond  those  for  an  economic  resurgence.  It  is  time  he  did  so,  but  whether  it  should  be  done  in  the  public  forum  (for  example,  in  his  address  to  the  Council  of  Europe  in  Strasbourg  on  Monday)  or  in  private,  is  a  tactical  question  which  can  only  be  decidcd  on  the  spot.  He  will  have  an  opportunity  to  lay  the  foundations  for  a  bargain  with  de  Gaulle  when  he  sees  him  in  Paris  on  Tuesday.   Alternatively,  Mr  Wilson  could  first  try  to  out  manoeuvre  de  Gaulle  by  marshalling  enough  support  in  the  other  capitals,  and  among  non-Gaullists  in  France.  Could  it  be  done?  The  Five  have  all,  at  one  time  or  another,  enthusiastically  declared  support  for  British  membership.  The  wrangling  which  went  on  between  France  and  the  Five  over  the  EEC's  agricultural  policy  and  majority  voting  resulted  in  the  Five  determining  not  to  approve  de  Gaulle's  every  wish.  Also,  the  coming  general  elections  in  France  may  show  the  extent  of  support  for  Britain  in  France  itself.  On  the  other  hand,  the  statement  by  the  West  German  Chancellor  after  his  meeting  with  the  President  this  week  that  "we  believe  the  key  problem  in  Europe  continues  to  be  the  Franco-German  relationship"  suggests  that  the  seeming  weakness  in  de  Gaulle's  position  may  be  only  a  temporary  one.   Either  way,  Mr  Wilson  has  a  very  long  and  very  difficult  road  to  travel  before  Britain  can  rectify  the  mistake  she  made  10  years  ago  in  not  joining.

heading: 'SHALOM' GERMAN LINER
article_text: SHALOM'  GERMAN  LINER   “Hanseatic”  (pictured),  once  the  flag  ship  of  the  Israel  shipping  line  Zim,  has  been  handed  over  to  its  new  own  ers,  The  Deutsche  Atlantik  Linie.   The  vessel  was  built  in  the  St.-Nazaire  shipyards  of  Chan  tiers  de  L’Atlantique  in  1964  for  the  Israeli  line  and  named  “Shalom”.   At  the  Deutsche  Werft  ship  yards  in  Hamburg  "Hanseatic”  is  to  be  refitted  and  made  ready  for  New  Year  cruises  on  December  27  and  January  11  to  the  Carribean  and  South  America.*   The  Deutsche  Atlantik  Linie  will  operate  “Hanseatic”  in  conjunction  with  the  passen   ger  liners  of  Norddeutsche  Lloyd.   “Hanseatic”,  although  not  the  largest  ship  of  the  two  shipping  lines  operating  from  Hamburg,  has  been  called  ‘Hamburg’s  first  lady  of  the  seas.  It  comes  between  the  32,360  ton  “Bremen”  and  the  21,514  ton  “Europa”.   “Hanseatic”  is  regarded  with  the  utmost  respect,  be  cause  with  a  crew  of  400  she  will  carry  600  passengers.  The  tone  of  the  ship  will  be  very  exclusive,  in  much  the  same  way  as  was  the  previous  liner  that  bore  the  name  “Hansea  tic”.  Elegance  is  the  primary   aim.

heading: German countesssuccessful editor
article_text: German  countess  successful  editor   Sv.S/,   *   Dr  Marion  Countess  Donhoff.   .  from.  Herbert  Hecht  in  Hamburg.   TJR  Marion  Countess   Donhoff  is  the  editor  of  'Die  Zeit',  a  highly-respected  West  German  newspaper.   For  more  than  500  years  her  forefathers  served  Polish  and  Prus  sian  kings  and  German  emperors.  Then  in  1945,  the  18th  generation  experi  enced  the  collapse  of  all  that  which  a  tough,  incor  ruptible  and  as  a  result  highly-respected  aristocra  tic  family  had  built  up.   The  countess,  then  34  years  old,  saddled  her  thoroughbred  foxhunter  and  set  out  on  a  long  ride  westwards,  more  than  1,200  miles  from  Konis  berg  in  East  Prussia  to  Hamburg.   There  she  soon  was  the  ccntre  of  discussion  be  cause  she  was  utterly  opposed  to  the  generalisa  tion  that  all  Germans  were  Nazis.   Her  letter  of  protest  did  not  actually  reach  the  British  supreme  comman  der  at  that  time  but  neither  did  it  go  unheard.   The  management  of  'Die  Zeit',  a  weekly  news  paper  devoted  to  politics  and  culture,  engaged  Dr  Marion  Countess  Donhoff,   who  is  a  doctor  of  poiiti-.  cal  science,  as  its  deputy   chief  editor.   Her  campaigns  against   what  she  considered  to  be  Chancellor  Adenauer's  in  flexible  policies,  for  the  freedom  of  Berlin,  her  struggle  against  everything  which  she  considered  un  democratic  made  her  known  around  the  world.   In  1962,  she  received  an  honorary  doctorate  from  the  faculty  of  philosophy  of  (he  Smith  College  (USA),  1964,  the  Joseph  E.  Drexel  prize  for  out  standing  journalistic  work,  1965,  the  Theodor  Heuss  prize  as  an  engaged  and  professed  citizen  of  a  democratic  Germany  for  outstanding  examples  of  civil  courage  and  exemp  lary  political  style.  In  1968  she  was  awarded  the  Isa  bclle  d'  Estc  prize,  only  given  to  women  and  which  is  presented  for  outstand  ing  achievements  in  some  particular  field  according  to  the  wishes  of  its  foun  der,  Princess  Ganzaga.   Then  on.  July  1,  1968,  the  woman  who  had  form  erly  been  the  owner  of  vast  estates,  bccamc  editor  of  'Die  Zeit',  circulation  300,000,;  and  considered  by  many  people  to  be  the  best  publication  of  its  kind  in  Europe.   Her  employees  say  she  is  clever,  cool,  just  and  conscientious.  Countess  Donhoff  has  not  married   and  in  her  spare  time  loves  hunting,  riding,  driving  a  Porsche  car  and,  of  course,  writing.

heading: GERMAN SOUL-SEARCHING
article_text: GERMAN   SOUL-SEARCHING   Jk  reader  sent  me  a  most   interesting  article  j  in  “Jedioth  Chadashoth”,  [an   Israeli  daily  of  the  more  Vhighbrow”  variety  which  is  published  in  the  German  langue;  !   The  article;  which  was   duly  translated  for  me,  yras  concerned  with  a'  very  defin  itive  wave  of  German  con   versions  to  Judaism.  '  j.   The  article  was  written   ^by  Schalom  Ben-Chorini  a   well-known  journalist  who  travelled  in  Northern  Ger  many  in  cities  such  as  Ham  burg  and  Luebeck,  and  also   in  the  Rhineand,  talking  to   the  various  people  concern  ed,  finding  out  what  lay  be   hind  this  emergence  of  j  in   terest  in  Judaism  and  what  was  the  moving  spirit  [be  hind  this,  desire  to  embrace   the  Jewish  faith.  j   The  article  is  extraordin  arily  interesting,  and  I  can  only  give  one  or  two  of  the  main  points  of  interest.  B^n-Chorin  finds  two  m  ain  reasons  why  this  should  be  in  the  country  he  calls  “the  land  without  Jews”.   The  first  one  is  that  the  young  people  haven’t  man  aged  to  come  to  terms  with  the  past.  They  are  met  by  a  “\vall  of  silence”.  Says  Ben  Chorin:  “Those  who  don’t   want  to  share  the  guiltj  of   their  fathers  feel  some  need  to  move  from  the.  camp  of  the  persecutor  to  the  camp  of  the  persecuted...”   This,  I  think,.  must  be   cepted  as  a  pretty  true  pic  ture  of  a  large  section  of  German  youth  today.   It  is  the  verdict  of  Gud  ilin  Tempel  in  her  passion  ately  sincere  book  “Speak  ing  Frankly  About  The  Ger  mans”,  and  it  is  the  verdict  of  the  investigation  which  we  saw  on  our  Television  sets'a  few  weeks  ago  where  every  young  German  said,  in  effect:  “...  We  cannot  talk  to  our  parents...  Nor  can  we  believe  that  they  didn’t  know  what  was  hap  pening  ..   Young  Germans  have  come  into  direct  Jewish  con  tact  due  to  the  co-operation  between  various  Israeli  and  German  youth  organisa  tions.  Perhaps  they  feel  a  need  to  expiate  the  sins  of  their  fathers.  Perhaps  it  is  merely  the  most  violent  re  bellion  they  can  make  against.  the  standards  of  their  fathers.   t^|7^HATEVER  the  rensons,   according  ,  to  this  ar  ticle,'  the  conversions  go  on.  The  Rabbis  treat  them  with  more  than  reserve.  The  training  period  is  so  long  that  only  the  most  deter  mined  survive  the  delay.   The  Rabbis  are  of  course  extremely  reluctant  in  the  case  of  older  Germans,  but  the  young  ones  they  cannot  reject.  In  one  group  alone,  in  Hamburg,  Hr.  Ben-Cho  rin  met  ten  young  Germans  in  process  of  being  convert   ed.  This  was  only  one  of   many  groups.   But  there  is,  according  to  this  article,'  a  second  reason  for  the  conversions.  It  is  a  purely  religious  swing  away  from  the  conception  of  the  Trinity  —  a  return  and  a  need  for  a  monotheistic  God.   Even  various  •  Theological  Colleges;  that  previously  re  jected  Judaism  as  the  moth  er  religion  from  which  Christianity  came,  have  now  changed  their  teachings  to  acknowledge  that  Christia  nity  owes  the  greater  part   of  its  teaching  to  the  parent  religion.   It  is  of  course  easy  to  see  in  a  fragmentary  German  desire  to  embrace  Judaism  a  great  deal  more  than  it  war  rants.  Psychologists  will  see  in  it  a  murderer’s  desire  to  embrace  the  body  of  the  vic  tim,  or  a  guilt  expiation  at   Yet  it  isn’t  likely  that  Jewish  religious  authorities  will  welcome  these  converts  with  great  joy.   There  is  something  a  little  unhealthy  in  this  converting  impulse.   The  Germans  —  on  the  other  side  of  the  coin  that  shows  brutality  and  sadism  —have  always  had  a  mas  ochistic  streak  as  well.  It  could  be  that  this  rejection  of  their  parents’  standards  is  an  example  of  this  char  acteristic.   Whatever  the  causes,  Mr.  Ben-Chorin’s  story  fits  a  new  piece  into  the  jig-saw  puzzle  that  is  Germany  to  day.  .

heading: West German scholarships
article_text: West  German   scholarships   The  German  Academic  Exchange  Service  is  offer  ing  14  scholarships  to  Aus  tralian  post  -  graduate  students  for  the  academic  year  1967-68.   The  scholarships  will  have  a  monthly  value  of  $90,  SI  10  and  SI80.  accord  ing  to  age  and  qualifica  tions,  and  will  enable  students  to  study  at  any  university  in  West  Ger  many  and  in  West  Berlin.   Application  forms-  are  available  from  the  Com  monwealth  Office  of  Edu  cation  in  Sydney.
