heading: German peace treaty
article_text: German  peace  treaty   jJOSCOW:  The  need  to  preserve  peace  in  Europe  and  relax  ten  sions  by  signing  a  German  peace  treaty  is  restressed  by  Khrushchov  j  in  a  letter  to  Rolf  Elias,  Chairman  of  the  German  Soviet  Friendship  :  Society  in  West  Berlin.   In  a  letter  to  Khrushchov  Elias  had  said  that  Khrushchov's  speech  at  the  SED  Congress  in  Berlin  would  stimulate  society  members  to  still  greater  efforts  for  peaceful  co  existence.  Elias  referred  to  the  Soviet-Ca  ribbean  policy  as  wise  and  humane.  In  reply  Khrushchov  said  that  -  prevention  of  a  Caribbean  conflict  '  does  not  guarantee  that  there  will  be  no  recurrence  in  other  parts  of  ;  the  world.  To  remove  such  a  danger  it  is  necessary  to  liquidate  the  factors  which  cause  crises;  hence  the  need  to  sign  a  German  peace  treaty  and  I  solve  the  West  Berlin  problem.

heading: GERMAN COMPENSATION ADOPTION
article_text: GERMAN  COMPENSATION   ADOPTION   Prepared  for  “Jewish  News  by  Dr.  0.  Freyer,   Sydney.   ^HE  final  Compensation  Law  (Schlussentschae   digungsgesetz)  is  likely  to  be  enacted  at  the  end  of  June,  and  probably  comes  into  operation  at  the  beginning  of  July.   After  deliberation  for  twc  years,  the  Compensation  Law  Committee  of  the  German  Parliament  submitted  a  ma  jority  report  to  the  Lower  House  on  May  13  and  the  second  and  third  readings  of  the  respective  draft  legisla  tion  was  expected  to  take  place  soon  after.   The  Report,  based  on  the  draft  previously  submitted  by   the  German  Government  in  November,  1903,  if  enacted  will  result  in  wide-spread  changes  in  the  structure  of  the  compensation  legislation,  i   It  is  expected  that  the  law  will  be  adopted  on  the  basis  of  this  Report,  with  minor  alterations.   IRON  CURTAIN   The  main  features  of  the  Report  include_   (a)  Claims  of  persecutees  who  left  the  Iron  Curtain  countries  after  October  1,  1953  .  (so  called'  “post  ‘53  cases”)_   A  fund  will  be  created  amounting  to  DM  700,000,000  from  which  the  claims  of  this  group  will  be  satisfied.   Persecutees  entitled  to  com  pensation  are  those  who  were  deprived  of  their  liberty  for  a  period  not  less  than  G  months  (the  mere  wearing   of  a  “David  Star”  or  the  i  living  under  legality  is  not  sufficient)  or  those  who  are  a.t  the  present  time  at  least  80%  incapacitated  or  widows  who  lost  their  husbands  as  a  result  of  persecution  and  who  did  not  re-marry.   The  basic  compensation  will  amount  to  DM  2,000.  How  ever,  persons  who  are  over  the  age  of  G5  years  are  en  titled  to  DM  2,500  and  widows  who  lost  their  husbands  as  n  result  of  persecution  DM  3,000.  Widow’s  who  were  deprived  of  their  liberty  for  not  less  thdn  1  year  are  entitled  to  DM  5,000.   This  basic  compensation  will  be  paid  immediately  af  ter  the  case  of  each  ap  plicant  has  been  proved.   The  additional  compensa  tion  will  be  determined  on  the  basig  of  funds  remaining  after  satisfying  all  applicants  in  respect  of  their  basic  com  pensation  and  in  determining  this  additional  compensation  tlie  following  graduations  will  apply:—   (x)  Persecutees  who  were  deprived  of  their  liberty  for  1  or  2  years  will  receive  a  single  fixed  amount   (xx)  Persecutees  who  were  deprived  of  their  liberty  for  2  to-  3  years  will  receive  double  the  fixed  amount.   (xxx)  Persecutees  who  where  deprived  of  their  liber   >  ty  for  3  to  4  years  will  re  ,•  ceive  treble  the  fixed  amount.  i  (xxxx)  Persecutees  who  .  were  deprived  of  their  liber  .  ty  for  more  than  4  years  will   receive  four  times  the  fixed  :  amount.   (xxxxx)  Widows  will  re  ’  ceive  5  times  the  fixed  !  amount.   The  maximum  additional  compensation  will  be  five  times  the  fixed  amount.   OTHER  GROUNDS   There  are  no  special  pro  visions  for  compensation  in  respect  of  “loss  of  health”,  however,  the  Government  is  entitled  to  divert  the  balance  remaining  of  the  afore  mentioned  funds  in  order  to  satisfy  the  claims  of  perse  cutees  who  suffered  exces  sive  loss  of  health.   (b)  Special  Drovision  for  persecutees  being  non-Ger  man  Nationals  who  were  persecuted  on  grounds  other  than'  racial  or  religious  (Po  les,  Czech,  Russians,  Ukrain  ians  etc.).   Compensation  ■  for  loss  of  health  is  provided  for  per  sons  who  held  the  status  of  Political  Refugees  on  Octo  ber  1,  1953.  This  is  provided  in  one  or  the  other  of  the  following  cases:—   (i)  Persons  who  suffer-1  ed  injuries  as  a  result  of  being  ill-treated  through  the  ignoring  of  human  rights  and  therefore  at  the  present  time  are  permanently  incapacitated   to  the  extent  of  not  less  than  25%.  This  group  is  en  titled  to  claim  compensation  bv  way  of  a  pension  as  from  October  1,  1953.   (ii)  Persons  who  ^were  brought  to  Germany  as  forced  labourers  .  (ZwangSarbeiter)  and  who,  through  ill-treat  ment,  contracted  some  form  of  illness  which  at  the  pre   sent  time  reduced  their  work  ing  capacity  bv  50%,  are  entitled  to  claim  a  pension  as  from  October  1,  1960.   Persons  included  under  item  (i)  and  who  became  political  persecutees  after  October  1,  1953  are  entitled  to  claim  compensation  in  form  of  a  lump  sum  payment  of  DM  6,000.  The  claims  of  per  secutees  included  under  points  (al  and  .(to)  above  must  be  lodged  by  September  30,1966.   (c)  Submission,  of  New  Claims.   A  person  who  made  a  gene  ral  claim  application  for  com  pensation  in  the  due  time  is  entitled  to  submit  a  new  claim,  although  this  claim  was  not  included  or  even  ex  cluded  in  his  general  ap  plication.  This  provision  ap  plies  subject  that  the  new  submission  is  made  riot  later  than  -  September  1,  1965.   (d)  Special  provisions  for  “loss  of  health”  in  respect  of  concentration  camp  in-mates.   Persons  who  were  interned  iin  a  concentration  camp  for  not  less  than  one  year  and  who,  at  present,  due  to  ill  ness  which  is  relative  to  their  internship  in  such  camps,  having  a  working  incapacity  through  illness  at  the  pre  sent  time  of  not  less  than  25%  will  be  entitled  to  take  advantage  of  a  legal  presump  tion  that  the  illness  was  actually  due  to  persecution.   The  Government  is  author  ised  to  determine  by  way  of   decree  what  camps  are  to  be  regarded  as  concentration  camps,  having  in  mind  that  camps  under  supervision  of  the  S.C.:  will  not  be  the  only  ones  covered  by  same.   (e)  Opening  of  “Loss  of  Health”  claims  which  such  claims  were  repudiated.   If  a  case  was  repudiated  only  on  medical  grounds  it  may  be  re-opened  when  the  facts  brought  forward  in  evidence  at  the  time  of  hear  ing  are  now  considered  to  be  contrary  to  accepted  medical  and  scientific  knowledge  and/  or  on  the  other  hand  if  it  proves  to  be  contrary  to  the  present  legal  interpretation  adopted  by  the  Supreme  Court.   (f)  Compensation  for  “Loss  of  Education”.   Additional  compensa  t  i  o  n  amounting  to  DM  5,000  is  provided  for  this  group  of  persecutees  who  where  forced  to  interrupt  their  education  and  who  failed  to  continue   same.   The  features  listed  above  are  the  main  ones  which  will  be  adopted  in  the  new  law  however  they  are  not  ex  haustive.   It  is  expected  that  both  j   Houses  of  the  German  Par-  •   liament  will  adopt  this  law  oh  the  lines  submitted  by  the  majority  of  the  Compensa  tion  Law  Committee.   It  is  interesting  to  note  that  the  main  difference  of  opinion  of  the  Committee  members  was  as  to  the  ex  tent  of  compensation  due  for  the  so  called  “post  ’53  cases’’.  There'  is  a  minority  Report  as  to  this  problem  which  seeks  inter  alia:—   (aa)  Compensation  to  be  paid  for  loss  of  liberty  amounting  to  DM  150  for  every  month  applicable.   (bb)  Widows  who  lost  their  husbands  as  a  result  of  per  secution  to  receive  a  pension  of  DM  250  as  from  July  1,   1965.   (cc)  Persons  who  are  at  least  60%  incapacitated  through  illness  resulting  from  their  wartime  experiences  to  receive  pension  of  DM  250  as  from  July  1,  1965.   It  is  not  likely  that  these  minority  proposals  will  be  adopted  by  the  German  Par  liament.  The  Minority  Report  proposes  in  addition,  an  in  crease  in  the  fund  for  so  called  “post  ’53  cases’’  to  DM  850,000,000  and  it  is  probable  that  this  proposal  oply  will  be  adopted.
snippet: THE final Compensation Law (Schlussentschaedigungsgesetz) is likely to be enacted at the end of June, and probably comes into operation at the beginning of July.

heading: GERMAN ARMS SUPPLIES
article_text: GERMAN  ARMS   SUPPLIES   New  York  (UPI):  West  Germany  plans  to  ship  to  .Israel  80  million  dollars  worth  of  arms,  Columbia  Broadcasting  System  Cor  respondent  Daniel  Schoor  re  ported  from  Bonn.   Speaking  on  a  Radio  World  News  roundup,  Schoor  said  “West  Germany  has  arrang  ed  for  shipment  to  Israel  80  million  dollars  worth  of  arms  including  submarines,  anti;  aircraft  artillery,  helicopters   and  American-made  M-48  Patton  Tanks.”   He  said  the  tanks  had  been  bought  by  Germany  from  the  U.S.  for  cash  and  therefore  no  American  permission  for  re-export  was  needed,  “but  I  understand  the  United  Sta  tes  has  been  consulted”,  Schoor  added.   “The  whole  program  is  financed  by  West  Germany  but  six  other  European  coun  tries  are  involved  in  pur  chases  and  shipping  arrange-,  ments,”  Schoor  said.   “They  include  Scandinavian  countries,  Switzerland  and  Spain.   “The  delivery.,.  .  was  authorised  by  Chancellor  Er  hard  on  the  ground  that  West  Germany  has  a  moral  obliga  tion  to  aid  in  Israel’s  sur  vival.  .  ,   “Arab  countries  are  threat  ening  to  retaliate  by  recog  nizing  East  Germany...”

heading: THIS GERMAN THOROUGHNESS
article_text: THIS  GERMAN  THOROUGHNESS   By  a  cunning  legal  tricK,  west  German  law  makers  appear  1o  have  sneaked  through  the  West  German  parliament  a  law  amendment  which,  unless  rescinded,  may  release  from  prosecution  most  Nazi  criminals  still  unpunished.   The  loophole  provision  is  so  complicated  that  it  evaded  the  vigilance  of  those  members  of  the  West  German  parliament  who  are  genuinely  in  favour  of  continuing  prosecution  of  Nazis  involved  in  mass  murder;  but  the'Federal  Supreme  Court,  in  a  test  case  decided  on  May  21st,  ruled  that  the  new  legal  amendment  is  valid  law.   Stripped  of  the  legal  verbiage  under  the  Ger  man  Penal  Code,  an  accessory  to  a  crime  is  equally  legally  responsible  with  the  main  culprit,  and  thus  a  person  accessory  to  murder  can  be  dealt;  with  exactly  as  the  murderer  himself.   In  September  last  year,  an  apparently  harm   less  amendment  to  the  Penal  Code  was  sneaked  through  parliament;  most  of  the  clauses  of  the  amendment  were  in  fact  perfectly  straightforward  minor  emendations  dealing  with  cases  of  unclear  wording  and  similar  deficiencies.   One  clause;  however,  which  was  represented  to  parliament  as  a  method  of  relieving  minor  offenders—traffic  offenders,  for  Instance—of  over  severe  penalties,  vitally  amended  Paragraph  50   of  the  Penal  Code.   Under  the  old  version  of  this  paragraph,  accessories  were  equally  responsible  wilh  the  main  culprit;  in  the  amended  version,  accessories  were  allotted  a  lesser  share  of  legal  responsibility  unless  it  could  be  shown  that  they  were  acting  "from  base  motives  or  with  malice  aforethought".   It  is  today  clear  that  this  clause  was  inserted  by  pro-Nazi  legal  draftsmen,  who  wished  to  create  a  loophole  for  Nazi  offenders;  but  the  catch  was  not  spotted  by  legislators,  and  the  .amendment  passed  parliament  without  challenge.
snippet: By a cunning legal trick, West German lawmakers appear to have sneaked through the West German parliament a law amendment which, unless rescinded, may release from prosecution

heading: German Circus
article_text: German  Circus   The  program  of  the  German  National  Circus,  which  should  accurately  be  called  the  Mun  ich  Circus,  fell  short  of  its  expectations  in  more  than  one  way.   While  their  printed  program  promised  a  number  of  animal  acts,  only  two  were  presented,  throwing  the  balance  to  the  side  of  acrobatic  acts.  They  were  precise,  but  not  ingenious.   Altogether  the  show  moved  too  slowly  and  lacked  humor.  The  clown  act  (“Oscar”  win  ning,  according  to  the  pro  gram)  would  have  been  “old”  thirty  years  ago.   Some  of  our  local  circuses  have  produced  slicker  shows.

heading: GERMAN SECURITY
article_text: GERMAN  SECURITY   JERUSALEM  (JTA):  62  countries  have  agreed  to  let  West  German  security  agents  be  stationed  at  their  airports,  according  to  Lufthansa  of  ficials.  Some  guards  have  al  ready  taken  up  their  assign   According  to  Axel  Linner,  a  public  relations  officer  of  Lufthansa,  the  only  refusals  had  come  from  the  Soviet  Union,  Poland,  Czechoslo  vakia,  Hungary,  Bulgaria  and  Rumania.  The  decision  to  station  guards  at  the  air  ports  had  been  taken  jointly  by  the  West  German  Go  vernment  and  Lufthansa.   Linner,  now  on  a  private  visit  to  Israel,  said:  “We  hope  to  show  all  airlines,  including  El  AI,  that  the   answer  to  the  terrorist   threat  lies  in  thorough  se  curity  controls  on  the  grounds."  Aat  the  airports,  the  agents  will  carry  out  checks  and  inspect  every  item  closely  that  is  carried  on  board,  including  food.

heading: German rocket
article_text: German  rocket   The  Australian  War  Memorial's  largest  relic,  a  World  War  II  German  V2  rocket,  complete  with  original  trailer,  is  removed  yesterday  from  a  storage  shed  at  the  Royal  Military  College,  Duntroon,  by  staff  of  the  memorial,  Mr  Bill  Hamilton,  left,  and  Mr  Col  Wise.  The  rocket  is  to  be  stored,'along  with  other  items,  in  the  memorial's  new  $2  million  conservation  and  storage  complex  at  Mitchell,   which  will  be  opened  at  9.30am  today  by  the  Minister  for  Home  Affairs,  Mr  Ellicott.
snippet: The Australian War Memorial's largest relic, a World War II German V2 rocket, complete with original trailer, is removed yesterday from a storage shed at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, by staff of the memorial, Mr Bill Hamilton, left, and Mr Col Wise. The rocket is to be stored, along with other items, in the memorial's new $2 million conservation and storage complex at Mitchell,

article_text: Mr  Marvin  Miller  and  his  bride,  formerly  Miss  Clarice  Hill,  centre,  receive  final  mar  riage  rites  at  the  foot  of  a  burning  cross  in  a  Ku  Klux  wedding  in  Lewisburg,  Ohio,  on  Saturday.  —  AAP-AP  cable  picture.   German  submarines   LONDON,  Tuesday  (AAP).  —  West  Germany  has  been  given  clearance  to  build  ocean-going  sub  marines  of  up  to  1,800  tons  for  the  first  time  since  the  U-boats  of  World  War  II,  The  Times  repor  ted  today,  Associated  Press   said.   It  said  one  of  the  main  restrictions  on  re-arma  ment  accepted  by  West  Germany  when  it  joined   the  Western  alliance  in  1954  was  lifted  by  the  council  of  the  Western  European  Union  which  comprises  Britain,  France,  Italy,  Benelux  and  Ger   many.   The  authorisation  will  enable  Germany  to  con  struct  submarines  capable  of  patrolling  over  the  whole  of  the  North  Sea  and  part  of  the  Atlantic,  The  Times  said.

heading: GERMAN SHEPHERDS
article_text: GERMAN  SHEPHERDS   There  has  been  a  noticeable  increase  in  the  popularity  of  German  Shepherds  in  Dampier  and  Karratha  This  animal  is  an  attractive  and  faithful  friend.  For  persons  with  newly-acquired  pets  and  also   persons  coming  into  W.A.  from  other  states  with  the  breed  I  wish  to  offer  some  advice.  1.  Pups  should  only  be  purchased  from  accredited  kennels.  2.  Animals  must  be  sterilized  before  entering  the  state  to  conform  with  the  Agricultural  Department  Law.  3.  Animals  must  be  tattooed  and  registered  with  the  Department  of  Agriculture.  4.  The  pet  must  be  enclosed  in  an  escape  -  proof  area,  garden  or  backyard  with  a  fence  not  less  than  4  foot  high  (1.2m).  5.  The  garden  area  or  yard  should  be  large  enough  to  allow  a  pet  plenty  of  room  for  exercise  which  will  assist  him  in  growth.  6.  The  animal  must  always  be  on  a  lead  when  being  taken  for  a  walk.  7.  When  thinking  of  obtaining  a  German  Shepherd  keep  in  mind  the  following  points,  good  stock,  sterilized,  vaccinated  against  distemper,  breed  has  no  history  of  hip  delexsia  or  arthritis.  8.  Points  to  look  for  in  the  animal's  appearance,  temperament,  stance,  animal  should  sit  well  -  not  splayed,  correct  colour,  i.e.  black  and  gold,  silver  sable  or  all  black,  ears  should  be  in  proportion  to  head,  nose  should  not  be  pointed.   R.S.P.C.A.  Inspector,  W.  Davenport.
snippet: There has been a noticeable increase in the popularity of German Shepherds in Dampier and Karratha This animal is an attractive and faithful friend.

heading: GERMAN VIEW
article_text: GERMAN  VIEW   He  said  that  during  one  of  Aj   his  lectures  on  the  book  a;   .  man  in  the  audience  got  up  ,w   and  said  that  he  had  been  a  Nazi  and  only  now  did  he   realise  for  the  first  time  .   how  wrong  he  had  been.  R   Fest’s  book  is,  of  course,  a  German’s  interpretation  of  the  Hitler  period  which   makes  it  even  more  in  teresting.  In  fact,  Fest,  the  editor  of  Albert  Speer’s  memoirs  and  the  author  of  the  book,  “The  Faces  of  the  '  Third  Reich'’,  was  asked  to   do  the  biography  by  New  York  publisher,  William  Jovanovich  who  was   specifically  looking  for  a   German  view.   The  48-year-old  Fest  said  that  he  had  always  wanted  to  do  something  about  this  period.   He  explained  -that  his  family  was  persecuted  by  the  Nazis  since  his  father  .had  belonged  to  anti-Nazi  parties  and  had  lost  his  Job   as  an  educator  after  Hitler  came  to  power.   Fest  himself  was  drafted  .  into  an  aircraft  battery  unit  at  the  age  of  15  and  two  years  later  was-captured  by  the  U.S.  Army  and  spent  }the  final  two  years  of  the  :war  as  a  POW.   The  book  itself  is  one  that   deserves  reading  by  .anyone  interested  in  the  Nazi  era  and  how  a  man  like  Hitler  could  take  control  of  a  major  nation.   As  a  book  on  Hitler  it  desetves  a  place  along  with  Allan  Bullock’s  “Hitler:  A  Study  in  Tyranny”  and  William  Shirer’s  “The  Rise  and  Fall  of  the  Third   Reich”  v   .  The  translation  by   Richard  and  Clara  Winston   is  well  done  and  the  book?  reads  smoothly  unlike  the  usual  ponderous  style  that  seems  to  be  typical  of  books-  translated  from  German.

Walter  Sdieel  of  West  Germany  rebuffed  a  Libyan  attempt  last  week  to  improve  relations  with  West  Germany  at  Israel’s   expense.   During  a  visit  to  Bonn.  Major  .  Adbul  Salam  Jal  loud,  the  Libyan  Prime  Minister,  hinted  that  West'  Germany  was  dependent  on  Libyan  oil  supplies  ahd  she  might,  accordingly,  re  consider  her  support  for  Israel.   He  added,  the.  Arabs  would  regain  all  territories  now  occupied  by  Israel,  even  if  it  took  20  years.   Replying,  Mr.  "  Scheel  said  that  the  West  Ger  man  Government  hoped  for  improved  relations  with  the  Arab  countries,  but  pointed  out  that  links  with  Israel  could  not  be  impaired.   Later  Major  Jalloud  met  Chancellor  Brandt,  who  explained  his  view  that  Middle  East  peace  was  possible  only  on  the  basis  of  the  existence  and  security  of  all  peoples  of  the  region.

Germany  is  economic  ally  self-sufficient  and  mot  dependent  on  Arab  capital.   2.  Germany  -  maintains   the  closest  ties  with  the  U.S.A.  and  is  influenced   by  American  policy.   3.  Public  opinion  in  Ger  many  is  friendly  towards  Israel. article_text: GERMAN  DISCUSSIONS   PEKING,  Monday  (AAP-Reuter).  —  The  for  mer  West  German  Foreign  Minister,  Dr  Schroeder,  held  a  second  round  of  talks  with  China's  Vice  Foreign  Minister,  Mr   Chiao  Kuaii-hua  in  Pe  king  today.   Dr  Schroeder  arrived  in  Peking  on  Saturday.   He  is  the  first  West  German  politician  to  visit  China  since  the  founding   of  the  people's  republic  in   1949.   Dr  Schroeder  is  chair  man  of  the  foreign  affairs  policy  committee  in  the  Bundestag  and  Shadow  Foreign  Minister*

heading: WEST GERMAN CALL
article_text: WEST  GERMAN  CALL   BONN:  West  Germany  will  not  consider  including  the  Palestine  Liberation  Organisation  in  a  European-Arab  dialogue  unless  the  PLO  accepts  Israel’s  existence  within  secure  borders  and  renounces  terrorism.   This  statement  was  made  in  an  interview  with  a  Paris  newspaper  by  the  Bonn  Chancellor,  Mr.  Helmut  Schmidt.   He  said  in  the  interview,  with  the  Paris  daily  Le  Figaro:  “So  long  as  the  PLO  has  not  taken  an  unam  biguous  stand  on  two  points,  namely  as  far  as  Israel’s  existence  within  safe  borders  and  the  renounciation  of  terror  acts  are  concerned,  I  cannot  seriously  put  this  question  to  myself”,  Chancellor  Schmidt  said  when  asked  about  PLO  participation.   Mr.  Schmidt,  who  visited  Paris  recently,  added  that  West  Germany  had  understanding  for  the  needs  of  the  Palestinians,  but  understanding  them  and  including  the  PLO  in  the  planned  dialogue  were  two  entirely  different  things.
snippet: BONN: West Germany will not consider including the Palestine Liberation Organisation in a European-Arab dialogue unless the PLO accepts Israel’s existence within secure borders and

heading: German aid pact
article_text: German  aid  pact   BONN,  (JTA):  The  German  Federal  Republic  is  to  provide  Israel  with  DM  140  million  In  capital  aid  for  1975  under  an  agreement  signed  today   in  Bonn.   The  assistance,  at  the  same  level  as  in  pre  vious  years,  will  be  used  mainly  to  finance  hous  ing  and  telephone  projects.  Part  of  it  will  go  to  Israel's  Industrial  Development  Bank.   A  six-man  Knesset  delegation,  led  by  Speaker  Yisrael  Yeshayahu,  visited  the  former  Nazi  con  centration  camp  in  Dachau  on  its  little  publicised  but  politically  significant  eight-day  tour  of  West  Gerriiany  and  West  Berlin.
snippet: BONN, (JTA): The German Federal Republic is to provide Israel with DM 140 million in capital aid for 1975 under an agreement signed today in Bonn.

German   consul   NEW  DELHI,  Wednesday   (AAP).  —  India  would   establish  consular-level  relations   with  East  Germany   but  had  ruled  out  formal   diplomatic  recognition,  the   West  German  ambassador  to  India  said  today,  the  .Associated  Press  reported. heading: E. German sentences
article_text: E.  German  sentences   EAST  BERLIN,  Sunday  (AAP-Rcuter).  -  An  East  German  court  has  sentenc  ed  two  Austrians  to  long  terms  of  imprisonment  for  helping  East  Germans  es  cape  to  the  West,  the  of  ficial  East  German  news  agency  reported  yesterday.   The  Schwerin  '  district  court  sentenced  Mr  Karl  Vala  to  the  maximum  15   year  sentence  for  "anti   State  human  trafficking"  and  Mr  Walter  Gerula  to  11  years.   In  the  past  few  months  48  West  _  Germans  and   West  Berliners  have  been  sentenced  in  East  Germany  for  the  same  offence,  but  the  case  of  the  two  Aus  trians  was  the  first  trial  of  non-German  citizens  re   ported  known  in  East  Ber  lin,  observers  said.   It  was  also  only  the  sec  ond  known  time  that  the  maximum  sentence  had  been  handed  down.  Not  all  cases  are  officially  re  ported,  and  last  December  a  young  Dutch  girl  receiv  ed  a  two-year  sentence  in  Erfurt  for  trying  to  smug  gle  her  boyfriend  out,   sources  said.

heading: Historic German accord
article_text: Historic  German  accord   The  convincing  win  of  Chancellor  Willy  Brandt's  ruling  coalition  in  the  November  19  West  German  elections  strongly  confirms  the  present  tendency  to  detente  in  Europe.   Brandt  s  success  was  particularly  sig  nificant  coming  as  it  did  immediately  following  the  initialling  of  his  govern  ment's  new  treaty  with  the  German  De  mocratic  Republic.  Conservative  opinion  in  West  Germany  is  notoriously  neural  gic  over  questions  of  relations  with  the  GDR.  The  fact  that  Brandt  was  so  strongly  confirmed  in  power  just  after  such  a  bold  step  had  been  taken  to  improve  relations  between  the  two  Germanys  says  much  for  the  profound  and  positive  changes  now  taking  place  in  West  Ger  man  opinion  on  external  policies.  One  can  gain  some  idea  of  the  extent  to  which  the  realities  of  power  are  chang  ing  attitudes  in  the  modern  world  by  re  calling  certain  past  attitudes  expressed  by  spokesmen  for  the  two  sides  in  Ger  many.  For  example,  Herr  Brandt  himself,  who  in  the  election  staked  his  fate  as  Chancellor  on  his  Ostpolitik  of  improv  ing  relations  with  the  East,  including  the  GDR,  said  in  West  Berlin  on  September  5,  1963:  "The  Ulbricht  regime  is  a  cancerous  tumor  in  the  bosom  of  the  German  peo  ple.  It  must  be  eliminated."  The  present  leader  of  the  GDR's  Soc  ialist  Unity  Party,  Herr  Erich  Honecker,  said  in  March,  1971:  "The  term  inter-German  (  innerdeutch  )  is  nothing  but  a  new  variant  of  the  West  German  spirit  of  fevanchism  against  the  GDR."  As  reported  by  the  GDR  newsagency,  ADN,  the  new  treaty  consists  of  a  pre  amble  and  10  articles.  In  it  the  two  parties  proceed  from  their  responsibility  for  the  maintenance  of  peace,  from  their  endeavour  to  make  a  contribution  to  detente  and  security  in  Europe,  as  well  as  from  historic  facts.  The  GDR  and  the  FRG,  according  to  article  one,  shall  "develop  normal  good-  neighborly  relations  with  each  other  on  the  basis  of  equal  rights."  In  article  two  they  stipulate  that  they  "shall  be  guided  by  the  purposes  and  principles  laid  down  in  the  Charter  of  the  United  Nations,  in  particular  the  sovereign  equality  of  all  states,  respect   for  independence,  autonomy  and  terri  torial  integrity,  the  right  to  self-deter  mination,  the  protection  of  human  rights  and  non-discrimination."  Article  three  stipulates  that  in  ac  cordance  with  the  United  Nations  Char  ter  the  GDR  and  the  FRG  "shall  settle  their  disputes  only  by  peaceful  means   and  refrain  from  the  threat  or  use  of  force."  "They  affirm  the  inviolability  now  and  in  the  future  of  the  frontier  exist  ing  between  them  and  undertake  to  fully  respect  each  other's  territorial  integrity."  On  this  point  the  preamble  to  the  treaty  says  "that  the  inviolability  of  the   frontiers  and  respect  for  the  territorial  integrity  and  sovereignty  of  all  states  in  Europe  within  their  present  frontiers  are  a  basic  prerequisite  for  peace."  A  supplementary  protocol  on  article  three  lays  down  the  formation  of  a  com  mission  of  authorised  representatives  of  the  Governments  of  the  two  states.  This  commission  "will  examine  the  marking  of  the  frontier  existing  between  the  two  states  and,  if  need  be,  renew  or  comple  ment  it  as  well  as  work  out  the  necessary  documentations  on  the  delimitation  of  the  frontier."  Other  articles  of  the  treaty  say  "that  neither  of  the  two  states  may  represent  the  other  in  international  affairs  or  act  on  its  behalf."  The  GDR  and  the  FRG  shall  promote  peaceful  relations  between  the  European  states  and  contribute  to  security  and  cooperation  in  Europe  and  support  ef  forts  designed  to  bring  about  arms  limi  tation  and  disarmament.  The  contracting  parties  "proceed  from  the  principle  that  the  sovereign  power  of  either  state  shall  be  confined  to  its  respective  territory.  They  shall  respect  the  independence  and  autonomy  of  either  state  in  its  internal  and  external  affairs."  The  GDR  and  the  FRG  declare  their  readiness  "to  settle  practical  and  human  itarian  matters  as  they  normalise  their  relations."  On  this  point  article  seven  provides  for  agreements  to  develop  co  operation  in  the  fields  of  the  economy,  science  and  technology,  traffic,  legal  rela  tions,  posts  and  telecommunications,  health,  culture,  sports,  environmental  protection  and  other  fields.  Details  have  been  settled  in  a  supplementary  proto  col  .  Both  states  shall  exchange  permanent  representations  which  shall  be  establish  ed  at  the  seat  of  the  respective  govern-  '  ment.  ;  f  The  GDR  arid  the  FRG  are  agreed  "that  bilateral  and  multilateral  inter  national  treaties  and  agreements  con  cluded  earlier  by  them  or  concerning  them  shall  not  be  affected  by  this  treaty."  Both  German  states  are  now  expected  to  make  application  to  join  the  United  Nations,  and  to  be  admitted  formally  as  members  on  September  18,  1973,  open  ing  date  of  the  next  General  Assembly.

heading: German bank closed
article_text: German   bank  closed   BONN,  Thursday  (AAP  Rcuter).  —  The  collapse  of  one  of  West  Germany's  biggest  private  banks  has  given  rise  to  fears  that  other  banking  institutes  may  have  run  into  diffic  ulties,  threatening  the  sav  ings  of  tens  of  thousands  of  West  Germans.   Bankhaus  Herstatt  KG,  of  Cologne,  was  officially  or  dered  to  cease  business  yes  terday  and  turn  in  its  bank  ing  licence  because  it  had  run  up  heavy  losses  in  foreign  exchange  deals.   The  move,  ordered  by  the   Federal  Supervisory  Office  for  the  Banking  Industry  and  announced  by  the  Central  Bank,  immediately  prompted  speculation  that  Herstatt  was  not  the  only  bank  in  trouble  over  foreign  exchange  trans  actions.   The  Central  Bank  an  nouncement  said  Herstatt's   losses  —  unofficially  estimated   to  total  the  equivalent  of  about  SA52.8  million,  were  caused  by  forward  exchange  deals,  a  form  of  currency  speculation.   Herstatt,  a  private  company  founded  19  years  ago,  was  ordered  to  wind  up  business  just  one  day  after  the  Central  Bank  announced  new  rules  tightening  surveil  lance  of  forward  exchange  operations.  These  are  due  to  take  effect  on  Tuesday.   LONDON,  Thursday  (AAP-Reuter).  —  The  West  German  mark  weakened  sharply  yesterday  in  late,  ner  vous  European  currency  trading  following  news  that  the  bank  had  "been  ordered  to  stop  trading.

heading: German takes slalom
article_text: German   takes  slalom   FALLS  CREEK,  Fri  day.  —  West  German  skier  Christian  Neureu  ther  proved  himself  the  most  successful  Olympic  racer  to  compete  in  Aus  tralia  when  he  won  the  Ross  Milne  Memorial  Slalom  at  Falls  Creek  to  day.   Neureuther,  22,  over  came  the  handicap  of  badly  damaged  ankles  to  record  a  mammoth  margin  of  1.17  scconds  against  a  field  which  includpd  42  over  seas  Olympic  racers.   The  win  made  him  the  first  skier  to  win  three  international  events  in  Australia.

But  the  Transport  Work  ers  Union  said  that  the   airline's  figure  was  in-  '  tinted  and  th:it  only  10  of  the  scheduled  90  to  100  aircraft  managed  to  take  off  from  Frankfurt. heading: GERMAN RIFT DEVELOPS
article_text: GERMAN  RIFT  DEVELOPS   EAST  BERLIN,  Wednesday  (AAP  Reuter).  -  A  major  crisis  in  relations  between  the  two  Germanys  loomed  to  day  as  East  Germany  cancelled  a  first  round  of  important  new  negotiations   between  them.   A  foreign  ministry  spokesman  con  firmed  that  talks  planned  to  begin  in   East  Berlin  this  afternoon  on  a  new   motorway  from  Berlin  to  Hamburg  had  been  called  off.   He  gave  no  reasons,  but  it  appeared  the  cancellation  could  be  linked  with  Monday's  vigorous  East  German  pro  test  to  Bonn  over  West  Germany's  han  dling  of  last  weekend's  25th  anniversary  of  the  East  German  uprising.

heading: Important German venture
article_text: Important  German   venture   Jl  COMPANY  to  pro   duce  automatic  transmissions  lor  Euro   pean  vehiclc  manufac  turers  has  been  formed  by-  Zahnradfabrik  Friedrichshafcn  AG,  West  Germany,  and  Borg-Warner  Corpora  tion,  Chicago.   This  followed  the  sign  ing  of  a  final  agreement  between  the  two  com  panies.   The  new  company,  ZF  Borg-Warner  G.m.b.H.,  will  represent  a  total  in  vestment  of  about  $US40  million,  according  to  the   chairman  of  Borg-Warncr,  Mr  R.  S.  Ingcrsoli.   ZF  Borg-Warncr  will  build  a  plant  in  West  Germany  which  is  sche  duled  to  be  in  operation  early  in  1972.  A  joint  technical  team  has  already  begun  activities  in  Fricd   richshafen.   At  full  production  the  plant  will  have  a  capacity  of  about  300,000  trans  missions  a  year  and  will  employ  about  2,000  people.   The  board  of  directors  will  have  an  equal  num  ber  of  representatives  from  ZF  and  Borg-Warncr.   European  demand  for  automatic  transmissions  is  expected  to  grow  rapidly   in  lhe  1970s,  Mr  Ingersol!   said.   Marketing  forecasts  esti  mated  that  40  per  cent  to  50  per  cent  of  new  Euro  pean  cars  will  be  equipped  with  automatic  transmis  sions  by  1975  compared  with  lhe  current  level  of  10  per  cent.   Borg  -  Warner  already  supplies  automatic  trans  missions  for  80  models  or  makes  of  cars  and  vans  produced  by  manufac  turers  outside  the  US,  mostly  European  com  panies.   Zahnradfabrik  Friedrich  shafen's  annual  sales  are  $230  million  and  Borg  Warner's  1969  sales  totalled  $1,086  million.

heading: German soccer coach?
article_text: German  soccer   The  Papua  New  Guinea  Football  Association  hopes  to  gain  a  West  German  soccer  coach  at  the  world  soccer  congress  in  June.  The  PNGFA  president,  Mr  Sali,  said  the  association  would  send  delegates  to  the  congress  where  the  matter  would  be  brought  up.  Mr  Sali,  who  is  also  a  Minister  for  State,  said  he  personally  wanted  a  West  German  coach.  Last  week  a  group  of  soccer  officials  said  they  wanted  to  recruit  an  overseas  soccer  coach  to  improve  the  sport  here.  They  said  the  man  would  cost  up  to  $12,000  a  year  but  were  convinced  the  money  could  be  found.

heading: Dunstan's German idea
article_text: punstan's  German  idea   Bv  John  Playford   nurinff  his  12-day  visit  to  West  Ger-  "  v  iii  January  of  this  year,  South  Australia's  Labor  Premier  Don  Dunstan  appears  to  have  become  infatuated  with   their  theory  or  wurKei  yai  m  management.  Returning  to  Adelaide,  he  soon  established  two  committees  to  in  vestigate  the  implementation  of  worker  participation  in  the  management  of  pub  lic  authorities  and  private  industry  in  South  Australia.  The  terms  of  reference  and  the  composition  of  these  bodies  have  not  yet  been  released,  although  it  is  known  that  a  number  of  social  scientists  are  closely  involved  in  the  whole  operation.  .  Membership  is-  said  to  include:  Prof.  G  M.  Badger,  Vice-Chancellor,  Univer  sity  of  Adelaide  and  a  member  of  the  Adelaide  Club;  Ian  Hay  ward,  Joint  Managing-Director  of  John  Martin  &  Co.  Ltd.,  Director  of  South  Australian  Insurance  Holdings  Ltd.,  and  also  a  member  of  the  Adelaide  Club;  J.  R.  Dri-  dan,  Chairman  of  the  Electricity  Trust  of  South  Australia;  John  Rob  bins,-  a  lec  turer  in  Politics,  University  of  Adelaide;  and  Jim  Shannon,  anti-communist  sec  retary,  S.A.  Trades  &  Labor  Council.  Machinery  for  worker  participation  in  management  has  been  introduced  by  government  legislation  in  West  Germany  on  a  wider  scale  than  any  other  ad  vanced  capitalist  country.  With  Chris  tian  Democratic  Union  and  Social  De  mocratic  Party  support  the  Codetermina-  tion  Law  was  passed  in  1951,  under  which  the  practice  was  instituted  in  the  coal  and  steel  industries.  Further  legis  lation  in  the  following  year  gave  legal  status  to  worker  participation  in  man  agement  in  all  private  and  public  com  panies.  The  ideology  built  around  codetermina-  tion,  known  as  Mitbestimmung,  was  an  attempt  to  narrow  political  and  econo  mic  differences  between  management  and  worker  to  compel  them  to  collabor  ate  in  the  factory,  thus  opening  the  way  to  the  harmonious  social  and  economic  reconstruction  of  postwar  West  Ger  many.  As  Herbert  J.  Spiro  wrote  in  The  Politics  of  German  Codetermination  (Harvard  University  Press,  1958):  "Co-  determination  became  a  vast  educational  scheme  designed,  over  a  period  of  years,  to  raise  the  workers'  level  of  understand  ing  and  thereby  to  help  bring  about  so  cial  peace  and  thus-  reduce  the  extent  of  the  sphere  of  political  conflict,  or  at  least  its  violence",  (p.  8).  The  evidence  shows  clearly  that  par  ticipation  leads  to  close  identification  with  management.  To  quote  from  Adolph  Sturmthal's  Workers'  Control  (Harvard  University  Press,  1964):  "But  the  change  was  not  automatically  one  to  a  system  of  democratic  partnership  but  rather  to  joint  paternalism.  The  significant  fact  is  that  in  many  cases  the  works'  coun  cil  has  joined  in  the  system  and  has  be  come  a  partner  in  a  management  team  which  administers  the  labor  force  of  the  enterprise  with  authority  and  benevol  ence."  (p.  68).  It  is  clear  that  managers  in  Germany  regard  worker  participation  in  manage  ment  as  a  means  to  reduce  the  influence  of  unions  inside  the  factory,  thereby  re  ducing  the  ability  of  workers  to  unite  in  presenting  demands  to  management.  The  famous  labour  lawyer  and  political  scientist  Franz  Neumann  wrote  in  Ger  many  and  the  Future  of  Europe,  edited  by  Hans  J.  Morgenthau  (University  of  Chicago  Press,  1952):  "It  has  become  in  creasingly  doubtful  to  me  if  any  program  of  codetermination  is  viable  and  desir  able,  and  I  have  become  more  and  more   convinced  that  in  reality  the  program  far  from  achieving  anything,  may  actu  ally  destroy  the  little  militancy  that  is  left  in  the  German  labor  movement."  (p.  103).  Participation  in  management  in  capi  talist  countries  is  essentially  an  experi  ence.  that  mystifies  the  workers  as  to  their  real  position.  Real  power  in  West  Germany  has  not  been  placed  in  the  hands  of  the  workers.  Management  still  take  all  important  policy  decisions;  the  factories  are  still  owned  by  the  share  holders;  the  workers  are  still  hired  labor.  Mitbestimmung  is  a  capitalist  theory  of  industrial  democracy,  the  latest  attempt  to  abandon  the  notion  of  class  struggle  and  to  entice  the  workers  away  from  socialism.  Understandably,  it  holds  considerable  attraction  for  the  technocratic  Premier  of  South  Australia  who  informed  the  Na  tional  Youth  Council  in  1969  that  "pri  vate  enterprise  is  a  meaningless  phrase"  and  who  asserted  before  the  American  Chamber  of  Commerce  in  Australia  in  1970  that  the  appropriation  of  private  capital  was  a  "totally  discredited  idea."

heading: German science pact
article_text: German  ^  science   pact   Australia  had  entered   into  a  scientific  and  .  technological  co-opera  tion  agreement  with  West  Germany,  the  Minister  for  Science,  Senator  Webster,  said  in  tha  Senate  yesterday.   The  agreement  was  tabled  after  Question  Time,  during  which  Sena  tor  Webster  told  Senator  Jessop  (Lib,  SA)  that  Australia  was  doing  a  great  deal  of  research  through  the  CSIRO  into  the  production  of  liquid   fuel  from  coal.   The  process  is  appar  ently  unique  to  Australia  and  West  German  scien  tists  recently  visited  Australia  to  study  the  research  pattern.   Pyrolysis  method   The.  research  was  being  concentrated  on  a  flash  pyrolysis  method  of  con  version  -  an  area  which  other  large  countries  were  not  investigating.   Senator  Webster  told  the  ?  Senate  that  he  had  opened  a  plant  for  the  CSIRO  within  the  past  few  weeks  designed',  to  cater  for  its  studies  into   the  matter.   He  believed  that  the  plant  would  result  in  a  saving  to  Australia  with  respect  to  heavy  oil  im  ports  and  prove  most  in  valuable  to  the  proposed  conversion  process.
snippet: Australia had entered into a scientific and technological co-operation agreement with West

heading: German Film Makers
article_text: German  Film  Makers   Two  leading  German  film  makers,  Ms  He|ma  Sanders  and  Mr.  Dieter  Hasemann,  will  visit  the  campus  "next  week.  Ms  Helma  Sanders  is  a  distinguished  film  maker  and  one  ôf  the  group  of  directors  of  the  New  German  Cinema  to  achieve  international  recognition.  Her  best  known  film  to  date  is  Shirin's  Wedding,  a  story  about  the  plight  of  a  "guestworker"  in  Europe,  a  Turkish  woman  who  comes  to  live  and  work  in  West  Germany.  This  film  has  won  the  Critic's  Prize  at  the  Locarno  Film  Festival  1976  and  was  successfully  premiered  in  Australia  at  last  year's  Sydney  Film  Festival.  Brian  Baxter  writes  about  Shirin's  Wedding:  "The  film's  quality  lies  in  its  resonances,  not  the  intellectual  arguments  (Ms  Sanders)  evoked  in  earlier  movies.  Helma  Sanders  has  directed  not  only  a  fierce  indictment  of  contemporary  Ger  :  many,  but  —  more  importantly  —  a  portrait  of  a  woman  at  the  mercy  of  society.  "Few  movies  have  so  sympathetically  and  systematically  chartered  the  decline  and  fall  of  a  human  being,  nor  as  accurately  related  them  to  the  responsible  society."  Helma  Sanders  will  be  on  campus  on  Friday,  April  24.  She  will  be  talking  about  her  films  and  film-making  in  Germany  at  2  p.m.,  at  the  Film  Centre,  Mechanical  Engineering  Building.  Shirin's  Wedding  will  be  screened  in  the  Film  Centre  at  4  p.m.  Mr.  Dieter  Haserhann,  who  is  accompanying  Ms  Sanders  on  her  visit  to  Australia,  is  a  producer  and  executive  of  PRO-KINO  Cinema  Co.  He  will  give  a  public  lecture  on  "The  Film  Industry  in  West  Germany:  Problems  and  Prospects"  on  Friday,  April  28,  at  1  p.m.,  Room  209  Morven  Brown  Building.  Since  German  film  makers  and   producers  share  many  problems  with  their  Australian  counterparts,  notably  the  competition  with  the  industrial  giants  of  the  U.S.,  Dieter  Hasemann's  talk  promises  to  provide  stimulating  insight  for  everybody  interested  in  films  and  the  cinema  industry  in  Australia.  Both  visits  are  sponsored  jointly  by  the  Schools  of  Drama  and  German.  Enquiries  ext.  2258  or  3436.
snippet: Two leading German film makers, Ms Helma Sanders and Mr. Dieter Hasemann, will visit the campus "next week. Ms Helma Sanders is a distinguished film

heading: CHINA German freed
article_text: CHINA   German   freed   HONG  KONG,  Sunday,  (AAP-Reuter).  -  China  has  released  a  German  businessman  20  years  after  sentencing  him  to  life  imprisonment  for  spying.   Mr  Hcinrich  Lipphardt,  63,  who  ran  a  business  in  north  China  until  the  communists  came  to  power  in  1949.  crossed  the  border  into  Hong  Kong  today.   The  West  German  con  s  u  1  ,  Mr  Ruprecht  Henatsch,  said  Mr  Lip  phardt  was  in  relatively  good  health  and  would  leave  for  West  Germany  as  soon  as  he  felt  fit  to  travel.   He  said  Mr  Lipphardt  had  been  arrested  by  the  Chinese  in  1954  after  being  found  guilty  of  spy  ing,  a  charge  he  had  de  nied.  He  had  been  sen  tenced  to  life  imprison  ment,  and  had  not  learned  of  his  release  until  four  days  ago.

heading: NZ, German relations
article_text: NZ,  German   relations   WELLINGTON,  NZ,  Friday  (AAP).  -  "The  signs  of  reconciliation  and  friendship  which  we  can  observe  in  New  Zealand  today  mean  a  lot  to  us  Germans",  the  President  of  West  Germany,  Mr  Scheel,  said  at  a  State  luncheon  in  his  honour  in  Wellington  today.   "We  do  not  efface  from  our  memory  what  has  happened  in  Germany  before",  he  said.  "We  are  aware  that  many  New  Zcalandcrs  died  on  the  bat  tlefield  in  two  wars  with  Germany  so  the  signs  of  reconciliation  and  friendship  which  we  can  observe  in  New  Zealand  today  therefore  mean  a  lot  to  us".   Mr  Scheel  said  also  that  developing  countries  must  be  given  a  chance  to  take  part  in  world  trade  as  partners  on  a  basis  of  equality.   "In  further  developing  the  world  economy,  the  highly  industrialised  countries  will  have  to  be  ready  to  modify  their  own  concepts  and  limit  their  own  expactations",  he  said.

heading: MIDDLE EAST German view (from the German Tribune, a weekly review of the German Press)
article_text: MIDDLE  EAST  ——————————————————————————   German  view    BY  WERNER  HOLZER   (from  the  German  Tribune,  a  weekly  review  of  the  German  Press)      Even  if  an  armistice  agreement  is  signed,  none  of  the  problems  that  have  made  the  Middle  East  a  continually  ticking  time  bomb  will  be  solved,  the  two  overwhelming  obstacles  to  peace  being  the  problem  of  the  homeless  Palestinians  and  the  Arabs’  hurt  pride  at  continually  sustaining  defeats  and  being  so  unable  to  help  themselves.     Israel’s  growing  reluctance  to  return  the  territories  occupied  in  1967  in  return  for  Arab  recognition  of  the  Jewish  state  is  likewise  an  ob-  stacle.   There  can  be  little  doubt  that  Israel’s  policy  in   recent  years  has  been  based  on  a  feeling  of  such  military  superiority  over  the  other  side  that  Jerusalem  was  intent  on   itself  deciding  the  form  possible  negotiations  were  to  take  and  the  extent  to  which  they  were  to  go.   The  Arab  governments  have  not  played  ball,  and  even  if  they  and  Israel  had  reached  agreement  on  negotiations  there  would  still  be  the  Palestinians,  who  are  operating  in-  creasingly  independently  and   ever  more  intently  on  destroying  the  Jewish  State.   The  Palestinians  (and  for  long  enough  the  Arab,  governments  too)  have  invariably  counted  on  massive  Soviet  support,  much  as  Israel  has  relied  on  continuing  aid  from  the  United  States.   In  Cairo  and  Damascus,  not  to  mention  other  Arab  capitals,  growing  doubts   have  for.  some  time  arisen  as  to  the  disinterested  nature  of  Soviet  support.  There  was  an  uneasy  and  not  entirely  unjustifiable  feeling  that  continuation  of   the  current  situation  midway  between  war  and  peace  was  probably  most  in  accord  with  Soviet  in-  terests  and  intentions.   Israel,  on  the  other  hand,  has  thus  far  shunned  serious  consideration  of  the  prospect  of  a  change  in  relations  with  its  major  ally.   Over  the  past  year  it  may  have  grown  obvious  enough  that  the  United  States  is   heading  towards  an  energy  crisis  that  will  no  longer  allow  it  to  enter  into  major  conflict  with  the  Arab  oil  exporting  countries,  yet  Mrs.  Meir’s  government  seems  unwilling  to  acknowledge  that  the  resulting  political  con-  sequences  for  Israel  could  prove  unforeseeable.     MUTUAL     At  all  events  there  are  growing  indications  that  Washington  is  at  least  as  strongly  interested  in  detente  with  the  Soviet  Union  and  unhindered  petroleum  supplies  as  it  is  in  good  relations  with  Israel.   This  being  the  case,  there  is  little  point  in  concluding  a  new  armistice  agree-  ment  in  the  Middle  East  without  at  the  same  time  making  a  genuine  attempt  to  reach  fundamental   solutions  —  an  attempt  that  must  be  made  by   both  sides.   Israel  will  not,  of  course,  want,  to  hear  anything  of  the  necessity,  and  it  will  be  up  to  the  Arab  govern-   ments  to  convince  the  Palestinian  leaders  that  their  hopes  of  total  destruction  of  the  Jewish  State  will  never  be  fulfilled,  the  conclusion  being  that  there  will  have  to  be  a  negotiated  solution,  albeit  one  that  takes  Palestinian   interests  into  accounts.
snippet: Even if an armistice agreement is signed, none of the problems that have made the Middle East a continually ticking time Bomb will be solved, the two overwhelming

heading: E. German escaper caught
article_text: E.  German   escaper   caught   ESSEN,  West  Germany,  Tuesday  (AAP).  —  A  26  year-old  escaper  from  East  Germany  was  ordered  to  be  held  on  a  West  German  ar  rest  warrant  yesterday  for  the  killing  of  two  East  Ger  •man  border  guards,  the  Essen  prosecutor  announc   ed.   Mr  Werner  Weinhold.  described  as  a  former  East  German  soldier,  was  picked  up  on  Sunday  night  in  the  Westphalian  city  of  Marl,  where  he  was  attempting  to  contact  relatives  two  days  after  fleeing  over  the  East  German  border  into  Ba  varia.   The  prosecutor  said  Mr  Weinhold  was  being  held  under  suspicion  of  two  eases  of  murder  and  other  crimes.   The  official  East  German  news  agency  ADN  said  East  Berlin  officials  had  de  manded  Mr  Weinhold's  extradition.

heading: GERMAN PLAN FOR REFORMS
article_text: GERMAN  PLAN  FOR  REFORMS   ?UNITED  NATIONS,  Wednesday  (AAP-Reuter).  -  .The  West  German  Foreign  Minister,  Mr  Genscher,  proposed  yester  day  a  nine-point  program  to  reform  the  world  economy.   In  an  address  to  the  UN  special  session  on  economic  problems,  he  suggested  that:   The  markets  o£  the  indus   trialised  countries  should  .  .  be  opened,  more  than  in   the  past,  to  the  products  o  f  _t  h  e  developing  countries,  in  particular  to  processed  products.   Commodity  export  earnings   of  the  individual  develop  ing  countries,  should  be  stabilised.   Excessive  commodity  price  -  fluctuations  should  be   prevented.   A  continuous  commodity   supply  should  be  ensured.   Industrialisation  in  the   developing  countries  should  be  accelerated  by  industrial  and  _  tech  nological  co-operation.   The  transfer  of  technology   from  the  industrialised  to  the  developing  countries  should  be  facilitated  and  improved.   Food  production  in  the   developing  countries  should  be  vigorously  in  creased.   The  flow  of  capital  to  the   developing  countries,  par  ticularly  to  the  poor  countries,  should  be  in  creased.   The  International  Monetary   .  Fund  should  aim  to  '  improve  world  trade  and   preserve  monetary  values.   Australia  backs  exchange   rates  plan.  -  Page  21.

heading: E. German team wins
article_text: E.  German  team  wins   ROTTERDAM,  Thurs  day,  (AAP-ReuterY  —  FC  Magdenburs  emphasised  past  Germany's  cmergenco  as  a  major  soccer  nation  last  night  when  it  won  tha  European  Cup  Winner's  Cup  from  AC  Milan,  of  Italy.   The  young  German  team,  which  started  as  clear  out  sider,  won  2-0.   Milan  had  won  the  trophy  twice  in  the  past  seven  years  and  was  vastly  more  ex  perienced  in  international  soccer  than  its  opponent.   MED1ELL1N,  Colombia,  Thursday  (AAP).  —  The  Chilean  soccer  team  tied  4-4  with  Colombia's  champion  team  Atletico  Nacional  last  night,  after  trailing  3-U  ;it   half  time.   Chile,  which  will  play  against  East  and  West  tier  many  and  Australia  in  the  World  Cup,  played  a  me  diocre  first  half  but  improved  remarkably  in  the  second.

heading: CONGRATULATIONS TO GERMAN CHANCELLOR
article_text: CONGRATULATIONS  TO  GERMAN  CHANCELLOR   The  Executive  Council  of  Australian  Jewry  (ECAJ)  has  sent  con  gratulations  to  West  German  Chancellor  Helmut  Schmidt  following  the  rescue  of  hijacked  hostages.  _   The  ECAJ  president  Dr  Joachim  Schneeweiss,  asked  the  West  German  ambassador  in  Australia,  Dr  H.  Blomeyer  Bartenstein  to  forward  it  to  Bonn.   Dr  Schneeweiss  ex  pressed  “the  unbounded   admiration  of  my  com  munity  for  the  effective  and  courageous  manner  in  which  your  government  has  handled  the  recent  hijacking  of  a  German  airliner.”   “The  successful  outcome  of  the  resolute  action  of  your  government  should  go  far  in  helping  to  curtail  the  carnage  perpetrated  by  in  ternational  terror,  threatening  innocent  lives   and  the  safety  of  airline  systems  throughout  the  world,”  the  message  said.   “History  has  shown  that  any  compromise  with  terror  can  only  breed  fur  ther  excesses  and  lead  to  disaster  compounded.  ’  ’   The  ECAJ  president  stressed  that  “those  gover  nments,  which  have  not  succumbed  to  international   blackmail,  must  ultimately  pave  the  way  for  effective  moves  to  root  out  this  modern  scourge  with  single-minded  determin  ation.”   “Your  government’s  recent  action  in  Somalia  must  influence  others  to  act  in  concert  and  bring  about,  once  and  for  all,  coordinated  world  action  against  international  terrorism,’’  Dr  Schneeweiss  said.   He  also  expressed  the  Australian  Jewish  com  munity’s  sympathy  to  the  widow  and  family  of  the  murdered  Lufthansa  pilot.

heading: BEGIN, GERMAN ENVOY TALK
article_text: •  German  Ambassador  Klaus  Schuetz  emerging  from  his  meeting  with  Prime  Minister  Begin.  He  is  es  corted  by  Chief  of  Protocol   Rehavam  Amir.   BEGIN,  GERMAN   ENVOY  TALK   JERUSALEM:  Prime  Minister  Begin  met  with  the  German  Ambassador,  Klaus  Schuetz  —  the  first  time  the  Premier  has  con  ferred  with  a  German  en  voy.   The  two  discussed  the  Sadat  visit  here,  and  also  the  Europeans’  general  at  titude  to  the  Middle  East  conflict,  especially  the  Palestinian  aspect  of  it.   Schuetz  is  to  fly  to  Bonn  to  prepare  for  Foreign  Minister  Dayan’s  visit  there  this  week'.   Begin  asked  him  to  com  municate  Israel’s  positions  directly  to  Chancellor  HelmutSchmidt.   The  meeting,  at  the  Premier’s  bureau,  was  not  advertised  in  advance.   Photographers  waiting  outside  noticed  the  envoy  entering,  but  their  request  to  photograph  the  start  of  the  meeting  was  turned  down.   Until  becoming  premier.  Begin  had  shunned  almost  all  official  contact  with  the  German  embassy.   After  taking  office,  however.  Begin  let  it  be  known  that  he  would  not  now  maintain  his  ‘boycott’  of  Germany  and  that  he  would  welcome  highranking  German  visitors  with  all  due  respect.

heading: Argentinian rebels take German
article_text: Argentinian  rebels  take   German   BUENOS  AIRES,  Tuesday  (AAP-Reuter).  —  German  born  Mr  Herbert  Pilz.  an  executive  in  Argentina  of  the  Merccde  s-Benz  Motor  Company,  was  kidnapped  in  Buenos  Aires  on  Friday,  apparently  by  left-wing  urban  guerillas,  police  sources  said  yesterday.   The  sources  said  Mr  Pilz,  48,  was  taken  near  his  home  in  the  northern  suburb  of  Munro  early  on  Friday  as  he   was  driving  to  the  Mercedes-!  Bcnz  plant,  45  kilometres  (28  miles)  to  the  south.  Mr  P:lz  is  -production  manager.  I   The  sources  said  the  kid  nappers  later  got  in  touch  with  Mcrccdcs-Benz  and  identified  themselves  as  a  left-wing  guerilla  group,  but  did  not  say  which  one.   It  was  not  immediately  known  if  the  kidnappers  de  manded  a  ransom  or  set  any  conditions  for  the  release  of  '  Mr  Pilz.

heading: Visit of German MPs
article_text: Mr  Eugen  Glombig  (left)  and  Mr  Karl  Gcltlner   Visit  of  German  MPs   Two  members  of  the   German  Federal  Lower  House,  the  ^  Bundestag,  spent  yesterday  in  Can  berra  before  going  to  Sydney  for  the  12th  world  congress  of  the  International  Society  for  Rehabilitation  of  the  Disabled.   They  were  Mr  Eugen  Glombig  (Social  Demo   cratic  Party)  and  Mr  Karl  Geldner  (Free  Democratic  Party),  who  are  members  of  the  Bundestag's  Labour  and  Social  Welfare  Com  mittee.   Mr  Glombig,  who  is  dis  abled  in  both  legs  since  contracting  poliomyelitis  at  the  age  of  two,  said  that  German  Federal  law  did  not  co'ver  cases  such  as  his.   However,  since  World  War  I  there  had  been  leg  islation  io  force  employers  to  give  jobs  to  people  who  had  been  handicapped  through  injuries  from  war  or  from  travelling  to  or   from  work.

heading: Some German varieties WINE
article_text: Some  German  varieties   By  DAN  MURPHY   In  the  course  of  our  study  of   medium-priced  white  wines,  inevitably  we  must  come  across  the  average  quality  but  popular  German  wines  which  arc  available  in  so  many  bottle  shops.   Immediately  to  your  minds  will  spring  the  thought  that  the  ubi  quitous  Blue  Nun  Licbfraumilch  is  included  in  this  group,  but  one  could  hardly  call  a  wine  sold  at  S4.36  a  bottle  a  medium  priccd   wine.   Whatever  may  be  the  reasons,  the  fact  that  Blue  Nun  is  one  of  the  three  or  four  top  selling  wines  of  the  world  is  not  due  to  its  price.   Kenderman's  "Black  Tower"  Licbfraumilch  which  has  hecome  the  sccond-largcst  selling  Ger  man  wine  in  the  world,  for  the  very  same  reason,  cannot  be  nom  inated  as  a  medium-priced  wine.   This  month  Kcndcrman,  through  its  associated  company  —  Havcrmcycr  —  is  releasing  another  Licbfraumilch  callcd  Wild  Soar.  In  n  similar  "crock"  type  bottle,  it  will  sell  at  the  same  price  as  Black  Tower  (about  S3.60).   These  three  are  stereotyped  wines  of  fairly  high  quality  which  depend  for  their  success  on  the  continuity  of  their  style  and  stan  dard  from  year  to  year,  country  to  country  and  bottle  to  bottle.   Licbfraumilch  docs  not  comc  from  one  German  district.  It  can  be  a  blend  but,  whatever  the  case,  it  is  a  matter  of  German  Wine  Law  that  it  has  its  origin  either  in  the  Rhcinhcsscn,  Rhcingau,  Nahe  or  Rheinpfalz  districts  ol  the  Rhine  Valley.   The  quality  of  Licbfraumilch  can  be  varied  but  in  fact,  what  ever  the  brand  name  or  shipper,  the  standard,  the  flavour  and  the  quality  is  much  the  same  and  it  is  extremely  unlikely  that  an  Aus  tralian  palate  could  pick  at  a   -   A  selection  of  German  whites.   "blind"  tasting  one  brand  from   another.   ft  is  immensely  important,  therefore,  that  you  shop  around.  A  large  number  of  stores  in  the  capital  cities  have  Licbfraumilch  at  priccs  varying  from  SI.95  to  S2.50  a  bottle  which  makes  them  more  than  competitive  with  most  Australian  whites  in  a  similar  pricc  bracket  and  of  a  similar  style.   The  lowest  quality  German  whites  —  Tafclwein  —  do  not  seem  to  be  imported  into  Aus   tralia.   A  qualitatswein  must  come  from  a  particular  region,  be  made  from  certain  grape  varieties  and  have  an  alcoholic  strength  of  8'^  per  cent  by  volume.  Under  pres  ent-day  German  Wine  Law,  a  quality  wine  must  carry  the  name  of  the  vineyard,  vineyard  area  or   district.   Licbfraumilch  has  a  special  ruling.  It  must  be  a  qualitaiswcin  which  has  passed  the  test  and  has  an  official  examination  number.  Most  of  the  other  quality  wines   arc  district  wines,  that  is  wines  which  do  not  come  from  any  particular  maker  or  village  but  arc  from  anywhere  within  a  dis  trict  wfv'ch  imparts  a  similar  taste  to  all  its  wines.   Wc  might  say  that  the  Hunter  Valley  is  a  district  in  this  sense.  Such  a  district  or  particular  area  is  called  a  Bcrcich  and  if  the  label  docs  not  bear  the  name  of  the  vineyard  locality,  the  word  Bercich  must  appear  first  on  the  label.  We  might  say,  for  example,  that  Pokolbin  is  the  vineyard  locality  (or  grosslage)  in  the  dis  trict  (or  Bercich)  of  Hunter  Val  ley.   Most  of  the  cheaper  German  wines  (apart  from  Licb  fraumilch)  imported  into  Aus  tralia  are  district  or  Bercich  wines.  We  see,  accordingly,  such  names  as  Bcrcich  Nierstcin,  Bereich  Johannisberg,  Bereich  Bcrnkastel  and  so  on.  Many  of  these  arc  obtainable  at  from  S2.25  to  $2.75  a  bottle.   German  exporters  are  con  scious  of  the  fact  that  there  is  a   certain  hesitancy  among  English  speaking  wine  buyers  to  ask  for  a  wine  labelled  "Bcrcich  some  thing  or  other".  Before  the  new  German  Wine  Law,  wine  from  the  area  surrounding  the  village  of  Nicrstein  in  the  Rhcinhcssen   region  was  labelled  simply   "Niersteiner".   Now  it  must  be  called  Bcreich  Nicrstein.'   As  you  can  see,  I  am  not  trying  to  teach  you  the  intricacies  of  German  Wine  Law  but  merely  to  point  out  to  you  that  there  are  German  wines  on  the  market  which  might  have  queer  sounding  titles  but  are  very  good  and  ex  tremely  reasonable  in  price.   Fairly  familiar  names  to  Aus   tralians  are  Saar-Ruwer  and  Bcrnkastel  from  the  Moscl  Val   ley;  Nicrstein  and  Bingcn  from  the  Rhcinhcssen;  Johannisberg  from  the  Rhcingau.  Look  for  the  word  Bcrcich  before  these  names   today  and  you  will  know  that  the   label  describes  a  wine  from  grapes  grown  within  the  bound  aries  of  the  district  named.

heading: W. German's ski win
article_text: W.  German's  ski  win   CRANS-MONTANA,  Switzerland,  Wednesday  (AAP-Reuter).  -  West  German  Christian  Ncu  reuthcr  won  his  first  World  Ski  cup  race  for  five  years  in  Crans-Montana  yesterday  as  the  top  slalom  special  ists  skidded  to  defeat  on  a  hard-packed  track  in  the   Valais  Alps.   World  Cup-holder  Ingemar  Stenmark,  of  Sweden,  was  elminated  when  he  fell  on  the  first  of  two  legs  while  accelerating  to  make  up  for  time  lost  when  he  hit  gate  stakes  on  the  upper  section  of  the  course.   Switzerland's  Peter  Luescher,  leading  Stenmark  by  five  points  in  the  overall  World  Cup  standings,  also  fell  early  on  his  first  descent.  But  he  scrambled  to  his  feet  after  sliding  through  a  gate  on  his  back  and  stayed   in  the  race  to  finish  17th.

heading: GERMAN $12m. FOR REFUGEES
article_text: GERMAN  $12m.  FOR  REFUGEES   BONN:  West  Germany  has  contributed  a  total  of  $12  mil  lion  to  the  United  Nations’  Re  lief  and  Works  Agency  (Unrwa)  for  Palestine  refugees  in  20  years,  from  1950  to  1970,  a  spokesman  for  the  Govern  ment  revealed  here  last  week.   He  said  that  with  these  payments  Germany  ranked  sixth  among  the  82  States  which  made  contributions  to   the  organisation.   (JCNS)
snippet: BONN: West Germany has contributed a total of $12 million to the United Nations’ Relief and Works Agency

heading: German urban guerillas buried
article_text: The  chairman  of  the  German  Social  Democratic  Party,  Mr  Brandt,  behind  bullet-proof  glass  as  be  speaks  at  a  party  rally  in  Munich  on  Wednesday.   German  urban   guerillas   buried   STUTTGART,  Thursday  (AAP-Reuter).   —  Three  leaders  of  the  Baadcr-Meinhof  urban   guerilla  group  found  dead  in  jail  nine  days  ago  were  buried  in  Stuttgart  today  amid  strict  security  precautions.   About  1,000  armed  police  stood  by  as  an  estimated   2,000  sympathisers  shouted  slogans  alleging  the  three,  Mr  Andreas  Baader,  Mr  Jan  Carl  Raspc  and  Miss  Gudrun  Ensslin,  had  been  murdered.   The  authorities  said  that  the  two  men  shot  themselves   and  that  Miss  Ensslin  hanged  herself  in  a  suicide  pact  a  few  hours  after  learning  that  an  attempt   by  hijackers  of  a  West  German  airliner  to  force  their  release  had  failed.   At  a  short  service,  Pastor  Bruno  Streibcl  said  thai  for  some  people  the  three  had  destroyed  basic  values,  others  saw  them  as  fighters  for  humanity,  despite   the  destruction  they   did.   Some  of  the  sympathisers   wore  masks  and  red  carnations.
snippet: STUTTGART, Thursday (AAP-Reuter).—Three leaders of the Baader-Meinhof

heading: Fond of German flavor?
article_text: Fond  of  German   Hardy  and  Christa  Jesehe  of  Stirling  Cakes  are  hard  at  work  in  their  bakery  preparing  for  yet  another  Christmas.  Hardy's  specialities  include  good  bid-fashioned  ginger-bread  fashioned  into  Hansel  and  Gretel  houses.  If  you  like  a  German  flavor  on  your  Christmas  table,  try  Stollert,  or  if  you  want  to  stick  with  Christmas  cake  and  Christmas  pudding,  Hardy  and  Christa's  recipe  is  unbeatable.

heading: W. German spy inquiry
article_text: W.  German  spy  inquiry   BONN,  Wednesday  (AAP  Renter).  —  A  senior  govern  ment  official  defended  yes  terday  the  decision  to  give  a  Chancellery  job  to  Mr  Guen  ter  Guillaume,  whose  arrest  as  an  East  German  spy  led  to  the  resignation  of  the  for  mer  Chancellor,  Mr  Brandt,  last  May.   Dr  Ernst  Kern,  Mr  Guil  laume's  former  department  chief,  was  giving  evidence  at  the  first  of  a  series  of  public  hearings  before  an  all-party  parliamentary  committee  charged  with  investigating  the  spy  affair.   Dr  Kern  was  the  first  of  23  witnesses  the  committee  plans  to  call  this  week.

heading: HIJACK German on trial
article_text: HIJACK   German   on  trial  ,   FRANKFURT,  'west  Germany,  Tuesday,  (AAP  Reuter).  -  A  West  Ger  man  went  on  trial  at  Frankfurt  yesterday  on  air-piracy  charges,  15  months  after  allegedly  threatening  to  blow  up  a  Lufthansa  aircraft  on  its  way  to  Frankfurt  from   Lisbon.   Mr  Friedlielm  Schuetz.  31,  was  also  charged  with  threatening  the  Boeing  727  crew  with  what  appeared  to  be  a  bomb.   Police  said  that  during  the  flight,  in  October,  1972.  Mr  Scluietz  had  de  manded  1.000  marks  (about  $255),  a  getaway  car  and  safe  passage  with  four  hostages.   The  aircraft  landed  safely  in  Frankfurt  and  while  Mr  Schuetz  was  walking  to  the  getaway  car,  police  shot  him.  He  was  taken  to  hospital  and  charged  with  air  piracy.   Police  said  the  "bomb"  had  been  a  glass  filled  with  semi-liquid  soap.

heading: German police seize arms
article_text: German  police   seize  arms   HAMBURG:  Small  arms  and  ammunition,  presumably  supplies  for  El  Fatah  terror  ists  in  Lebanon,  were  seized  by  police  last  Week.   Forewarned  customs  of  ficials  at  the  airport  found  arms  and  ammunition  hidden  in  US-made  water-boilers  which  were  on  the  point  of  •  being  sent  to  Lebanon.  The   seized  cargo  included  about  4000  rounds  of  ammunition,  60  pistols,  two  sub-machine  guns  and  “walkie-talkie”  sets.   The  German  police  are  seeking  information  from  foreign  countries  in  their  search  for  the  alleged  arms  dealers,  a  spokesman  said.   (JCNS)
snippet: HAMBURG: Small arms and ammunition, presumably supplies for El Fatah terrorists in Lebanon, were seized

heading: German writer visits Canberra
article_text: German  writer  visits  Canberra   "My  mother  and  father  and  brother  were  murdered  by  the  Nazis",  Mr  Marcel  Reich-Rainicki  said  yesterday.  "I  suppose  I  escaped  by  a  near  xniracle.  That  is  all".   '  Mr  Reich-Rainicki,  a  leading  Geirnan  writer  and  literary  critic  arrived  in  Canberra  from  Hobart  yesterday  during  a  tour  of  the  cultural  and  literary  centres  of  Australia  and  New  Zealand.  He  will  leave  Canberra  on  Mon  day.  !   He  is  to  give  conferences  and  lectures,  and  conduct  seminars  at  universities  on  topics  such  as  'Literature  today  —  Why  and  for  Whom',  'German  Con  temporary  Writers  and  Polities',  and  'Literary  Life  in  a  Divided  Ger  many'.   His  tour  is  sponsored  by  tbe  Goethe  Institute  in  JVIu.th,  which  is  annually  sending  outstanding  repre  sentatives  of  the  German  contemporary  literary  scene  to  Australia  and  New  Zealand.   Mr  Reich-Rainicki  was  born  in  1920  in  the  Polish  town  o£  Wloclawek,  his  father  being  Polish  and  his  mother  German.  From  1929  the  family  lived  in   Berlin.   Deported  to   Poland   Shortly  after  he  gradu  ated  from  the  Fichte  Col  lege  in  Berlin  in  1938  the  family  became  victims  of  the  Hitlerian  policy,  Marcel  being  deported  to  Poland.  From  1940  to  1943  he  lived  in  the  ghetto  of  Warsaw,  where,  mirac  ulously,  he  managed  to  escape  th*  terror  of  the   SS.   Mr  Reich-Rainicki   After  the  war  he  began  working  as  a  freelance  writer  and  lecturer  for  a  publishing  house  in  Poland,  with  German  literature  as  his  main  interest.   He  began  to  publish  editions  in  Polish  of  Goethe,  Fontana,  Hein  rich  Mann  and  Thomas  Mann,  Herman  Hesse  and   many  others,  "Thereby  proving  my  teacher  right  when  he  forecast  that  I  would  be  a  critic  and  not  a  novelist  or  dramatist  in  my  own  right".   "I  edited  also  an/  an  thology  of  German  novels  and  short  stories  which  were  written  by  writers  in  exile  from  1932  to  1945'T,   be  said.   In  1958  Mr  Reich  Ranicki  settled  perman  ently  in  Hamburg,  where  he  lives  with  his  wife  and  24-year-old  son.  Since  I960  he  has  been  the  liter  ary  critic  of  the  German  weekly  Die  Zeit,  and  is  a  contributor  to  the  Encyclo  paedia  Britannica.   He  has  achieved  fame  for  books  such  as  'German  Literature  Today',  pub  lished  in  I960,  and  critical  evaluations  of  writers  such  as  Boell,  Duerenmatt,  John  son  and  Grass.  He  has  also  worked  Ti  I   aa  guest  professor  at   universities  in  the  USA,  Canada,  Israel  and  Swe   den.   In  Canberra  Mr  Reich  Rainicki  was  to  give  a  lecture  in  the  German  Reading  Room,  Bailey  Ar  cade,  Civic,  last  night  at  the  invitation  of  the  Aus  tralian  Goethe  Society  in  Canberra.  This  morning  he  will  speak  to  a  seminar  of  students  and  staff  at  the  department  of  Germanic  languages  at  the  ANU,  under  the  direction  of  Dr  M.  Stoljar,  acting  head  of  the  department.   A  special  feature  of  Mr  Reich-Rainicki's  visit  to  Canberra  will  be  his  meet  ing  with  the  Canberra  composer  Mr  Larry  Sitsky,  professor  of  Music  at  the  School  of  Music,  Canberra,  ■whose  opera  'Lenz',  on  the  theme  of  the  short  novel  of  the  same  name  by  Georg  ■  Buechner,  will  have  its  world  premier*  by  tho  Aus   tralian  Opera  in  Melbourne  in  spring.   Buechner's  drama  'Woy  zck'  will  be  presented  by  the  German  Theatre  En  semble  Die  Bruecke  on  September  4  in  the  Can   berra  Theatre.
