heading: GERMAN THRILLER IS INGENIOUS
article_text: GERMAN  THRILLER   IS  INGENIOUS    'NIGHTS  Of  The  Long   Knives'  is  another  of  H,  H.  Kirst's  excellent  German  thrillers.  The  plot  is   ingeniously  intricate,  the  tension  is  cleverly  sustained,  the  attention  to  social  detail  is  impressive  and  the  narrative  technique  is   brilliant   The  story  opens  with  a  murder  in  Lugano,  Switzerland.  The  police  discover  that  the  victim,  Heinz-Hermann  Norden,  a  reserved  and  studious  German  expatriate,  was  once  a  member  of  the  infamous  Wesel  Group,  an  elite  unit  of  Hitler's  SS.   Their  search  for  Norden's  killers  leads  them  back  to  the  Germany  of  the  early  1930s  when  the  Group  was  formed  by  SS  General  Waldemar  Wesel.   Its  members  —  six  ruthless  young  fanatics,  trained  in  the  techniques  of  terror  and  assassination  —  were  responsible  for  the  deaths  of  many  of  Hitler's  opponents  at  the  beginning  of  the  Nazi  era.  ||   NIGHTS  OF  THE  LONG  KNIVES   By  H  H.  Kirst   Collins  279pp  $9.55   Reviewer:   PETER  KAY   ||  Reconstructing  the  past,  the  police  follow  the  activities  of  tbe  Wesel  Group  through  the  pre-war  years  and  beyond,  from  the  liquidation  of  Ernst  Rohm,  erstwhile  SA  Chief  of  Staff  and  former  intimate  of  the  Fuhrer,  to  the  pilot  project  that  provided  a  model  for  every  extermination  camp  from  Auschwitz  to  Belsen.   Their  investigations  reveal   that  bitter  feuds  and  rivalries  between  members  of  the  Group  had  grown  in  intensity  over  the  years  and  had  ultimately  erupted  into  violence,  more  than  40  years  later  in  Lugano.   Finally  the  killers  are  identified,  but  it  appears  for  a  time  that  one  of  them  will  escape  until  an  exhilarating  last-page  twist  neatly  completes  the   denouement.
snippet: 'NIGHTS Of The Long Knives' is another of H H. Kirst's excellent German thrillers. The plot is

heading: IN BRIEF German normalisation
article_text: IN  BRIEF   German  normalisation   BONN,  Thursday  (AAP).  —  West  Germany  and  East  Germany  agreed  yesterday  to  begin  formal  negotiations  soon  on  a  scries  of  long-delayed  nor  malisation  agreements,  officials  of  both  sides  an  nounced  after  talks  in  Bonn,  Associated  Press  reports.   Increased  traffic  across  East  Germany's  border  with  the  West  is  among  matters  in  the  negotiations,  which  will  take  placc  on  an  as  yet  undetermined  date   in  East  Berlin.
snippet: BONN, Thursday (AAP).—West Germany and East Germany agreed yesterday to begin formal negotiations soon on a series of long-delayed normalisation agreements, officials of both sides

heading: pilbara pets GERMAN SHEPHERD
article_text: pilbara  pets   GERMAN  SHEPHERD   When  asking  a  friend  who  owns  one  of  these  magnificent  breed,  the  difference  between  the  Alsatian  and  German  Shep-  herd,  I  was  immediately  asked  if  I  knew  anything  about  dogs.  I  was  told  I  would  have  to  be  pretty  silly  not  to  know  the  difference  —  none.   During  the  World  Wars  the  British  dropped  the  name  German  Shepherd  and  decided  on  the  name,  Alsatian  Wolf  Dog.  This  is  probably  why  a  lot  of  people  associate  the  German  Shepherd  with  the  wolf,  but  it  is  totally  incorrect.  In  fact,  in  spite  of  their  wolf-like  appear-  ance,  the  German  Shepherd  belongs  to  the  breed  which  have  the  least  traces  of  wolves.  The  Shepherd  can  be  traced  farther  back  in  time  than  any  other  breed.  The  oldest  of  dogs  resembling  the  Shepherd  is  about  twenty  thousand  years  old.  The  breed  in  early  times  was  originally  used  for  hunting  and  as  a  watch  dog.  More  recently  they  have  been  used  as  Shepherd  dogs  watching  cattle,  hence  the  name.  They  were  also  once  regarded  as  the  only  dogs  suitable  of  guiding  the  blind.  They  are  now  also  used  as  police  dogs,  where  their  duties  entail:--  tracking,  rescue  and  messenger  carriers.  Above  all  they  are  an  excellent  family  pet.  They  seem  quite  suited  to  the  climate  of  the  Pilbara.  I  must  sympathize  with  the  owners  of  a  German  Shepherd  for  it  seems  that  they  are  always  the  first  to  have  the  finger  pointed  at  them  when  there  is  any  trouble.  Doberman  owners  often  have  the  same  problem—  I  know  I've  got  one.
snippet: When asking a friend who owns one of these magnificent breed, the difference between the Alsatian and German Shepherd, I was immediately asked if I knew

heading: GERMAN TROOPS FREE HOSTAGES
article_text: TROOPS   ?   BONN,  Tues,  AAP  —  West  German  commandos  attacked  behind  the  blinding  flash  of  special  grenades  and  swarmed  aboad  a  hijacked  Lufthansa  airline  at  Mogadisau  in  Somalia  to  kill  three  terrorists  and  free  unharmed  86  hostages  in  a  seyen-minute  raid  today.  The  West  German  Government  announced  that  a  woman  hijacker  was  wounded  and  captured.   The  spectacular  raid  on  the  jet  parked  on  a  runway  at  Mogadishu,  in  north-east  Africa,  came  about  90  minutes  before  a  deadline  set  by  the  hijackers  for  the  killing  of  the  hostages.  It  ended  a  five-day  ordeal  that  covered:  about  11,000  kilometres  and  took  the  plane  to  six  countries.  Among  those  rescued  were  11  West  Ger-.  man  beauty  queens  and  an  American-  woman.  Mrs  Christine  Santiago,  44,  of  Santee,  California  and-  her  five-year-old  son.  .  Authorities  said,  the  -hostages  would  return  to  Frankfurt  international  Airport  in  West  Germany  late  this  afternoon.  Two  ot  the  hijackers  were  members  of.  a  West  German  terrorist  gang  and  two  of  them  members  of  an  extremist  wing  of  the  Palestine  Liberation  Organisation.  Three  were  shot  dead  before  they  could  carry  out  their  threat  to  blow  up  the  plane,  and  one  German  raider,  the  woman,  was  wounded,  the.  Government  said,  Using  special  grenades  creating  a  blinding  flash  and  deafening  noise,  28  men  of  Unit  .9  of  the  Federal-Border  Troops  blew  open  the  Boeing  737's  doors  about  midnight,  the  Government  said.  A  swift  shoot-out  ensued  in  which  the  hijackers  were  shot  dead  and  within  seven  minutes  all  the  hostages  had  left  the  plane.  About  60  luen  of  the  crack  German  Unit  9  flew,  aboard  a  Lufthansa  Boeing  707  from  the  Greek  island  of.Crete  to  Mogadishu  yesterday,  landing  after  dark.  to  The  raid  was  directed  by  GerdBoeden,  head  of  the  anti-terrorist  squad  of  the  German  Federal  Police,  and  Ulrich  Wegener,  head  of  the  raiding  troops.  Spokesmen  said  they  had  been  secretly  following  the  hijacked  aircraft  on  its  trip.  Lufthansa  spokesman  Frank  Cesarz  said  the  raid  had  been  planned  to  the  last  detail.  "The  men  of  the  frontier  protection  troops  had  trained  for  a  long  time  on.  an  aircraft  of  the  same  type,"  he  said.  The  border  guards  are  the  senior  military  arm  of  West  Germany.  They  were  the  first  armed  unit  formed  after  World  War  2.  Their  prime  mission  is  to'  guard.  West  Germany's  border  and  they  also  provide  elite  troops  that  guard  the  Chancellor,  President  and  other  Government  officials.  They  wear  a  'green  uniform,  boots  and  unmistakable  coal-shuttle  helmets  with  leather  flaps  at  the  rear.  :  The  lightning  •  raid  resembled  the  Israeli  raid,  at  Entebbe  Airport  in  Uganda  on  July  4,  1976,  when  Israeli  commandos  flew  secretly  into  the  airport  and  rescued  102  hijacked  hostages  in  a  shoot-out  with  Arab  and  West  German  terrorists.   The  hijackers  seized  the  German  Boeing  737  plane  at  midday  last  Thursday  over  the  French  Riviera  as  it  was  flying  from  Majorca  to  Frankfurt.  They  later  forced  the  plane  to  fly  to  Rome,  Cyprus,  Bahrain,  Dubai.  Aden  and  finally  Somalia.  All  over'  ^  ••:•«••  ML  J.O  HI  1lit^S  •  m  m  w  w  w  They  demanded  the  release  of  13  terrorist  prisoners  held  in  German  and  Turkish  jails  and  a  $U.S.15.5  million  (K13  million)  ransom.  Both  Germany  and  Turkey  stood  firm  as  one  deadline  after  another  set  by  the  hijackers  came  and  went.  Jubilation  in  Germany  was  dampened  by  the  death  of  Juergen  Schumann,  the  37-yearold  captain  of  the  plane  who  was.  shot  to  death  yesterday.  The  hijackers  unceremoniously  dumped  his  body  from  the  aircraft  while  the  hostages  watched  in  horror.,  There  was  still  no  word  on  the  fate  of  .industrialist  Hanns-Martin  Schleyer,  62,  kidnapped  by  West  German  terrorists  on  September  5.  An  ultimatum  on  his  life  expired  on  Sunday.  His  kidnappers  had  tied  his  fate  to  the  demands  of  the  four  hijackers.  The  special  plane  carrying  all  the  hostages  left  Mogadishu  at  5.30  am.  Injured  passengers  were,  given  first  aid  by  Somali  and  German  doctors  in  the  airport  waiting  room.Some  of  the  injured  were  taken  to  Medina  hospital  in  Mogadishu  for  treatment  and  then  returned  to  the  airport  for  the  flight  home:  The  Somali  news  agency,  Sonn  a,  quoted  Information  Minister  Abdulkasim  Salad-  Hasan  as  saying  the  rescue  operation  was  completed  in  10  minutes.  The  Minister  added  the  rescue  was  carried  out  "by  Somali  security  forces  in  conjunction  with:  some  German  technical  experts."  He  said  his  Government  had  no  option  but  to  use  force  "to  save  the  lives  of  innocent  passengers,  once  all  other  channels  had  been  exhausted."  Sonna.said  there  was  "great.rejoicing"  at  Mogadishu's  small  airport  over  the  success  of  the  raid.  A  Lufthansa  spokesman  said  details  of  the  raid  were  sketchy.  Commandos  practised  attacking  an  identical  plane  before  being  sent  to  Mogadishu,  sources  said.  .  .  .  ..  .  They  stormed  into  the  aircraft  through  emergency  exits  on  both  wings,  without  any  warning  to  the  occupants  of  the  plane,  the  Lufthansa  spokesman  said.  Informed  sources  said  commandos  found  that  the  hijackers  had  placed  explosives  inside  the  plane  and  poured  petrol  onto  the  aisle  carpeting,  apparently  to  cause  "a  fire  in  the  event  of  an  attack.  Passengers  were  bound  in  their  seats,  the  sources  said.  There  was  some  shooting,  causing  bullet  damage  to  the  inside  of  the  aircraft,  the  spokesman  said.  There  was  no  panic.  The  passengers  were  evacuated  as  fast  as  possible  by  sliding  down  inflated  slides  from  the  emergency  exits.  The  three  stewardesses  directed  the  evacuation,  he  said.   no  news  BONN,  Tues. They  shot  themselves  through  the  head.  Andreas.  Baader  and  Gudrun  .  Ensslin  were  tlie  first  to  die.  The  third  guerrilla  chief.  Ja^n-Carl  Raspe,  died  later.  They  were  among  the  11  guerrillas  demanded  bv  Mr  Schleyer's  kidnappers  and  the  hijackers.  -

heading: GERMAN NO TO ATAROT
article_text: BONN:  The  German   government  has  not  yet  replied  officially  to  Israel’s  compromise  proposal  on  the  Atarot  Airport  dispute,  officials  in  Jerusalem  said  recently.   The  German  government  had  objected  to  El  Al’s  original  plan  to  fly  directly  from  Frankfurt  to  the  Jerusalem  airport  of  Atarot,  which  is  in  territory  formerly  held  by  Jordan.  Germany  claimed  this  would  contravene  UN  resolutions  forbidding  Israel  to  make  changes  in  the  status  of  the  occupied   areas.   Israel’s  “compromise”,  proposed  to  Germany  through  its  ambassador  here,  calls  for  the  El  A1  planes  to  land  at  Ben  Gurion  Airport  and  then  continue  to  Atarot  on  what  would  be  classified  as  an  internal  flight.  The  Frank  furt-Lod  flight  and  the  Lod  Atarot  flight  would  be  booked  on  separate  tickets.   The  German  Foreign  Ministry  spokesman  statec  that  his  government  op  posed  Frankfurt-Atarot  flights.   From  a  legal  standpoint,  .  the  spokesman  said,  there   was  no  difference  whether  the  flights  were  direct  or  included  a  stop-over  at   Lod.
snippet: BONN: The German government has not yet replied officially to Israel’s compromise proposal on

heading: German volunteers
article_text: German  volunteers   By  MYRA  NOVECK/Jerusalem  Post  Reporter   “OUR  volunteers  come  because  they  feel  responsibility  for  the  his  tory  of  our  country  and  a  responsibil  ity  for  the  future  of  our  country.  We  want  to  push  for  the  development  of  reconciliation  and  peace,”  says  20  year-old  Christianna  Dahm  of  Col  ogne,  a  volunteer  for  Action  for  Reconciliation  and  Peace  Services,  a  group  of  young  Germans  whose  goal  is  to  encourage  reconciliation  be  tween  Germany  and  countries  that   suffered  under  the  Nazis.   The  group  has  160  volunteers  in  nine  countries.  Nearly  a  quarter  of  the  volunteers  work  in  Israel.  The   idea  for  the  original  organization  came  out  of  a  discussion  by  German  Protestant  clergymen,  led  by  Lothar  Kreissig  in  the  late  Fifties,  who  “were  looking  for  a  way  to  overcome  the  problems  of  relations  between  Ger  mans  and  other  nations  as  a  result  of   the  war  and  the  Holocaust,”  says  Dahm.   In  Israel  the  organization  concen  trates  on  working  with  the  elderly  -  particularly  German-  and  Yiddish  speaking  persons  who  were  the   direct  victims  of  Nazism  -  as  well  as  with  handicapped  children.  Volun  teer  jobs  include  teching  extra  curricular  subjects,  tutoring,  work  in  homes  for  the  aged  and  home  visits  to  the  elderly.   Action  for  Reconciliation  is  an  18-month  programme,  although  a  West  German  law  just  passed  and  lengthening  army  service  will  mean   new  male  volunteers  will  in  future   participate  for  two  years  if  they  choose  to  join  the  Action  group  and  thus  fulfil  their  national  service  re   quirement  as  an  alternative  to  army  service.  The  programme  begins  with   a  one-month  seminar  in  West   Gemany,  which  includes  visits  to  concentration  camps,  work  in  the  camp  museums  and  discussions  with   former  inmates.   The  volunteers  then  go  to  the  country  of  their  choice.  The  Israeli  contingent  spends  the  first  three  months  in  a  work-language-study  programme  on,  a  kibbutz  before  being  sent  to  serve  in  institutions   around  the  country.  In  most  cases,  the  institution  provides  room  and  board,  and  sometimes,  pocket  money.  If  it  can’t  afford  that  and  Action  officials  think  it’s  important  enough,  the  organization  foots  the  bill,  but  resources  are  limited.   Two-thirds  of  the  organization’s  national  budget  comes  from  private   donations.   The  volunteers  say  they  rarely  encounter  anti-German  feeling  here,  although  they  say  earlier  groups  had  more  problems,  and   some  kibbutzim  still  refuse  to  take  German  volunteers.  On  the  other   hand,  many  of  the  elderly  with  whom  they  work  feel  more  comfort  able  speaking  German  than  Hebrew  and  still  feel  an  attachment  to  Ger  man  culture.   “it’s  the  second  generation  that  is  more  of  a  problem,”  says  28-year   old  Einat  Weiss,  housemother  at  a  seminar  centre  serving  the  volun  teers,  who  explains  that  the  Israeli  born  children  of  refugees  or  Holo  caust  survivors  see  only  the  negative  side  of  Germany  while  the  parents  remember  “another”  Germany.   Ironically,  Israel’s  economic   crunch  has  made  it  harder  for  the  Germans  to  find  suitable  volunteer  work.   Apart  from  having  contact  with  kibbutz  members,  the  volunteers  also  spend  weekends  with  city  fami   lies.   “You  get  to  know  a  country  and  the  people  get  to  know  you  and  maybe  after  that  they’ll  think  a  little  differently,”  says  volunteer  Bern  hard  Rohrbacher,  20,  from  Bonn.  That’s  the  sigh  of  reconciliation',  adds  Dahm.  “It’s  small  steps  and   hard  work.”
snippet: “OUR volunteers come because they feel responsibility for the history of our country and a responsibility for the future of our country. We

heading: German award
article_text: German  award   The  former  executive  director  of  the  Australian  Mining  Industry  Council,  Mr  G.  Paul  Phillips,  has  been  awarded  the  West  German  Commander's  Cross  of  the  Order  of  Merit  for  his  work  toward  the  establishment  of  fruitful  relations  between  Australia  and  West  Germany.   Mr  Phillips  was  executive  director  of  AMIC  from  its  inception  in  1967  until  his  retirement  last  month.
snippet: The former executive director of the Australian Mining Industry Council, Mr G. Paul Phillips, has been awarded the West German Commander's Cross

heading: German pensions
article_text: German   pensions   In  your  paper  of  September  8  on  page  15  there  was  reference  to  the  fact  that  the  German  pensions  are  not  means  tested.   This  is  not  the  case.  One  must  declare  the  German  pension  as  an  income  and  it  is  included  in  one’s  total  income  and  means  tested.   I  suggest  readers  who  are  affected  enquire  at  the  Social  Ser  vices  Department.   (Name  and  address  supplied  but  withheld  from  publication)
snippet: In your paper of September 8 on page 15 there was reference to the fact that the German pensions are not means tested.

heading: GERMAN CRIME
article_text: GERMAN  CRIME   TEL  AVIV  (UPI):  About  350  Israeli  women  are  working  as  prostitutes  in  West  Germany  and  about  400  young  Israelis  are  serving  time  in  German  prisons  on  drug-related  charges,  the  Jerusalem  Post  reported  last   week.   The  newspaper  said  the  figures  were  cited  by  Herut  Lapid,  head  of  the  Kibbutz  Movement  Criminal  Rehabilitation  Department,  following  a  recent  visit  to  West  Germany,  where  he  met  with  prisoners  and  law  enforcement  officials.   According  to  Lapid,  there  are  many  more  Israeli  women  working  as  prostitutes  in  Germany  besides  the  350  registered   with  the  authorities.   He  said  his  movement  was  running  a  special  program  to  rehabilitate  former  prisoners  by  integrating  them  into  various   kibbutzim.   But  Lapid  said  for  the  time  being  the  kibbutz  movement  felt  more  qualified  to  handle  people  who  had  served  time  for  crimes  against  property  rather  than  drug  dealers  or  brothel  keepers.   Lapid  said  he  was  trying  to  persuade  every  kibbutz  to  accept   at  least  one  former  cri  minal.
snippet: TEL AVIV (UPI): About 350 Israeli women are working as prostitutes in West Germany and about 400 young Israelis are serving time in German prisons on drug-related charges, the Jerusalem Post reported last

heading: German tribute
article_text: •  German  tribute   BONN:  Israel’s  President  Mr  Chaim  Herzog  has   received  a  letter  from  the  West  German  President  Mr  Richard  Von  Weizecker,  paying  tribute  to  the  decisive  part  played  by  Mr.  David  Ben-Gurion  in  the  development  of  positive  ties  between  their  two  countries.   On  the  occasion  of  the  100th  anniversary  of  Mr  Ben  Gurion’s  birthday,  the  German  President  wrote:  “Only  those  aware  of  the  heavy  burden  left  by  the  horrible  crimes  against  the  Jewish  people  which  is  still  weighing  on  the  relations  between  our  two  nations  are  able  to  measure  Ben-Gurion’s  contribution  to  Israeli-German  ties.”

heading: GERMAN PENSIONS
article_text: German  law  regarding  the  payment  of  social  in  surance  pensions  is  to  be  changed.   The  United  Restitution  Organisation  has  an  nounced  that  this  may  have  some  bearing  on  pensions  received  by  some  Jewish   Australians.   The  new  law  allows  for  widowers  to  receive  60  per  cent  of  their  late  wives’  pension.   This  brings  it  into  line  with  the  practice  for   widows.   However,  from  now  on,  the  income  of  the  surviving  spouse  will  be  taken  into   GERMAN  PENSIONS   account,  so  the  pension  now  received  may  be  reduced  by  40  per  cent.   The  reduction  will  be  made  gradually,  over  a  period  of  10  years.   Pensions  paid  under  the  German  Federal  Compen  sation  Law  are  fully  ex  empt.   Current  recipients  of  the  pensions  are  to  be  given  the  choice  between  the  new  or  old  criteria  and  must  in  form  the  Social  Insurance   authorities  in  Germany  by  the  end  of  1988.
snippet: German law regarding the payment of social insurance pensions is to be changed.

heading: GERMAN VISITORS
article_text: GERMAN  VISITORS   FRANKFURT,  (JCNS):  133,767  West  German  tourists  visited  Israel  in  1984,  20  per  cent  more  than  the  year  before,  it  was  revealed  by  the  official  Israeli  travel  bureau  here.  The  German  visitors  spent  a  total  of  330  million  marks  in  the  Jewish  state.  Average  duration  of  their  stay  there  was  17.6  days.  _

heading: German Jews
article_text: German  Jews   IN  ADDITION  to  the  review  on  the  great  Heine  (AJN  18/11),  per  mit  me  to  add  the  following.  The  first  German-language  Free  School  for  Jews  was  opened  in  Berlin  by  David  Friedlaender  in  1778  the  aim  being  the  replace  ment  of  Yiddish,  still  the  vernac  ular  of  the  Jewish  people,  by  the  German  language.  This  was  rapidly  followed  by  Reform  Schools  all  over  Germany   whereby  many  Jews  turned  to  li  terature.  Literary  salons  sprang  up  in  Berlin.   A  member  of  such  a  cultural  centre  was  Henriette  Herz,  a  well  educated  young  Jewish  woman  whose  salon  was  the  venue  of  cul  tured  people  —  Jewish  and  non  Jewish  —  exchanging  ideas  and  literary  talk.  Moses  Mendelsohn’s  daughter  Doro  thea  Veit,  Rachel  Varnhagen  von  Ense  and  also  Heinrich  Heine  vis  ited  the  salon.  The  aforemen  tioned  were  the  most  famous  Jewish  women  of  that  era  and  like  Heinrich  Heine,  by  dint  of  ne  cessity,  converted  to  Christianity.   Heinrich  Heine,  the  gifted  poet  and  writer,  following  his  uni  versity  education  and  obtaining  a  degree  in  law,  reluctantly  con  verted  to  Protestantism  since  Civil  Service  careers  were  still  bar  red  to  Jews.  Never  practising  law,  his  fame  as  writer  and  poet  had  already  been  established.  He  wrote  biting  satires  on  the  Ger  man  Parliament,  which  landed  him  in  grave  conflict  with  the  Ger  man  authorities.  He  .chose  exile  in  Paris,  married  a  simple  unedu  cated  country  girl,  and  lived  there  the  rest  of  his  life.  Heine  died  in  1856.   It  was  only  in  the  year  1926  that  Heines  memorial  was  com  pleted  in  Hamburg’s  City  Park,  but  in  1933  Hitler  destroyed  Heine’s  monument  due  to  the  poet’s  innate  Jewishness.  Never  theless  Heine’s  German  songs,  especially  the  lovely  “Lorelei”  be  came  so  popular  that  the  Nazis  were  obliged  to  include  them  in  anthologies  albeit  labelling  them  “Author  Unknown!’  In  1981,  a  col  lection  was  made  for  a  new  me  morial  which  was  to  be  cast  in  bronze.  Not  only  the  German  people  but  the  whole  world  now  benefits  from  the  writings  of  Germany’s  greatest  acknow  ledged  lyricist.   George  Reinisch   McKinnon   _J  ,.  ■>  •-t:Vi

article_text: German   minister  '   Dr  Hildegard  Hamm  Brucher,  Minister  of  State  at  the  West  German  Foreign  Office,  arrives  at  the  West  German  Ambassador's  resi  dence  in  Canberra  yester  day. heading: German tourism
article_text: German  tourism   BONN.  -  West  German  tourism  to  Israel  seems  to  have  overcome  its  post-Lebanon  War  low,  but  remains  sensitive  to  political  influences,  Eli  Noy,  director  of  the  Israeli  tourism  office  in  Frankfurt,  said  recently.   In  1981,  155,000  visitors  from  the  federal  republic  visited  Israel,  Noy  said.  The  number  dropped  to  107,000  and  to  111,000  in  1982  and  1983  respectively.  Nineteen  eighty  four  brought  a  recovery  with  133,000  visitors  and  the  first  four  months  of  this  year  rought  a  rise  of  25  per  cent  compared  to  the  same  period  last  year,  he  said.   Political  developments  remain  im  portant  for  tourism  from  Germany,  Noy  said.  Thus,  there  were  Israeli  fears  that  the  political  storm  sur  rounding  the  40th  anniversary  of  the  Nazi  surrender  in  May,  including  the  Bitburg  affair,  might  damage  tourism  from  Germany.  But  these   fears  were  not  borne  out.
snippet: BONN. - West German tourism to Israel seems to have overcome its post-Lebanon War low, but remains sensitive to political influences, Eli

heading: GERMAN HONORED
article_text: GERMAN  HONORED   BERLIN:  The  Service  Cross  of  the  West  German  Federal  Order  of  Merit  has  been  awarded  to  Wilhelm  Tichauer,  chairman  of  the  local  Jewish  community.   The  honor  is  for  efforts  in  the  fields  of  German  Jewish,  Christian-Jewish  and  German-Israeli  under  standing  and  co-operation.   It  also  acknowledges  the  maintenance  and  restora  tion  of  sites  of  Jewish  worship  and  culture  in  this  south  western  region  of  West  Germany.
snippet: BERLIN: The Service Cross of the West German Federal Order of Merit has been awarded to Wilhelm

heading: German hymns
article_text: German  hymns   .A.  member  of  the  literary  committee  for  the   Australian  Hymn  Book,  Mrs  Honor  Thwaites,  will  speak  at  the  Anglican  Church  of  St  John  the  Baptist,  Rcid,  on  Sunday.   She  will  speak  at  the  7pm  evensong  service  on  the  background  of  her  new  translation  for  a  number  of  German  hymns  included  in  the  book.  Mrs  Thwaites  will  describe  the  life  and  times  of  some  of  the  German  writers  whose  hymns  have  been  sung  for  centuries.  She  will  also  explain  how  the  hymns  came  to  be  written.
snippet: A member of the literary committee for the Australian Hymn Book, Mrs Honor Thwaites, will speak at the Anglican Church of St John the Baptist, Reid, on Sunday.

heading: German champs
article_text: German  champs   KARACHI,  Saturday  (AAP).  —  West  Germany  won  the  eighth  Cham  pions  Trophy  world  hockey  tour  nament  yesterday,  defeating  the  Neth  erlands  2-1  on  the  final  day.   Australia  took  second  place  and  Pakistan  third,  although  Pakistan  beat  Australia  3-1  earlier  in  the  day. heading: GERMAN VISITOR
article_text: GERMAN  VISITOR   JERUSALEM  (UPI):  West  German  President  Richard  Von  Weizsaeker,  telling  Israelis  “the  past  cannot  he  wiped  out”,  made  the  first  visit  by  a   West  German  head  of  state  to  a  memorial  to   Jews  killed  by  the  Nazis   in  World  War  II.   Mr  Weizsaeker  was  greeted  at  Ben-Gurion  Airport  by  his  Israeli  counterpart,  Chaim  Herzog,  as  the  West  German  national  an  them  was  played.   “The  past  cannot  be  wiped   out,”  Mr  Weizsaeker  said.  “We  Germans  certainly  will  not  thrust  away  remembrance  of  the  past.  The  more  openly  we  face  the  truth,  the  freer  we  are  to  meet  present-day  challenges.”   “The  past  can  never  be  forgot  ten,  but  the  future  must  never  be  ignored,”  Mr  Herzog  said.   “It  is  to  that  future  that  we   here  in  Israel  are  engaged  in  the  enormous  task  of  building  a   nation.”   Mr  Weizsaeker  later  visited  the  Yad  Vashem  Holocaust  Memorial  to  six  million  Jews  killed  by  the  Nazis  during  World   War  II.   Several  dozen  young  Israelis,  dressed  in  the  striped  uniforms  worn  by  Nazi  concentration  camp  inmates,  protested  the  visit,  the  first  ever  by  a  West   German  head  of  state.   But  Israel  Radio  said  “most  of  those  Israelis  present  were  im  pressed  with  the  sincerity  of  Mr   Wfeizsaeker’s  visit.”   Mr  Weizsaeker  and  his  wife  first  spent  time  alone  in  the  remembrance  shrine,  then  lin  gered  far  past  the  scheduled  time  in  the  exhibits  section.   Mr  Weizsaeker  later  attended  a  tree-planting  ceremony  in  the  Garden  of  Righteous  Gentiles,  dedicated  to  those  who  helped  save  Jews  during  the  war.   During  World  War  II,  Mr   Weizsaeker  served  with  an  in   fantry  regiment  in  Poland  and   Russia.

heading: GERMAN JUSTICE
article_text: GERMAN  JUSTICE   WASHINGTON  (UPI):  President  Reagan  told  the  mother  of  slain  navy  diver  Robert  Stethem  that  he  is  satisfied  “justice  will  be  done”  in  the  prosecution  of  accused  hijacker-murderer  Mohammed  Ali  Hamadei.   “I  am  confident  the  German  Government  will  fulfil  its  inter   national  legal  obligations  and  Hamadei  wfll  get  the  justice  he  deserves,”  Reagan  told  Stethem’s  mother,  Patricia,  in  a  telephone  call.   The  call  came  as  the  west  German  Government  an  nounced  its  decision  to  not  ex  tradite  Hamadei  to  the  United  States  to  stand  trial  for  the  murder  of  Robert  Stethem  and  the  hijacking  of  a  TWA  jetliner  two  years  ago.   Instead,  Hamadei  will  be  tried  in  West  Germany  on  murder  and  air  piracy  charges  arising  from  the  hijacking,  as  well  as  un  related  charges  of  possess  ing  explosives  when  arrest  ed  January  13  at  Frankfurt  Airport.   Patricia  Stethem,  in  an  earli  er  appearance  on  the  NBC  “lb  day”  program,  said  her  fami-a  ly  was  “devastated”  by  the  ex-"   tradition  decision  ana  added,  “we  really  feel  that  not  enough  pressure  was  enforced  by  our  government  to  bring  Hamadei   here”.   White  House  spokesman  Marlin  Fltzwater  told  reporters  that  Reagan  telephoned  Stethem’s  mother  following  be  ing  informed  of  her  comments.   “V\fe  have  made  every  effort  to  ensure  justice  in  the  prose  cution  of  the  hijacker  Hamadei,”  he  quoted  Reagan  as  saying.  “I  nave  the  per  sonal  assurances  of  (West  Ger  man)  Chancellor  (Helmut)  Kohl  that  justice  will  be  done.   The  ChanceDor  has  told  us  that   there  will  be  no  deal  and  they  will  not  grant  him  clemency.”   Reagan  told  Stethem  that  U.S.  officials  are  co   operating  with  Wfest  German   authorities  on  evidence  in   the  hijacking  case  ‘‘to  see  that  tney  get  all  they  need   for  a  conviction”.   The  United  States,  which  hailed  Hamadei’s  arrest  as  a  blow  against  terrorism,  had  pressed  for  months  for  his  ex  tradition  and  a  trial  on  Ameri  can  soil.  The  Wfest  German  de  cision  represented  a  rebuff  to  Reagan,  who  discussed  the  matter  with  Kohl  just  two  weeks  ago  at  the  economic  summit  in  Italy.   For  the  record,  however,  the  administration  expressed  satisfaction  with  what  Fitz  water  called  “repeated  assur  ances”  that  “the  charges  brought  against  Hamadei  will  be  speedy,  vigorous,  complete  and  to  the  full  extent  or  the  law”.   “VAfe  are  confident  that  the  rule  of  law  will  prevail  in  this  case,  as  it  has  on  numerous  occasions,”  he  added.   In  her  televised  interview,  Stethem  voiced  concern  that  Hamadei  could  be  tried,  con  victed  and  sentenced,  then  later  set  free  by  VAfest  Germa  ny  -  perhaps  in  a  trade  for   two  Wfest  German  business  men  held  in  Lebanon,  whose  fates  were  believed  by  many  to   have  influenced  the  extradition  decision  in  Bonn.
snippet: WASHINGTON (UPI): President Reagan told the mother of slain navy diver Robert Stethem that he is satisfied “justice will be done” in the prosecution of accused hijacker-murderer Mohammed Ali Hamadei.

heading: German support
article_text: >   •  German  support   AACHEN:  An  Action  Group  for  the  Jews  in  the  Soviet  Union  was  recently  formed  here  by  Jewish  students  in  West  Germany,  to  co-ordinate  activities  on  behalf  of  Soviet  Jews  on  a  national  level.   Pointing  out  that  comparable  groups  had  been  active  in  a  number  of  European  countries  for  years  already,  the  new  group  appealed  to  Jewish  organisations  and  private  in  dividuals  in  this  country  to  support  its  activities.
snippet: AACHEN: An Action Group for the Jews in the Soviet Union was recently formed here by Jewish students in West Germany, to co-ordinate activities on behalf of Soviet Jews on a national level.

heading: GERMAN ENVOY
article_text: GERMAN   ENVOY   Dr  Karl-Helnz  Scholtyssek  has  been  ap*  pointed  Consul  General  ot  the  Federal  Republic  of  Ger  many,  with  jurisdiction  through  the  States  of  Vic  toria,  South  Australia;  Western-  Australia  and  Tasmania.   Dr.  Scholtyssek  was  born  at  Beuthen  in  1931  .  He  studied  economics!  and  political  sciences  at  Cologne  Universi  ty  and  at  Hamilton  College,  USA.  He  holds  a  doctorate  in   economics.   He  joined  the  foreign  ser   vice  in  1959  and  served  at  Madrid,  Sydney,;  Wellington,  J-iong  Kong,  Athens  and  Rio  de  Janeiro.  . heading: GERMAN BOOKLET
article_text: GERMAN  BOOKLET   German  youth  are  becoming  more  eager  tc  know  about  the  evil  done  to  the  Jews  undei  Hitler,  according  to  Sydney  school  teachei  and  poet  Jeremy  Lockhart  Nelson.   Mr  Nelson  visited  Ger  many  late  last  year  and  learnt  of  the  young  people’s  desire  from  a  Lutheran  Pastor.   In  a  letter  to  Senator  Peter  Baume,  he  said  that  the  young  Germans  are  largely  the  grandchildren  of  the  generation  which  committed  the  mass  mur  ders.   Unlike  their  mothers  and  fathers  who  would  hardly  talk  about  the  evil  and  tried  to  pretend  it  had  never  hap  pened,  the  children  of  this  generation  wanted  to  face  the  truth,  he  said.   To  help  them  understand  the  problem,  a  special   booklet  entitled  “Die  Reic  hkristallnacht”  has  beer  produced  and  distributed  through  the  schools.   Essentially  a  church  publication,  the  booklet  leaves  nothing  to  the  imagination  and  shows  graphic  pictures  and  news  headlines  to  prove  the  enor  mity  of  the  holocaust.
snippet: German youth are becoming more eager to know about the evil done to the Jews under Hitler, according to Sydney school teacher and poet Jeremy Lockhart Nelson.

heading: Waldheim innocent: German
article_text: Waldheim  innocent:  German   MOENCHENGLAD  BACH,  West  Germany,  Friday  (Router).  -  An  ex-German  Army  of  ficer  who  was  Dr  Kurt  Waldhcim's  boss  during  World  War  II  said  yes  terday  that  the  former  United  Nations  Secre  lary-Gcneral  had  not  been  involved  in  any  atrocities  against  Yugo  slav  partisans.   Mr  Herbert  Warn  storff,  7  3,  Dr  Waldhcim's  direct  boss  from  the  spring  of'l  944  to  the  end  of  the  war,  said,  "I  rule  out  the  pos  sibility  that  Waldheim  committed  any  war   crimes.   "He  was  always  with  us  at  his  desk.  So  how  could  he  possibly  have  committed  these  crimes  without  us  knowing  about  it?" heading: German Moshan plans
article_text: •  German  Moshan  plans   BONN:  A  group  of  Jewish  families  in  West  Germany  plans  to  establish  a  settlement  in  Israel.  It  will  be  the  first  settlement  by  Jewish  emigrants  from  Germany  since  the  Hitler  era.   The  families  will  be  settling  in  Israel  proper,  not  in  occupied  territories,  and  their  village  will  be  organised  like  a  moshav.   The  group,  trying  to  recruit  members  so  the  settlement  will  have  at  least  25  families,  has  Jewish  Agency  support.

heading: German attitude shifts
article_text: •  German  attitude  shifts   HurNix:  me  Bonn  government  has  been  the  target  of  mounting  pressure  from  the  Arab  world  because  of  a  perceiv  ed  pro-Israel  shift  in  its  Middle  East  policy,  West  German  diplomatic  sources  said  here  today.   The  pressure  is  being  exerted  how,  they  said,  because  Bonn  will  assume  the  rotating  chairmanship  of  the  European  Economic  Community  (EEC)  Council  of  Ministers,  beginning  January  1,1983.   Since  taking  office  in  October,  Chancellor  Helmut  Kohl  has  indicated  that  he  wants  to  improve  relations  with  Israel.  Unlike  his  predecessor,  Chancellor  Helmut  Schmidt,  Kohl  has  avoided  public  criticism  of  Israeli  policies  and  announced  his  intention  to  visit  Israel  some  time  next  year.
snippet: BONN: The Bonn government has been the target of mounting pressure from the Arab world because of a perceived pro-Israel shift in its Middle East policy, West German diplomatic sources said here today.

heading: German’s shame
article_text: German’s  shame   The  gesture  by  Heinz  Galinski,  president  of  the  Council  of  Jews  in  (West)  Germany,  in  shaking  the  hand  of  the  now  deservedly  dis  graced  Philipp  Jenninger,  former  president  of  the  Bundestag,  is  one  that  is  totally  unacceptable  to  post-Holocaust  Jewry.   Galinski’s  bowed  head,  averted  gaze  and  proferred  hand  is  an  elo  quent  portrait  of  the  obsequious  attitude  that  has  no  place  in  the  current  psychological  make-up  of  any  minority,  much  less  Jewry.   Both  presidents  deserve  disgrace  and  banishment  from  their  respec  tive  communities.  However,  un  like  Galinski,  Janninger’s  action  has  one  enormous  redeeming  vir  tue.  He  is  an  honest  man;  he  said  what  he  truly  felt.   T.D.  Kramer  South  Strathfield,  NSW
snippet: The gesture by Heinz Galinski, president of the Council of Jews in (West) Germany, in shaking the hand of the now deservedly

heading: German Feminist Films
article_text: German  Feminist  Films   For  Australian  women  making  films,  reliant  on  grant  monies  and  the  non-  theatrical  market  for  distribution,  the  experience  of  West  German  feminist  film  makers  provides  an  interesting  com  parison.  The  films  brought  together  by  the   Goethe  Institute  and  screened  in  a  series  of  programs  across  Australia  recently  were,  by  and  large,  made  with  money  from  television  and  the  guarantee  of  T.V.  exposure.  As  Dr  Jutta  Brueckner,  the  film  maker  who  accompanied  the  tour  explains  (see  interview),  the  films  presented  are  not  typical  or  representative  of  the  body  of  West  German  women's  film  production.  No  short  films  appeared  in  the  program,  for  example.  But  the  collection  did  reveal  an  en  couraging  diversity  of  styles  and  sub  ject  matter,  linked  by  the  common  theme  of  alienation  both  from  the  prevailing  image  of  woman  and  from  confining'  mores.  Do  Right  and  Fear  No  One  is  the  earlier  of  Brueckners  two  films.  When  she  began  it  she  knew  next  to  nothing  about  the  mechanics  of  making  a  film,  but  a  great  deal  about  her  protagonist,  Gerda  Siepenbrink  (Jutta's  mother),  the  kind  of  lower  middle  class  woman  who  grew  up  after  World  War  1  and  matured  during  the  Nazi  era.  From  a  fatherless  and  hence  poor  family,  Gerda  was  raised  in  an  even  more  relentlessly  conformist  environment  than  her  peers.  Her  mother  didn't  want  people  to  say  her  daughters  ran  wild  for  want  of  paternal  control,  so  they  were  kept  at  home,  sewing,  during  their  non-working  hours.  When  the  insurance  money  for  her  husband's  death  arrived  Gerda's  mother,  short  of  funds  for  daily  necessities,  in  vested  it  in  a  good  family  burial  plot.  JBeyond  every  other  consideration,  res:  pectability  was  the  most  important  human  achievement  in  her  eyes,  and  this  rite  instilled  in  her  daughters.   Brueckner  constructed  the  film  of  animated  still  photographs  combined  with  Gerda  narrating  the  richly  ironic  soundtrack  in  a  curiously  deadpan  fashion,  perhaps  still  unaware  of  the  ab  surdity  of  investing  in  death  in  the  midst  of  life.  The  opening  section  of  the  film  uses  the  photographs  of  August  Sander  who  attempted,  in  his  work,  to  construct  a  composite  portrait  of  Germany  during  the  pre-war  years  and  whose  work  was  subsequently  banned  and  burned  by  the  Nazis.  There  is  very  little  camera  move  ment  in  this  section,  with  each  image  replacing  the  next  at  a  measured  pace.  The  photographs  are  of  different  people  and  unrelated  to  the  narration  except  in  so  far  as  Gerda  is  representative  of  many  of  her  country  men  and  women  of  the  era.  When  the  protagonist  begins  to  develop  a  personality  based  less  on  her  background  and  more  on  .her  consider  ation  of  the  forces  that  have  shaped  her  life,  her  own  image  takes  the  place  of  the  historic  photographs.  As  she  takes  on  a  more  challenging  job,  the  pace  of  the  images  quickens,  climaxing  in  her  dis  covery  that  her  husband  has  been  seeing  another  woman,  which  is  illustrated  by  a  rapid  series  of  blurred  images,  conveying  the  uncontrollable  fury  of  a  woman  wronged.  A  portrait  of  both  a  generation  and  one  woman  plodding  towards  emanci  pation,  Do  Right  and_  Fear  No  One  ex  presses  a  gently  guarded  optimism  about  the  possibilities  for  change  within  a  life  time.  But  what  happens  when  the  con  ventions  and  expectations  are  gone?  Brueckner  looks  at  a  contemporary  Gerda  -  Rita  Rischak  —  in  her  second  film,  A  Totally  Neglected  Girl  (subtitled  How  Low  Can  a  Girl  Sink?).  Like  Gerda,  Rita  is  real,  this  time  one  of  the  film  maker's  best  friends.  She  lives  with  her  righteous  and  oider-obsessed  parents  and  her  five-   year-old  illegitimate  son.  But  the  location  and  particulars  aside,  Rita  could  be  any  one  and  the  persistent  self-hatred  she  espouses,  combined  with  half-formed  dreams  of  a  glamorous  (or  at  least  self-  fulfilling)  existence,  must  be  familiar  to  many  many  women.  Although  the  men  in  her  life  are  ciphers,  vapid  and  transient,  (including  the  one  who  has  fathered  her  son)  and  she  no  longer  bothers  hiding  her  con  tempt  for  them,  she  still  expects  one  per  fect  specimen  to  turn  up  and  wisk  her  away  from  her  drab  life  into  a  fantasy  world  of  love,  beauty,  motherhood  and  eternal  youth.  Rita's  tussle  between  dreams  and  reality  is  played  out  over  one  day  in  her  life,  one  on  which  she  has  to  find  a  new  job  or  tell  her  parents  how  she  had  to  leave  her  old  one.  For  its  sheer  hopelessness,  A  Totally  Neglected  Girl  is  a  frightening  film,  salvaged  from  complete  despair  by  the  heroine's  witty  perceptions  of  her  pre  dicament  combined  with  her  spunk  in   the  lace  ot  the  wall  of  conformity  around  her.  In  An  All  Round  Reduced  Personality,  Helke  Sanders  (not  to  be  confused  with  Helma  Sanders,  director  of  Heinrich  and  Shirrin's  Wedding)  examines  another  di  mension  of  encirclement.  She  juxtaposes  a  personality  under  seige  with  a  city,  Berlin,  similarly  surrounded.  Edda  Chiemnykewski  (played  by  Sanders  herself);  mother,  lover,  freelance  photojournalism  and  member  of  a  women's  photographic  project,  juggles  a  myriad  of  daily  demands  on  her  time  while  trying  to  remain  herself,  a  growing  personality.  The  film's  title  derives  from  a  slogan,  "the  all-round  realised  socialist  person  ality"  broadcast  on  East  German  radio.  Disenchanted  with  both  east  and  west,  and  caught  geographically  between  the  two,  Edda's  attention  focuses  instead  on  the  thousands  of  minor  issues  and  irrit  ations  that  make  up  an  individual's  ex  istence  and  on  the  integration  of  the  personal  and  the  political.  The  two  come  together  when  the  women's  photography  group  is  asked  to  prepare  a  photographic  exhibition  de  picting  Berlin  from  a  woman's  viewpoint.   The  view  turns  out  to  be  less  conform-  ingly  female  than  the  city  fathers  had  hoped,  illustrating,  very  gently,  that  women  are  people  too.  An  All  Round  Reduced  Personality  is  a  disarmingly  low-key  film,  riddled  with  cynicism  but  never  bleak,  and  shot  with  a  documentary  feel.  The  single  true  documentary  in  the  collection  is,  by  contrast,  a  dramatised  re-enactment  of  a  woman's  experiences  as  a  battered  wife,  and  what  she  does  about  it.  The  Power  of  Men  is  the  Patience  of  Women  (Cristina  Perincioli)  fuses  the  experiences  of  several  women  who  found  their  way  to  a  Berlin  women's  refuge  to  create  the  central  character,  Addi.  Addi  endures  a  violent  husband  be  cause  of  her  economic  dependence  on  him.  Their  young  son,  increasingly  dis  turbed  by  events  at  home  and  sent  home  by  his  kindergarten  because  of  his  anti  social  behaviour,  heightens  her  isolation.   When  she  sees  a  documentary  about  a  women's  refuge  on  television  she  simply  calls  a  cab  and  leaves  without  turning  off  the  set.  The  film  does  not  moralise,  or  even  accuse.  Nor  does  it  fall  into  the  trap  of  portraying  the  villain  as  a  self-propelled  ogre.  Susceptible  to  violent  outbursts  and  alternately  cruel  and  then  concerned.  Addi's  husband  is  himself  the  product  of  an  uncaring  background  -  an  adult  version  of  what  his  son  is  well  on  the  way  to  becoming.  Though  the  refuge,  to  which  Addi  eventually  escapes,  is  presented  as  a  sal  vation,  the  film  in  general  avoids  a  tone  of  grating  self-congratulation  that  some  times  characterises  feminist  documentaries  about  the  movement's  achievements.  Staff  of  the  Paddington  Town  Hall,  where  these  films  were  shown  in  Sydney,  tell  of  a  man  who  periodically  comes  in  to  enquire  about  screenings  by  the  Gothic  Institute.  What  he  probably  has  in  mind  are  films  like  Elfi  Mikesch's  I  Often  Think  of  Hawaii  and  Ulrike  Ottinger's  Madam  X  —  an  Absolute  Dictator,  two  murky  ex  amples  of  supposedly  feminist  aesthetic.  I  Often  Think  of  Hawaii  is  a  stulti  fying  boring  film  about  the  stultifying  boring  lives  led  by  people  forced  to  live  in  housing  estates  and  work  at  lousy,  repetitive,  poorly-paid  jobs.  Mikesch  focuses  most  of  her  attention  on  the  pipe-dreams  of  one  such  family  -   turning  her  subjects  into  objects  of  in  tellectual  curiosity  fop  the  well-educated.  Films  such  as  this  echo  Martin  Nicklaus'  celebrated  remarks  about  sociologists:  Professional  palms  turned  upwards  and  professional  eyes  cast  downwards.  They  should  be  viewed  as  a  sort  of  cinematic  colonialism  and  do  nothing  to  advance  the  cause  of  feminism  or  anything  else.  In  Madame  X,  Ulrike  Ottinger  indulges  in  another  kind  of  feminist  myth-making,  with  a  141  minute  endurance  test  that  owes  a  lot  to  Lord  of  the  Flies.  Ottinger  has  gathered  together  seven  women  repre  senting  seven  different  female  stereotypes,  put  them  out  to  sea  on  a  junk  and  left  them  to  it.  Meanwhile  she  experiments  with  a  variety  of  encounters  and  camera  angles  which  are  supposed  to  prove  (I  think)  that  we  are  all  trapped  by  the  past  and  forging  a  new  society  is  going  to  be  a  lot  more  difficult  than  Utopians  imagine.  Most  of  the  budget  for  this  film  appears  to  have  been  squandered  by  the  art  department  and,  in  particular,  on  some  wonderfully  lavish  costumes.  The  rest  of  the  production  is  an  obscure  celebration  of  the  amateurish  which,  had  it  been  directed  by  a  man,  would  not  have  rated  a  showing.   What,  for  me,  is  confusing  about  these  films  is  that  they  seem  to  have  so  little  in  common  with  the  films  of  men  like  Herzog,  Wenders,  Fassbinder  and  Haupt  that  have  been  shown  here  and  it  is  not  enough  to  say  defiantly  that  women  make  films  differently  from  men.  The  aest-known  contemporary  German  films  have  a  sense  of  self-assurance.  These  films,  by  and  large,  do  not.  People  steeped  in  the  Australian  feminist  film  tradition  also  will  find  very  little  in  these  films  with  which  they  would  feel  familiar.  Australian  women's  films  seem  to  have  a  sense  of  purpose  -  conflicting  purpose  often  —  but  purpose  nonetheless.  By  contrast,  these  German  women's  films  have  a  strong  grasp  of  the  flaws  in  the  present,  know  exactly  what  was  wrong  with  the  past  and  have  almost  nothing  to  say  about  the  future.   Barbara  Alysen   Redupers   RONDA  MACGREGOR  ?  RIM  EDITOR  A  PHONE  622  080
snippet: For Australian women making films, reliant on grant monies and the nontheatrical market for distribution, the experience of West German feminist film

heading: German ties worsen
article_text: ?   EAST  BERLIN,  Tues,  AAP-.—  East  .German  .  leader  Mr  -  Erich  .-/Hon-;,  ecker  has  buried  an  era  of  good  relations  between,  •  East  Berlin  .and.  1  Bonn  with  a  major  attack  on  West  Germany  and  a  demand  that  Bonn  formally  recognise  the  existence  of  two  German  states.  .  Speaking  in  .  the  ~  southern  town  of  Gera  last  night,  Mr  Honecker  delivered  one  of  his  strongest  denunciations  of  the  Bonn  Government's  policies  in  years.  The  speech  came  as  /East  Germany  put  into  force  drastic  increases  in  exchange  require-  -  ments  .for  Western  visitors  which  had  already  soured  relations  between  the  two  states  and  caused  fury  in  Bonn.  The  Communist  Party  chief  accused  West  Germany  of  being  the  major  initiator,  along  with  the  United  States,  of  a  deliberate  Western  attempt  to  wreck  East-West  detente.

heading: Saudi-German link
article_text: •  Saudi-German  link   BONN:  The  Rheinmetall  Company  which  manufactures  the  powerful  Leopard  2  tank  cannon  has  refused  to  confirm  or  deny  reports  that  Saudi  Afrabia  is  soon  to  buy  24  percent  of  the  film.   A  company  spokesman  in  Duesseldorf  said  that  they  were  “surprised.”   The  Saudi  bid  to  buy  shares  of  Rheinmetall  has  been  interpreted  here  as  a  move  which  will  give  them  access  to  sensitive  military  technology  and  which  will  place  them  in  a  better  position  to  eventually  purchase  the  Leopard  2  tanks.   Israel  has  opposed  any  move  by  West  Germany  to  sell  the  tanks  to  Saudi  Arabia,  stressing  that  Israel’s  national  security  would  be  gravely  endangered.   Israel  has  also  expressed  criticism  of  any  move  that  would  enable  the  Saudis  to  be  represented  on  the  Board  of  Rheinmetall  because  of  the  undue  influence  it  would  have  in  the  firm’s  operations  and  sales.
snippet: BONN: The Rheinmetall Company which manufactures the powerful Leopard 2 tank cannon has refused to confirm or deny reports that Saudi Afrabia is soon to buy 24 percent of the film.

Fifty  five  per  cent  of  the  visitors  had  described  their  vaca   tions  in  Israel  as  “very  good”,  another  33  per  cent  as;;  “good”.

heading: West German policy
article_text: •  West  German  policy   Bonn:  Israel’s  right  of  existence  within  secure  borders  con*'  tinues  to  form  an  essential  part  of  West  Germany’s  Middle  East  policy,  Government  circles  here  have  pointed.  out,  following  an  appeal  by  Israeli  Foreign  Minister  Itzhak  Shamir  to  Bonn  not  to  support  any  initiative  aimed  at  the  establish  ment  of  a  Palestinian  State  which  would  spell  the  beginning  of   the  end  of  the  Jewish  State.

heading: PROVIS UPSETS GERMAN
article_text: PARIS,  Saturday  (AAP).  —  Melbourne  teenager  Nicole  Provis  scored  the  biggest  win  of  her  ten  nis  career  yesterday,  when  she  came  from  1-0  down  to  topple  sev  enth  seed  Claudia  Kohde-Kilsch  in  the  third  round  of  the  French  Open.   (  In  a  match  which  featured  13  breaks  of  serve,  the  18-year-old  outplayed  her  more  experienced  West  ,  German  oppo  nent  in  every  department.   The  1-6,  6-4,  7-5  win  earned  Provis  a  fourth-round  meeting  with  another  West  Ger  man,  15th-seeded  Sylvia  Hanika  and  a  dis  tinct  possibility  of  reaching  the  quarter-finals.  -  While  Kohde-Kilsch  is  ranked  ninth  in  the   world,  Hanika  is  28th  and  apart  from  an  appearance  in  the  final  in  1981,  she  has  never  gone-beyond  the  fourth  round  of  the  French  Open.  .   Provis  is  53rd  in  world  rankings  and  -  seemed  certain  to  be  overpowered  yesterday   with  her.  form  in  the  first  set  providing  no  clue  to  the  fightback  that  followed.   :  The  first  four  games  of  the  second  set  went  to"  serve  as  the  Australian  introduced  more  variety  to  her  game.   .  She  broke  Kohde-Kilsch's  serve  in  the  fifth  game,  was  broken  herself  in  the  sixth  and  then  the  two  players  traded  breaks  until  Provis  .  held  serve  in  the  10th  game  tp  take  the  set  6-4.   ;  The  pattern  was  repeated  in  the  third  set,  as  the  first  four  games  went  with  serve,  the  next  four  against  and  finally  Provis  put  together   two  in  a  row  to  take  the  match.   Provis  blamed  her  mental  approach  for  her  slow  start  to  the  game  as  well  as  for  her  strong  finish.   .  i  often  seem  to  go  out  there  and  find  myself  down  1-6  and  suddenly  wake  up  and  realise  I'd  better  do  something,"  she  said.   .  "In  the  last  few  games  I  knew  I  had  to  keep  calm  and  take  a  bit  of  pace  off  my  serve.   "My  arm  was  starting  to  shake  toward  the  finish/but  in  the  end  she  made  the  mistakes."   Provis  is  the  first  Australian  woman  since  Diane  Balestrat  and  Wendy  Turnbull  in  1980  to  go  beyond  the  third  round  of  the  French  Open.   It  is  also  a  personal  highlight  for  Provis  who  has  never  been  beyond  the  third  round  in  a   Grand  Slam  tournament,  having  been  beaten  at  that  stage  in  the  US  Open  last  year.   ■  Second  seed  Martina  Navratilova,  who  has  been  going  to  Paris  for  15  years  without  ever  finding  an  opportunity  to  see  the  Mona  Lisa,  gave  herself  ample  time  for  sightseeing  with  her  brisk  victory  at  the  French  Open  championships  yesterday.   The  31-year-old  player,  who  is  twice  former  champion  and  also  runner-up  in  each  of  the  past  three  years,  reached  the  last  16  with  a  6-2,  6-2  victory  over  Austrian  Barbara  Paulus  in  50  minutes  of  dazzling  tennis  on  the  centre  court  at  Roland  Garros.   Watched  by  actress/singer  Liza  Minelli,  Navratilova  produced  her  own  one-woman  cabaret  against  a  more  than  competent  17  year-old  opponent  who  is  among  a  band  of  fine  players  emerging  from  Austria  at  the   present  time.   Throughout  the  five  days  of  the  champion  ship,  Navratilova  has  continually  stressed  her  belief  that  she  remains  the  best  player  in  the  world,  despite  the  claims  of  reigning  French  and  Australian  champion  and  official  world  No  1,  Steffi  Graf.   Her  argument  is  open  to  question,  but  Na  vratilova  has  dropped  only  seven  games  in  three  matches  —  though  second-round  oppo  nent  Hellas  Ter  Riet  of  the  Netherlands  pul  led  out  through  illness  at  6-0,  1-0  —  and  her  powers  appear  undiminished.   Tomorrow  her  opponent  for  a  place  in  the  quarter-finals  will  be  the  13th-seeded  Russian  Natalia  Zverva.  Zverva  was  world  junior  champion  in  1987  when  she  won  the  French,  U.S.  and  Wimbledon  events  for  that  age.   Zverva,  as  American  as  Chris  Evert  in  ap  pearance  with  her  blonde  ponytail  arid  dou  ble-fisted  backhand,  thrashed  Melissa  Gurney  of  the  US  6-0,6-4  on  No  2  court.   Two  other  women's  seeds  won  with  vary  ing  degrees  of  discomfort.   Sixth-ranked  Helena  Sukova,  of  Czechoslo  vakia,  dropped  eight  games  to  wily  claycourt  "  specialist  Mercedes  Paz,  of  Argentina,..and  West  German  Sylvia  Hanika-had  even  more  trouble  in  subduing  French  number  two  Isa  belle  Demongeot  in  a  three-hour  war  of  attri  tion  on  the  centre  court.   Hanika  won  3-6,  7-5,6-4  without  ever  gain  ing  totally  ascendancy  over  a  gritty  opponent  who  thoroughly  deserved  the  rousing  ovation  she  was  granted  by  the  centre-court  crowd.  .   Sukova  went  through  6-4,6-4.   Nicole  Provis  slams  home  a  backhand  shot  as  part  of  her  history-making  win   oyer  West  German  Claudia  Kbhde-Kilsch  in  the  French  Open's  third  round.   BIGGEST  OLYMPIC  TEAM  GETS  OK   MELBOURNE:  The  Australian  Olympic  Federation  yesterday  ratified  a  270-member  Olympic  team  to  compete  in  the  Seoul  ,  Olympics  later  this  year.   The  team  —  the  latest  team  to  represent  Australia  overseas,  with  30  more  members  than  the  1984  team  —  could  grow  even  larger.   '  The  men's  and  women's  road-cycling  team  is  currently  in  Europe  attempting  to  qualify  while  the  women's  basketball  team  left  Aus  tralia  on  Friday  to  compete  in  the  qualifying  titles  in  Malaysia  next  month.   -  AOF  vice-president  John  Coates  said  he  would  lead  a  four-man  party  to  Seoul  soon  to  inspect  the  Olympic  Village.   /  He  said  it  was  important  the  Australian's  ./were  jjllocatfd  statable  accommodation  .close  »  to'treriiHHjpfaCTlhits.  &  v  "•  •»'»  Ut   "There  are  low-rise  and  high-rise  buildings  in  the  village,  and  all  have  only  one  lift,"  Coates  told  the  AOF  Assembly  meeting  yes-,  terday.   "It's  important  we  don't  end  up  in  a  24-sto  rey  building  with  only  one  lift.   He  said  the  Olympic  team  would  gather  in  Canberra  from  August  25  to  28  for  medical  and  drug  tests  and  counselling  from  former  Olympians  and  psychologists.   "It's  the  first  time  we  have  done  this  and  we  hope  it  will  bring  the  team  together  as  a  cohesive  unit,"  Coates  said. heading: German arms query
article_text: •  German  arms  query   DUSSELDORF:  A  Bonn  Government  spokesman  has  denied  West  German  press  reports  that  Chancellor  Helmut  Schmidt  has  decided  against  supplying  Leopard  tanks  and  other  arms  to  Saudi  Arabia.   The.  spokesman,  also  dismissed  reports  that  West  Germany  is  trying  to  devise  a  compromise,  under  which  West  German  arms  would  be  supplied;  to  Saudi  Arabia  within  the  framework  of  the  North  Atlantic  Treaty  Organisation  (Nato),  with  the  participation  of  other  member  countries.   Chancellor  Schmidt’s  Government  is  being  subjected  to  conflicting  pressures  on  the  issue.  ■
snippet: DUSSELDORF: A Bonn Government spokesman has denied West German press reports that Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has decided against supplying Leopard tanks and other arms to Saudi Arabia.

heading: GERMAN FAMILY SOUGHT
article_text: The  Australian  Jewish  Historical  Society  has  received  an  enquiry  from  Germany,  seeking  infor  mation  about  a  lost  family.   The  society’s  archivist  Helen  Bursten  said  Norbert  Sils,  of  Velbert,  West  Ger  many,  was  looking  for  any  information  about  the  fam  ily  of  Max  and  Kathe  Ding  felder.   Max  was  born  in  1890  and  Kathe  in  1913  with  the  maiden  name  Lustig.   Ms  Bursten  invited  any  one  with  any  relevant  information  to  contact  her  at  the  society’s  Sydney  office,  based  at  the  Great  Synagogue.

heading: GERMAN-ISRAELI RELATIONSHIP
article_text: L   GERMAN-ISRAELI  RELATIONSHIP   To  the  Editor  of  The  Jerusalem  Post   Sir,  -1  refer  to  Susan  Hattis  Rolef  s  review  (February  7)  of  Lily  Gard  ner’s  book,  Special  relationship  be  tween  West  Germany  and  Israel  -  a  highly  interesting  and  extremely   well-documented  book  which  merits  the  attention  of  all  people  of  good  will,  especially  among  the  younger  generations  in  Israel  and  West  Ger  many.   I  am  somewhat  disturbed  by  some  of  Ms.  Rolefs  unfounded  judge  ments  concerning  the  German  youn  ger  generation  and  its  attitude  to  wards  Israel.   Having  worked  for  a  number  of  years  in  the  field  of  bilateral  youth  exchanges  between  Israel  and  West  Germany,  I  cannot  accept  the  allega  tion  that  the  “German  post-war  gen  eration...  is  not  committed  to  sup  port  Israel.  Some  tend  even  to   associate  it  with  Fascism.”   It  is  quite  true  that  there  has  been  a  remarkable  (and  necessary)  change  of  attitudes  towards  Israel  since  1967/68  among  the  politically  interested  young  people  in  Ger  many,  but  it  is  incorrect  to  describe  this  changement  in  terms  of  mere  anti-Semitism  and  anti-Zionism.  (Most  young  people  here  have  no   idea  what  Zionism  means  and  what   its  implications  are  for  the  Jewish  people.)   The  “intricate  network  of  rela   tions”  now  existing  between  our  two  countries  does  not  depend  solely  on  the  generation  born  before  World  War  II.  The  politically  responsible  younger  generation  in  all  democratic  parties  of  the  Federal  Republic  sup  port  the  uniqueness  of  the  German  Israeli/Jewish  relationship  without  agreeing  with  each  and  every  politic   al  move  of  the  Israeli  or  West  Ger  man  government.   We  wanted  critical  and  concerned  citizens  -  now  we  have  some  in  both  our  countries,  let  them  meet.  They   are  better  than  those  so-called   “friends  of  Israel”  with  a  Nazi  past   and  sometimes  a  less  democratic  present.   HARTWIG  BIERHOFF  Bonn.   Susan  Hattis  Rolef  comments:   I  am  certainly  well  aware  of  the  many  bilateral  youth  exchanges  be  tween  Israel  and  the  Federal  Repub  lic  of  Germany:  I  have  just  had  a  17-year  old  German  boy  from  Braunschweig  staying  in  my  home  for  10  days.  But  what  percentage  of  German  youth  is  involved  in  these  programmes?  Do  they  all  return  to  Germany  committed  to  the  pre  servation  of  the  “special”  rela  tionship  between  the  two  countries?  And  what  about  all  the  young  Ger  mans  who  have  greater  sympathy  for  the  Palestinians  and  regard  Israel  merely  as  an  occupier  and  oppres  sor,  the  sort  of  state  they  have  learned  to  despise  in  Anti   Faschismus  classes  at  school?   Undoubtedly,  a  large  number  of  highly  devoted  people  are  doing  marvellous  work  in  trying  to  im  prove  German-Jewish/Israeli  rela  tions.  I  myself  am  involved  in  this  process  on  many  levels.  However,  both  from  personal  exeprience  in  Germany  and  from  empirical  evi  dence,  I  am  not  as  optimistic  about   the  future  as  Dr.  Feldman  is  in  her  book.   People  like  Hartwig  Bierhoff  cer  tainly  deserve  encouragement  -  but   not  at  the  cost  of  realism.
snippet: To the Editor of The Jerusalem Post Sir, - I refer to Susan Hattis Rolef's review (February 7) of Lily Gardner’s book, Special relationship

heading: German’s retried
article_text: German’s  retried   FRANKFURT:  The  retrial  opened  before  a  jury  here  of  three  German  physicians  charged  with  complicity  in  the  murder  of  thousands  of  mentally  handicapped  persons  under  the  Nazi  euthanasia  programme  in  1940  and  1941.   Dr  Aquilin  Ullrich,  71,  Dr  Heinrich  Bunke,  71,  and  Dr  Klaus  Endruweit,  72,  had  been  acquitted  on  this  same  charge  here  in   1967.   Proceedings  against  Dr  Endruweit  were  immediately  separated  from  the  rest  for  reasons  of  the  defendant’s  ill-health,  who  claimed  that  he  was  physically  unfit  to  stand  trial,  and  ask  ed  that  his  case  be  suspended.   Dr  Ullrfch  surprised  the  jury  with  the  same  plea,  but  the  court  declined  to  decide  in  his  favour,  pointing  at  medical  testimonies  submitted  last  autumn  saying  that  all  three  suspects  were  “fit  for  trial,”  provided  that  weekly  sessions  in  court  were  limited  to  a  maximum  three  hours.   Their  1967  acquittals  had  been  based  on  the  argument  that  they  had  been  unaware  of  the  criminal  character  of  their  active  part  in  the  Nazi  mercy-killing  programme.   The  verdict  had  been  annulled  by  the  Federal  Supreme  Court.  A  first  retrial  in  1972  had  been  dropped  because  of  the  defen  dants’  ill-health.  From  1972  to  1985,  all  three  had  successfully  claimed  to  be  unfit  for  further  court  proceedings  but  continued  to  work  as  full-time  physicians  all  the  time.
snippet: FRANKFURT: The retrial opened before a jury here of three German physicians charged with complicity in the murder of thousands of mentally handicapped persons under the Nazi euthanasia programme in 1940 and 1941.

heading: TELEVISION German Jews
article_text: TELEVISION   German  Jews   The  situation  of  Jews  in  post-war  Germany  will  be  examined  in  a  television  documentary  on  Wednesday.   The  program  will  be  screened  on  SBS’s  Religions  of  the  World  pro   gram.   Presenter,  Adolf  Holl,  discussed  with  a  young  German  writer  his  reac  tions  to  the  position  of  Jews  in  today’s  Germany.   He  also  talks  to  Holo  caust  survivors  in  Poland.   A  German  rabbi  explains  his  position  and  function  in  the  Jewish  community.
snippet: The situation of Jews in post-war Germany will be examined in a television documentary on Wednesday.

heading: East German visitor
article_text: East  German  visitor   East  German  Secretary  of  State  for  Church  Affairs  Kurt  Loeffler  said  he  saw  his  visit  to  Israel  last  week  as  a   first  step  towards  establishing  bilat  eral  relations.  “You  can't  attempt  everything  at  once.  It  requires  much  understanding  all  round,  so  that  no  difficulties  arise,"  he  told  The  Post.   Loeffler  and  his  party  of  three  were  guests  of  Yad  Vashem.  He  de  clined  to  visit  Christian,  Jewish  or  Moslem  holy  places,  concentrating   on  talks  to  facilitate  Israel  research   on  the  Holocaust  in  East  Germany.   He  deplored  Mayor  Teddy  Kol   lek's  refusal  to  receive  him  because   the  GDR  does  not  recognize  Israel.   (Editorial  -  Back  Pap}

heading: Seeking German settlers
article_text: Seeking  German   settlers   Sir,  -  1  am  a  tutor  at  Wollongong  University  currently  researching  the  history  of  German  settlement  in  Australia.   What  I  seek  therefore,  is  to  cor  respond  with  German  settlers  who  are  willing  to  relate  their  experiences  as  migrants  in  a  strange  country.  Why  did  they  leave,  how  did  they  settle,  how  have  they  coped?  Do  they  feel  that  their  stories  are  unique  or  special?   If  so  would  any  interested  readers  of  this  letter  please  contact  me,  Alfred  Werner,  c/-  The  Sociology  Department,  Wollongong  Univer  sity,  PO  Box  1144,  Wollongong,  NSW  2500.  All  material  will  be   returned  if  required.   ALFRED  WERNER
snippet: Sir, — I am a tutor at Wollongong University currently researching the history of German settlement in Australia.

The  behaviour  of  the  youth  is  a  result  ol  many  lactors  and  is  full  of  just  as  many  contradictions.  The  economic  situation  of  the  country  is  very  oppressive.  Jobs  arc  scarce  and  opportunities  lor  the  individual  to  distinguish  him/  herself  rare.  In  post-war  Germany  effort  was  required  to  develop  the  shattered  economy  to  its  present  sophisticated  level.  But  today  most  potential  has  been  realized.  The  economy  can  not  really  progress  much  further  and  thus  the  future  for  young  school-leavers  and  students  looks  fairly  grim.  Tertiary  education  is  structured  differently  in  Germany  if  you  are  fortunate  enough  to  secuie  a  place  at  a  tertiary  institute  close  to  home,  you  are  faced  with  the  prospect  of  a  heavy,  long  course  based  purely  on  lectures  (no  tutorials)  and  in  most  cases,  the  lack  of  any  campus  life  whatsoever.  Some  courses  are  only  assessed  at  the  completion  of  study  and  the  rate  of  failure  is  predictably  high.  For  example,  Law  in  Munich  is  examined  for  the  first  time  at  the  end  of  a  five  year  course. The  parents,  on  the  other  hand  are  intensely  proud  ol  what  they  have  achieved  since  the  war,  of  the  material  comforts  which  they  have  been  able  to  provide  their  childien  with  and  are  confused  and  hurl  by  this  criticism  and  rejection,  which  they  attribute  to  laziness  and  lack  ol  motivation. heading: German exodus resumes
article_text: German  exodus   resumes   HOF,  West  Germany:  Cheering  and  weeping  with  joy,  the  first  of  nearly  5000  East  German  refugees  who  had  holed  up  in  West  Ger  man  embassies  in  Czecho  slovakia  and  Poland  arrived  in  the  West  yesterday.   On  Saturday,  East  Germany  agreed  to  the  exodus  after  a  re  markable  accord  between  Soviet  bloc  and  Western  nations  ended  a  deadlock  that  forccd  many  of  the  refugees  to  spend  weeks  camping  outside  the  embassies.   The  first  train  carrying  East  Germans  who  had  sought  refuge  in  the  West  German  embassy  in  Prague  arrived  in  the  Bavarian  city  of  Hof  at  6.14am.  Several  hundred  local  residents  who  gathered  to  greet  the  newcomers  applauded  as  the  train  pulled  in   to  the  station.   Well-wishers  handed  out  bot  tles  of  wine,  champagne  and  fruit  .  as  the  East  Germans  got  off  the   train.   Jorg  Hauschild,  who  travelled  with  his  wife,  Veronica,  and  three  children,  said:  "We're  so  very  happy  to  be  here,  but  we're   so  tired."   Uwc  Kucster,  34,  an  engineer  from  Cottbus,  said  he  decided  to  leave  East  Germany  after  being  harassed  by  authoritios^forapply  'Mg'tb  leave  the  country  legally.   "We  had  no  future  there,"  he  said  as  he  hugged  his  wife.  "We  ...had^'asflat,  we  didn!t  live  badly.   But  it^was  like  we  were  living  behind  a  big  mountain  that  we'd  never  get  over."   •  The  agreement  announced  on  Saturday  covered  some  3500  East  Germans  who  began  crowd  ing  into  the  embassy  in  Prague  several  weeks  ago  and  more  than  800  East  Germans  at  the  embassy  in  Warsaw,  Poland.   The  accord  and  its  details  were  announced  by  officials  in  West  Germany,  East  Germany,  Czechoslovakia  and  Poland.   On  arriving  in  Hof,  many  of  the  refugees  quickly  made  their  way  to  a  bank  of  telephone  booths  in  the  station  in  mostly  futile  efforts  to  reach  relatives  in  East  Germany.   Most  had  little  or  no  West  German  money  and  the  few  who  did  faccd  constant  busy  signals   from  commynist  East  Germa  ny's  overtaxed  telephone  cir  cuits.   Amid  the  crush  on  the  plat  form,  station  loudspeakers  called  out  the  names  of  new  arrivals  who  had  relatives  waiting  for  them.  Officials  said  about  780  refugees  were  on  the  train.   In  Poland,  more  than  800  ref  ugees  boarded  an  East  German  train  that  left  Warsaw's  Eastern  Station  before  dawn  yesterday,   headed  for  the  West  German  bor-y  der  city  of  Helmstedt.  They  were  due  to  arrive  later  in  the  day.   A  diplomat  told  them  before  they  left  Warsaw:  "You  can  go  tomorrow  to  Octoberfest  in  Mu  nich."   More  than  3500  East  Ger  mans  were  en  route  by  train  from  Prague  to  West  Germany  by  ear  ly  yesterday,  West  German  offi   cials  said.   Some  of  the  refugees  had  spent  weeks  huddled  in  tents  and  on  cots  in  the  embassy  com  pound  amid  growing  crowding,  spreading  disease  and  worsening   weather.   East  Germany,  which  had  harshly  criticised  Hungary  for  al  lowing  a  similar  refugee  exodus,  said  it  granted  the  transfer  as  a  "humanitarian  act".  .   7  Horst  Wafierischmidt,'.a~state"   secretary  in  the  federal  Interior  Ministry,  said  Bonn  had  not  paid  ,  to  secure  passage  for  the  refugees.   "There  was  no  buy-out,  no  ransom,"  Mr  Waffenschmidt  said.  "No  money  was  demanded  and  no  money  was  paid."   West  German  Foreign  Minis  ter  Hans-Dietrich  Genscher  had  made  an  unexpected  visit  to  Prague  on  Saturday  and  deliv  ered  news  of  the  accord  to  East  Germans  at  the  embassy.   "I  call  you  fellow  citizens,  and  express  a  hearty  welcome,"  Mr  Genscher,  speaking  from  an  em  bassy  balcony,  told  the  weary  but  ecstatic  crowd  huddled  in  the  muddy  compound.   He  told  reporters  the  solution  was  agreed  early  on  Saturday  in  consultations  with  the  East  Ger  mans,  Czechoslovaks  and  Poles.   —  AP

article_text: ?   The  executive  officer  and  president  of  the  PNG  Chamber  of  Commerce  and  Industry,  Mr  John.  Cruikslhank,  returned  recently  from  Germany  after  attending-  a  three  -  week  training  course  for  chamber  officials  from  developing"  countries.  .  The  course,  financed  by  the  government  of  the  Federal  Republic  of  Germany,  focussed  on  :  trade  promotion  services.  Officials  from  national  chambers  of  commerce  and  industry  in  15  developing  countries  were  selected  from  60  applicants  to  attend  the  course.  PNG  was  the  only  South  Pacific  country  represented.  The  course  covered  the  organisation  and  management  of  technical  trade  promotion  services,  trade  promotion  techniques,  export  marketing  methods  and  trade'  facilitation  measures.  The  course  was  the  first  to  be  conducted  under  the  International  Trade  Centre's  program  of  co-operation  with  national  chambers  of  commerce.   ? heading: West German problems
article_text: •  West  German  problems   .  FRANKFURT:  Problems  concerning  the  security  and  func  tioning  of  Jewish  communities  ini  West  Germany  in  the  face  of  recent  neo-Nazi  activities  and  excesses  both  in  this  country  and  abroad  were  discussed  at  a  meeting  of  the  board  of  the  Central  Council  of  Jews  in  Germany  here  recently.   In  the  light  of  reports  that  private  groups  in  Israel  were  planning  to  send  special  security  commandos  to  protect  Jewish  institutions  in'this  country  and  elsewhere,  the  board  pointed  out  that  Jewish  security  was  not  a  problem  of  private  initiative  but  had  to  be  ensured  by  the  state  organs  whose  undebated  duty  it  was  to  protect  Jewish  institutions  against  all  possible  threats  from  outside.   Plans  to  send  Israeli  volunteers  to  take  over  security  tasks  with  the  Jewish  communities  here  were  also  rejected  by  Ger  man  police  circles.  A  spokesman  said  here  that,  apart  from  the  legal  problems  involved,  no  such  Israeli  help  was  required,  since  the  West  German  security  agendes  were  themselves  able  enough  to  take  care  of  all  security  affairs  in  this  country.

heading: German musical magic
article_text: German  musical  magic   Visiting  German  hornist,  Hermann  Baumann,  rehearses  at  the  Canberra  School  of  Music  for  his  concert  at  the  Llewellyn  Hall   tonieht.   German  virtuoso  of  the  French  and  natural  horns  Hermann  Baumann  will  weave  his  musical  magic  in  a  perfor  mance  at  the  Llewellyn  Hall,  Canberra  School  of  Music,  tonight.   Mr  Baumann,  recognised  along  with  Australian  Barry  Tuckwell  as  the  great  virtuoso  hornists  in  the  world,  will  perform  a  program  of  works  by  Bee  thoven,  Brahms,  Glazunov,  Pfluger,   Ireland  and  Strauss,  as  well  as  his  own  compositions.   He  will  be  accompanied  by  associ  ate  artist,  pianist  Malcolm  Tapscott.   Mr  Baumann,  who  is  reknowned  for  his  unique  teaching  methods,  taught  a  master  class  at  the  School  of  Music   after  rehearsal  yesterday.   Admission  is  free  for  the  8.15pm   concert.
snippet: German virtuoso of the French and natural horns Hermann Baumann will weave his musical magic in a performance at the Llewellyn Hall, Canberra

heading: GERMAN LEADS OFF
article_text: GERMAN  LEADS  OFF   SURFERS  PARADISE:  The  longest  yet  Com-   monwealth  Bank  Cycle  Classic  begins  in  earnest  today  when  70  Australian  and  international  riders  face  the  Pacific  Highway  from  the  Gold  Coast  to  Baliina. Held  on  a  1km  course  around  a  suburban  shop-   ping  centre,  the  time  trial  was  a  test  of  rider  against  the  clock,  the  heat  and  a  gusty  wind.  ;   Australian  rider  Barney  St  George  described  it  as  a  good  course,  but  said  most  of  the  riders  would  have  suffered  through  lack  of  familiarity.
