heading: East German visit
article_text: •  East  German  visit   EAST  BERLIN:  East  German  Communist  Party  and  State  chief  Erich  Honecker  paid  a  four-day  official  visit  to  Syria   last  week.   At  a  reception  given  to  him  by  President  Assad,  he  condemned  the  “bloody  misdeeds”  against  the  Palestinian,  Lebanese  and  Syrian  peoples  committed  by  Israel.  He  called  for  immediate  Israeli  withdrawal  from  Lebanese  territory.   While  in  Damascus,  the  East  German  leader  signed  several  agreements  on  future  East  German-Syrian  co-operation,  in  the  fields  of  trade,  industry,  health,  social  affairs  and  the  sciences,  and  exchange  of  technical  know-how.
snippet: EAST BERLIN: East German Communist Party and State chief Erich Honecker paid a four-day official visit to Syria last week. At a reception given to him by President Assad, he

heading: New German president
article_text: New  German  president   BONN:  Baron  Richard  von  Weizsaecker,  who  as  an  officer  in  the  Wehrmacht  was  implicated  in  the  failed  attempt  to  assassinate  Hitler  in  1944,  was  overwhelmingly  elected  as  the  sixth  President  of  the  West  German  Federal  Republic.   Weizsaecker,  64,  a  member  of  Chancellor  Helmut  Kohl’s  ruling  Christian  Democratic  Union  and  a  former  mayor  of  West  Berlin,  received  832  votes  in  the  Federal  Parliament  to  68  for  his  only  rival,  author  Luise  Rinser.   Weizsaecker,  a  captain  in  1944,  was  one  of  the  few  named  in  connection  with  the  attempted  military  coup  against  Hitler  to  survive.  Nineteen  of  his  regimental  colleagues  were  among  the  officers  executed.
snippet: BONN: Baron Richard von Weizsaecker, who as an officer in the Wehrmacht was implicated in the failed attempt to assassinate Hitler in 1944, was overwhelmingly elected as the sixth President of the

heading: German arms deal
article_text: •  German  arms  deal   London:  West  German  businessmen  are  secretly  trying  to  sell  weapons  to  at  least  four  Arab  countries,  according  'to  documents  gathered  by  the  ‘London  Observer’.   The  largest  of  the  projected  arms  sales  contracts  is  for  42,000  military  vehicles  for  Syria  made  by  Magirus-Deutz   Company,  the‘Observer’said.   Another,  projected  contract  is  for  ultracentrifugal  machines  for  Libya  to  enable  the  country  to  make  atomic  bombs.  Other  projected  contracts,  the  Observer  reported,  are  for  Leopard  assault  tanks  for  Saudi  Arabia  and  2,000  Magirus-Deutz  military  vehicles  for  Iraq.  In  an  exclusive  front  page  story,  details  are  given  of  deals  in  the  pipeline  which,  if  concluded,  would  be  of  immense  benefit  to  Syria,  Libya;  Saudi  Arabia  and  Iraq.  Libya,  for  example,  would  be  able  to  make  a  nuclear  bomb,  and  Syria  would  be  able  to  reduce  its  dependence  on  Soviet  supplies.   The  consortium  of  companies  calling  themselves  the  Nato  Standard  Company,  and  including  MagifusVDeutz  are  also  shown  by  the  Observer  report  to  have  played  a.  vital  part  in  the  Yom  Kippur  War.

heading: East German visitor
article_text: East  German  viator   East  German  Secretary  of  State  for   Church  Affairs  Kurt  Loeffler  said  he  saw  his  visit  to  Israel  last  week  as  a   first  step  towards  establishing  bilat  eral  relations.  “You  can't  attempt  everything  at  once.  It  requires  much  understanding  all  round,  so  that  no  difficulties  arise,"  he  told  The  Post.   Loeffler  and  his  party  of  three  were  guests  of  Yad  Vashem.  He  de  clined  to  visit  Christian,  Jewish  or  Moslem  holy  places,  concentrating   on  talks  to  facilitate  Israel  research   on  the  Holocaust  in  East  Germany.   He  deplored  Mayor  Teddy  Kol  iek's  refusal  to  receive  him  because  the  GDR  does  not  recognize  Israel.   (Editorial  -  Back  Page)

heading: German police protest
article_text: German  police  protest   FRANKFURT,  West  Germa  ny,  Wednesday  (Reuter).  —  Tens  of  thousands  of  police,  many  wear  ing  black  armbands,  marched  in  protest  rallies  in  West  Germany  yesterday  after  two  colleagues  were  killed  by  gunfire  while  dis  persing  a  torchlight  demonstra  tion.   In  a  number  of  cities,  police  cars  and  motorcycles  patrolled  with  black  mourning  ribbons  fluttering  from  radio  aerials  as  officers  mani  fested  grief  and  anger  at  the  kill  ings.   Mr  Klaus  Eichhoefer,  44,  and  Mr  Thorsten  Schwalm,  23,  were  shot  on  Monday  night  after  police  were  ordered  to  disperse  a  torch  light  procession  by  150  demon  strators  protesting  against  the  opening  of  a  runway  extension  at  Frankfurt  airport   Six  policemen  were  also  injured  in  the  clash,  two  by  gunshots,  and   one  was  in  a  grave  condition.   A  big  manhunt  was  launched  for  the  killer  or  killers.  Police  ar  rested  a  man  yesterday  after  find  ing  a  9mm  pistol,  of  the  type  used  in  Monday  night's  killings,  at  his   home.   They  said  the  weapon  had  been  stolen  from  a  police  officer  during  an  anti-nuclear  demonstration  in  1986.   The  murders,  the  first  of  police  on  demonstration  duties  in  West  Germany,  were  condemned  by  all  political  parties.  Members  of  Chancellor  Kohl's  Christian  Dem  ocrats  renewed  demands  for  legis  lation  to  ban  the  wearing  of  masks  by  demonstrators.   About  3500  police  officers  marched  in  Hamburg,  3000  in  West  Berlin  and  a  similar  number  in  Duesseldorf.  Other  rallies  were  staged  in  Bonn,  Kassel,  Koblenz,  Dortmund,  Bremen,  Mainz,  Lud   wigshafen,  and  Kaiserslautern.   The  marches  were  organised  by  the  German  Police  Union  to  pro  test  against  the  killings  and  de  mand  more  protection  for  officers  assigned  to  control  demonstra  tions.   The  torchlight  procession  out  side  Frankfurt  airport  was  part  of  protests  which  have  continued  against  the  runway  extension  de  spite  the  fact  it  has  been  in  opera  tion  since  1984.   When  police  ordered  the  march  ers  to  disperse,  protesters  wearing  black  hoods  and  masks  pelted  them  with  fireworks  and  fire  bombs.  The  shots  rang  out  when  200  police  backed  by  water  cannon  went  in  to  make  arrests.   West  German  authorities  an  nounced  a  100,000-mark  ($A87,788)  reward  would  be  of  fered  for  information  leading  to  conviction  of  the  killer  or  killers.
snippet: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Wednesday (Reuter). — Tens of thousands of police, many wearing black armbands, marched in

heading: West German challenge
article_text: West  German  challenge   HAMBURG,  Thursday  (AAP-Reuter).  —  A  group  of  West  German  yachtsmen  announced  yesterday  they  would  be  issuing  a  challenge  for  the  America's  Cup  in  1986.   Four  other  challengers  from  Australia  and  one  each  from  Britain,  France,  Sweden,  Italy  and   Canada  will  conduct  an  elimination  series  in  1983   to  determine  the  challenger  for  the  match  against   the  US  defender.
snippet: HAMBURG, Thursday (AAP-Reuter). — A group of West German yachtsmen announced yesterday they would be issuing a challenge for the America's Cup in 1986.

heading: German tennis unwinds
article_text: Picture:  Rauler   Larry  Robinson,  of  the  Montreal  Canadiens,  catches  a  high  stick  in  the  face  from  from  Brad  McCrimmon,  of  the  Calgary  Flames,   during  first  period  action  at  Calgary.  The  Canadiens  won  4-3.   German  tenuis  unwinds   By  DAVID  IRVINE   Never  before  have  the  Germans,  a  nation  with  no  great  tradition  in  tennis,  known  such  success  as   in  1988.   Apart  from  his  Davis  Cup  heroics,  Boris  Becker  was  a  worthy  winner  of  the  Masters  while,  on  ¡he  women's  front,  Steffi  Graf  recorded  only  the  third  Grand  Slam  of  all  time  —  then  burnished  it  with  Olympic  gold.   Since  Becker's  first  Wimbledon  triumph  at  17,  the  number  of  players  throughout  West  Germany  is  said  to  have  doubled  to  over  two  million.   Yet  still  the  feeling  persists  that,  though  the  personalities  are  projected,  the  game  itself  remains  a  lesser  relation  of  soccer  and  even  handball.   Many  believe  —  and  perhaps  with  good  reason  —  that  Becker  and  Graf  will  do  even  better  next  year.  If  they  do,  their  impact  through  television  will  again  be  limited.  Already  it  seems  the  main  channels  will  be  priced  out  of  the  Wimbledon  market.  West  Germans,  it  seems,  are  still  not  con  vinced  that  Becker  and  Graf  are  the  sort  of  catalyst  Björn  Borg  was  to  a  generation  of  Swedes.   "Here  in  Sweden,"  they  observe,  "tennis  is  avail  able  for  all.  In  Germany  people  are  still  priced   out."   They  also  say  —  and  the  evidence  tends  to  support  them  —  that  even  someone  as  talented  as  Carl-Uwe  Steeb,  who  made  the  cup  triumph  possi  ble  by  beating  Mats  Wilander,  prefers  the  comfort  of  the  Bundesliga,  where  sponsorship  can  bring  lucrative  rewards,  to  the  competitive  demands  of   the  circuit.   League  tennis,  which  extends  the  clay-court  sea  son,  has  been  the  bane  of  a  succession  of  West  German  national  coaches.  A  decade  ago  Rolf  Gehring  and  Uli  Pinner  were  among  Europe's  best,  but  they  never  sought  to  prove  it  on  a  world-wide   stage.   In  Becker  and  Graf,  though,  their  nation  has  been  blessed  with  two  superstars  possessing  an  insatiable  appetite  for  success.  Becker  says  he  is  ready  to  lift  his  game  to  a  new  level.   "Now  I  have  a  pretty  good  backhand  and  a  better  volley.  But  it's  more  that  my  approach  has  changed.  I'm  taking  it  more  seriously  than  before."   Since  losing  to  Stefan  Edberg  in  this  year's  Wim  bledon  final  —  his  greatest  disappointment  in  1988  —  Becker  has  been  beaten  onlj  twice.  From  April  to  December,  Graf  lost  just  once.  "But  we  both  like  winning,"  he  grins  as  if  in  explanation.   Though  Becker  made  his  mark  first,  it  is  Grafs   influence  which  is  perhaps  more  apparent.  A  re  cent  survey  showed  that  German  girls  arc  as  eager  to  play  like  her  as  Americans  are  to  follow  Chris  Evert's  example.  As  not  one  Evert  clone  has  suc  ceeded  since  Tracy  Austin  and  Andrea  Jaeger  "re  tired  hurt"  this  could  mean  that  if  Evert  and  Martina  Navratilova  choose  to  quit  —  which  may  well  happen  during  the  next  two  years  —  European  domination  of  the  women's  game  will  be  almost  complete.  Graf,  who  hits  her  ground  strokes  with  such  ferocity,  has  little  to  fear  from  the  game's  base-liners  and  has  shown,  increasingly,  that  the  forecourt  holds  no  terrors  for  her.   Becker,  who  raised  some  eyebrows  in  New  York  recently  by  declaring  that  clay  was  his  favourite  surface,  has  emerged  as  a  genuine  all-court  compet  'itor  over  the  past  year  —  and  seems  more  deter  mined  than  ever  to  match  Gottfried  von  Cramm,  the  only  German  ever  to  win  the  French  title.   Von  Cramm  won  the  French  twice,  was  run  ner-up  three  times  at  Wimbledon  and  once  at  Forest  Hills,  and  was  twice  US  doubles  champion  with  Henner  Henkel.  Few  doubt  Becker  can  im  prove  on  that.  For  Graf  a  unique  second  successive  Grand  Slam  in  1989  is  the  immediate  goal.   —  Guardian
snippet: Never before have the Germans, a nation with no great tradition in tennis, known such success as in 1988. Apart from his Davis Cup heroics, Boris Becker

heading: German Jews book topic
article_text: German  Jews   book  topic   Community  ofF&te,  the  memoirs  of  German  Jews  in  Melbourne,  captures  for  future  generations  what  it  was  like  being  a  migrant  in  the  Australian  Jewish  community  during  Vforld  V\for  II  and  immediately  following,   Professor  Louis  Whller  said.   Their  problems  -  were  not  unlike  those  faced  by  people  escaping  from  other  parts  of  war-time  Europe,  he  said.   Professor  Waller  was   speaking  at  the  launching  of  a  book  “Community  of  Fate”  by  Dr  John  Foster  in  B’nai   B’rith  House.   The  function  was  organised  jointly  by  the  Victorian  B’nai  B’rith  Council  and  the   publishers  Allen  and  Unwin   Australia.   The  book  contains  essays  by  14  members  of  the  communi  ty  who  fled  Germany  in  Wbrld  War  II  and  settled  in  Melbourne.   Professor  Whller  said  the   query  on  where  do  I  come  from  is  a  Jewish  question.   “Those  in  the  book  know,  and  knew,  from  whence  they   came.   “They  had  their  origins  in  various  parts  of  Germany.   “Where  am  I  is  another   Jewish  question  and  this  too  they  know.   “They  fled  to  what  to  all  in  tents  and  purposes  is  the  farthest  part  of  the  Jewish   world.   “Why  they  are  here  is  something  that  is  less  known.   INFLUENCE   “One  tiling  is  sure  -  Kristallnacht  had  its  effect  and  that  is  why  people  are   here.   “In  many  of  the  chapters,  there  is  a  feeling  of  how  un  just  the  situation  was.  V\fe  are  and  were  Germans  who  were  also  Jews.   “How  could  they  do  it  to  us  is  an  underlying  question,”  he   said.   Professor  Waller  said  in  many  of  the  chapters,  there  were  references  to  early  years  in  Melbourne  Jewry.   He  highlighted  the  memoir  by  Mrs  Suzie  Ehrmann  which  spoke  of  the  early  days  in  St  Kilda  Synagogue,  under  Rabbi  Jacob  Danglow,  where  while  the  order  of  service  was  not  unfamiliar,  the  atmosphere  and  attitude  towards  foreigners  was  cold.!   The  work  also  highlights  the  early  days  of  the  nearby  "tem  ple  Beth  Israel  and  B’nai   B’rith.   “It  is  an  historical  document  which  has  been  given  substance  by  historical  expertise.   INSPIRED   Dr  Foster  in  his  address  to  the  function  thanked  the  14   individuals  who  had  agreed   to  share  their  memories  with  his  students  in  what   was  originally  a  research  assignment.   He  said  the  idea  for  the  book  had  come  from  discussion  with  Mr  Kurt  Lippmann  and  his  wife  Marion.   But  his  interest  in  Jews,  and  German  Jews  in  particular  had   come  much  earlier.   Dr  Foster  said  that  one  of  his  fondest  and  earliest  memories  of  a  world  other  than  his  own  Australian  Christian   background  had  come  from  German  Jewish  neighbours  in  a  block  of  flats  in  St  Kilda  when  he  was  two  or  three  years  old.   “I  was  attracted  by  the  friendship  and  the  exciting  ac   cents  and  owe  much  to  Ger  trude  and  Fred  Katz  who  were   those  neighbours,”  he  said.   Mrs  Katz  is  one  of  the  14   people  in  the  book.   Mr  Kurt  Rathner  (chairman,  B’nai  B’rith  Council,  Victoria)  who  chaired  the  evening,  said   B’nai  B’rith  is  not  a  German   organisation  but  open  to  all  sections  of  the  community.   “If  a  book  is  written  about  any  other  section  of  Melbourne  or  Australian  Jewry,  B’nai  B’rith  gladly   would  be  associated  with  that   launching  too,”  he  said.
snippet: Community of Fate, the memoirs of German Jews in Melbourne, captures for future generations what it was like being a migrant in the Australian Jewish community during World War II and immediately following, Professor Louis Waller said.

heading: German makes catered for
article_text: German  makes   catered  for   Owners  of  Mcrcedcs-Bcnz  and  Volkswagen  vehi  cles  can  get  specialised  treatment  from  Phillip  Auto  ;  Engineers.   The  business  has  been  operating  for  eight  years  'and  moved  from  Colby  Court  to  join  the  Motorco   Center.   '  According  to  Mr  Bob  Cook,  who  operates  the  ;  business  with  Mr  Uwe  Nissen,  the  bulk  of  the  'company's  work  comes  from  VW  owners  with  about  ;30  per  cent  from  Mercedes-Benz  drivers.   A  high  proportion  of  the  VW  work  is  on  Kombis  !iand  campervans,  which  arc  quite  common  in  Can   berra.   Mr  Cook  said  he  has  been  working  on  the  two  "German  makes  for  more  than  20  years,  and  has  equipped  the  business  with  many  of  the  specialised  tools  required  for  the  marques.   The  company,  which  has  three  mechanics  and  an  apprentice,  also  has  a  Bosch  tune-up  machine,  a  lathe  for  brake  work  and  a  large  range  of  high-turnover   spare  parts.   The  business  also  handles  general  repairs  to  all  makes,  and  is  authorised  to  carry  out  repairs  for  ,  registration.

heading: W. German secretary defects
article_text: W.  German   secretary  defects   BONN,  Tuesday  (Rcutcr).  -  West  Germany  announced  today  that  a  sec  retary  in  the  office  of  the  Chancellor,  Dr  Helmut  Kohl,  had  defected  and  was  suspected  of  being  a  communist   spy.   However,  government  sources  re  tracted  earlier  statements  that  the  sec  retary,  Mrs  Herta-Astrid  Willner,  45,  had  had  access  to  details  of  President  Reagan's  'Star  Wars'  spacc  defcncc  research  project.   A  spokesman  announced  today  that  Mrs  Willner  and  her  husband,  Mr  Herbert  Adolf  Willner,  had  defected  to  East  Berlin  and  that  investigations  had  been  opened  against  both.   A  spokesman  for  the  chancellery  officially  denied  that  she  had  seen  'Star  Wars'  material  but  acknowledged  that  she  could  have  had  access  to  secret  information  on  Eureka,  the  European  high-technology  drive,  and  West  Ger  many's  nuclear  program.

heading: German press man dies
article_text: German  press   man  dies   The  press  and  cultural-affairs  at  tache  of  the  Embassy  of  the  Federal  Republic  of  Germany,  Mr  Hinrich  Kark,  has  died  in  Canberra,  aged  63.   Mr  Kark.  who  had  planned  to  stay  on  in  Canberra  after  his  retirement  in  1986,  had  a  long  and  close  association  with  Australian  media  circles.   Born  in  Hagcn  in  1921,  he  joined  the  West  German  Foreign  Service  in  Bonn  in  1954  and  served  in  Santiago,  Chile,  from  1956-59  before  his  first  posting  to  Canberra  from  1961-72.  He  returned  in  1980  after  a  tour  of  duty  in  Tokyo.   Mr  Kark,  who  suffered  a  heart  at  tack  last  year,  died  at  his  home  in  Richardson  on  Sunday.   He  leaves  a  wife,  Irmgard,  and  four  children.  Anne,  Henry,  Sabine  and  .  Tina,  and  three  grandchildren.   .The  funeral  is  at  Norwood  Park  Crematorium  at  3pm  today.  The  family  has  requested  that  no  con  dolences  be  offered.
snippet: The press and cultural-affairs attache of the Embassy of the Federal Republic of Germany, Mr Hinrich Kark, has died in Canberra, aged 63.

heading: IN BRIEF German victory
article_text: IN  BRIEF   German  victory   DORTMUND,  West  Germany,  Monday  (AAP  Reuter).  —  West  Germany  beat  Britain  in  an  indor  athletics  match  on  Friday  night.  The  German  men  won  by  79  points  to  59  and  the  women  65-41.   More  enter  mile  field   NEW  YORK,  Monday  (AAP-AP).  —  John  Walk  er,  of  New  Zealand;  Filbert  Bayi,  of  Tanzania;  Ireland's  Ray  Flynn,  and  West  German  Thomas  Wessinghage  and  Harald  Hudak  have  been  added  to  the  field  for  the  prestigious  Wanamaker  Mile  at  the  Wanamaker  Millrose  Games  scheduled  for  February  6  at  Madison  Square  Garden.  Eamonn  Coghlan,  of  Ireland;  Steve  Scott,  of  the  US,  and  Craig  Masback  had  entered  previously.   Charge  dismissed   MOLINE,  Illinois,  Monday  (AAP-AP).  —  A  judge  has  dismissed  a  charge  against  Australian  golfer  Bruce  Devlin  of  soliciting  a  prostitute  the  night  before  last  July's  Quad  Cities  Open  PGA  golf  tournament.  The  case  was  dismissed  after  the  woman  failed  to  show  up  in  court.
snippet: DORTMUND, West Germany, Monday (AAPReuter). — West Germany beat Britain in an indor athletics match on Friday night. The German men won by 79 points to 59 and the women 65-41.

heading: Awareness of German contribution
article_text: Awareness  of  German  contribution   IT  is  time  that  we  ourselves  become  aware  of  it  and   that  we  made  our  fellow  citizens  aware  of  it:  We  immigrants  have  not  only  helped  to  develop  the  economy  of  this  country  into  one  of  the  most  suc-  cessful  ones  anywhere,  but  we  are  also  deeply  rooted   in  Australia's  consciousness.  One  simply  cannot  speak  of  modern  Australia  without  referring  to  our  contribu-   tion.   For  Australians  of  German  origin  such  a  reflection  is  of  greatest  importance.  We  have  the  habit  of  wanting  to  stay  inconspicuous  and  are  inclined  rather  to  play  down  the  contributions  of  fellow  countrymen  —  even  if  they  be  men  like  Ludwig  Leichhardt  and  Hans  Heysen.   Es  ist  an  der  Zeit,  daß  wir  uns  selbst  darüber  klar  werden  und  daß  wir  es  unseren  Mitbürgern  klar  machen:  Wir  Einwanderer  haben  nicht  nur  mitgeholfen  die  Wirtschaft  dieses  Landes  zu  einer  der   leistungsfahigsten  überhaupt  zu  entwickeln,  sondern  wir  sind  auch  in  dem  australischen  Selbstverständnis  tief  Verwurzelt.  Man  kann  einfach  nicht  mehr  vom  neven  Australien  sprechen  ohne  unseren  Anteil  daran  zu  berücksichtigen.   Gerade  für  die  Deutschstammigen  in  Australien  ist  eine  solche  Besinnung  von  größter  Wichtigkeit.  Wir  haben  nämlich  die  Angewohnheit  nur  nicht  auffallen  zu  wollen  und  neigen  dazu,  die  Beiträge  von  Landsleuten  —  selbst  wenn  es  ein  Ludwig  Leichhardt  und  ein  Hans  Heysen  ist  —  eher  hinunter  zu  spielen.

heading: Spy’s German past
article_text: Spy’s  German  past   LONDON:  Michael  Bettaney,  the  MI5  agent  jailed  for  23  years  was  known  for  his  extreme  pro-Nazi  views.   While  at  Oxford,  he  even  joined  a  pro-Nazi  students’  alliance,  and  had  a  collection  of  Nazi  war  medals  at  his  home.  He  was  heard  to  curse  in  fluent  German,  and  to  say  that  “Hitler  had  been  right  all  along”.   Observers  have  been  puzzled  about  Bettaney’s  sudden  switch  from  the  Right  to  Communism.   He  claimed  to  his  interrogators  that  he  was  converted  to  Communism  as  late  as  1982,  but  it  is  not  known  why  the  would  be  traitor  switched  his  views,  and  attempted  to  pass  British  secrets  to  the  Russians.

heading: German athletes for Canberra
article_text: German  athletes  for  Canberra   The  Australian  selection  trials  for  the  Pacific  Conference  Games  to  be  held  in  Canberra  on  December  20  and  21  received  a  boost  this  week  with  the  announcement  by  the  Australian  Amateur  Athletics  Union  that  four  leading  ath  letes  from  West  Germany  -  three  women  and  one  man  -  would  take  part.   The  four  are  being  brought  to  Australia  primarily  to  run  in  three  of  the  earlier  Alcoa  Challenge  Series  meetings,  of  which  the  selection  trials  are  one.   The  other  two  meets  at  which  they  will  compete  will  be  in  Perth  on  December  7  and  Adelaide  on  December  14.   Two  of  the  visitors,  Brigitte  Kraus,  24,  and  Vera  Stciert,  23,  are  specialists  in  the  800m,  1500m  and   3000m.   Kraus  is  a  former  Olympian,  having  competed  in  Montreal.  She  has  won  30  West  German  cham  pionships.   Steiert  was  second  in  the  1500m  and  3000m  titles  in  West  Germany  this  year.   The  third  woman  is  Gabby  Busmann,  a  .200m-400m  specialist  with  the  best  times  of  23.41s   and:  51.10s  to  her  credit.   ;Thelonemaleis  Henning  von  Papen,  26,a  national  representative  in  the  800m  and  1500m.   Travelling  with  the  group  will.be  one  of  West  Germany's  leading  coaches,  Joha'nn  Spilker.  He  will  give  lectures  at  all.  three:  centres.   In  addition  to  the  Alcoa  meets,  there  will  be  a  further  series,  in  Hobart  on  January  11,  Melbourne  on  January  15,  Brisbane  on  March  1  and  Sydney  on   March  8.   Nominations  to  take  part  in  the  Australian  trials  will  close  on  December  1,  which  means  that,  for  Canberra  athletes,  the  interclub  competition  at  Woden  Park  today  is  the  last  opportunity  they  have  to  attain  the  qualifying  standards  laid  down  by  the   AAAU.   The  Union  has  stipulated  athletes  should  reach  the   last  Australian-championship  qualifying  standards  to  qualify.   They  should  have  acquired  this  standard  within  the  past  six  months.  Although  for  the  decathlon  a  12  month  period  was  allowed.   After  last  week's  contest  at  Woden  Park  on  a  wet   track  and  the  possibility  that  this  week  the  surface  ,  will  again  be  damp,  performances  are  not  likely  to  be  ;  a  particularly  high  standard.  '   The  program  will  begin  at-1.15pm.   On  the  track,  100m,  400ni,  1500m  and  3000m  :  events  will  be  run.   The  ACT  Amateur  Athletics  Association  was  ;  forced  last  week  to  cancel  hurdles  and  steeplechase  events  at  Woden  Park  because  of  the  unavailability  of  equipment.  Therefore,  the  3000m  was  .  added,  although  not  in  the  points-scoring  competition.   There  a;sq  will  be  jumping  and  throwing  events   this  afternoon.   Competition  will  be  round  three  of  the  lnterclub  premiership.

heading: 'German-style' proliferation WINE
article_text: 'German-style'  proliferation   By  BRENT  WHYTE*   If  imitation  is  the;sincerest  flattery,  then   German  vintners  must  feel  very  flattered  in  light  of  the  increasing  proliferation  of'German-style'   wines.   The  first  'German-style'  wines  were  produced  well  over  a  century  ago  by  German  emigrants  whose  vinicuitural  traditions  and  skills  were  transplanted  miles  away  from  the  Rhine  and  Mosel  valleys.   Even  today  wines  are  grown,  produced  and  bottled  in  places  where  large  numbers  of  Germans  immi  grated  —  such  as  North  and  South  America,  Aus  tralia,  South  Africa  —  which  are  generically  called  'Rhine'  or  'Mosel'  wines.  However,  these  new-world  wines  which  are  named,  bottled  and/or  labelled  to  resemble  German  wines  do  not  necessarily  have  any  relation  to  any  emigrant  heritage.   These  are  often  produced  by  large  corporations  which  have  implemented  the  recommendations  of  marketing  research  departments  to  produce  and  pack  age  an  imitation  of  a  quality  product  which  has  already  achieved  public  acceptance.  Advertising  and  promotional  campaigns  play  up  the  'German'  charac   ter  of  these  wines.   In  spite  of  their  old-world  appellations  these  'Ger  man-style'  wines  are  usually  found  only  in  the  new  world  countries  where  they  are  produced.   Another  breed  of  'German-style'  wine  has  recently  emerged  which  is  distributed  worldwide.  Para  doxically,  this  new  imitator  is  produced  right  at  home  in  Germany  ...  paying  compliment  to  German  ex  pertise,  in  vinicuitural  technology.  These  'German  style'  wines  are  made  from  grapies  or  blends  of  wines  from  different  EEC  countries  which  are  transported  into  Germany  to  be  made  into  wine  or  blended,  then  put  into  containers  (bottles,  casks  ,  or  tanks)  and   marketed.  Because  the  final  stage  of  production  takes  place  in  Germany,  these  wines  may  be  labelled  'Product  of  Germany'-—  even  though  the  wine  itself  is  not  necessarily  of  German  origin.   ,  Often  these  table  wines  from  different  countries  of  the  EEC  are  given  German-sounding  names  and  German-looking  bottles  and  labels.  Add  to  this  the  German  name  and  address  of  the  producer  or  bottler  or  shipper  —  which  must  appear  on  the  label  —  and  the  consumer  can  easily  mistake  one  of  these  'German  style'  wines  for  an  authentic  German  wine.   There  is  an  easy  way  to  identify  an  authentic  German  wine:  look  for  the  wine's  official  quality  control  number,  the  'A.P.Nr',  on  the  label.   A  German  wine  bearing  an  'A.P.Nr.'  offers  the  "consumer  the  following  guarantee.   The  wine  is  100  per  cent  German  in  origin  and  the   name  of  a  designated  wine-growing  region  within  Germany  —  or  the  umbrella  geographical  designa  tion  "Liebfraumilch"  —  must  appear  on  the  label.  And  the  wine  has  passed  a  three-stage  test,  beginning   with  Government  inspections  in  the  vineyards  at  harvest  time,  followed  by  a  laboratory  analysis  of  the  young  wine,  arid  ending  with  a  blind  sensory  test  conducted  by  professional  wine  tasters  at  Government  testing  stations.  The  final  two  digits  of  the  'A.P.Nr.'  indicate  the  year  in  which  the  wine  passed  the  test.   One  reason  that  more  'German-style'  wines  are  appearing  in  supermarkets  and  wine  shops  around  the  world,  often  displayed  in  the  midst  of  authentic  German  wines,  is  that  the  supply  of  German  wines  is  limited  by  natural  factors.   The  weather  greatly  influences  the  quantity  of  wine  able  to  be  produced  each  year.  At  present,  supply   vwine   is  tight  due  to  the  1980  and  1981  harvests  which,  when  combined,  equal  slightly  more  than  one  year's  average  production.   Furthermore,  the  vineyards  on  the  slopes  along  the  Rhine  and  Mosel  are  situated  between  riverbanks  and  forested  hillsides,  and  thus  cannot  be  expanded.  As  demand  for  German  wine  continues  to  increase  both  at  home  and  abroad  some  distributors  are  trying  to  meet  the  need  with  'German-style*  wines.   Even  the  best  imitation  cannot  substitute  for  the  real  thing.  Authentic  German  wine  has  a  character   and  tradition  of  its  own.   Certain  elements  which  contribute  to  the  unique  character  of  German  wine  can,  of  course,  be  suc  cessfully  "relocated"  abroad:  grape  varieties,  techno  logical  improvements,  even  winemakers.  But  other  factors,  such  as  the  soil  and  climatic  conditions  where  German  wines  grow,  will  always  remain  indigenous  to  Germany.   This  is  why  a  German  Riesling  wine  has  a  bouquet  and  taste  which  is  distinct  from  that  of  an  American  or  Australian  Riesling  wine.  The  one  is  not  necessarily  better  or  worse  than  the  other,  they  are  by  nature   different.   And  so  it  is  with  German  wine  and  'German-style'  wine:  no  matter  how  much  alike  they  appear,  they  are  by  nature  different.   *Mr  Whyte  is  the  manager,  German  Wine   Information  Service,  North  Sydney.
snippet: IF imitation is the sincerest flattery, then German vintners must feel very flattered in light of the increasing proliferation of 'German-style' wines.

heading: GERMAN ARMS TO SAUDI?
article_text: GERMAN  ARMS  TO  SAUDI?   JERUSALEM,  (JTA):  Deputy  foreign  minister  Yehuda  Ben  Meir  warned  of  a  cloud  that  could  darken  Israeli-German  relations:  the  possibility  that  Bonn  might  sell  advanced  weaponry  to  Saudi  Arabia  or  other  Arab  countries.   Delivering  a  key-note  speech  on  the  opening  day  of  the  annual  meeting  of  the  Israel-Germany  Friendship  Associations,  Ben-Meir  said  Israel  could  not  agree  with  nor  acquiesce  in  such  a  prospect.   Israeli  sources  forecast  in  tensified  diplomatic  action  by  Jerusalem  in  the  weeks  ahead  designed  to  forestall  any  arms  sales.   Recently,  following  Chancellor  Helmut  Kohl’s   visit  to  Saudi  Arabia,  Ger  man  officials  sought  to  distinguish  between  offensive  weapons,  such  as  the  Leopard  Two  tank,  and  defensive  weapons  such  as  anti-tank  devices  and  anti  aircraft  systems.   But  Israel  has  declared  firmly  that  it  recognises  no  such  distinction.  Ben-Meir  in  his  address  today  dwelt  on  the  special  character  “  —  the  Bonn-Jerusalem  relation  ship”,  a  character  moulded  by  the  Holocaust  experience.   SUPPORT   Referring  to  the  Lebanon  situation,  Ben-Meir  urged  European  and  other  Western  States  to  exercise  their  in  fluence  and  persuasive  powers  over  Syria  to  moderate  Damascus’  hostili  ty  to  the  Lebanon-Israel  agreement  of  May  17.   The  Deputy  Minister  said  this  agreement  was  the  manifestation  of  “Lebanon’s  desire  for  sovereignty  and  in   dependence.  But  Syria  sought  to  impose  its  own  will”  on  Lebanon,  to  the  detriment  of  Lebanon’s  sovereignty,  Ben-Meir  said.   He*  predicted  that  a  new   PLO  that  would  arise  from  the  debacle  of  Tripoli  (where  Yasser  Arafat  was  still  being  pounded  by  the  Syrian  backed  rebels)  would  be  a  front  organisation  for  Syria.   Ben-Meir  expressed  the  hope  that  Palestinians  living   in  Judea  and  Samaria  would  recognise  the  vast  gap  —  “between  the  PLO  and  real  freedom  fighters”  and  would  in  consequence  of  this  realisation  turn  towards  direct  negotiations  with  us  within  the  framework  of  Camp  David.   Attending  the  two-day  meeting  were  German  and  Israeli  parliamentarians,  members  of  the  friendship  societies  in  each  country.   The  German  side  is  led  by  Eric  Blumenfeld,  President  of  the  Israelisch-Deutsche  Geseljschaft  and  a  member  of  the  European  Parliament.
snippet: JERUSALEM, (JTA): Deputy foreign minister Yehuda Ben Meir warned of a cloud that could darken Israeli-German relations: the possibility that Bonn might sell advanced weaponry to Saudi Arabia or other Arab countries. Delivering a key-note

heading: GERMAN DEAL WITH SAUDIS?
article_text: GERMAN  DEAL  WITH   SAUDIS?   BONN,  (JCNS):  Possible  West  German  tank  exports  to  Saudi  Arabia  have  been  discussed  at  a  secret  meeting  in  southern  Germany  between  Chancellor  Helmut  Kohl  and  the  Defence  Minister  of  Saudi  Arabia,  Prince  Sultan,  it  was  learned  here.   The  Prince  is  said  to  have  renewed  his  Government’s  continued  interest  in  the  supply  of  the  most  modern  German  tank,  of  the  Leopard  II  type,  as  well  as  in  the  delivery  of  other  Ger  man  military  equipment.   The  deal  would  involve  some  3  billion  pounds,  in  formed  circles  here  pointed   out.   CONSULT   ISRAEL   According  to  .  these  circles,  Chancellor  Kohl  ex  pressed  his  readiness  to  reconsider  the  matter  after  consultations  with  the  United  States  and  Israel.  Kohl  is  said  to  have  stressed  Germany’s  special  relation  ship  with  the  Jewish  State  and  underlined  that  any  agreement  on  arms  exports  of  this  quality  would  repre   sent  a  moral  category  to  be  considered  in  the  light  of  this  special  relationship.   Earlier,  the  Saudi  Ara  bian  Defence  Minister  had  already  met  with  the  chair  man  of  the  German  Chris  tian  Social  Union  (CSU),  Franz  Josef  Strauss,  and  the  Federal  Interior  Minister,  Friedrich  Zim  mermann,  who  is  also  a  leading  CSU  represen  tative,  at  Geneva,  it  was  disclosed  here.   The  CSU  is  said  to  be  openly  favouring  arms  transactions  with  the  Arab  kingdom,  while  the  Chris  tian  Democrat  Union  (CDU)  is  reported  to  be  split  on  the  issue,  and  the  Foreign  Minister,  Hans  Dietrich  Genscher,  who  heads  the  Free  Democrat  Party  (FDP),  is  opposed  to  the  transaction.   Helmut  Kohl,  Chancellor   According  to  informed  circles  here,  the  matter  has  already  been  the  subject  of  secret  contacts  between  the  governments  of  West  Ger  many  and  Israel,  on  an  unofficial  level.  A  high  ranking  German  official  had  flown  to  Israel  recently  to  ascertain  Israel’s  views.   Hans-Dietrich  Genscher,   Foreign  Affairs   It  was  reported  that  Israeli  representatives  had  voiced  strong  objections.   On  the  other  hand,  Israel  had  for  long  been  express  ing  its  interest  in  the  delivery  of  West  German  tank  guns,  it  was  pointed  out  by  informed  circles  here,  who  added  that  the   Friedrich  Zimmermann,   Interior   German  Government  might  eventually  be  ready  and  in  clined  to  supply  both  states  with  the  requested  equip   ment.   A  German  Government  decision  on  the  matter  was  expected  before  Chancellor  Kohl’s  scheduled  visit  to  Israel  in  September.
snippet: BONN, (JCNS): Possible West German tank exports to Saudi Arabia have been discussed at a secret meeting in southern Germany between Chancellor Helmut Kohl

heading: German head to visit
article_text: •  German  head  to  visit   JERUSALEM:  West  German  President  Richard  von  Weizsaecker  will  visit  Israel  in  October.   A  joint  announcement  made  here  and  in  Bonn,  specified  October  841  as  dates  for  the  visit.   The  invitation  to  him  came  from  President  Chaim  Herzog.  The  West  German  President,  who  recently  made  a  tour  of  Arab  countries,  will  be  the  first  German  head  of  State  to  come  here,  although  German  chancellors  have  done  so.
snippet: JERUSALEM: West German President Richard von Weizsaecker will visit Israel in October. A joint announcement made here and in Bonn, specified October 8-11 as dates for the visit.

heading: German sub tender submitted
article_text: German  sub  tender  submitted   Australian  Marine  Systems,  the  company  formed  to  offer  the  West  German  Type  2000  submarine  to  the  Australian  Government  as  the  replacement  for  the  Royal  Australian  Navy's  Oberon  submarines,  submitted  its  final  tender  documents  in  Canberra  yesterday  before  the  2pm  deadline.   Speaking  at  a  news  conference,  the  project  manager,  Dr  John  White,  said  the  company  had  been  able  to  better  the  target  of  60  per   cent  Australian  contcnt  specified  by  the  gov   ernment.   "The  devaluation  of  the  Australian  dollar  made  it  easier  for  us  to  achicvc  the  target,  and  in  fact  we  believe  we  can  achievc  a  level  of  Australian  contcnt  far  in  cxcess  of  most  people's  expectations,"  he  said.   Dr  White  stressed  the  importance  of  project  management  in  the  company's  sub   mission.

heading: German president accompanying Herzog
article_text: German  president  accompanying  Herzog   Bv  WLADIMIR  STRUMINSKI   BONN.  -  In  an  unprecedented,  step,  German  President  Richard  von  Veiszaecker  will  accom   pany  President  Herzog  throughout  his  visit  this  week,  von  Weiszaecker  told  reporters.   Herzog,  due  to  arrive  here  on  Monday,  will  visit  the  former  death  camp  Bergen-Belsen,  the  city  of  Worms,  and  West  Berlin.  The  German  president  offered  to  accompany  Herzog  because  of  the  great  importance  he  attaches  to  the  visit,  which  he  called  “an  extraordinary  event  in  the  relations  between  the  two  countries  and  the  two  peoples.”   Von  Weiszaecker  also  said  that  his  visit  to  Israel   in  1985  and  Herzog’s  visit  to  Germany  were  just   two  events  in  the  development  of  bilateral  rela  tions.  He  stressed  that  Herzog’s  visit  did  not  conclude  “a  chapter  of  history.”   Asked  about  his  defence  of  his  father  Ernst  von   Weiszaecker,  who  was  tried  for  war  crimes  by  the  Allies  after  World  War  II,  the  president  said  that  he  had  helped  his  father  “out  of  deep  conviction,”  adding  that  he  would  do  it  again.   Weiszaecker’s  father  had  been  a  senior  official  in  the  German  Foreign  Ministry  and  accepted  a  promotion  by  the  Nazis  to  deputy  minister.  The  German  president  said  that  his  father  had  tried  to  prevent  the  war,  adding  that  though  he  failed,  he   had  made  his  decision  based  on  “moral  considera   tions.”   In  another  development  here  yesterday,  the  head  of  the  committee  of  German  local  councils,  Hans  Diedeken,  announced  that  40  West  German  regional  councils  wanted  to  establish  ties  with  Israeli  counterparts.   Ten  local  councils  in  Germany  and  50  towns  already  have  “twins”  in  Israel.   Herzog  met  last  week  with  Swiss  President  Pierre  Aubert  in  Berne  and  later  sat  among  the  spectators  in  Lausanne  as  Maccabi  lost  their  European  Cup  match.  Earlier  Herzog  and  his  party  visited  Basel,  to  mark  the  90th  anniversary  of  the  First  Zionist  Congress  held  there  in  1897.
snippet: BONN. — In an unprecedented, step, German President Richard von Veiszaecker will accompany President Herzog throughout his visit this week, von Weiszaecker told reporters.

heading: W. German coalition crisis
article_text: W.  German  coalition  crisis   BONN,  Thursday  (Reuter).  —  A  political  show  down  between  rightists  and  moderates  has  provoked  a  crisis  in  West  Germany's  coalition  government.   On  the  surface,  the  row  is  about  the  moderate  wing's  determination  to  grant  asylum  to  14  Chileans  branded  terrorists  by  the  government  of  President  Pinochet  and  Chancellor  Helmut  Kohl's  right-wing  Bavarian  allies.  But  the  real  struggle  concerns  the  future  direction  of  the  centre-right  coalition  and  the  growing  rift  between  Mr  Kohl's  leftward-moving  Christian  Democrats  and  the  Bavarians.   Political  analysts  say  the  survival  of  the  coalition  couldflre  in  question.   *   "■X.

heading: Powerful German team here
article_text: Powerful  German  team  here   SYDNEY:  East  Ger  many's  mighty  track  and  field  machine  will  arrive  in  Sydney  today  en  route  to  Canberra  for  next  week's  World.Cup  Athlet   ics.   East  Germany  has  named  its  strongest  team  and  has  included  three  of  the  world's  latest  record  holders,  Sabine  Busch,  Heike  Dreschlcr  and  Ulf  Timmermann.   Busch  ran  53.56s  for  the  400m  hurdles  at  the  team's  World  Cup  warm  up  meeting  in  Berlin.   Her  record  was  nearly  a  second  faster  than  the  winning  time  at  last  year's  Los  Angeles  Olym  pics.   At  the  same  meeting,  Dreschlcr  leaped  7.44m  in  the  women's  long  jump  for  her  record  and  Tim  mermann  broke  the  men's  world  shot-put  re  cord  with  a  throw  of  22.60m.   Oceania  chief  selector  Paul  Jcncs  said  it  was  ob  vious  the  East  Germans  had  two  things  in  mind  for  Canberra.   First  to  win  the  World  Cup  outright  and  second  ly  to  take  revenge  on  the  Soviet  Union  which  hu  milatcd  them  at  last  month's  Europa  Cup  finals  in  Moscow.   WORLD  CUP  ATHLETICS   C*nt*tr*.  Oct  4,5.6

heading: Book Review Righteous German
article_text: Book  Review   Righteous  German   TERENCE  PR1TTIE   Schindler’s  Ark.  By  Thomas  Kepeally.  Hodder  &  Stoughton.   Thomas  Keneally’s  novel  brings  back  memories  to  hundreds  of  Jewish  Holocaust  survivors  of  the  man  who  became  the  greatest  figure  in  their   lives,  i   In  Jerusalem’s  Yad  Vashem  a  handful  of  the  elect  have  been  honoured  by  trees  planted  in  memory  of  “Righteous  Gentiles”  —  men  and  women  who  risked  their  lives  to  save  those  of  Jews  in  the  black  days  of  Nazi  persecution.  High  among  these  is  the  name  of  Oskar  Schindler,  a  Sudeten  Gentian  who  against  all  SS  pressure  insisted  on  employing  Jews  in  his  war  time  factories  near  Cracow  in  Poland,  Jews  who  were  never  beaten  or  killed  and  whom  he  treated  with  respect  and  even  affection  —  those  with  whom  he  had  most  contact  were  referred  to  as  “Schindler’s  Children”  and  many  of  them  remained  in  close  contact  with  him  up  to  the  time  of  his  death,  in  October  1974.  At  a  rough  estimate  he  helped  to  save  the  lives  of  about  1200  Jews.   This  he  did  not  only  by  treating  them  well  and  feeding  them  in  a  way  which  would  have  been  deemed  lucullan  by  the  inmates  of  concentration-camps,  but  by  using  his  personal  good  relations  with  the  SS  to  prevent  their  deportation  to  such  places  of  horror.  When  some  of  the  women  from  his  Brinnlitz  factory  were  removed  to  Auschwitz,  he  followed  them  there  and  argued  stoutly  and  stubbornly  for  their  return  to  his  care.  His  case  was  that  they  were  all  skilled  workers  —  his  factories  produced  mainly  enamel  ware  but  munitions  too  —  and  that  their  departure  had  disrupted  production.  Keneally  tells  the  almost  unbelievable  story  how  Schindler  won  his  case,  and  how  the  SS  authorities  at  Auschwitz,  even  while  busy  with  their  extermination,  returned  all  “his  Jews”  to  him,  and  to  safety.   This  was  a  typical  instance  of  Oskar  Schindler’s  “chutzpa.”  He  was  no  intellectual.  He  was,  intriguingly,  a  man  of  few  principles;  he  drank  a  great  deal,  he  was  habitually  unfaithful  to  his  wife  and  unashamedly  promiscuous,  he  had  not  the  slightest  hesitation  in  using  the  black  market  and  bribing  whenever  expedient  —  to  gain  the  concession  of  safeguarding  ‘‘his  Jews”  from  the  SS,  he  used  an  interesting  admixture  of  .diamonds,  alcohol  and  ham.  But  he  had  what  the  Nazis  would  have  considered  a  shocking  “weakness”  —  for  Jews.  By  presenting  the  story  as  a  novel,  Keneally  tries  to  show  how  something  ,deep  within  Schindler,  some  unexplained  instinct,  prompted  his  determination  to  succour  and  defend  the  Jews  in  his  care.   He  met  no  heroic  end,  dying  of  hardening  of  the  arteries  which  may  well  have  been  brought  on  by  his  drinking  habits.  He  was  none  the  less  a  “Righteous  Gentile”  for  all  that  —  if  only  because,  with  the  end  of  the  war  in  sight,  he  made  a  birthday-speech  in  front  of  members  of  the  dreaded  SS,   promising  that  he  would  stick  the  war  \   out  until  “his  Jews”  were  safe  and  i  free.  He  was  37,  and  risking  the  whole   second  half  of  his  life.  His  life,  both  l  before  and  after  the  war,  was  that  of  a   drinker  and  businessman  and  totally  /  j   unmemorable  and  after  the  war  he  had  i  to  be  helped  repeatedly  by  survivors   among  “his  Jews.”  Yet  he  was  one  of  j   that  small  band  of  Germans  who  ?  needed  a  recognisable  challenge  to  his  true  morality,  and  who  rose  to  the  occasion.   Keneally’s  novel  has  just  won  the  !  Booker  Prize,  Britain’s  premier  i  literary  award,  and  deservedly  so.  After  talking  to  many  surviving   “Schindler  Jews”  about  their  ]  memories,  he  has  presented  his  story  j  as  “faction”  —  a  detailed,   documented  true  story  presented  and  .  *  built  up  as  fiction  —  but  he  draws  a  *  convincing  picture  which  lingers  in  the  1  mind  of  the  total  Jewish  nightmare  of  1  the  Holocaust  and  of  one  ordinary  |   German’s  stand  against  it.

heading: German biplane raises questions
article_text: German  biplane  raises  questions   A  PHOTOGRAPH  which  appears  to  contradict  official  history  has  prompted  Maj  Victoria  Gregson  of  HQ  3MD  to  seek  the  help  of  ARMY'S  readers.   Maj  Gregson  discovered  the  photo  graph  among  a  collection  of  more  than   100  pictures  her  father  brought  back  from  wwi.  "The  picture,  which  I  believe  was  taken  by  my  father,  shows  a  group  of  Austra  lian  Light  Horsemen  towing  away  a  cap  tured  German  aircraft  somewhere  in  .  Palestine,"  Maj  Gregson  explained.  Both  Maj  Gregson's  father  and  uncle  served  with  the  4th  Light  Horse  and  this  is  where  the  apparent  contradiction  occurs.   "In  his  Official  History  of  Australia  in  the  War  of  1914-18,  Volume  VII,  Sinai  and  Palestine,  Henry  Gullett  mentions  the  capture  of  three  aircraft,  one  still  packed  in  its  crate  and  two  complete  air  craft  taken  near  Jenin,"  Maj  Gregson  said.  "But  Mr  Gullett  speaks  of  only  the  9th  and  10th  Light  Horse  being  involved  in  the  Jenin  capture,"  Maj  Gregson  added.  The  questions  Maj  Gregson  would  like  answered  are:  Is  the  picture  of  the  4th,   9th  or  10th  Light  Horse?  Did  the  4th  Light  Horse  manage  to  bag  a  handsome  prize  of  their  own?;  or,  if  Mr  Gullett  was  correct,  what  was  her  father  doing  gallop  ing  around  the  countryside  with  the  wrong  Regiment?  Maj  Gregson  visited  Israel  in  1985  and  toured  many  of  the  places  immortalised  on  the  Light.  Horse  Regiment  Guidons  and  has  contributed  to  'Ich  Dien',  the  magazine  of  the  4thl/19th  Prince  of  Wales'  Light  Horse  Regiment  on  the  subject  of  the  Australian  Light  Horse  in  Palestine.   ?  LEFT:  Australian  Light  Horsemen  tow  away  a  captured  German  aircraft.  The  biplane  has  the  num  ber  D636  painted  on  its  tail  and  is  be  lieved  to  be  an  Alba-  tros  D5,  an  early  fighter  aircraft  seen  more  commonly  on  the  Western  front.  Can  any  of  our  read  ers  identify  the  unit  whicfi  captured  the  aircraft?

heading: Manila wants German industry
article_text: Manila  wants   German   industry   WEST  German  industries  and  com   mercial  concerns  are  being  actively  encouraged  to  use  the  Philippines  as  a  base  for  computer  software  development  activities.   The  call  came  from  Dr  Victor  Sandoval,  president  of  Nixdorf  Computer  Philippines  Inc.,  during  an  ad  dress  in  Bonn  to  members  of  West  Germany's  presti  gious  Deutsche'  Industrie  und  Handelskammer  (DIHT)  —  the  West  German  Chamber  of  Commerce.   Dr  Sandoval  was  a  member  of  a  high-powered  Fili  pino  investment  promotion  group,  headed  by  Philip  pines  president  Corazon  Aquino,  which  recently  toured  West  Germany,  France  and  Belgium.   Dr  Sandoval  told  DIHT  members  that  with  1992  approaching,  Europeans  will  have  to  think  of  the  'glob  alisation  of  end-user  markets  as  well  as  production   resources.'   A  single,  unique  characteristic  of  computer  software  —  the  fact  that  it  is  perfectly  transportable  and  can  be  shipped  over  telephone  lines  at  extremely  high  speeds  —  made  this  globalisation  unavoidable.   "The  location  of  the  end-user  market  relative  to  the  location  of  the  production  plant  becomes  immaterial,"  said  Dr  Sandoval.   "The  software  producer  can  thus  set  up  a  plant  where  production  facilities  and  input  resources  are  optimal,  and  still  be  in  a  position  to  market  the  pro   duct  world-wide.   "In  the  information  technology  field,  generally,  hardware  costs  are  decreasing  and  software  costs  are  climbing;  Germany  is  no  exception,"  Dr  Sandoval   said.   In  Germany,  the  services  of  software  professionals  are  not  only  expensive,  they  are  difficult  to  recruit.   Viewed  from  this  standpoint,  according  to  Dr  San  doval,  the  Philippines  is  one  of  the  most  attractive  countries  in  the  world  for  software  production,  for  a  variety  of  reasons:   •  The  Philippines  offers  a  large  pool  of  easily  trainable  staff;  from  a  population  of  60  million,  a  company  can  be  very  selective  in  recruitment.   •  Englishes  universally  spoken.   •  Salaries  in  the  computer  sector  are  at  about  80  per  cent  of  corresponding  salary  levels  in  Germany.   •  In  general,  operating  costs  in  the  Philippines  are  lower  than  in  other  countries  around  the  region.   •  The  Philippines  boasts  an  adequate  network  of  data-quality  transmission  links  to  all  major  centres  of   the  world.   Dr  Sandoval  said  that  typically,  software  activities  in  the  Philippines  covera  wide  spectrum,  including  the  coding  of  program  routines,  the  testing  of  programs,  the  development  of  application  software  packages,  and  the  conversion  of.programs  to  suit  new  conditions.   He  said  that  while  American  companies  were  strongly  represented  in  the  field,  Nixdorf  itself  had  also  recognised  the  potential  with  the  establishment  of  the   NixdorfComputer  Software  Centre  in  the  Philippines.'  :  ,   I  Nixdorfnow  maintains  a  full  research  and  developer  .j,t  I  ment  team  in  Manila  —  right  at  the  centre  of  the   Asia-Pacific  region.   "The  company  is  thus  a  step  closer  to  making  ■sure  -  that  its  products  meet  the  special  requirements  of  its  Asian  customers,"  said  Dr  Sandoval.
snippet: WEST German industries and commercial concerns are being actively encouraged to use the Philippines as a base for computer software development

heading: Miss World a German
article_text: Miss  World  a  German   LONDON,  Friday  (AAP).  -  Miss  Germany,  18-year-old  Gabriella  Brum,  who  was  crowned  Miss  World  in  London  last  night,  "picked  up"  a  prize  worth  $A40,000  and  "a  title  which  will  take  her  all  over  the  world",  accord  ing  to  the  Daily  Mirror  newspaper  in  London  today.  *   Another  British  national  news  paper,  The  Sun,  reported  yesterday  :  that  the  winning  Miss  World  would   receive  a  cheque  for  $A10,000  prize  money.  And  then  there  would  be  "the  dreamy  prospect"  of  earning   I   AAP-AP  satellite  picture   West  Germany's  Gabriella  Brum,  18,  smiles  happily  after  winning  the  Miss  World  1980  title  at  London's  Royal  Albert  Hall  on   Thursday  night.   between  $A  100,000  and  $A200,000  in  the  year  ahead. The  two  girls  tipped  as  favourites  by  the  bookies,  Miss  Israel,  Anat  Zimerman,  18,  and  Miss  UK,  Kim  Ashfield,  21,  were  fourth  and  fifth.   Miss  Australia,  18-year-old  model  and  student  Linda  Leigh  Shepherd,  failed  to  reach  the  final   15.

heading: Sydney hosting German confab
article_text: Sydney  hosting  German  confab   Experts  from  throughout  the  world  will  address  a  two-day  conference  on  the  German  Jewish  Experience  in  Sydney  next  month.   The  conference  has  been   jointly  arranged  by  the  School  of  German  Studies  of  the  University  of  New  South  Wales  (UNSW)  and  The  Goethe  Institute.   It  will  be  held  at  the  Goethe  Institute,  Woollahra,  from  July  27-29.   Experts  and  academics  from  Canada,  Germany,  New  Zealand,  Austria  and  the  United  States  are  due  to  address  the  conference.   In  addition,  academics  from  NSW,  Armidale,  La  Trobe,  Monash,  Deakin  and  Macquarie  Universities  will   be  in  attendance.   HIGHLIGHT   One  of  the  highlight  addresses  will  be  delivered  by  Martin  Broszat  from  Munich  on  Kristallnacht  —  a  turning  point  on  the  way   to  the  Holocaust.   Evelyn  Scherabon  Firchow,  from  Minnesota,  will  address  the  conference  on  Aspects  of  German  migration  to  the  United   States.   Hartmut  Zelinsky,  from  Munich,  will  deliver  a  paper  on  Anti-Semitism  of  the  Wagner  Circles  and  another  overseas  academic,  Richard  Albrecht,  from  Mannheim,  will  talk  on  The  Case  of  Theodore  Lessing.   The  trilogy  of  Benjamin  Buber-Scholem  will  be   discussed  by  Peter  Janz,  from  Berlin,  and  Michael  Wagner,  from  Vienna,  will  present  The  Bosel  connec  tion  —  A  case  study  on  anti  Semitism  in  the  Austrian  civil  service.   Other  topics  to  be  covered  include  17th  cen   tury  anti-Semitism,  the  Jewish  factor  in  the  Ger  man  economy  before  1933,  Silesian  Jews  in  the  textile  industry,  the  shtetl,  adjustment  of  East  Euro  pean  Jews  in  Australia,  Neonazism  in  Germany  today,  the  internment  of  Jewish  refugees  in  Aus  tralia,  proposals  for  Jewish  block  settlement  in  Aus  tralia,  Jews  as  displaced  persons  in  Europe  after  the  Second  World  War  and  aspects  of  neofascism.
snippet: Experts from throughout the world will address a two-day conference on the GermanJewish Experience in Sydney next month. The conference has been

heading: German payments
article_text: German  payments   IN  THE  column  Around  the  Jew  ish  World  you  reported  informa  tion  (AJN10/1)  under  the  title  “Indemnity  Payments,”  which  suggests  that  the  German  gov  ernment  has  agreed  in  principle  to  make  new  personal  indemnity  payments  to  Holocaust  survivors  who  are  now  not  eligible  for  monthly  pensions.   On  the  basis  of  this  report  I  contacted  the  Conference  on  Jew  ish  Material  Claims  chairman  Saul  Kagan  in  New  York,  who  responded  on  January  16,1997  as   follows:   “We  can  tell  you  that  we  are  in  the  midst  of  the  negotiations  with  the  German  government  and  hope  to  reach  an  agreement  in  the  very  near  future.  Currently  there  are  no  changes  in  the  eligi  bility  criteria  governing  the  Arti  cle  2  fund.”   In  light  of  the  above,  would  you  kindly  advise  how  you  came  to  publish  incorrect  information  building  false  hope  in  people’s  minds  who  are  awaiting  those  changes?   Mine  ataner   Coombabah,  Qld   (In  fact,  if  Mr  Staner  com  pares  the  two  statements  they  are  not  necessarily  contradicto  ry.  Our  report  came  from  the  Jewish  Telegraphic  Agency  in  New  York  whose  stories  are  filed  to  Jewish  newspapers  and  organisations  around  the  world.  That  includes  the  Claims  Confer   ence  from  whom  JTA’s  informa  tion  was  obtained.  We  had  no  reason,  therefore,  to  doubt  the  report's  validity  and  JTA  have  not  published  a  correction.  Nev  ertheless  we  are  seeking  further  clarification  from  JTA  and  will  report  as  necessary.)

heading: German investment
article_text: German  investment   VOLKSWAGEN  AG  has  announced  a  $300  million  investment  in  an  Israeli  magnesium  plant,   marking  the  first  major  investment  by  a  German   firm  in  the  state  of  Israel.   While  Daimler-Benz  and  Siemens  have  opened  offices  in  Israel  in  the  past  two  years,  neither  company  has  made  any  m^jor  investments  to  date.   Volkswagen  has  invested  in  a  plant  run  by  the   Dead  Sea  Works,  a  company  that  mines  chemicals  from  the  waters  of  the  Dead  Sea.   Tony  Kaye
snippet: VOLKSWAGEN AG has announced a $300 million investment in an Israeli magnesium plant, marking the first major investment by a German firm in the state of Israel.

heading: German soldiers
article_text: German  soldiers   GERMANY  sent  a  first  group  of  officer  cadets  for  military  train  ing  in  Israel.  The  17  cadets,  who  began  their  stay  with  a  visit  to   the  Yad  Vashem  Holocaust  Memorial  Museum  in  Jerusalem,  will  spend  three  weeks  partici  pating  in  training  exercises  alongside  Israeli  soldiers.  The  cooperative  project  comes  after  the  German  army  was  rocked  by  a  series  of  neo-Nazi  incidents  during  the  past  year.

heading: GERMAN PENSION
article_text: German  Pension   I  AM  writing  to  you  regarding  Ger   man  Pension  Reform  1992  which   may  become  of  serious  interest  to  members  of  the  Community.   The  London  Jewish  Chronicle   published  a  reference  to  an   amendment  to  become  law  as   from  January  1,  1992  which  con  cerns  refugees  from  Nazism  who  left  Germany  before  1939,  and  to  date  do  not  receive  a  pension.   To  date,  the  ruling  has  been  that  only  persons  who  worked  in  Germany  and  paid  contributions  to  the  Social  Service  Insurance,  are  eligible  to  apply  for  a  pension  on  reaching  the  age  of  65.   No  specific  information  is  available.  The  German  Embassy  in  London  advises  that  it  is  a  very  complex  legal  matter  not  yet  final  ly  ruled  on.  They  advise  possible  applicants  to  write  direct  to  the  BUNDES  VERSICHERUNGS  ANSTALT  FUER  ANGESTELLTE,  Postfach,  D-1000  Berlin  88.  Alter  natively  they  will  pass  on  any  let  ters  and  applications  received  by  them  in  London.   On  consultation,  the  German  Consul-General  in  Melbourne  has  even  less  knowledge  and  advises  likewise  to  write  direct  to  Berlin.   The  Chronicle  mentions  a  deadline  of  March  3,  and  for  this  reason,  hundreds  of  would-be  contenders  in  the  UK  have  sub  mitted  their  relevant  details  in   writing  to  the  above  authority,  i.e.  all  the  emigration  details  of  dates,  German  place  of  birth  or  resi   dence,  naturalisation  and  resi  dence  in  the  UK,  etc.   Although  writing  on  behalf  of  this  association,  I  am  unable  to  supply  any  further  information,  and  I  would  advise  anyone  to   write  to  Berlin  either  direct  or   through  a  restitution  agent  who  has  a  channel  through  a  qualified  representative  in  Germany.   Mike  Sondheim  (President)  Hay-Tatura  Association.
snippet: I AM writing to you regarding German Pension Reform 1992 which may become of serious interest to members of the Community.

article_text: German  ignorance   ONLY  29  percent  of  German  teen  agers  knew  that  6  million  Jews  died  during  World  War  II,  and  some  31  percent  of  German  teen-agers  do  not  know  where  Auschwitz  is,  according  to  a  German  poll.  Some  506  teens  were  surveyed.

heading: GERMAN PENSIONS
article_text: German  pensions   AN  AMENDMENT  to  the  German  Social  Insurance  Law  and  a  deci  sion  by  the  European  High  Court  appear  to  make  it  possible  for  Nazi  victims  resident  in  the  Unit  ed  Kingdom  to  obtain  a  German  old  age  pension,  subject  to  mak  ing  voluntary  contributions  towards  its  grant.   Previously  this  was  only  open  to  persons  who  had  been  employed  and  made  social  secu  rity  contributions  in  Germany  prior  to  their  migration,  but  this  restriction  seems  no  longer  to  apply.   The  effect  of  the  amendment  and  the  high  court  decision  is  still  not  entirely  certain.  However,  the  German  Federal  Pension  Office  recommends  that  those  Nazi  refugees  or  their  widows  or  wid  owers,  who  are  not  already  in  receipt  of  a  German  old  age  pen  sion,  should  make  applications  to  be  allowed  to  make  payment  of  voluntary  contributions  in  order   to  obtain  a  German  old  age  pen   sion.   Applicants  must:  (1)  originally   have  been  German  nationals  or  have  had  a  German  cultural  back  ground,  and  (2)  have  left  their  residence  within  the  boundaries  of  Germany  as  at  December  31,  1937  or  in  Nazi-annexed  territory  after  January  30,  1933.  Persons  who  had  not  reached  their  65th  birthday  on  January  1,1992,  must  submit  applications  by  March  31,  1992,  addressed  to:   Bundesoersicherungsanstalt   fur,  Angestellte,  Postfach,  1000  Berlin  88,  Germany.

heading: GERMAN JEWS
article_text: GERMAN  JEWS   WITH  THE  recent  publication  of  Volume  1  of  German-Jewish  History  in  Modern  Times  ,  a  four-volume  series  has  been  launched  to  detail  the  history  of  the  Jews  in  German-speaking  countries  from  the  first  Jewish  settlements  in  the  Middle  Ages  to  the  Holocaust.   Sub-titled  Tradition  and   Enlightenment:  1600-1780  (Columbia  University  Press,  435pp,  US$50.00),  and  edited  by  Professor  Michael  Meyer  of  Hebrew  Union  College,  this  first  volume  focuses  on  the  Jewish  world  in  Central   Europe  from  the  beginning  of  the  so  called  modern  period  to  the  advent  of  the  prolonged  struggle  for  Jewish  emancipa   tion.   T^s  a  project  of  the  Leo  Baeck   Institute,  the  series  aims  to  advance  scholarship  of  the  Jews  in  German  speaking  lands.  Volume  2,  when  released,  will  chronicle  the  century  of  emancipation  and  acculturation  to  1871;  Volume  3  will  focus  on  the  disputed  inte  gration  of  Jews  in  the  Reich  from  1871  to  1918;  while  Volume  4  will  look  at  the  era  of  cultural  renewal  in  the  Weimar   Republic  and  the  ultimate  destruction  of  German  Jewry  by  National  Socialism.   SERGE  LIBERMAN

heading: GERMAN INVESTMENT
article_text: VOLKSWAGEN  AG  has  announced  a  $300  million  investment  in  an  Israeli  magnesium  plant,   marking  the  first  major  investment  by  a  German   firm  in  the  state  of  Israel.   While  Daimler-Benz  and  Siemens  have  opened  offices  in  Israel  in  the  past  two  years,  neither  company  has  made  any  major  investments  to   date. heading: German racism
article_text: German  racism   BONN:  Incidents  of  antisemitism  rose  in  Germany  last  year,  especially  among  the  youth,  according  to  figures  released  last  week  by  the  General  Secu  rity  Service.   By  mid-November  1994,  the  number  of  antisemitic  incidents  stood  at  802,  compared  to  656  incidents  during  the  entire  year  of  1993.  Fewer  Jewish  cemeteries  were  desecrated,  but  more  cases  of  ethnic  incitement  were  recorded,  particularly  the  denial  of  the  Holocaust.

heading: German compensation
article_text: German  compensation   FOR  AS  many  as  2,500  Holocaust  sur  vivors  in  Australia  and  as  many  as  60,000  around  the  world,  the  news  from  Germany  is  disturbing  and  depressing.  After  raising  expectations  amongst  the  survivors  after  East  and  West  Germany  came  together  in  1993  by  inviting  them  to  apply  for  restitu  tion,  the  German  government  has  now  severely  limited  the  number  of  eligible  restitution  recipients.   It  is  as  much  the  way  the  German  gov  ernment  has  gone  about  definining  some   of  the  eligibility  criteria  for  compensation,  as  it  is  the  unwillingness  to  meet  all  or  most  of  the  claims,  which  has  so  trauma  tised  and  angered  the  Holocaust  survivors  and  outraged  international  Jewish  organi  sations.  When  a  reunified  Germany  demanded  that  the  victims  —  many  now  in  their  70s  and  80s  —  provide  documenta  tion  to  satisfy  a  bureaucrat  in  Bonn’s  Finance  Ministry  that  they  suffered  in  a  concentration  camp,  or  a  ghetto  or  were  hidden  underground,  the  injustice  and  inhumanity  of  it  cries  out  for  review  and   redress.   Certainly  some  30,000  survivors  of  the  91,000  who  applied  for  compensation  have  been  deemed  eligible  and  the  former  West  German  government  had  a  record  of  acknowledging  its  obligations  to  pay  repa  rations  to  Israel  and  Holocaust  survivors.  But  there  can  be  no  statute  of  limitations  on  those  obligations  and  the  German  gov  ernment,  as  a  matter  of  law  and  morality,  should  honour  them.

heading: German industry
article_text: German  industry   I  am  bedazzled  at  you.  You  who  drive  BMWs  and  Volkswagens,  you  who  use  Siemens  equip  ment,  you  who  fly  Lufthansa,  you  who  use  Hugo  Boss  and  who  listen  to  BASF  tapes.   Are  you  not  the  very  same  people  who  were  repelled  by  the  conduct  of  German  industry  portrayed  in  black  and  white  in  Schindler’s  List?  If  you  saw  the  movie  I  hope  you  are.  If  you  did  not  see  the  movie,  you  should.  Presently  there  is  a  class  action  under  way  against  numerous  German  companies,   the  total  assets  of  which  amount  to  well  above   US  $630  billion.  That  is  the  approximate  sum  of  the  empires,  whose  foundations  were  built  at  gun  point  and  built  by  Jewish  and  non   Jewish  slave  and  forced  labourers.   Yet  you  endorse  their  products.  In  the  face  of  numerous  campaigns  to  buy  Australian  made,  you  not  only  choose  to  export  our  money,  you  choose  to  direct  those  dollars   towards  the  Mark.   The  current  position  of  Count  Otto  Lambsdorff,  Spokesman  for  German  Industry,   is  that  he  has  offered  a  sum  to  the  one  million   living  survivors  that  boils  down  to  US  $5263  for  forced  labourers  and  US  $1547  for  slave  labourers.  The  larger  of  these  figures  is  com  parable  to  two  years  on  the  dole.   For  up  to  six  years  of  barbarities  that  nei  ther  you  nor  I  have  the  right  even  to  attempt   to  describe.   The  vast  majority  of  these  assaulted  human  beings  are  in  their  late  70s.  Lambsdorff  wants  this  class  action  to  drag  on  as  long  as  possible  with  this  specific  fact  in  mind.  Perhaps,  he  hopes,  by  the  time  the  courts  come  to  dealing  with  the  matter,  the  plaintiffs  will  no  longer  be  around  to  voice  what  protest  they  are  still  able   to  voice.   I  hope  that  he  is  wrong.  I  also  hope  that  we  cherish  the  variety  of  products  we  have  to   choose  from.   Do  they  pay?  Or  do  you  pay  them?   Joel  Burstyner
snippet: I am bedazzled at you. You who drive BMWs and Volkswagens, you who use Siemens equipment, you who fly Lufthansa, you who use Hugo Boss and who listen to BASF tapes.

heading: German crimes trial
article_text: German  crimes  trial   ACCUSED  Nazi  war  criminal  Jo-t  sef  Schwammberger  was  indicted  last  month  in  court  at  Stuttgart,   West  Germany,  on  charges  of,  murdering  “at  least  50  Jews”  dur  ing  World  War  II.  He  also  was  charged  as  an  accessory  to  the  murder  of  at  least  3,377  other  peo  ple,  according  to  the  World  Jew  ish  Congress,  which  learned  of  the  indictment  from  the  Jewish  com  munity  of  West  Berlin.  Schwamm  berger  admitted  to  ordering  the  execution  of  one  person  under  “special  circumstances,”  but  other  than  that,  “he  has  completely  de  nied  his  crimes,”  according  to  Hel  mut  Kronbacher,  spokesman  for  the  prosecutor’s  office.   Schwammberger,  78,  who  is  be  ing  held  at  the  Stammheim  maxi  mum  security  prison,  was  extradited  from  Argentina  in  May,  after  a  long  proceeding  that  in  cluded  his  hospitalisation  in  an  Ar  gentine  hospital  for  a  mysterious  coma.  The  Stuttgart  court  found  him  fit  to  stand  trial.  The  prosecutor’s  office  said  the  trial  would  probably  begin  early  next  year.  That  would  likely  make  Schwammberger  the  first  alleged  Nazi  war  criminal  to  be  tried  in  a  unified  Germany.  A  guilty  verdict  would  bring  a  life  sentence.   A  former  lieutenant  in  the  Waf  fen  SS  and  commandant  of  several  concentration  camps  in  Poland,  Schwammberger  allegedly  was  known  for  his  particularly  cruel  killings  of  Jews.  He  has  been  ac  cused  by  survivors  of  camps  of  Jewish  areas  in  the  Polish  towns  of  Przemysl,  Mielec,  Rozwadow  and  Stalowa-Wola  of  smashing   children’s  heads  against  walls,  throwing  people  alive  into  fires  and  shooting  people  point-blank.  Witnesses  said  they  saw  Schwammberger  use  pliers  to  re  move  gold  teeth  from  prisoners.  He  was  known  as  the  “butcher  of  Rozwadow.”   After  the  war,  Schwammberger  was  arrested  in  Austria  with  bags  of  jewellery  stolen  from  Jews,  which  he  admitted  under  question  ing.  He  escaped,  probably  in  1948,  to  Argentina  with  what  is  believed  to  have  been  help  from  Odessa,  a  Nazi  fugitive  network.  Before  escaping  detention  in  1945,  Schwammberger,  an  Austrian  by  birth,  admitted  having  shot  about  35  Jews,  according  to  the  Austrian  police.  The  Austrian  police  files  were  obtained  by  the  Anti  Defamation  League  of  B’nai   B’rith.   The  indictment  in  Stuttgart  stems  from  a  warrant  for  Schwammberger’s  arrest  that  West  Germany  issued  in  1972.  Addi  tional  charges  against  him  were  made  in  recent  years.  The  Wiesen  thal  Centre  expects  to  play  a  strong  role  at  the  trial,  having  represen  tatives  present  and  bringing  new  witnesses  to  testify,  “including  some  whom  we  recently  found  and  others  who  were  frightened  of  go  ing  on  their  own,”  Rabbi  Marvin  Hier  of  the  Los  Angeles-based  Simon  Wiesenthal  Centre  said.   “At  this  trial,  there  will  be  more  witnesses  to  testify  against  Josef  Schwammberger  than  there  was  at  any  Nazi  war  criminal  trial  of  re  cent  memory,  including  Adolf  Eichmann,”  he  said.   (Jewish  lelegraphic  Agency)

heading: German Jews growth
article_text: German  Jews  growth   Bonn:  ACTIVISTS  in  the  Jewish  community  of  Germany  say  it  is  possible  there  are  more  than  40,000  Jews  living  in'  Germany,  some  5,000  in  excess  of  the  offi  cial  tally,  and  that  the  community  is  well  on  its  way  to  increasing  its  membership  to  50,000.  The  acti  vists  feel  that  perhaps  some  5,000  Jews  in  Germany  go  uncounted  be  cause  of  failure  to  register  as  such.   The  German  government  col  lects  taxes  for  recognised  religious  communities.  The  authorities  transfer  to  the  churches  10  percent  of  the  income  tax  revenues  col  lected  from  the  churches’  mem  bers.  Individuals  who  fail  to  register  as  members  of  a  religious  community  save  10  percent  on  their  income  taxes.   “Actually,  we  have  very  few  cases  of  people  who  go  to  the  au  thorities  and  tell  them  that  they  are  withdrawing,”  a  Jewish  commun  ity  official  said.  “But  we  know  of  many  Jewish  newcomers  who  sim   ply  do  not  register  as  Jews  when  they  settle  in  the  country.  Yet  they  come  to  synagogues  and  partici  pate  in  many  other  ways  in  com  munity  activities,”  the  official   said.   The  Jewish  community  is  now  embarking  on  an  effort  to  con  vince  all  Jews  in  the  country  to  reg  ister  as  members.  This  would  broaden  the  financial  basis  of  the  group,  as  well  as  provide  more  ac  curate  statistics  on  just  how  many  Jews  have  chosen  Germany  as  their  country  of  residence.   To  achieve  that  goal,  Jewish  communities  throughout  the  coun  try  have  begun  to  match  their  membership  lists  with  lists  of  reg  istered  Jews,  as  provided  by  the  in  come  tax  authorities.  Individuals  who  are  not  registered  with  the  au  thorities  and  therefore  do  not  pay  religious  tax  are  being  reminded  that  the  revenue  from  this  source  is  the  most  important  single  source  of  income  for  community  activi   ties.   (JTA)
snippet: Bonn: ACTIVISTS in the Jewish community of Germany say it is possible there are more than 40,000 Jews living in Germany,

Both  warships  are  in  Copenhagen  harbour.
