heading: Australian-German links
article_text: Australian-German  links   MADE  IN  AUSTRALIA.  Australian  Poet-   ry  Today.  Gegenwartsdichtung  Austral-   ians.  The  OZIit  Collection  Vol  3.  Bilin-  gual.  Edited  by  Cisela  Triesch  and  Rudi  Krausmann.  Cangan  Books  Australia.  317pp.  $29.95.   Reviewer:  RALPH  ELLIOTT.   Geoff  PAGE's  recent  A  Read-   er's  Guide  to  Contemporary  Australian  Poetry  discusses  the  work  of  100  contemporary  poets,   neatly  arranged  alphabetically  from  Robert  Adamson  to  Fay  Zwicky.  For  good  measure,  the  book  concludes  with  a  list  of  100  other  poets  sug-  gested  as  no  less  worthy  of  the  read-  er's  attention,  and  I  can  think  of  other  poets  who  deserve  a  place  in  either  list,  like  Canberra's  Michael  Thwaites  and  Geoff  Page  himself,  who  modestly  excluded  himself,  but  who  does  Figure  in  Made  In  Austra-   lia.   That  Gisela  Triesch's  and  Rudi  Krausmann's  bilingual  anthology  is  restricted  to  a  mere  80  poets  is  due  to  each  poem  being  faced  by  a  trans-  lation  into  German.  Forty-six  of  these  poets  also  figure  in  Page's  Guide,  and  there  is  more  than  coinci-  dental,  at  times  verbal,  similarity  be-  tween  Page's  lengthy  introduction  to  contemporary  Australian  poetry  and  Volker  Wolfs  German  introduction  to  the  bilingual  anthology.  Who  is  echoing  whom  is  not  for  me  to  spec-   ulate.   Wolf  is  one  of  the  group  of  transla-  tors  which  also  includes  the  two  edi-  tors,  charged  with  the  gargantuan  task  of  rendering  into  German  verse  the  enormous  variety  of  language  and  styles  represented  in  poems  as  diverse  as  Les  Murray's  "The  people  are  eating  dinner  in  that  country  north  of  Legge's  Lake"  and  Ania  Walwicz's  performance  poems  (i.e.  poetic  prose  pieces)  "Australia"  and   "The  Tattoo".   Inevitably,  the  translations  vary  considerably.  Where  Australian  poets  use  rhyme,  like  Rosemary  Dobson,  Chris  Wallace-Crabbe,  and  Eva  John-  son,  this  is  ignored  by  the  transla-  tors,  and  the  distinctive  cadences  of   individual  poems  are  often  lost,  espe-  cially  where  short  English  words  are  rendered  by  lengthy  German  nouns  or  verbs,  an  extreme  example  being  Bruce  Dawe's  "like  a  traffic-report  helicopter  over  the  bankup"  which  becomes  the  monstrous  "wie  ein  Ver-  kehrsueberwachungshubschrauber  ueber  dem  Stau".  Jack  Davis's  rhyth-  mic,  melodic  "We  welcome  the  sun  down  that  heralds  the  dark"  explodes  into  the  prosy  "Wir  begruessen  den  Sonnenuntergang,  der  die  Dunkelheit  ankuendigt".   Occasionally  one  wonders  whether  the  translators  really  caught  the  po-  et's  meaning.  In  Geoff  Page's  "Small  town  Memorials"  the  final  four  lines  appear  to  me  to  refer  to  the  two  world  wars  in  reverse  order:  "The  next  bequeathed  us/Parks  and  pools/But  something  in  that  first/De-  manded  stone."  The  translation  turns  both  "next"  and  "first"  into  plural  nouns,  which  does  not  make  much  sense.  In  Judith  Beveridge's  "In  the  Park"  the  line  "of  the  moon  adrift"  becomes  "des  Mondes,  der  fei",  which  I  assume  is  a  misprint  for  "frei".  And  are  Laurie  Duggan's  "Qantas  Bags"  really  "Tueten"  in  German,  a  word  which  connotes  ice  cream  cones  and  even  breathalyzers  rather  than  cabbin  baggage?   Admittedly,  these  are  trifling  cav-  ils  in  a  book  well  furnished  with  good  German  translations,  and  they   are  unlikely  to  detract  from  the  en-  joyment  which  Austrian  or  German  or  Swiss  readers  will  derive  from  the  poems  in  this  excellent  anthology.  Moreover,  considering  the  steady  in-  flux  of  English  words  into  contempo-  rary  German,  of  which  visitors  to  German-speaking  countries  or  view-  ers  of  Derrick  must  be  very  con-  scious,  it  seems  quite  proper  that  Jennifer  Strauss's  "sand  and  sex"  should  appear  as  "Sand  und  Sex"  or  that  Robert  Harris's  "junkies"  should  appear  as  "die  Junkies"  in  Rudi  Krausmann's  translation.  Even  the  retention  of  "possum"  in  the  German  text  of  some  poems  seems  appropri-  ate,  although  in  another  poem  the  word  is  rendered  by  the  German   word  "Beutelratten".   Most  of  the  translations  do  justice  to  the  original  Australian  poems.  In  a  few  instances  they  seem  almost  an  improvement  on  the  originals,  which  is  not  unknown  in  the  history  of  po-  etic  translations.  Nancy  Cato's  "The  Dead  Swagman"  reads  very  well  in  the  German  version,  where  the  pen  ultimate  line  "die  Wurzeln  und  Kno-  chen  beruehren  sich  auf  dem  Boden"  suggests  an  even  closer  intimacy  of  the  dead  man  and  the  tree  than  the  original.  Other  renderings  which  have  struck  me  as  particularly  felici-  tous  are  Krausmann's  translations  of  Kate  Llewellyn's  "Finished"  and  the  German  version  by  Krausmann  and  Gerald  Ganglbauer  of  Richard  Tip-  ping's  "Mangoes".  The  German  writ-  er  Hans  Magnus  Enzensberger  trans-  lated  (except  for  one  stanza)  the  longest  poem  in  the  book,  John  Tran-  ter's  "The  False  Atlas";  it  is  a  re-  markably  close  yet  wholly  idiomatic  German  rendering.   As  Gisela  Triesch  points  out  in  her  postscript,  almost  half  the  poets  here  represented  are  women,  and   there  is  a  fair  selection  of  Aboriginal  and  ethnic  writers.  They  all  rightly  belong  in  an  anthology  of  "Austra-  lian  Poetry  Today",  and  the  themes  which  many  of  their  poems  address,  like  Eva  Johnson's  "Right  To  Be",  Hyllus  Maris's  "Spiritual  Song  of  the  Aborigine",  or  Marita  Kefala's  "They  Are  Still  Coming",  continue  to  be  highly  topical  in  Australia  today.   The  arrangement  of  the  poets  in  Made  in  Australia  is  by  date  of  birth,  beginning  with  Margaret  "Diesendorf,  who  was  born  in  1912  and  died  two  years  ago,  and  leading  up  to  poets  born  in  1960.  Obviously,  editorial  preference  and  available  space  deter-  mined  inclusions  and  omissions,  but  few  readers  will  dispute  that  it  is  a  well-balanced,  carefully  selected  an-  thology.  The  inclusion,  as  the  last  poem,  of  Maureen  Watson's  "Step-  ping  Out"  with  its  final  "I  don't  walk,  I  strut,/"Cause  now,  I'm  liber-  ated"  provides  a  very  moving  end-  ing.  There  are  no  dates  alongside  her   name.   The  only  thing  I  miss  in  this  otherwise  highly  commendable  book  are  brief  biographical  notes,  such  as  Geoff  Page  provides  in  his  Guide.  Australian  readers  can  turn  to  the  recent  second  edition  of  The  Oxford  Companion  to  Australian  Literature,  but  others?  However,  it  is  the  poems  themselves  that  matter,  and  there  is  God's  Plenty  in  Made  in  Australia,  a  book  of  which  lovers  of  poetry  may  well  feel  proud.   Made  in  Australia:  Australian  Poetry  To-  day  will  be  launched  al  Tilley's,  Lyne-  ham,  on  Tuesday  at  8pm,  by  Dr  Anna  Jankovic,  First  Secretary,  Embassy  of  Austria.  At  the  launch  there  will  be  read-  ings  by  Rosemary  Dobson,  Alan  Gould,  Rudi  Krausmann,  and  Geoff  Page.  In-  quiries:  249  7068.
snippet: GEOFF page's recent A Reader's Guide to Contemporary Australian Poetry discusses the work of 100 contemporary poets,

heading: German tourist rescued
article_text: German  tourist  rescued   A  German  tourist  was  resuscitated  by  life  savers  at  Chiton  Rocks  in  a  dramatic  rescue  on  Monday.   The  55-year-old  man  was  swimming  with  Ave  other  people  near  a  rocky  outcrop,  away  from  the  surf  club,  when  all  six  got  into  trouble.  While  five  managed  to  get  into  shore  unharmed  their  friend  was  caught  in  a  rip  and  swallowed  a  lot  of  water  before  reaching  the  water's  edge.   The  man  was  unconscious  and  not  breathing  when  life  savers  arrived  on  the  scene.  They  gave  the  man  oxygen  and  revived  him  before  an  ambulance  arrived.  The  man  was  later  admitted  to  South  Coast  District  Hospital  where  he  was  reported  to  be  in  a  stable  condition.  The  Ave  life  savers  involved  in  the  rescue  were  Glen  Duncan,  Michael  Shaw,  Bob  Paynter,  Avril  Hinsliff  and  Catherine  McMahon.
snippet: A German tourist was resuscitated by life savers at Chiton Rocks in a dramatic rescue on Monday.

heading: GERMAN FIRMS SUED
article_text: GERMAN  FIRMS  SUED   HOLOCAUST  survivors  are  filing  a  class  action  lawsuit  in  Newark,  New  Jersey,  against  several  German  firms  that  alleged  ly  profited  from  slave  labour  during  the   Holocaust.   The  case  comes  on  the  heels  of  a  simi  lar  lawsuit  already  filed  in  a  Brooklyn  court.  Volkswagen,  Krupp,  Siemens  and  Daimler-Benz  are  among  the  firms  named   in  the  suits.
snippet: HOLOCAUST survivors are filing a classaction lawsuit in Newark, New Jersey, against several German firms that allegedly profited from slave labour during the

heading: German orchestra visits
article_text: German  orchestra  visits   Jerusalem:  THE  president  of  Germany,  Richard  von  Weizsac  ker,  arrived  here  for  a  brief  visit  whose  highlight  was  a  special  con  cert  by  the  Dresden  Orchestra,  un   der  the  baton  of  Daniel  Barenboim.   It  was  the  first  time  a  German   orchestra  has  ever  performed  in  Israel,  a  fact  Weizsacker  alluded  to  in  his  speech  to  the  concert  audi   ence.  Proceeds  from  the  concert   will  help  Israel  absorb  immigrants  from  Ethiopia  and  the  Soviet   Union.   Addressing  the  audience,  which   included  some  of  Israel’s  most   prominent  political,  cultural  and  business  leaders,  President  Chaim  Herzog  praised  the  German  lead  er’s  unflagging  personal  involve  ment  in  the  battle  against  racism   and  discrimination.

heading: German Jews react
article_text: German  Jews  react   Bonn:  ulkmainy  b  Jewish  community  nas   reacted  sharply  to  a  new  wave  of  neo-Nazi  violence  against  foreigners,  strongly  con  demning  an  arson  attack  this  past  weekend  that  claimed  the  lives  of  five  people  of  Turk  ish  origin  in  the  western  German  town  of  Solingen.  The  tragic  attack  only  proved  that  recent  German  legislation  making  it  more  difficult  for  political  refugees  to  enter  the  country  has  not  helped  to  curb  hatred  against  foreigners  living  here,  according  to  Ignatz  Bubis,  chairman  of  the  Central  Coun  cil  of  Jews  in  Germany.
snippet: Bonn: GERMANY'S Jewish community has reacted sharply to a new wave of neo-Nazi violence against foreigners, strongly condemning an arson attack this past weekend

heading: feature German antisemitism
article_text: ^feciture/   German  antisemitism   Colin  Tatz   1  THOUGHT  we  were  finally  done  with   the  “Hitler-arrived-h  om-outer-space-in  1933”  explanation  of  German  anti  semitism.  Yet  Professor  Bill  Rubinstein,  reviewing  Daniel  Goldhagen’s  Hitler’s  Will  ing  Executioners  (AJN  31/5/96),  revisits  this  mischief.  Perhaps  not  mischief  —  rather,  some  appallingly  bad  history.   It  is  “simply  wrong",  he  declares,  to  say  “that  Germany  was  pervasively  antisemitic  before  Hitler  came  to  power”.  There  was  a  “golden  age  of  Jewish  achievement”,  typi  fied  by  Berlin  giving  Einstein  “a  princely  official  residence”  in  1930.  Jews,  he  con  tends,  were  “universally  accepted  in  Weimar  Germany”;  most  had  good,  “even  excellent  relations  with  their  Gentile  neigh  bours  until  1938”  —  in  fact,  he  writes,  most  didn’t  perceive  Germany  as  “murderously  anti-Jewish  even  after  1933”  and  “most  Ger  mans  remained  where  they  were  until  after  Kristallnacht”.   In  so  saying,  Rubinstein  deplores  the  “ahistoricity  which  bedevils  so  many  works   on  the  Holocaust".   My  concern  is  with  his  unhistoriCity.  What  can  and  should  be  said  about  the  position  of  German  Jews  from  the  end  of  the  19th  century  until  1933  in  the  cultural,  political,  academic,  scientific,  social  and  even  sporting  fields?   Modern  German  antisemitism  began  with  the  peasant  riots  of  1819.  And  while  there  are  different  antisemitisms,  much  of  the  content  forms  a  continuity.  From  the  mid  dle  of  the  last  century,  the  Jew  was  depict  ed  in  literature  as  being  without  soul,  with  out  the  traditional  humble  German  virtues,  uprooted,  troublesome,  malevolent,  shift  less.  Much  of  the  literature  followed  Gus  tav  Freytag’s  character  Veitel  Itzig,  who  was  ugly,  grasping,  without  a  shred  of  humani  ty.  Hermann  Godsche’s  novels  revealed  the  Jews  as  conspirators  against  the  Gentile   world.   Wilhelm  Marr,  who  coined  the  word  “Antisemitism”  and  founded  the  Antisemite  League  in  1879,  placed  much  store  in  these  literary  pieces.  His  “Semitism”  was  invent  ed  to  distinguish  between  German  and  Jew,  not  between  Christian  and  Jew.  Through  his  works  and  those  of  Eugen  Duhring  and  Heinrich  von  Treitschke,  the  stereotype  of  the  dangerous  Jew  was  integrated  into  the  dynamics  of  the  Volkisch  struggle  against  a  state  that  didn’t  represent,  for  them,  the  true  will  of  the  German  Volk.   As  early  as  1895,  Hermann  Ahlwardt  introduced  a  Reichstag  Bill  to  close  Ger  many’s  borders  to  “Israelites  who  are  not  citizens  of  the  Reich”.  Teutons  wanted  no  more  Jews,  people  of  a  different  race  and  culture,  people  who  would,  as  cholera  bacil  li,  cause  the  death  of  Germans.  Mixing  the  metaphor,  he  saw  them  as  beasts  of  prey  who  had  best  be  exterminated.  But  tramps,  beggars  and  social  nuisances  were  differ  ent:  they  were  “Germans  like  us"  —  some  thing  the  Jew  could  never  be.  The  Bill  was  defeated  by  167  to  51  in  favour  —  but  suc  ceeded  in  1906.   The  German  rather  than  the  Nazi  state  had  a  view  of  the  Jews  as  a  biologically  determined  race.  Frenchman  Comte  Arthur  de  Gobineau’s  works  on  “the  essential  inequality  of  the  human  races”  postulated  that  mixed  and  mongrel  man  had  finally  come  together  in  a  “pure  blood  type”  and  that  Jews,  as  “baneful  germ  plasms”,  were  the  omnipresent  danger  to  that  purity.  De  Gobineau  societies  spread  throughout  Ger  many,  aided  by  Wagner  and  his  son-in-law,  Houston  Stewart  Chamberlain.  They  spear  headed  an  antisemitism  which,  while  not  yet  physically  murderous,  was  homicidal  in  language,  spirit  and  intent.  From  then  on,  journals  and  university  departments  of  “racial  hygiene”  flourished  —  well  before  Hitler.  Volkisch  belief,  now  substantiated  by  “science”,  owed  nothing  to  Hitler,  but  much  to  Imperial  and  Weimar  Germany.   Legally,  Jews  received  little  justice  and  almost  no  satisfaction  from  the  Weimar  courts.  The  Centralverein  fur  deutsche  Staatsburger  judischen  Glaubens,  founded  in  1893,  spent  decades  fighting  attacks,  calum  nies  and  libels  on  Jews,  using  Paragraph  130  of  the  Criminal  Code  (on  incitement  to  racial  violence)  and  then,  in  despair  at  the  courts  finding  any  favour  for  Jews,  using  Paragraph  166  on  crimes  against  religion.   The  chief  defamer  was,  of  course,  Julius  Streicher  and  his  Der  Sturmer.  In  the  “Great   24   Nuremberg  Ritual  Murder  Trial”  of  1929,  Streicher  was  charged  with  suggesting  that  some  unsolved  deaths  were  Jewish  ritual  murders.  He  was  given  two  months  in  prison,  but  nearly  every  other  case  brought  against  him  resulted  in  acquittal  because  he  argued,  successfully,  that  he  was  never  attacking  the  Jewish  religion,  but  the  sepa   rate  Jewish  race!   In  1924  a  judge  came  to  the  aid  of  a  news  paper  editor  charged  with  incitement  against  Jews.  This  was  “far  from  incite  ment”,  he  ruled:  “even  the  best  men  of  our   An  illustration  from  one  ot  Julius  Streicher’s  antisemitic  children’s  books  depicts  blond  German  children  rejoicing  as  grossly  caricatured  Jewish  chddren  are  expelled  from  school.  Sbartav  oflhe  Dictators,  Time  Life  Books   nation  share  this  view”  (of  Jews).  A  Berlin  court  rejected  a  Jewish  landlord’s  claim  of  defamation  against  an  evicted  foreign  ten  ant  who  called  him  “a  German  swine”.  The  startling  judgment  was  that  “despite  his  German  citizenship,  the  plaintiff  does  not  fall  into  the  category  of  persons  popularly  connoted  by  the  word  ‘German’.”  Und  so  weiter'm  the  pre-Hitlerian  courts.   The  German  Youth  Movement,  the  Wan  denogel,  was  based  on  the  concept  of  Volk  —  that  is,  German  faith,  heroism,  tradition,  lore  and  all  the  Nordic  virtues.  By  1914,  92  percentre  of  the  local  chapters  reported  they  had  no  Jewish  members;  in  fact,  84  percent  had  specific  constitutional  clauses  banning  Jews.  Blau  Weiss,  the  Blue  and  White  Jewish  Youth  Movement,  was  found  ed  in  1916  in  self-recognition  of  Jews  as  sep   arate  from  the  mainstream.   How  comfortable  could  Jews  be  in  such  environments?  German  students  were  swept  up  by  Volkisch  ideology,  their  frater  nities  embracing  virulent  hostility  to  all  things  Jewish.  The  Jews  were  “the  enemy  within”  —  something  they  expressed  vio  lently.   Die  Mitteilungsblatter,  the  major  Jewish  journal  devoted  to  combatting  anti  semitism,  had  much  to  report.  Thus,  when  a  distinguished  legal  professor  told  his  class  to  read  the  works  of  two  Jewish  legal  theorists,  he  was  jeered  and  decried.  In  1920  Berlin  University  students  threatened  to  riot  if  the  university  went  ahead  with  a  memorial  service  for  the  assassinated  For  eign  Minister,  the  Jewish  Walter  Rathenau.   As  ever,  the  only  protection  for  Jews  was  to  form  their  own  fraternities,  starting  as  early  as  1896.  As  ever,  they  were  ostracised   by  university  authorities  and  closed  (down  at  every  opportunity.  Heidelberg  University  decreed  that  “the  very  existence  of  a  Jew  ish  fraternity  is  sufficient  to  endanger  peace  amongst  the  students”.   The  highest  form  of  social  interaction   among  students  was  duelling,  for  sport  and  for  honour.  Early  on,  Ger  man  students  barred  Jews  from  this  signifi  cant  activity.  Smash  the  Jewish  conspiracy  and  the  Volk  will  flourish  —  that  was  the  message  from  noisy  students  and  very  silent,  very  acquiescent  professors.   Jews  were  excluded  from  the  socially  important  gymnastic  organisations.  As  always,  they  had  to  form  their  own  Tumer  schaften.  Gershom  Scholem  has  written  poignantly  about  the  assimilating,  German  loving,  German-craving  Jews.  The  German  liberals  asked:  what  kind  of  civilisation  or  religion  or  culture  or  “race”  is  this  that  sur  renders  itself  in  this  way?  And  the  Jew  haters  asked:  what  kind  of  fifth  column,  what  kind  of  bacillus,  is  this  that  invades  us,  that  purports  to  be  “us”  when  it  so  patently  isn’t,  and  can’t  be?  Crushed  by  this  dilemma,  German  Jewish  male  youth  resort  ed  to  suicide  in  cosmic  numbers  between  the  wars.  Suicide  a  litmus  of  “excellent  rela  tions”  within  Germany?   Einstein,  his  “princely  official  residence"  notwithstanding,  was  hated  by  many.  As  one  Nobel  Laureate  observed:  “A  Jew  con  spicuously  lacks  understanding  for  the  truth,  in  contrast  to  the  Aryan  research  sci   entist.”   Rubinstein’s  “golden  age”  of  achievement  really  began  with  the  creation,  in  Septem  ber  1933,  of  the  first  (and  only)  Jewish  roof  body,  the  Reichsuertretung  der  Deutschen  Juden,  under  Rabbi  Leo  Baeck.  Under  the  direction  of  Martin  Buber,  Jewish  adult  edu  cation  programs  led  to  Schocken  Books  publishing  5000  tiles  between  1933  and  1938.  A  great  achievement  —  but  how  “golden"  were  the  dynamics  that  gave  rise   to  it?   So  what  did  the  majority  of  German  Jews  perceive  about  their  world?  How  comfort   able  were  they  in  a  society  in  which  they  believed  they  were  integrated  and  accept  ed,  in  which  they  pursued  German-ness  rather  than  Jewishness,  but  which  degrad   ed  them  in  special  laws,  denied  them  judi  cial  fairness,  excluded  them  from  the  social  and  sporting  life  of  universities,  despised  them  in  mainstream  literature,  excoriated  them  as  racially  different  —  and  danger   ous?   What  they  did,  Professor  Rubinstein,  was  leave,  in  great  numbers.  To  the  best  of  any  one’s  knowledge,  there  were  566,602  Jews  in  Germany  in  1933  —1  a  mere  0.86  percent  of  the  population.  By  1941,  347,103,  or  60  percent,,  had  left.  More,  significant  is  that  252,400,  or  just  on  45  percent,  had  left   before  Kristallnacht,  and  before  the  forced  emigration  policy  got  fully  under  way.   The  years  tell  their  own  story:  63,400  left  in  1933,  mainly  due  to  the  “de-Judaising"  of  the  public  service;  45,000  emigrated  in  1934  because  of  panic,  uncertainly,  alarm  at  the  desecration  of  shules  and  the  increase  in  arbitrary  arrests.  Enough  Jews  thought  1935  “a  good  year”  —  the  year  the  Nurem  berg  Laws  made  them  non-citizens;  the  feel  ing  was  that  they  could  accommodate  to  this  if  this  was  the  worst  that  was  to  be.  “Let’s  wait  another  winter,”  they  ratio  nalised,  even  though  the  optimists  knew  there  could  be  no  return  to  early  Weimar.  Only  35,000  left.  The  following  year  was  also  a  “good”  one,  the  Olympic  year,  when  34,000  emigrated.  1937  was  the  best  year  yet;  there  appeared  to  be  an  “accommoda  tion”  of  sorts  and  the  number  of  Jews  in  concentration  camps  was  low  —  only  7000!  The  following  year,  in  the  10  months  before  November  9,49,000  Jews  left.   Hitler  didn  t  arrive  with  an  X-File  package  called  antisemitism.  There  were  two  (or  more)  antisemitisms  in  Germany  and  it  cer  tainly  was  Hitler  who  radicalised  the  tradi  tional  form  of  it.  Rubinstein  asserts  that  Jews  were  comfortable  with  the  Weimar  brand  and  “enjoyed  excellent  relations”  with  their  despisers  and  detractors.  If  that  is  true,  then  it  tells  us  something  about  some  German  Jews  and  their  perceptions,  or  absence  of  them.  To  say  that  they  were  happy  is  not  to  say  that  there  was  no  objectively  visible  and  provable  danger  intrinsic  to  their  past  and  their  present.   Colin  Tatz  is  Professor  of  Politics  at  Mac  quarie  University  and  director  of  Macquarie’s  Comparative  Genocide  Studies  Centre.
snippet: I THOUGHT we were finally done with the “Hitler-arrived-h om-outer-space-in1933” explanation of German anti-semitism. Yet Professor Bill Rubinstein,

heading: German ambassador appointed
article_text: German  ambassador  appointed   BONN:  The  architect  of  Germa  ny's  new  and  more  expansionary  Asia  policy  will  be  its  next  ambassador  to  Australia.   German  Foreign  Minister  Klaus  Kinkel  said  yesterday  Klaus  Geller  would,  subject  to  the  formality  of  Australian  Government  approval,  take  over  in  Canberra  in  October.   The  appointment  of  Dr  Geller,  who  heads  the  Foreign  Ministry's  Asia  Pacific  desk,  is  seen  as  an  indication  of  how  seriously  Germany  now  takes  Australia  as  an  economic  and  politic  al  player  in  the  region.   He  has  developed  an  "Asian  Con  cept"  to  increase  Germany's  political  and  economic  standing  in  the  region.
snippet: BONN: The architect of Germany's new and more expansionary Asia policy will be its next ambassador to Australia.

heading: German leader reassures
article_text: German  leader  reassures   Staff  writer   THE  STRENGTH  of  today’s  German  democracy  was  the  best  defence  against  any  threat  of  neo-Nazism,  Germany’s  President  Richard  von  Weizsaecker  told  a  delegation  of  Australian  Jewish  leaders  last  week  in  Melbourne   Unlike  the  ’30s,  when  the  Weimar  Republic’s  democracy  did  not  go  very  deep,  President  von  Weizsaeck  er  said  he  took  comfort  from  the  “liberal,  open-minded  and  tolerant”  reaction  by  the  German  people  to  recent  outbursts  of  violence  against  immigrants  and  guest-workers.   The  many  Germans  who  protest  ed  against  the  eruption  of  violence  as  soon  as  it  had  occurred  had  not   waited  for  their  political  leaders  to  l  act  but  had  taken  their  own  initia   \  tive,  the  German  president  said.   At  the  same  time  the  government  was  doing  its  utmost  to  oppose  the  racist  violence,  he  claimed,  citing  the  decision  by  the  Interior  Ministry  last  week  to  file  suit  against  the  extreme-right  wing  FRP  party  and  declare  it  unconstitutional.   President  von  Weizsaecker  was  speaking  last  Friday  afternoon  at  the  Grand  Hyatt  Hotel  during  his  first  official  engagement  after  arriving  in  Australia  as  the  guest  of  the  govern  ment  and  Governor-General  Bill  Hay  den.  He  was  responding  to  an  address  of  welcome  from  Executive   Council  of  Australian  Jewry  presi  dent  Isi  Leibler  who  spoke  on  behalf  of  11  invited  representatives  of  Jew  ish  communal  organisations.   “This  is  a  very  good  first  appoint  ment  in  Australia  under  your  aus  pices,”  the  German  head  of  state  told  the  Jewish  leaders.  He  was  accompanied  by  Germany’s  Minister  of  State  (Foreign  Affairs  Ministry)   Ursula  Seiler-Albring,  other  officials  from  the  Foreign  Ministry  and  the  office  of  the  federal  president,  and  the  German  Consul-General  in  Mel  bourne  Hans-Georg  Fein.   During  his  response  to  Mr  Leibler,  who  had  expressed  grave  disquiet  over  the  resurgence  of  neo-Nazism  in  Germany,  President  von  Weizsaecker  said  that  nothing  justi  fied  even  a  single  act  of  violence,  the  painting  of  one  swastika  or  the  dese  cration  of  any  Jewish  cemetery.  But,  he  added,  the  violence  in  Germany  had  to  be  understood  against  the  background  of  recent  events.   In  his  welcoming  remarks  Mr  Leibler  said  Australian  Jewry  was  particularly  sensitive  to  the  issues  of  Holocaust  remembrance  because,  with  the  exception  of  Israel,  it  had  a  greater  proportion  of  survivors  than  in  any  other  country.   Referring  to  the  German  presi  dent’s  speech  to  the  Bundestag  in  1985  Mr  Leibler  said  it  had  been  a  milestone  along  the  road  of  improved  German-Jewish  relations.  “Jews  throughout  the  world  admire  and  respect  you  as  an  outstanding  German  leader,  “  Mr  Leibler  said.   The  new  Germany  would  be  judged  on  its  performance,  not  on  its  past,  Mr  Leibler  said.  But  Jews  must  never  suggest  that  reconcilia  tion  could  be  achieved  by  forgiving  or  forgetting.   “In  this  sense,  our  meeting  with  you  today  is  an  important  step  in  the  ongoing  process  of  reconcilia  tion.  And  while  there  cannot  be  a  total  normalisation  of  relations  dur  ing  our  generation,  we  Jews  recog  nise  the  progress  made  by  Germain  leaders  who  have  tried  to  educate  towards  a  sense  of  history  and  morality  among  young  Germans,"   Mr  Leibler  said.
snippet: THE STRENGTH of today’s German democracy was the best defence against any threat of neo-Nazism, Germany’s President Richard von

heading: German armour invades

heading: German swimmers unite
article_text: German  swimmers  unite   WEST  BERLIN:  East  and  West  Germany  will  hold  their  first  combined  trials  to  create  a  joint  swimming  team  for  the  coming  World  Championships,  the  West  German  Swimming  Federation  confirmed  on  Monday.   The  East  German  newspaper  Junge  Welt  said  in  its  edition  on  Monday  that  the  trials  would  create  the  first  joint  sports  team  between  the  two  countries.   The  trials  are  to  take  place  in  Freiburg,  West  Germany,  from  November  8-11,  the  federation  said.   Next  year's  World  Championships  are  scheduled  to  take  place  in  Perth  in  January.
snippet: WEST BERLIN: East and West Germany will hold their first combined trials to create a joint swimming team for the coming World Championships, the West German Swimming Federation confirmed on Monday.

heading: German inflation beaters
article_text: German  inflation  beaters   By  WILL  HUTTON   LONDON,  Thursday:  Two  years  ago  Germany  was  written  off  as  the  sclerotic  giant  that  could  recover  its  economic  dy-  namism  only  if  it  "Thatcher-  ised"  its  corporatist  economic  structure.   Today,  it  is  beginning  to  re-  sume  its  role  as  the  feared  su-  per  competitor.   The  source  of  comparative  ad-  vantage  is  simple:  it  is  the  country's  capacity  to  mobilise  resources  for  investment,  giving  it  the  highest  capital  stock  per  worker  in  Europe.   The  debate  about  whether  the  resulting  wages  and  social  wel-  fare  system  are  too  expensive  is,  in  a  sense,  besides  the  point.   Germany  has  an  investment  system  which  gives  it  the  wealth  for  such  complaints  to  be  possible.   The  key  is  the  mobilisation  of  huge  flows  of  cheap,  low-mar-  gin,  long-term  bank  finance  to  support  the  build-up  of  industri-  al  capital.   The  German  "Mittelstand",  the  family  owned  medium-sized  companies  which  form  the  back-  bone  of  German  industry,  is  a  beneficiary  of  the  system  as   much  as  the  giant  international  combines.  Herein  lies  the  source  of  German  productivity  and  innovation.   It  is  also  why  there  is  such  a  strong  financial  and  industrial  interest  in  low  inflation.  Lend-  ing  long-term  loans  is  not  very  easy  if  the  price  level  keeps  in-  creasing  in  an  unstable  and  un-  predictable  way  —  if  the  loan's  value  halves  in  real  terms  over  its  life,  then  making  such  a  loan  is  inherently  unattractive.   The  more  long-term  the  loan,  the  greater  the  risk  —  and  thus  the  greater  the  interest  in  infla-  tion  being  low.   Thus,  the  success  of  the  Bun-  desbank,  praised  by  the  British  Right  for  its  anti-inflationary  credentials,  is  less  a  result  of  its  being  independent  than  be-  cause  it  is  part  of  the  anti-infla-  tionary  system  upon  which  Ger-  man  industrial  success  is  built.   Hence,  the  strong  desire  to  back  it  —  and  the  wariness  of  substituting  a  single  European  currency  for  the  Deutschemark.  Inflation  would  undermine  the  source  of  Germany's  compara-  tive  advantage.   The  commitment  of  the  sys-  tem  to  providing  long-term  debt   finance  to  raise  investment  lev-   els  is  breathtaking.  The  IKB,  for  example,  is  an  industrial  in-  vestment  bank  with  a  100  loan  salesmen  making  between  three  to  five  visits  a  day  trying  to  sell  Mittelstand  companies  long-term  loan  packages.   The  margin  on  IKB's  lending  is  1  per  cent.  Margins  are  bid  down  by  keen  competition  be-  tween  the  big  regional  Landes-  banks,  the  specialist  industrial  banks  in  some  regions,  the  local  municipal  savings  banks  and  the  big  three  commercial  banks  —  the  Deutsche,  Dresdner  and  Commerzbank.   Each  has  a  mandate  to  serve  particular  markets  —  for  small  business  or  for  giant  industrial  combines,  but  there  is  a  com-  plex  system  for  "refinancing"  them  so  they  can  get  the  long-term  deposits  to  lend.   For  example,  the  Kreditan-  stalt  fur  Wiederaufbau,  the  re-  construction  bank,  specialises  in  packages  of  long-term  fi-  nance  —  partly  raised  from  the  Frankfurt  money  markets  and  partly  subsidised  by  govern-  ment  —  which  can  be  used  for  everything  from  export  finance  to  social  housing.   This  avalanche  of  cheap  long-term  debt  allows  firms  to  be  choosy  about  the  terms  on  which  they  raise  money  from  the  alternative  source  of  fi-  nance  —  the  stock  market.   Few  medium-sized  companies  have  more  than  half  their  shares  quoted  on  the  stock  mar-  ket,  and  those  that  do  are  care-  ful  to  issue  as  many  as  possible  without  voting  rights.   Most  search  for  a  bank,  in-  surance  company  or  partner  who  will  hold  a  large  block  of  equity  as  a  long-term  invest-  ment.  Virtually  no  German  company  has  a  majority  of  its  voting  equity  freely  traded  be  tween  a  floating  population  of  owners.  Takeover  becomes  more  difficult,  another  bias  to  "long-  termism"  and  more  investment.   This  is  the  content  in  which   owners  and  managers  consult   with  their  workforces  in  works  councils.  Ownership  is  secured.  Long-term  finance  is  plentiful.  Investment  rates  are  high.   The  task  is  to  get  the  best  from  the  human  capital  work-  ing  in  the  firm  —  hence  the  commitment  of  both  parties  to  exchanging  information  and   consulting.   —  The  Guardian

heading: German Jews react
article_text: German  Jews  react   duiiii.  ocjaivi/ai11  o  jcwibii  cumin  unity  na^   reacted  sharply  to  a  new  wave  of  neo-Nazi  violence  against  foreigners,  strongly  con  demning  an  arson  attack  this  past  weekend  that  claimed  the  lives  of  five  people  of  Turk  ish  origin  in  the  western  German  town  of  Solingen.  The  tragic  attack  only  proved  that  recent  German  legislation  making  it  more  difficult  for  political  refugees  to  enter  the  country  has  not  helped  to  curb  hatred  against  foreigners  living  here,  according  to  Ignatz  Bubis,  chairman  of  the  Central  Coun  cil  of  Jews  in  Germany.
snippet: BONN: GERMANY'S Jewish community has reacted sharply to a new wave of neo-Nazi violence against foreigners, strongly condemning an arson attack this past weekend

heading: German shule rededicated
article_text: German  shule  rededicated   Igal  Avidan   Berlin:  THE  synagogue  in  the  Bavarian  town  of  Ermreuth,  which  was  destroyed  during  the  Holo  caust,  was  rededicated  recently  under  tight  security  measures.   At  the  ceremony,  the  Bavarian  interior  minister,  Gunther  Beck  stein,  and  a  number  of  officials  from  the  American  Embassy  expressed  their  solidarity  with  the  Jewish  people.   Several  descendants  of  former  Jewish  citizens  of  Ermreuth,  which  is  located  near  Nuremberg,  made  the  journey  there  for  the   dedication.   These  included  Malcolm  Hoen  lein,  executive  vice  chairman  of  the  Conference  of  Presidents  of   Major  American  Jewish  Organisa  tions  and  members  of  his  family.  Hoenlein’s  great-great  grandfather  established  the  synagogue  in  1822  and  his  grandfather  ran  services  there  earlier  this  century.   The  shule  was  destroyed  on  Kristallnacht,  the  massive  pogrom  that  enveloped  much  of  Germany  in  November  1938.  It  was  rebuilt  and  rededicated  largely  as  a  result  of  the  non-Jewish  citizens  of  Ermreuth.   At  the  ceremony,  Beckstein  reminded  those  in  attendance  that.the  co-existence  of  Christians  and  Jews  in  Germany  has  not  only  a  past  but  also  a  future.   He  demanded  all  citizens  join  forces  against  “all  forms  of  hatred  against  foreigners  and  anti  semitism”.   After  the  Torah  scroll  was  placed  in  the  ark  and  the  mezuzah  attached  to  the  entrance  of  the  shule,  a  plaque  was  unveiled  com  memorating  the  deportation  of  the  Jewish  citizens  of  Ermreuth  by  the  Nazis  during  World  War  II.   JTA
snippet: Berlin: THE synagogue in the Bavarian town of Ermreuth, which was destroyed during the Holocaust, was rededicated recently

heading: German accord sought
article_text: German  accord  sought   BREST,  Soviet  Union:  The  Soviet  Foreign  Minister,  Eduard  Shevardnadze,  and  West  Germany's  Hans-Dietrich  Genscher  started  talks  yesterday  on  how  to  remove  obstacles  in  the  path  to  a  fully  sovereign  new  German  state.   Western  diplomats  said  they  did  not  expect  a  breakthrough  to  be  announced  after  the  talks  but  said  the  two  men  could   reach  crucial  accords.  These  could  be  put  later  this  month  to  six  foreign  ministers  of  countries  in  the  so-called  "two-plus-  four"  talks  involving  the  two  German  states  and  the  four  World  War  II  allies.   The  Soviet  Union  insists  that  a  united  Germany  must  not  be  a  member  of  the  NATO  alliance.   —  Reuter

heading: German leagues unite
article_text: German  leagues  unite   FRANKFURT,  West  Germany:  East  German  soc  cer  clubs  have  agreed  to  join  the  powerful  West  Ger  man  Bundesliga  in  the  1991-92  season.   The  East  and  West  German  soccer  federations  agreed  that  East  Germany  would  withdraw  from  quali  fying  matches  for  the  1992  European  championship  and  the  1992  Olympic  Games  in  Barcelona  as  a  prelude  to  the  creation  of  a  single  national  side.   The  West  German  DFB  and  the  East  German  DFV  agreed  to  expand  the  West  German  first  division  from  18  to  20  teams  with  the  addition  of  the  champions  and  runners-up  from  East  Germany's  top  teague.
snippet: FRANKFURT, West Germany: East German soccer clubs have agreed to join the powerful West German Bundesliga in the 1991-92 season. The East and West German soccer federations

heading: German student visits
article_text: German  student  visits   EXCHANGE  STUDENT  As  part  of  the  Lions  Club  International  Youth  Exchange,  the  Goolwa  Lions  Club  hosted  19  year-old  German  exchange  stu  dent  Kathrin  Jaeger  on  Monday,  August  2.  She  is  pictured  here  with  Goolwa  Lions  Club  President  Maggie  Harding  and  also  Gail  Smith  of  the  Goolwa  Lions  Club  who  acted  as  a  tour  guide  on  the  day.  Maggie  presented  Kathrin  with  a  koala  as  a  small  gift  for  her  to  show  her  family  when  she  returns  to  Germany.

heading: German neo-Nazis
article_text: German  neo-Nazis   MEMBERSHIP  in  German  neo   Nazi  groups  increased  markedly  between  1994  and  1997,  according  to  the  German  news  magazine  Der  Spiegel.  Membership  increased  from  5,400  to  7,500  dur  ing  the  three-year  period,  accord  ing  to  the  magazine,  which  cited  numbers  obtained  by  state  agen  cies  that  monitor  extremist  groups.
snippet: MEMBERSHIP in German neoNazi groups increased markedly between 1994 and 1997, according to the German news magazine

heading: German Jews critical
article_text: I  German  Jews   critical   Berlin:  JLWlbH  leaders  m  Germany  have  expressed  their  disappointment  with  the  government’s  response  to  continuing  attacks  on  foreigners  in  this  country.   The  Jewish  president  of  the  International  League  for  Human  Rights  in  Berlin,  Alisa  Fuss,  has  protested  a  new  policy  limiting  asylum-seekers  from  entering  Germany  and  returned  an  honorary  medal  she  had  received  from  the  German  president.   And  the  head  of  the  10,000-strong  Jewish  community  in  Berlin,  Holocaust  survivor  Jerzy  Kanal,  called  a  news  conference  here  saying  that  Germany’s  Jews  felt  “uneasy”.   The  policy,  scheduled  to  go  into  effect  on  July  1,  was  also  criticised  by  the  Ger  man  writer  Gunther  Grass.
snippet: Berlin: JEWISH leaders in Germany have expressed their disappointment with the government’s response to continuing attacks on foreigners in this country.

heading: German court denial
article_text: German  court  denial   Berlin:  GERMANY’S  highest  appeals  court  is  denying  accusations  that  a  ruling  it  issued  last  month  gave  the  green  light  to  right-wing  groups  here  to  spread  the  theory  that  the  Holocaust  never  took  place.   In  the  wake  of  a  barrage  of  criticism  from  Jewish  groups,  German  politicians  and  the  media,  the  Federal  Court  of  Justice  in  Karls  ruhe  issued  a  statement  last  week  clarifying  its  position  and  denying  it  had  acquitted  an  alleged  perpetrator  of  the  so-called  “Auschwitz  lie”.   The  federal  court’s  March  15  ruling  voided  the  one-year  prison  sentence  given  by  the  Mannheim  District  Court  to  right-wing  extrem  ist  Gunther  Deckert  for  denying  the  Holocaust  occurred.  The  appeals  court  called  for  Deckert  to  be  retried  in  the  lower  court.   Deckert,  who  is  chairman  of  the  National  German  Party,  was  convicted  of  incitement  to  racism  by  organising  a  1991  lecture  in  Ger  many  by  American  Holocaust-denier  Fred  Leuchter.  Deckert  also  served  as  Leuchter’s  interpreter.  The  appeals  court  called  on  the  lower  court  to  demonstrate  that  Deckert  him   self  identified  with  Nazi  ideology  and  did  not  just  translate  another’s  words.

heading: German language school
article_text: German  language  school   THE  ACT  German  Language   School  has  been  operating  since  1958.  It  teaches  German  as  a  real  and  living  form  of  communi  cation,  a  spokesperson  said.   "There  is  a  conscious  emphasis  on  modern  spoken  German,  especially  with  the  young  students  where  the  ap  proach  to  teching  is  largely  conversa  tional.  The  syllabus  for  the  senior  forms  and  for  adult  students  adopts  a  more  structured  approach.   "An  objective  is  to  awaken  in  stu  dents  an  appreciation  for  and  a  genu  ine  liking  of'things  German"  within  a  contemporary  European  context.  Stu  dents  are  introduced  to  the  lifestyle,  culture,  geography  and  history  of  Ger  man  speaking  countries.  Our  aim  is  to  make  the  courses  as  effective  and  en  joyable  as  possible."   The  School  has  two  departments,  cach  operating  independently  from  different  locations  and  at  different  times:  The  Saturday  Morning  School  for  Children  and  the  Adult  Classes   Division.  ^  The  Saturday  Morning  School  for   Children   The  Saturday  Morning  School  for  Children  has  two  tiers.  The  primary  scctor  caters  for  pupils  of  primary   school  age  from  5  years  onwards.   The  secondary  sector  takes  students  of  high  school  age  through  to  year  12.   Courses  cater  for  beginners  and  ad  vanced  students.  The  secondary  tier  course  is  accredited  by  the  ACT  De  partment  of  Education,  so  that  stu  dents  unable  to  take  German  at  their  normal  secondary  school  or  college  can  take  German  at  the  ACT  German  Language  School  as  an  external  sub  ject,  which  will  then  be  recorded  on  their  regular  Year  12  Certificate,  if  they  wish.   Placement  of  students  is  based  on  age  and  prior  knowledge  (if  any)  of  German.  Lessons  are  from  9am  to  11.30am  (senors  to  11.45am)  each  Sat  urday  during  school  terms,  at  Alfred  Deakin  High  School,  Deakin.   Reports  are  issued  to  students  each  year,  and  a  prize-giving  ceremony  takes  place  at  the  end  of  the  year.   The  Saturday  Morning  School  for  Children  acknowledges  the  financial  assistance  of  the  Embassy  of  the  Feder  al  Republic  of  Germany  and  the  Com  monwealth  Department  of  Employment,  Education  and  Train  ing,  enabling  tuition  fees  to  be  kept  at  a  very  reasonable  level.

heading: letters German left
article_text: letters   German  left   I  WISH  Joachim  Fest,  the  German  historian  whose  Plotting  Hitler's  Death  was  reviewed  by  Professor  Bill  Rubinstein  (AJN1/8)  could  see  that  review.  What  would  he  make  of  the  extraordinary  last  para  graph,  in  which  Rubinstein  states  that  from  the  German  left,  “virtu  ally  nothing  was  heard,”  in  opposi   tion  to  Hitler?   After  1933,  of  course  not.  It  was  not  easy  to  make  protests  from  behind  the  barbed  wire  fences  of  Buchenwald  and  Dachau,  where  the  Nazis  incarcerated  and  mur  dered  thousands  of  their  political  opponents  —  Socialists,  Com  munists,  religious  oppositionists   and  others.   In  practical  terms,  resistance  to  Hitler  could  come  only  from  the  political  right,  the  same  end  of   the  spectrum  as  Hitler  himself,  because  that  was  all  that  remained  after  the  physical  removal  of  both  the  centre  and  the  left  from  the  political  arena.   Before  1933?  One  of  the  great  tragedies  of  modem  German  his  tory  is  that  the  Social  Democrats  and  the  Communists,  who  togeth  er  could  possibly  have  stopped  Hitler,  wasted  far  too  much  ener  gy  attacking  each  other.  Hindsight   has  shown  that  the  reasons  for   this  split  were  quite  spurious,  dic  tated  on  the  one  hand  by  an  inap  propriate  sense  of  honour  and  on  the-other  by  fealty  to  the  strategy  of  the  Comintern.   But  neither  group  spared  the  Nazis  in  their  press  and  public  statements.  The  names  of  play  wright  Bertolt  Brecht  and  artists  John  Heartfield  and  Kathe   Kollwitz  are  only  three  among  hundreds  of  German  anti-Nazi  publicists,  all  of  them  associated  with  the  left,  that  come  to  mind.  That  they  failed  to  halt  Hitler  is  part  of  the  German  tragedy,  and  is  certainly  not  a  cause  for  shame  or  condemnation.   Steve  Brook  Elwood

heading: German records found
article_text: German  records  found   By  IAN  McPHEDRAN,   Foreign  Affairs  Reporter   German  consular  documents  seized  by  Australia  before  both  World  Wars  have  been  handed  back  to  the  German  Govern  ment  hv  Fnrpicm  Affaire  Minictor-  flarotVi   Evans,  concluding  what  he  described  as  a  "detective  tale  of  some  consequence".   The  documents  were  crated,  vaulted  and  for  gotten  at  the  Australian  Archives  until  they  were  drawn  to  the  attention  of  a  German  ar  chivist,  Dr  Jurgen  Real,  in  1991.   They  had  been  held  in  secret  by  the  Com  monwealth  Investigation  Service,  the  predeces  sor  of  the  Australian  Secret  Intelligence  Or  ganisation,  when  the  Germans  asked  for  them  back  in  the  1950s.  Unaware  of  their  existence,  the  Department  of  External  Affairs  replied  that  they  had  been  destroyed.   A  departmental  historian,  Dr  John  Cumps  ton,  unearthed  the  documents,  written  in  old  German  script,  in  the  1960s  and  was  apparent  ly  ordered  to  destroy  them  to  avoid  embarrass   ment.   He  refused  and  they  were  sent  to  the  Aus  tralian  Archives  to  be  held  in  confidence,  un  recorded  in  other  historical  information.   According  to  the  Director-General  of  the  Australian  Archives,  George  Nichols,  about  18  per  cent,  or  80,000  linear  metres,  of  the  Ar  chives'  holdings  remained  unevaluated.   "Within  that  there  are  small  parcels  that  we  know  very  little  about,"  he  says.   Senator  Evans  said,  "We  are  delighted  to  be  able  to  close  this  chapter  of  history  and,  in  the  context  of  the  Prime  Minister's  forthcom  ing  visit  to  Germany,  to  give  back  to  Germany  what  rightfully  belongs  to  it."   German  Ambassador  Klaus  Zeller  received  a  letter  yesterday  from  Senator  Evans  which  contained  a  complete  schedule  of  the  material.   He  said  archives  were  important  to  a  coun  try's  history.  "What  is  more  important  than  archives  are  our  present  relations  and  our  fu  ture  relations.  Our  present  ones  are  very  good  and  they  are  documented  by  the  keen  interest  our  Government  has  in  enhancing  them,"  he   said.   Copies  of  the  documents,  which  concern  shipping,  trade  and  the  movement  of  people,  will  be  held  by  the  Australian  Archives.   Foreign  Affairs  Minister  Gareth  Evans,  left,  presents  the  documents  to  German  Ambassador  Klaus  Zellor.
snippet: German consular documents seized by Australia before both World Wars have been handed back to the German Government by Foreign Affairs Minister Gareth

heading: East German claims
article_text: East  German  claims   EAST  GERMAN  authorities  have  announced  that  there  will  be  an  early  settlement  of  outstanding  claims  for  con  fiscated  property.   A  decree  outlining  procedures  for  lodging  claims  has  been  issued  as  part  of  the  unification  process  of  East  and  West  Germany.   An  announcement  las  week  from  the  Australian  For  eign  Affairs  and  Trade  Department  said  the  deadline  for  lodging  claims  is  October  13  this  year.  It  was  originally  January  31,  1991.   The  department  said  a  claim  did  not  have  to  be  ac  companied  by  full  documentation  when  filed.  Documents  could  be  handed  in  later.   Claimants  living  outside  East  Germany  have  to  lodge  claims  at  the  city  or  municipal  office  of  the  area  where  the  property  they  are  claiming  is  situated.
snippet: EAST GERMAN authorities have announced that there will be an early settlement of outstanding claims for confiscated property. A decree outlining procedures for lodging claims has

heading: German crimes trial
article_text: German  crimes  trial   ACCUSED  Nazi  war  criminal  Jo  sef  Schwammberger  was  indicted  last  month  in  court  at  Stuttgart,  West  Germany,  on  charges  of  murdering  “at  least  50  Jews”  dur  ing  World  War  II.  He  also  was  charged  as  an  accessory  to  the  murder  of  at  least  3,377  other  peo  ple,  according  to  the  World  Jew  ish  Congress,  which  learned  of  the  indictment  from  the  Jewish  com  munity  of  West  Berlin.  Schwamm  berger  admitted  to  ordering  the  execution  of  one  person  under  “special  circumstances,”  but  other  than  that,  “he  has  completely  de  nied  his  crimes,”  according  to  Hel  mut  Kronbacher,  spokesman  for  the  prosecutor’s  office.   Schwammberger,  78,  who  is  be  ing  held  at  the  Stammheim  maxi  mum  security  prison,  was  extradited  from  Argentina  in  May,  after  a  long  proceeding  that  in  cluded  his  hospitalisation  in  an  Ar  gentine  hospital  for  a  mysterious  coma.  The  Stuttgart  court  found  him  fit  to  stand  trial.  The  prosecutor’s  office  said  the  trial  would  probably  begin  early  next  year.  That  would  likely  make  Schwammberger  the  first  alleged  Nazi  war  criminal  to  be  tried  in  a  unified  Germany.  A  guilty  verdict  would  bring  a  life  sentence.   A  former  lieutenant  in  the  Waf  fen  SS  and  commandant  of  several  concentration  camps  in  Poland,  Schwammberger  allegedly  was  known  for  his  particularly  cruel  killings  of  Jews.  He  has  been  ac  |  cused  by  survivors  of  camps  of   Jewish  areas  in  the  Polish  towns  of  Przemysl,  Mielec,  Rozwadow  and  Stalowa-Wola  of  smashing   children’s  heads  against  walls,  throwing  people  alive  into  fires  and  shooting  people  point-blank.  Witnesses  said  they  saw  Schwammberger  use  pliers  to  re  move  gold  teeth  from  prisoners.  He  was  known  as  the  “butcher  of  Rozwadow.”   After  the  war,  Schwammberger  was  arrested  in  Austria  with  bags  of  jewellery  stolen  from  Jews,  which  he  admitted  under  question  ing.  He  escaped,  probably  in  1948,  to  Argentina  with  what  is  believed  to  have  been  help  from  Odessa,  a  Nazi  fugitive  network.  Before  escaping  detention  in  1945,  Schwammberger,  an  Austrian  by  birth,  admitted  having  shot  about  35  Jews,  according  to  the  Austrian  police.  The  Austrian  police  files  were  obtained  by  the  Anti  Defamation  League  of  B’nai   B’rith.   The  indictment  in  Stuttgart  stems  from  a  warrant  for  Schwammberger’s  arrest  that  West  Germany  issued  in  1972.  Addi  tional  charges  against  him  were  made  in  recent  years.  The  Wiesen  thal  Centre  expects  to  play  a  strong  role  at  the  trial,  having  represen  tatives  present  and  bringing  new  witnesses  to  testify,  “including  some  whom  we  recently  found  and  others  who  were  frightened  of  go  ing  on  their  own,”  Rabbi  Marvin  Hier  of  the  Los  Angeles-based  Simon  Wiesenthal  Centre  said.   “At  this  trial,  there  will  be  more  witnesses  to  testify  against  Josef  Schwammberger  than  there  was  at  any  Nazi  war  criminal  trial  of  re  cent  memory,  including  Adolf  Eichmann,”  he  said.   (Jewish  Telegraphic  Agency)

heading: German terrorist killing
article_text: German  terrorist  killing   BONN:  Detlev  Rohwedder,  powerful  head  ofa  controversial  agency  privatising  former  East  Ger  man  firms,  has  been  murdered  by  suspected  ur  ban  guerrillas  in  Duesseldorf,  police  said.   The  Federal  Prosecutor's  Office,  which  quickly  launched  an  investigation,  said  an  anonymous  caller  to  a  news  agency  in  Paris  claimed  responsi  bility  for  the  murder  in  the  name  of  Germany's  Red  Army  Faction.   Mr  Rohwedder,  58,  was  killed  by  shots  fired  into  his  house  overlooking  the  Rhine  about  11.30pm  on  Monday  (7.30am  AEST  yesterday)  police  said.  His  wife,  Hergard,  was  wounded  but  not  seriously.   The  attack  was  another  blow  to  Chancellor  Helmut  Kohl,  whose  plans  for  a  quick  economic  revival  of  the  east  have  bogged  down  while  large  firms  there  collapse,  unemployment  soars  and  angry  workers  march  for  jobs.   As  chairman  of  the  Berlin-based  Treuhand  agency,  Mr  Rohwedder  had  the  final  say  over  the  fate  of  east  Germany's  outdated  industry  and  the  waning  job  hopes  of  its  angry  workers.   His  increasingly  vocal  critics  in  the  ex-commu  nist  east  have  described  him  as  the  callous  face  of  Western  capitalism.   Mr  Rohwedder,  a  former  Economics  Ministry  official  who  turned  the  ailing  Ruhr  steel  manufac  turer  Hoesch  into  a  profitable  high-tech  group,  was  the  most  powerful  representative  sent  by  Bonn  to  rescue  the  depressed  east.   The  growing  uncertainty  in  the  region  has   undermined  investor  confidence  in  the  mark  and  German  stocks.   Government  spokesman  Dieter  Vogel  said  Dr  Kohl  was  informed  immediately  of  the  killing  and  was  deeply  upset.   "There  was  probably  no  other  manager,  or  maybe  no  other  person  at  all  in  Germany,  who  worked  so  hard  to  lay  the  foundation  for  the  economic  reconstruction  of  former  East  Germa  ny,"  Mr  Vogel  said.   "This  was  not  often  recognised  in  comments  made  by  politicians  and  other  people."   East  Germans  have  bitterly  attacked  Dr  Kohl  and  the  Treuhand  at  job  marches  in  recent  weeks  as  it  became  clear  their  region,  which  the  chancel  lor  had  promised  would  become  a  "flourishing   AP  plctur*  Detlev  Rohwedder:  shot  at  home.   landscape",  would  have  up  to  four  million  jobless  by  July.   Dr  Kohl,  on  an  Easter  slimming  holiday  in  the  Austrian  Alps,  has  not  visited  Germany's  new  poorhouse  since  its  voters  helped  re-elect  him  in   December.   The  communist  government  of  East  Germany  helped  train  members  of  the  Red  Army  Faction,  which  staged  several  attacks  in  West  Germany  in  the  1970s.  The  guerrilla  group  came  back  to  haunt  the  uniting  Germany  by  murdering  its  most  prominent  banker,  Alfred  Herrhausen,  in  Frankfurt  in  November,  1989.   East  Germany  gave  runaway  faction  members  a  safe  haven  and  let  them  build  new  lives  there  until,  in  the  run-up  to  unification  last  October,  they  were  unmasked  and  handed  over  to  Bonn   aumonues.   —  Reuter
snippet: BONN: Detlev Rohwedder, powerful head ofa controversial agency privatising former East German firms, has been murdered by suspected urban guerrillas in Duesseldorf, police said.

heading: East German recruited
article_text: East  German  recruited   Professor  Theo  Koerner,  the  mastermind  behind  East  Germany's  stunning  successes  at  world  championships  and  Olympic  games  between  1967  and  1986,  has  been  recruited  by  Australia"  to  help  its  preparation  for  the  world  championships.   In  the  19  years  that  Koemer  was  director  of  coaching,  East  Germany  won  73  Olympic  or  world  championship  gold  medals.   He  will  help  oversee  national  squad  preparations  and  Australian  Institute  of  Sport  training  before  the  first  world  championships  to  be  held  in  Australia  at  Lake  Barrington,  Tasmania  between  October  28  and  Novem   ber^   The  idea  to  recruit  Koemer  came  from  Australia's  national  director  of  coaching,  Peter  Stocker,  a  Swiss,  who  took  over  last  year  from  Romanian  Reinhold  Batschi,  the  head  coach  at  the  Australian  Institute  of  Sport.   Stocker  said  Koemer  is  a  legend  in  world  rowing,  and  his  assistance  will  be  invaluable  in  what  is  a  critical  year  for  the  sport  in  Australia.   Koemer  attended  a  national  coaches  seminar  in  Can  berra  and  is  visiting  several  states  to  help  coach  national  crews  training  in  state  capitals  and  meet  with  state  coach  ing  directors  and  representatives  of  state  institutes  and   associations.
snippet: Professor Theo Koerner, the mastermind behind East Germany's stunning successes at world championships and Olympic games between 1967 and 1986, has been recruited by Australia to help its preparation for the

heading: German orchestra visits
article_text: German  orchestra  visits   Jerusalem:  THE  president  of  Germany,  Richard  von  Weizsac  ker,  arrived  here  for  a  brief  visit  whose  highlight  was  a  special  con  cert  by  the  Dresden  Orchestra,  un  der  the  baton  of  Daniel  Barenboim.   It  was  the  first  time  a  German  orchestra  has  ever  performed  in  Israel,  a  fact  Weizsacker  alluded  to  in  his  speech  to  the  concert  audi   ence.  Proceeds  from  the  concert   will  help  Israel  absorb  immigrants  from  Ethiopia  and  the  Soviet   Union.   Addressing  the  audience,  which  included  some  of  Israel’s  most  prominent  political,  cultural  and  business  leaders,  President  Chaim  Herzog  praised  the  German  lead  er’s  unflagging  personal  involve  ment  in  the  battle  against  racism   and  discrimination.
snippet: Jerusalem: THE president of Germany, Richard von Weizsacker, arrived here for a brief visit whose highlight was a special

heading: German Jews critical
article_text: critical   Berlin:  JEWISH  leaders  in  Germany  have  expressed  their  disappointment  with  the  government’s  response  to  continuing  attacks  on  foreigners  in  this  country.   The  Jewish  president  of  the  International  League  for  Human  Rights  in  Berlin,  Alisa  Fuss,  has  protested  a  new  policy  limiting  asylum-seekers  from  entering  Germany  and   I  returned  an  honorary  medal  she  had   received  from  the  German  president.   And  the  head  of  the  10,000-strong  Jewish  community  in  Berlin,  Holocaust  survivor  Jerzy  Kanal,  called  a  news  conference  here  saying  that  Germany’s  Jews  felt  “uneasy”.   The  policy,  scheduled  to  go  into  effect  on  July  1,  was  also  criticised  by  the  German  writer  Gunther  Grass.
snippet: Berlin: JEWISH leaders in Germany have expressed their disappointment with the government’s response to continuing attacks on foreigners in this country.

heading: German deficit rising
article_text: German  deficit  rising   The  Bundesbank  on  Wednesday  stepped  up  pressure  on  the  Bonn  government  to  curb  the  ballooning  public  deficit  as  Helmut  Schlesinger,  the  central  bank  president,  made  it  clear  that  further  interest  rate  cuts  will  have  to  wait.   Spending  cuts  were  now  unavoid  able  if  Germany  was  not  to  endanger  confidence  in  its  finances,  he  said.   Highlighting  much  stronger-than  expected  monetary  growth  and  the  inflationary  dangers  this  posed,  Mr  Schlesinger  said,  "Anyone  who  calls  for  a  strong  easing  of  monetary  poli  cy  now  for  economic  reasons  is  put  ting  at  risk  the  confidence  that  our  economy  still  enjoys."   The  Bundesbank  president  also  sent  out  an  unprecedented  signal  for  other  European  countries  to  take  over  the  interest  rate  leadership  from  Germany  in  an  effort  to  pre-empt  pressure  growing  on  the  mark.   "Those  currencies  internationally  recognised  as  stable  could,  to  a  cer   tain  extent,  dictate  their  own  interest  rate  levels",  he  said.   "Talk  of  the  deepest-evcr  German  recession  can  still  come  true  if  we  carry  on  making  big  mistakes."   Although  the  Bundesbank  is  open  ly  concerned  about  the  expansion  in  M3  money  supply,  economists  be  lieve  this  is  being  used  as  a  vehicle  for  attacking  the  main  worry  —  the  public  deficit.  It  is  exerting  pressure,  to  try  to  force  fiscal  austerity  on  the  government.   "Theo  Waigel,  the  Finance  Minis  ter,  has  to  complete  his  1994  budget  by  mid-July,"  said  Gerhard  Grebe,  chief  economist  with  Bank  Julius  Bar  in  Frankfurt.  "The  Bundesbank  wants  to  see  concrete  spending  cuts,  which  means  no  interest  rates  easing  before  then."   German  industrial  output  rose  a  seasonally  adjusted  0.5  per  cent,  in;  April  from  March,  but  fell  7.7  per   —  Tlw  Independent■

heading: West German leader pledges united German support for Israel
article_text: eader  pledges  united  German  support  for  Israel   Charles  Hoffman   WEST  GERMAN  Chancellor  Helmut  Kohl  pledged  this  week  that  a  united  Germany  would  maintain  a  “close,  trustful  dia  logue”  with  Israel  and  would  “fight  without  compromise  all  those  who  spread  antisemitic  pre  judice  or  decry  the  Jewish  relig   ion  and  faith”.   Chancellor  Kohl  was  speaking  at  a  World  Jewish  Congress  meet  ing  in  Berlin,  the  first  time  the  WJC  has  met  on  German  soil  since  its  founding  in  Switzerland   in  1936.   The  principal  speakers  were  WJC  president  Edgar  Bronfman  and  Mr  Kohl.   The  gathering  was  held  at  the  initiative  of  West  Germany’s  Jewish  community  and  drew  an  audience  of  prominent  Jewish  leaders  from  Europe,  Israel  and  America.  Their  presence  signalled  that  Jews  are  prepared  to  adjust  to  the  reality  of  one  Germany,  if  it  adheres  unswervingly  to  demo  cratic  principles  and  peace.  But  the  notable  absence  of  a  few  Jew  ish  leaders  sent  a  different  mes  sage:  that  time  could  not  obliter  ate  what  Germany  did  when  it  was  last  a  powerful  united  coun  try.   Mr  Bronfman  emphasised  the  grip  of  history  when  he  observed  at  the  outset  that  “there  are  many  Jews  who  could  not  bring  them   selves  to  be  in  this  city  because  of  the  anguish,  the  pain  that  Berlin  signifies”.  He  said  he  understood  “the  intensity  of  their  anger  and  their  bitterness”,  but  added,  “We  are  here  because  we  have  some  thing  to  say  to  a  united  Ger  many.”   Although  they  delivered  their  speeches  separately,  Mr  Bronf  man  and  Mr  Kohl  engaged  in  a  dialogue  of  sorts.  Mr  Bronfman  raised  several  demands  that  he  said  the  Jewish  people  must  make  of  a  united  Germany.   “The  new  Germany  must  for  ever  teach  what  happened  [during  the  Holocaust]  so  that  the  lowest  point  ever  reached  in  man’s  inhu   manity  to  man  can  never  occur  again,”  he  said.  The  new  Ger  many  must  be  a  true  democracy,  which  means  that  “all  minorities  are  guaranteed  equal  protection  under  the  law”,  he  said.  He  also  said  the  German  people  “must  always  support  Israel.  You  must  never  help  those  who  would  help  destroy  the  Jewish  State.”   Mr  Bronfman  said  Germany   must  never  become  a  nuclear  power.  Nor  must  it  have  the  means  of  perpetrating  mass  kill  ing  or  destruction  through  bio  logical  or  chemical  warfare.  It  should  also  not  help  any  third  party  attain  such  a  capability,  he  said,  alluding  to  the  involvement  of  West  German  firms  in  the  con   struction.of  a  chemical  weapons  factory  in  Libya.   “Germany  must  enact  strong  legislation  to  prevent  such  threats  against  mankind  and  against  Israel  and  vigilantly  enforce  that  legislation.  Never,  never  streng  then  the  enemies  of  Israel!”  Mr  Bronfman  declared.  “The  path  for  the  new  Germany  should  be  clear,”  he  said.  “The  Jewish  peo  ple  pray  that  you  will  prove  that  the  world  has  nothing  to  fear,  that  you  will  follow  the  path  away  from  your  worst  traditions  and  towards  the  best  traditions  of  which  you  are  so  capable.   “The  great  challenge  is  to  build   (Continued  on  page  28)   GERMAN   (Continued  irom  page  3)   a  Germany  firmly  rooted  in  peace  and  respect  for  universal  human  values,”  he  concluded.   In  response,  Mr  Kohl  sketched  his  vision  of  the  responsibilities  of  a  united  Germany.   “It  remains  the  duty  of  all  democratic  forces  to  fight  with  out  compromise  all  those  who  spread  antisemitic  prejudice  or  decry  the  Jewish  religion  and  faith,”  the  chancellor  said.  “For  us  Germans  one  of  the  most  im  portant  lessons  of  history  is  that  a  democracy  must  not  put  itself  at  the  mercy  of  its  enemies,  but  must  actively  fight  them.”   With  respect  to  German  rela  tions  with  Israel,  Mr  Kohl  stressed  that  “close,  trustful  dia  logue  must  remain  a  key  element  of  the  Middle  East  policy  pursued  by  a  united  Germany.  I  per  sonally  guarantee  this,”  he  added.   “To  us  Germans  the  right  of  self-determination  of  nations,  including  our  own,  is  a  particu  larly  valuable  asset,”  Mr  Kohl  ex  plained.  “However,  we  are  also  aware  that  Palestinians’  right  of  self-determination  meets  its  limits  where  Israel’s  right  to  exist  is  con  cerned.  A  fair  balance  must  be  found  between  the  legitimate  in  terests  of  both  sides,”  he  said.   The  chancellor  directly  ad  dressed  the  question  of  whether  the  Federal  Republic’s  relations  with  Israel  and  the  way  it  has  dealt  with  its  Nazi  past  will  be  continued  in  the  future  by  a  united  Germany.   While  he  answered  with  a  re  sounding  affirmative,  he  admit  ted  that  much  educational  work  must  be  done  in  East  Germany  so  that  the  people  there  have  a  true  picture  of  the  terrors  and  horrors  of  the  Nazi  past,  instead  of  the  distorted  picture  created  by  the  former  communist  regime.   Mr  Kohl  also  spoke  of  the  dangers  of  rising  nationalism  in  Europe.  He  cited  “the  activities  of  the  antisemitic  [Russian]  organisation  Pamyat  or  the  riots   in  Romania  against  the  Hungar  ian  minority”  as  “proof  that  we  in  Europe  still  have  a  number  of  obstacles  to  overcome”.   The  meeting,  held  at  the  head-,  quarters  of  the  Berlin  Jewish  community,  was  chaired  by  Men  del  Kaplan,  chairman  of  the  Jew  ish  Agency  board  of  governors  and  a  vice-president  of  the  WJC.   Mr  Kaplan  said  a  united  Ger  many  “should  take  the  lead  in  eradicating  racism  and  antisemitism  from  the  world  and  should  support  Israel  with  all  your  strength,  with  its  united  capital  the  city  of  Jerusalem”.   The  World  Zionist  Organisa  tion,  which  is  a  partner  in  the  Jewish  Agency,  decided  to  boy  cott  the  WJC  meeting  in  Berlin.  WZO  chairman  Simcha  Dinitz,  who  is  also  a  WJC  vice-president,  believes  now  is  not  the  time  for  conciliatory  gestures  by  the  Jew  ish  people  toward  the  German  unification  process.

heading: German recession nearing bottom
article_text: German  recession  nearing  bottom   From  STEVE  CRAWSHAW   in  Bonn   LEADING  economic  fore   casting  organisations  in  Germany  suggested  on  Monday  that  the  country's  reces  sion  was  poised  to  bottom  out.  Five  of  the  six  main  economic  in  stitutes,  in  their  joint  annual  re  port,  predicted  growth  next  year  of  1.5  per  cent  -  1  per  cent  in  the  west,  and  7  per  cent  in  the  east.   Inflation  is  predicted  to  fall  slightly.  Prices  are  expected  to  rise  by  around  3.5  per  cent  in  western  Germany  and  by  4.5  per  cent  in  the  east.  But  unemployment  is  ex  pected  to  rise  further,  to  2.6  mil  lion  in  the  west  and  1.2  million  in  the  east,  giving  an  overall  figure  of  just  under  10  per  cent.   One  of  the  six  organisations  takes  a  dissenting,  more  pessimis  tic,  view,  which  is  presented  sepa  rately  within  the  100-page  report.  The  German  Institute  for  Eco  nomic  Research  in  Berlin  argues  that  there  will  be  a  further  0.5  per  cent  contraction  of  the  economy  next  year,  on  top  of  the  1.5  per  cent  shrinkage  this  year.  But  even  the  institute  tempers  its  pessimism   with  talk  of  a  turnaround  by  the  middle  of  next  year.   The  annual  autumn  forecast  of  the  six  organisations  accuses  the  Government  of  having  "no  medi  um-term  plan"  for  its  economic  and  financial  policies,  and  sug  gests  that  it  deals  "only  in  ad  hoc  measures".  This  phrase  was  seized  on  by  the  opposition  Social  Demo  crats.  The  Finance  Minister,  Theo  Waigel,  preferred  to  emphasise  that  the  forecast  "strengthens  our  belief  in  a  positive  economic  de  velopment",  while  also  stressing  the  need  for  spending  cuts.   The  economic  institutes  argue  against  wages  in  the  east  being  brought  to  parity  with  the  west  too  quickly,  saying  the  continued  rais  ing  of  incomes  in  the  east  "by  transfer  of  public  money  would  only  weaken  the  economic  base  in  western  Germany,  on  which  the  upturn  of  the  east  German  econo  my  will  depend  for  some  time  to   come".   Similar  recent  suggestions  from  Oskar  Lafontaine,  deputy  leader  of  the  Social  Democrats,  have  caused  enormous  divisions  within  the  party,  with  sharp  protests  from   the  east.  East  Germans  are  indig  nant  not  just  at  their  own  standard  of  living,  still  much  lower  than  in  the  west,  but  also  because  the  west  seems  uninterested  in  their  con   cerns.   Part  of  the  forecasters'  condi   tion  for  an  upturn  is  that  wage  settlements  next  year  should  be  smaller  than  those  in  1993.  The'  tone  is  clear:  "There  are  many  signs  that  there  will  be  no  econom  ic  relapse."   Those  people  doubtful  of  Mon  day's  forecast  have  at  least  one  good  reason  for  scepticism  about  a  quick  upturn.  Last  year's  forecast  was  notoriously  over-optimistic:  it  predicted  economic  growth,  in  stead  of  the  1.5  per  cent  contrac  tion  that  has  deeply  shocked  west   ern  Germans.   Partly,  perhaps,  because  of  a  de  sire  not  to  encourage  higher  wage  demands,  employers'  organisa  tions  were  cautious  in  their  re  sponse  to  the  report,  emphasising  that  the  predictions  were  only  "hopes".  The  Federation  of  Ger  man  Banks  called  the  recort  "rela   tively  optimistic".   -  Th#  IrxtofwndMTt  |

heading: German visitor Warramboo CWA
article_text: German  visitor   Warramboo  CWA   WARRAMBOO  Country  Women's  Association  members  travelled  to  Mount  Wudinna  for  their  April  meeting  for  a  picnic  lunch  followed  by  a  meeting.  During  this  time  a  young  German  tourist  joined  the  group  asking  questions  about  Mount  Wudinna  and  district  and  the  association.  After  climbing  the  rock  he  rejoined  the  members  and  shared  his  travel  experiences  from  New  Zealand  and  around  Australia,  then  told  members  about  his  homeland.  He  is  a  sales  representative  for  clean-  ~  ing  agents  and  lives  near  Frankfurt  in  East  Germany.  After  taking  photographs  he  left  for  Ceduna;  his  impromptu  visit  was  a  highlight  of  the  meeting.  The  roll  call  for  the  day  was  a  favourite  Easter  hymn.  Sunshine  lady  Ettie  Tidswell  pinned  a  birthday  spray  on  Sylvy  Dolphin.  Handicraft  secretary  Anne  Stubing  thanked  those  who  helped  at  the  handicraft  school  hosted  by  the  branch  in  March.  Everyone  agreed  the  40th  birthday  dinner  and  entertainment  was  most  enjoyable.  Six  members  hope  to  attend  the  Lally's  Rally  at  Wirrulla  on  Monday,  April  19.  The  competition  for  Salt  and  Pepper  shakers  was  won  by  Ettie  Tidswell,  second  Jean  Sampson,  third  Joan  Winter.  Members  then  walked  around  the  base  and  surrounds  of  the  Rock,  concluding  a  lovely  relaxed  day.

heading: Walking victory to German
article_text: Walking  victory  to  German   German  international  Alfons  Schwarz  won  the  10,000m  and  Tas  manian  champion  Rohan  Best  the  5000m  as  the  National  Sports  Pro  gram  eight  day  walking  clinic  ended  with  walkers  club  races  at  Black  Mountain  on  Sunday.   Schwarz  defeated  Mick  Dando   (ACT)  and  Harry  Summers  (Vic)  in  45min  25sec.  Victorian  junior  star  Michelle  Rudd  recorded  her  best  time  55min  9si:c  to  win  the  womens  10,000m  from  Gwen  Vines  (ACT).   Daniel  Andrikis  (Woden)  was  the  most  improved  athlete  of  the  week  cutting  a  massive  44sec  off  his  time   to  record  22min  2sec  and  finish  sec  ond  behind  Tasmanian  record  hold  er  Rohan  Best  in  the  5000m.   Jo  Strangman  scored  a  surprise  victory  over  top  Victorian  junior  Julie  Beecrof  and  Sue  Ellen  Hor  rocks  to  win  the  women's  5000m  in  26min  lOsec.   □  OUTSTANDING  YOUNG  Queanbeyan  athlete  Matthew  Beck  eriham's  victory  over  Dan  Jukic  (B/S)  and  Paul  Sakora  (W/C)  in  the  200m  gave  him  an  unbeaten  lead  in  the  Onga  Pumps  junior  point  score   competition  held  in  conjunction  with  the  interclub  premiership.   Beckenham  will  win  the  perpetu  al  trophy  and  cash  prize  irrespective  of  Wednesday's  interclub  results.  Si  mon  Evans  (SCT)  again  clocked  the  fastest  junior  time  over  the  800m,  2min  3sec,  defeating  David  Quayle  (W/C)  and  Chris  Puleston  (Qbn).   Jason  Anderson  (ANU-B/S)  beat  clubmate  James  Dixon  in  winning  the  under-20  in  22.6sec,  this  equalled  Lee  Bradbury  time  in  the  open  200m.   —  PETER  WADDELL

heading: Ashrawi claims German support
article_text: Ashrawi  claims   German  support   David  Kantor   Bonn:  PALESTINIAN  spokeswoman  Hanan  Ashrawi  has  received  a  pledge  of  German  sup  port  for  her  cause  after  meetings  in  Bonn  with  top-level  officials.   Germany’s  Deputy  Foreign  Minister,  Helmut  Schaeffer,  was  among  those  who  met  Ashrawi  and  told  her  Germany  shared  the  Palestinians’  belief  that  Labour’s  victory  in  the  Israeli  election  had  increased  the  chances  for  progress  in  the  peace  talks.   At  a  news  conference  at  the  local  office  of  the  Palestine  Liberation  Organisation,  Ashrawi  expressed  satisfaction  with  Labour’s  electoral  success  and  said  it  encouraged  the  chances  for   peace.  •  -  <:   But  she  warned  that  the  Palestinians  would  not  be  satisfied  with  limited  autonomy  and  were  sticking  to  their  goal  of  full  independence.   Germany’s  Economics  Minister,  Jurgen  Molle  man,  told  Ashrawi  he  would  discuss  with  his  col  leagues  in  the  European  Community  a  Palestini  an  request  for  increased  financial  assistance.  The  EC  has  already  given  considerable  financial  support  to  the  Palestinians  for  various  human!
snippet: Bonn: PALESTINIAN spokeswoman Hanan Ashrawi has received a pledge of German support for her cause after meetings in Bonn with top-level officials.

heading: Debt prompts German sale
article_text: Debt  prompts  German  sale   MELBOURNE:  Computer  Power  Group  Ltd  has  sold  its  German  education  and  train  ing  business  to  a  unnamed  Ger  man  investment  bank  for  $30  million  in  a  bid  to  reduce  its  debt.   The  sale  of  the  business,  which  Computer  Power  bought  1989,  yielded  a  profit  of  $8  mil  lion,  according  to  a  statement.   Funds  raised  through  the   sale  would  be  used  to  reduce  the  group's  outstanding  debt  to  $45  million  from  $73  million,  with  the  remainder  being  used  for  working  capital.   "While  opportunities  exist  in  Europe  and  the  Eastern  Bloc  in  the  computer  services  mar  ket,  the  company  believes  it  is  difficult  to  fully  capitalise  on  these  opportunities  from  Aus  tralia,  both  because  of  distance   and  language  constraints,"  said  chief  executive  Roger  Allen,  adding  that  the  company  had  been  trading  "buoyantly".   Last  month  Computer  Pow  er  announced  a  lift  in  net  inter  im  profits  to  $3.48  million  for  the  six  months  to  March  31   from  $2.49  million  in  the  pre  vious  corresponding  period.   Computer  Power  shares  were  steady  yesterday  at  21c.
