heading: German choir at Montefiore
article_text: German  choir  at  Montefiore   THE  Munich  Boys  Choir,  aged  from  nine  to  20,  made  history  at  the  Monte  fiore  Home,  Hunters  Hill,  recently;  they  are  believed  to  be  the  first  Ger  man  group  to  visit  and  entertain  at  a  Sydney  Jewish  organisation.   The  concert  to  an  enthusiastic  audi  ence,  packing  fte  Home’s  Recreation  Centre,  was  the  choir’s  1001st  since  its  establishment  in  1952,  and  the  last  on  its  Australian  tour.  This  was  also  the  choir’s  108th  international  tour.   In  Australia  the  boys  were  guests  of  the  National  Boys  Choir,  Melbourne,  where  they  gave  most  of  their  Aus  tralian  performances  as  part  of  a  cul   turai  exchange  visit  after  the  Mel  bourne  choir  was  in  Munich  in  1991.   The  Munich  boys’  Montefiore  Home  con  cert  was  a  goodwill  guesture  arranged  through  an  Australian  accountant  with  offices  in  both  Sydney  and  Melbourne,  Siegfried  Engelhardt,  who  saw  the  visit  as  “an  olive  branch  offering”.  The  choir  of  33  was  directed  by  their  chief  conductor,  Bernhard  Reiman  in  folk  songs,  songs  written  specially  for  the  choir,  works  from  the  classical  repertoire  (Mozart,  Schubert,  Brahms)  and  ended  with  a  tribute  to  their  Australian  audience  with   Botany  Bay  and  Waltzing  Matilda,  adding  AuMe  Lang  Syne  as  an  encore.   After  the  concert,  many  of  the  boys  made   Mr  Goodman  with  members  of  the  Boys  Choir.   instant  friends  with  Home  residents.  Isaac  (Goodie)  Goodman;  for  many  years  associat  ed  with  the  Great  Synagogue,  had  great  fun  singing  along  with  some  of  the  boys  in  English  —  the  unlikely  number  Old  Macdonald  Had  a  Farm.  Montefore  Home  chief  executive  officer  Gary  Vanderluis  said  the  visit  was  a  great  suc  cess.  Before  accepting  the  offer,  an  informal  poll  of  residents’  reactions  was  held;  with  overwhelmingly  positive  results.  Mr  Vander  sluis  pointed  out  that  the  oldest  member  of  the  choir  would  have  been  bom  almost  40  years  after  the  Holocaust  and  the  choir  itself  was  not  established  until  seven  years  after  the

heading: German drug company bought
article_text: German  drug  company  bought   Jerusalem:  TEVA  Pharmaceutical  Industries  —  one  of  Israel’s  leading  pharmaceutical  companies  —  has  announced  plans  to  expand  its  operations  in  Europe  through  the  acquisition  of  an  unnamed  Ger  man  drug  marketing  company.   Teva  will  initially  acquire  an  80  per  cent  share  for   DM  22.4  million.   At  the  time  of  the  signing  of  the  agreement,  Teva  will  pay  50  per  cent  of  the  sum  with  the  remaining  30  per  cent  made  in  four  quarterly  payments  and  20   per  cent  to  be  put  into  escrow.  Teva  will  also  acquire  an  additional  13.3  per  cent  of  the  German  firm  in  question  for  DM  4.25  million  at  a  later  date.   The  drug  marketing  company  operates  mainly  in  Germany,  but  is  also  active  in  Austria  and  Switzer  land.  The  company  posted  a  profit  of  DM  3.6  million  in  1991  and  a  half-year  1992  profit  of  DM  2.3  million.   Ismel  Business  Today

heading: A 'German-inspired plot'
article_text: A  'German-inspired  plot'   BELGRADE:  With  Yugoslavia  splitting,  some  people  are  more  con-  vinced  than  ever  that  Serbia  is  the  target  of  an  international  conspira-   cy.   If  Serbian  officials  and  media  commentators  are  to  be  believed,  Yugoslavia  is  now  the  victim  of  a  German-Austrian  plot  to  dominate  central  Europe  again.   The  republic,  Yugoslavia's  larg-  est,  has  traditionally  been  distrust-  ful  of  both  Germany  and  Austria,  against  which  it  fought  in  two  world   wars.   It  perceives  that  the  West  Euro-  peans  consider  Serbia,  ruled  for  centuries  by  Turks  who  wiped  out  much  of  its  impressive  art  and  liter-  ature,  as  backward.   The  supposed  conspiracy,  aimed   at  resurrecting  a  "Fourth  Reich"  consisting  of  Germany  and  the  pre-  World  War  I  Austro-Hungarian  Empire,  is  responsible  for  Slove-  nia's  and  Croatia's  break  with  Yu-  goslavia,  TV  commentator  Mila  Stula  said.   Both  republics,  Yugoslavia's  northernmost  states,  declared  them-  selves  independent  on  June  25.   Though  Serbia  is  expected  grudgingly  to  accept  Slovenian  in-  dependence,  it  is  unlikely  to  see  ri-  val  Croatia  go  the  same  way  without  trying  to  annex  large  chunks  of  its  territory  where  ethnic  Serbs  live.   Clashes  broke  out  between  feder-  al  troops  and  Slovene  defence  forces  after  they  occupied  border   crossings  controlled  by  the  central  government.   "German  and  Austrian  interests  are  once  again  behind  Slovenia's  and  Croatia's  secession,"  said  an  editorial  in  the  Politika  daily,  which  usually  reflects  the  opinions  of  the  ruling  Socialist  Party  of  Serbia.   A  theory  developed  by  law  pro-  fessor  and  ideologue  Budimir  Kosu-  tic,  of  Serbia's  ruling  party,  even  implicated  the  United  States  in  a  global  conspiracy  to  prevent  the  unity  of  Europe.   Even  before  Slovenia's  and  Cro-  atia's  independence  declarations,  the  Serbs  smarted  under  the  per-  ception  the  United  States  was  tar-  geting  them.   Continued  on  Page  2   'German-inspired  plot'   Continued  from  Page  1   State-controlled  media  condemned  Wash-  ington's  admonishments  that  Serbia's  elected  Government  of  renamed  communists  was  committing  human-rights  violations  and  not  observing  democratic  freedoms.   The  Serbs  also  rejected  US  State  Depart-  ment  urgings  that  they  drop  their  objection  to  the  election  of  Stipe  Mesic,  a  Croat,  as  chair-  man  of  the  federal  presidency.   They  told  the  Americans  to  keep  out  of  Yugoslav  affairs,  permitting  Mr  Mesic's  elec-  tion  only  last  weekend,  after  the  fighting  broke   out.   "The  US  fears  that  a  united  Europe  would  be  an  unbeatable  global  competitor,"  Mr  Ko-  sutic  wrote  in  the  mass-circulation  Politika  Ekspres.   To  prevent  Europe  from  uniting,  the  Unit-  ed  States  is  backing  the  "expansionism"  of  the  united  Germany,  hoping  it  would  tear  the  European  Community  apart.   "Germany  is  gathering  around  countries  which  were  the  fascist  allies  of  the  Third  Reich  in  World  War  II  including  Croatia  and  Slove-  nia,"  Mr  Kosutic  said.   "A  scenario  created  in  a  special  operations   centre  in  Vienna,  which  includes  representa-  tives  from  Germany,  Austria,  Croatia,  Slove-  nia  and  some  other  states,  is  aimed  at  establishing  a  German  sphere  of  influence  stretching  from  the  Baltic  to  the  Adriatic."   Their  aim,  according  to  Mr  Kosutic,  "is  the  break-up  of  Yugoslavia  [and]  renewed  geno-  cide  against  the  Serbian  people".   In  a  veiled  reference  to  Hungary,  Politika  also  accused  "other  traditional  enemies  of  the  Serbian  people  in  our  neighbourhood"  of  par-  ticipating  in  the  alleged  plot.   A  joint  German-Austro-Hungarian  army  occupied  Serbia  in  1916.  Fighting  a  rearguard  action,  its  army  withdrew  to  Greece,  where  it  joined  a  Franco-British  force  on  the  Salonika   Front.   Croatia  and  Slovenia,  until  then  Austro-  Hungarian  provinces,  joined  Serbia  to  form  the  Kingdom  of  Yugoslavia  after  the  defeat  of  the  Central  Powers  in  1918.   But  when  the  Germans  again  attacked  the  country  in  1941,  most  Slovene  and  Croat  officers  deserted  from  the  Royal  army.   A  pro-Nazi  fascist  puppet  regime  set  up  in  Croatia  murdered  hundreds  of  thousands  of  ethnic  Serbs  in  the  infamous  Jasenovac  and  other  extermination  camps.  —  AP
snippet: BELGRADE: With Yugoslavia splitting, some people are more convinced than ever that Serbia is the target of an international

heading: German donates to Wizo
article_text: I  German  donates  to  Wizo   Bonn:  AN  elderly  German  retired  state  employee  has  donated  a  million  marks  to  Wizo.  In  a  ceremony  at  the  Israeli  Con  sulate  in  Berlin,  84-year-  old  Gunther  Rutschke  explained  his  motive  for  the  donation,  which  is  equivalent  to  about  A$900,000:  “I  want  to  prove  that  there  are  other,  good  Germans,  who  really  care  about  what  happened  to  the  Jews.”  Rutschke,  who  donated  the  money  from  his  life  savings,  added  that  no  sum  can  compensate  the  Jews  for  their  sufferings  under  the  Third  Reich.  But  he  said  it  was  nevertheless  important  to  demonstrate  to  the  Jews  that  many  Germans  love  the  Jewish  people.

heading: German tourist still missing
article_text: German  tourist  still  missing   HOBART:  The  parents  of  missing  tourist  Nancy  Grunwaldt  returned  to  Germany  yesterday  after  a  fruitless  effort  to  help  find  their  daughter.   Bernd  and  Helga  Grunwaldt  spent  a  week  in  north-eastern  Tasmania  after  having  their  airfares  paid  from  a  public  appeal  which  raised  more  than  $8000  —  $3000  of  it  state  gov-   ernment  funds.   But  despite  their  assistance,  which  included  helping  to  search  areas  where  Ms  Grunwaldt  may  have  gone  missing,  police  have  been  unable  to  unearth  any  new  leads.   In  a  press  conference  at  a  cold  Launceston  airport,  Mr  Grunwaldt  thanked  Tasmania  for  its  support  be-  fore  boarding  a  plane.   "We're  most  grateful  for  everyone  who  has  been  involved  with  helping  to  try  to  find  Nancy."  said  Mr  Grun-  waldt,  as  his  wife  wept  quietly  beside   him.   "We  have  now  seen  where  Nancy  has  been  and  travelled.   "We  have  been  overwhelmed  with  your  response,  generosity  of  dona-  tions  and  hospitality.  May  God  bless  you  all."   Ms  Grunwaldt  was  last  seen  on  March  12,  heading  south  of  the  north-east  coastal  town  of  Scaman-  der  on  a  rented  red  mountain  bike.   Police  yesterday  reported  no  new  leads  in  the  case  but  repeated  that  a  $30,000  reward  for  vital  information  was  still  in  effect.
snippet: HOBART: The parents of missing tourist Nancy Grunwaldt returned to Germany yesterday after a fruitless effort to help find their daughter.

heading: Crash spoils German hopes
article_text: Crash  spoils   German  hopes   COFFS  HARBOUR:  The  mighty  German  racing  machine  received  a  setback  yesterday  when  two  of  its  crack  riders  crashed  out  of  the  second  round  of  the  Pacific  Power  Common  wealth  Bank  Cycle  Classic.   The  Germans  have  won  the  tour  for  the  past  two  years,  but  last  year's  winner  Mike  Weissman  lost  any  chance  of  repeating  his  feat  when  he  and  teammate  Ralf  Schmidt  crashed   in  the  closing  laps  of  the  30km  criter   ium.   In  the  criterium  through  the  Coffs  Harbour  business  district,  the  race  developed  into  a  procession  after  a  few  early  attempts  to  break  away.  After  the  fall  the  action  began.   In  the  stir  up  which  followed,  Aus  tralian  David  McKenzie  fought  his  way  to  the  front  of  the  bunch  and  flew  across  the  line  just  ahead  of  Robert  Vinovskis  of  Latvia,  with  Australian  Henk  Vogels  third.
snippet: COFFS HARBOUR: The mighty German racing machine received a setback yesterday when two of its crack riders crashed out of the second

heading: Monaco win for German
article_text: Monaco  win  for  German   Two  in  a  row  at  Monaco:  Michael  Schumacher.   By  PETER  BREWER  in  Monaco   A  superior  race  strategy  and  chassis  set-up  gave  world  champion  Michael  Schumacher  his  second  successive  victory  in  the  prestigious  Monaco  For  mula  One  Grand  Prix  yesterday.   The  26-year-old  German,  driving  a  Renault  powered  Benetton,  stumped  his  British  rival  Da  mon  Hill  with  a  shrewd  plan  in  which  he  stopped  only  once  to  refuel  during  the  78-lap  race  and  reaped  the  benefit  to  claim  one  of  the  most  con  vincing  victories  in  the  53-year  history  of  the  Monte  Carlo  classic.   Despite  troubles  which  put  him  0.8sec  behind  the  pole  winner  Hill  during  qualifying,  Schumach  er  sprinted  away  from  the  front  row  of  the  grid  and  stayed  right  on  the  tail  of  his  rival's  Williams-Renault  car  for  23  laps.   When  Hill  was  forced  into  the  pits  to  refuel,  Schumacher  stayed  out  on  the  track  and  kept  up  a  withering  pace  at  the  front.  He  was  headed  only  briefly  —  for  less  than  one  lap  of  the  3.32km-street  circuit  —  on  lap  36  by  Ferrari  driver  Jean  Alesi.   But  when  Alesi  was  also  forced  into  the  pits  to  refuel,  Schumacher  reasserted  his  dominance  and  cantered  to  a  comfortable  34.8sec  victory  over  Hill,  with  Ferrari  driver  Gerhard  Berger  36.6sec  further  back  in  third  place.   Alesi,  who  had  shown  such  promising  pace  dur  ing  qualifying,  tangled  with  Ligier  driver  Martin  Brundle  on  lap  -12  at  the  exit  to  the  harbour-side  swimming  pool  chicane.  Both  cars  were  damaged  in  the  puzzling  incident  and  could  not  continue.   Schumacher's  easy  win  was  an  anti-climatic  end  to  what  had  earlier  promised  to  be  a  close  race,   and  Hill  admitted  as  much  afterwards.   "I  am  bitterly  disappointed,"  Hill  said,  after  ru  ing  the  Williams  team's  time-consuming  plan  to  stop  twice  to  refuel.   "In  the  race,  our  car  didn't  match  up  to  the  way  it  performed  during  qualifying.  Once  again,  the  Benetton  team  had  a  better  [race]  strategy."   The  bumpy  and  daunting  Grand  Prix  track  ex  tracted  its  usual  high  toll.  Only  10  cars  from  the  26  starters  were  classified  as  finishers.   In  fourth  place  was  Schumacher's  team-mate.  Johnny  Herbert,  followed  by  Mark  Blundell  in  the!  Mercedes-powered  McLaren,  then  Germany'??  Heinz-Harald  Frentzen  (Sauber-Ford).  Italian  Pier  luigi  Martini  soldiered  on  to  grab  an  unexpected  sixth  place  for  the  battling  Minardi  Ford  team.
snippet: A superior race strategy and chassis set-up gave world champion Michael Schumacher his second successive victory in the prestigious Monaco Formula One Grand Prix yesterday.

heading: Strikes hamstring German airports
article_text: Strikes  hamstring  German  airports   FRANKFURT:  Frankfurt  airport  re  opened  yesterday  after  security  staff  strikes  on  Tuesday  forced  a  one-day  closure  but  German  air  travel  contin  ued  to  be  dogged  by  delays.   Closures  at  other  airports  and  logisti  cal  problems  caused  by  the  diversion  of  flights  on  Tuesday  meant  delays  were  likely  on  most  services,  a  spokesman  for  the  national  carrier  Lufthansa  said.   Airports  in  Hanover,  Hamburg,  and  Berlin's  Tegel  and  Tempelhof  re  mained  shut  due  to  striking  security  staff.   Stuttgart  airport  was  also  closcd  for  the  first  time  since  the  wave  of  stop  pages  began  10  days  ago  —  the  longest  public  service  strike  in  post-war  Ger   many.   A  spokesman  for  the  largest  public  service  union,  OeTV,  said  his  union  was  calling  300,000  workers  out  on  strike  yesterday.   It  has  been  the  highest  number  called  out  so  far,  up  from  275,000  the  previ  ous  day.  They  were  to  be  joined  by  postal  and  rail  workers.  Public  trans  port  remained  at  a  standstill  in  major  cities,  garbage  continued  to  pile  up  on  city  streets  and  government  offices  and  hospitals  were  short-staffed.   The  Lufthansa  spokesman  said  the  airline  had  hoped  to  resume  all  inter  continental  flights,  through  Frankfurt  yesterday  but  delays  were  inevitable.   Baggage  handling  staff  strikes  was  causing  long  delays  at  other  key  airports  such  as  Duesseldorf  and  Cologne  Bonn,  he  said.   Crucial  pay  talks  were  to  resume  lat  er  yesterday  in  Stuttgart  between  em  ployers  and  unions  demanding  a  9.5  per  cent  wage  rise.   The  three  employer  groups  —  feder  al,  regional  state  and  local  government  —  have  said  they  will  increase  their  offer  at  the  meeting  due  to  start  at  4pm  (2am  today  Canberra  time).   No  details  have  been  given,  but  they  did  say  pay  raises  for  lower  paid  work  ers  would  be  increased.   The  employers  are  offering  a  4.8  per  cent  pay  package  and  news  that  they  plan  to  increase  it  has  raised  hopes  that  the  strike  could  soon  be  settled.   The  Berlin  newspaper  BZ,  quoting  government  sources,  said  on  Tuesday  that  lower-paid  workers  would  be  of  fered  a  5.4  per  cent  increase  while  the  better-paid  would  get  about  4  per  cent.   —  Retfter

heading: German Jews sound alarm
article_text: German  Jews  sound  alarm   DAVID  KANTOR   Bonn:  GERMANY’S  small  Jew  ish  community  has  sounded  an  alarm  over  the  escalation  of  neo  Nazi  violence,  especially  in  form  er  East  Germany.   Heinz  Galinski,  chairman  of  the  German  Jewish  community,  has  urged  Interior  Minister  Wolfgang  Schaeuble  to  enforce  the  bans  on  events  such  as  the  celebration  of  Hitler’s  birthday,  which  invariably  stir  violence,  or  a  vigil  in  Munich  several  weeks  ago  at  which  the  truth  of  the  Holocaust  was  publicly  denied.   About  150  neo-Nazi  youths  and  Skinheads  were  taken  into  tem  porary  custody  in  Dresden  on  Saturday  to  prevent  a  clash  with  anti-fascists  after  they  marched  through  the  city  to  mark  the  fuhrer’s  102nd  anniversary.  About  15  neo-Nazis  were  arrested  in  Ober  weser,  near  Kassel  in  central  Ger   many,  after  a  Hitler  party  that  damaged  shops  and  parked  cars.   In  Osnabruck,  in  the  north  state  of  Hanover,  neo-Nazi  activists  at  tacked  a  group  of  Kurds  who  were  on  a  hunger  strike  to  protest  the  Iraqi  massacre  of  their  people.  Some  Kurds  were  badly  beaten  by  the  time  police  arrived  and  their  tent  was  demolished.   In  Magdeburg,  in  the  centre  of  what  was  formerly  East  Germany,  dozens  of  neo-Nazi  hooligans  clashed  with  police  after  throwing  cans  and  assaulting  spectators  at  a  local  soccer  match.  Several  arrests  were  reported.  Incidents  involving  neo-Nazis  were  also  reported  in  Leipzig,  Cottbus  and  Birkenwerda  in  eastern  Germany.   Galinski  demanded  that  the  authorities  intervene  more  forceful  ly  when  right-wing  extremists  dis  play  Nazi  symbols  in  violation  of   the  law  and  spread  anti-semitic  propaganda.   In  Munich,  neo-Nazis  claimed  no  Jews  were  ever  killed  at  Ausch  witz  and  Treblinka.  How  can  Ger  many  subject  its  small  surviving  Jewish  community  to  such  outra  geous  expressions?  Galinski  asked.   The  Jewish  leader  had  urged  the  prime  minister  of  Saxony,  Kurt  Biedenkopf,  to  ban  the  Hitler  birthday  march  in  Dresden.  Dres  den  has  become  the  centre  of  neo  Nazi  activity,  which  spread  after  the  Communist  regime  was  ousted  from  East  Germany  in  1989.  In  re  cent  weeks,  visitors  from  Poland  have  been  attacked  in  eastern  Ger  many  after  the  country  abolished  visa  requirements  for  them.   Sociologists  have  blamed  the  emergence  of  right-wing  extremism  in  the  former  Communist-ruled  territory  on  unemployment,  poor  living  conditions  and  the  collapse  of  state  and  parental  authority.   (JTA)

heading: German claims deadline extended
article_text: German  claims  deadline  extended   THE  deadline  for  lodging  claims  with  the  Claims  Conference  good   will  Fund  has  been  extended  to  December  31,1998.   Those  who  failed  to  register  claims  for  restitution  of  Jewish  property  in  the  former  East  Germany  by  31  December,  1992  —   the  German  Government  deadline   —  may  now  apply  to  the  Claims   Conference  Goodwill  Fund.   The  fund  shares  net  proceeds   from  the  recovery  of  properties  which  it  obtained  as  the  legal   successor  to  unclaimed  Jewish  property.   Individuals  wishing  to  lodge  a   claim  should  write  to  the  Claims   Conference  Successor  Organisation  Goodwill  Fund  at  Sophienstrasse  26,  60487  Frankfurt  am  main,  Germany.  Claimants  should  include  their  name  and  address,  address  of  the  property,  name  of  the  original   property  owner  and  relationship  to  the  original  owner.   The  Claims  Conference  is  estab   lishing  a  department  for  property   identification  so  that  relatives  of   people  who  may  have  owned  prop  erty  can  receive  assistance  in  iden  tifying  it.  There  is  no  fee  involved.   Claimants  should  write  to  Peter   Heuss,  Department  for  Property   Identification  at  the  above  address  by  December  31,1998.
snippet: THE deadline for lodging claims with the Claims Conference goodwill Fund has been extended to December 31,1998.

heading: Mareike’s German Festivities
article_text: Mareike  's  Germanfestivities   M  areike  Schlessmann  Mareike  is  from  Prum,  in  Germany,  near  the  border  of  Belgium.  On  a  student  exchange,  she  is  going  to  school  at  St  Joseph's  College.  She  said  people  started  celebrating  Christmas  on  December  24,  usually  by  going  to  church  in  the  evening.  Mareike  said  the  main  reason  for  this  was  because  Germany  in  winter  was  very  dark  and  the  Christmas  trees  and  lights  looked  spectacular.  In  Mereike's  part  of  Germany,  a  vvhite  Christmas  is  quite  unusual.  Because  her  grandparents  Iive  a  long  distance  away,  she  usually  celebrates  Christmas  with  her  brother,  sister  and  parents:  I  n  Germany  we  celebrate  Christmas  on  the  24th,  in  the  evening.  If  you're  religious  you  go  to  church  in  the  evening  and  then  you  go  home  and  get  your  presents.  On  the  25th  we  don't  go  to  mass.  It's  a  family  day;  you  spend  the  day  with  family.  It's  always  warm  inside  and  dark  and  cold  outside.  My  mother  usually  cooks  ducks  and  we  always  cook  cookies  with  icing.  Everyone  starts  cooking  them  in  November  and  keeps  cooking  them  until  Christmas.  People  with  open  fire-places  also  often  cook  apples  in  the  fire  or  else  in  the  oven.  Mareike  has  a  recipe  for  some  of  the  cookies  her  family  bakes  for  the  Christmas  festivities.   Black  and  White  biseuits  Ingredients:  300  grams  of  butter  150  grams  of  castor  sugar  pinch  of  salt  400  grams  plain  flour  30  grams  cocoa  egg-white  Method:  Knead  the  butter  with  castor  sugar  and  salt.  Add  flour,  knead  again  and  divide  the  dough  into  two  equal  parts.  Knead  cocoa  into  one  part.  Leave  both  dough  portions  wrapped  in  foil  for  two  hours  in  the  fridge.  Roll  both  dough  portions  out  to  the  same  size  and  place  on  plates  that  have  been  coated  with  egg-white.  The  egg-white  makes  the  two  doughs  stick  together.  Place  the  dough  on  top  of  each  other  and  roll  up.  Retum  to  fridge  until  cold  and  then  cut  the  roll  into  half  centimetre  thick  slices.  Bake  at  190  degrees  celsius  for  10  minutes.  Biseuits  will  harden  on  cooling.   •  Away  from  home...  exchangee  Mareike  Schlessmann.

heading: German honour for Goldhagen
article_text: German  honour  for  Goldhagen   DANIEL  DAGAN   BONN  —  The  Bonn-based  Journal  for  German  and   International  Politics  has  decided  to  award  author  Daniel  Goldhagen  its  annual  Democracy  Prize.   In  a  statement,  the  journal  said  Goldhagen,  more  than  any  other  scholar,  stirred  the  con  science  of  the  German  public  with  his  book  Hitler's  Willing   Executioners.   In  August,  the  book  sold  out  its  first  German  edition  of  40,000  copies  in  less  than  a  week  and  prompted  a  flurry  of  debate.   For  many  Jews  in  Germany,  the  book’s  value  lies  in  that  it  tells  non-Jewish  Germans  that  the  Holocaust  did  not  begin  in  the  gas  chambers  and  was  not  perpetrat  ed  solely  by  SS  officials  in  the  death  camps.   They  point  to  Goldhagen’s  suggestion  that  the  persecution  began  in  schools,  at  the  work  place,  in  stores,  at  every  street  comer  —  that  it  was  committed   by  millions  of  “simple”  Germans  from  every  walk  of  life.   Daniel  Goldhagen   Goldhagen,  whose  book  has  been  on  Germany’s  bestseller  list  for  months,  told  the  editors  of  the  journal,  “When  I  wrote  my  book  I  believed  it  was  only  about  how  to  understand  and  think  about  the  past.   “More  and  more,  I  have  come  to  realise  that  the  book  is  also   about  the  present  and  the   future.”   Meanwhile,  the  public  debate  continues  about  Goidhagen’s  the  sis,  though  with  less  intensity  than  when  the  book  was  first  pub  lished  here  last  year.   Frank  Schirmacher,  co-pub  lisher  of  the  daily  Frankfurter  Allgemeine  Zeitung,  wrote  recently:  “Goldhagen  is  building  a  new  mythology  around  the  Holocaust.  He  traces  it  back  to  the  Faustian  depths  of  German  consciousness  and,  by  doing  so,  prevents  it  from  being  dealt  with   on  a  rational  basis.”   Rudolf  Augstein,  founder  and  publisher  of  Der  Spiegel,  wrote,  on  the  other  hand,  that  while  “very  little,  one  could  even  say  next  to  nothing”  was  to  be  gained  from  Goidhagen’s  book,  “the  sim  ple  fact  that  the  history  of  the  Holocaust  is  being  gone  into  again  can  only  be  good,  and  will  certainly  cause  a  stir.   “If  Goldhagen  manages  this,”  he  concluded,  “he  will  have   achieved  quite  a  lot.   JTA

heading: German upheaval benefits youngsters
article_text: German  upheaval  benefits  youngsters   A  recent  upheaval  in  the  hierarchy  of  German  hockey  has  resulted  in  a  major  reshuffle  in  the  team's  line-up  with  a  number  of  young  players  selected.   For  right-winger  Sven  Meinhardt  it  camc  as  a  real  surprise  when  he  was  invited  by  the  new  coach  to  join  the  team  for  its  tilt  at  the  Champions  Trophy  in  Melbourne.   Having  been  a  member  of  the  German  under-21  youth  team  helped  Meinhardt  as  his  coach  in  that  team  was  appointed  to  the  national  post  after  a  player  revolt  resulted  in  the  removal  of  the  long-serv  ing  national  coach.   At  19  and  the  youngest  member  in  the  squad  Meinhardt  is  regarded  chiefly  as  a   reserve  on  this  tour  but  he  has  been  used  as  a  replacement  during  this  tournament.   His  biggest  thrill  came  during  the   match  against  the  Netherlands  on  Wed  nesday  when  he  was  called  upon  to  take  the  penalty  stroke  that  enabled  Germany  to  pull  ofT  a  4-4  draw.   "My  teammates  say  that  I  am  some  times  a  person  with  no  nerves  so  they  asked  me  to  take  it,"  Meinhardt  said.  "Usually  I  am  about  the  third  in  line  for  strokes  so  it  was  nice  to  be  given  the  chance  with  so  much  depending  on  the   outcome.   "We  felt  that  we  played  very  well  as  a  team  against  the  Dutch  and  have  been  very  happy  with  our  build-up  to  this  championship.   "After  we  lost  so  many  players  through  the  administrative  problems  we  expected  to  have  a  tough  time  here  in  Melbourne  but  we  have  been  improving  with  each   match.   "The  side  was  very  disappointed  with  the  loss  to  Pakistan  in  the  first  round  but  we  put  that  down  to  too  much  hard  work  in  the  week  before  the  tournament.   "Our  aim  is  to  build  up  our  strength  and  experience  as  we  have  so  many  young  players  at  the  moment  but  we  are  confident  of  having  a  very  strong  team  in  the  Barcelona  Olympics.   "This  is  my  first  tour  away  and  I  would  like  to  find  a  permanent  spot  in  the  team  to  play  in  the  Olympics.   "They  use  me  mainly  as  a  reserve  at  the  moment  but  I  am  hopeful  of  gaining  a  regular  spot  in  the  team.  My  father  had  a  big  influence  on  my  hockey  career  as  he  was  a  goalkeeper  for  many  years  and  got  me  interested."   Meinhardt  is  studying  for  his  A-Ievel  passes  in  Dusseldorf  where  he  is  a  mem   ber  of  the  six-times  champion  German  club  Uhlenhorst,  regarded  as  the  best  hockey  club  in  Europe.   Although  he  has  had  limited  field  time  during  this  tournament  Meinhardt  has  scored  two  goals  and  is  looking  forward  to  the  match  against  Australia  in  the  last   round  tomorrow.   Before  that  Germany  will  take  on  the  USSR  at  3pm  today  while  Pakistan  will  meet  Great  Britain  in  the  early  game  at  lpm.  A  big  win  to  Pakistan  against  Brit   ain  could  still  see  it  in  with  a  chance  of  taking  out  the  tournament.   .  There  are  many  variations  for  Paki  stan  to  win  with  Australia  having  to  lose  to  Germany  while  Pakistan  would  still  have  to  beat  the  Netherlands  in  the  last  round  to  have  any  chance;   —  GEOFF  THOMSON
snippet: A recent upheaval in the hierarchy of German hockey has resulted in a major reshuffle in the team's line-up with a number of young players selected.

heading: German camp site safe
article_text: German  camp  site  safe   DAVID  KANTOR   Bonn:  FACED  with  growing  protests  by  Jews,  Gypsies  and  others,  the  state-run  company  charged  with  privatising  the  econ  omy  of  former  East  Germany  said  it  would  halt  the  extraction  of  gypsum  from  a  hill  near  the  site   of  the  former  Dora-Nordhausen  labour  camp.   The  Treuhand  company  an  nounced  in  Berlin  that  it  would   put  off  plans  to  sell  the  area  to  a  Munich-based  mining  company  until  a  satisfactory  arrangement  could  be  found.  The  government  of  the  federal  state  of  Thuringia  said  it  was  working  on  a  compro   mise  that  would  allow  for  eco  nomic  exploitation  of  the  area  while  still  preserving  the  site  as  a   memorial.   The  former  labour  camp  and  its  underground  factory,  where  the  V-2  rockets  used  against  Britain  were  produced,  is  situated  near  the  town  of  Nordhausen.  A  Nordhausen  official,  Tilo  Grosse,  warned  last  week  that  the  pro  posed  sale  would  all  but  destroy  any  hope  of  creating  a  memorial   at  the  site.   The  controversy  surrounding  the  Dora-Nordhausen  site  is  not   unique  in  East  Germany.  Efforts  to  stimulate  the  economy,  after  years  of  economic  doldrums  un   der  Communist  rule,  have  led  to  similar  proposals  -  and  consider   able  tension  -  at  other  sites  as  well.   Two  weeks  ago,  the  weekly  Die  Zeit  ran  a  front-page  article  about  the  efforts  to  build  a  shop  ping  mall  at  the  site  of  the  former  camp  at  Ravensbruck.  The  article  said  that  the  residents  of  the  area  “cannot  distance  themselves.  They  don’t  show  any  kind  of  rela  tion  to  the  inherited  burden.”   “Ever  since  1945,  we  have  been  confronted  by  our  Nazi  past,”  the  article  continued,  argu  ing  that  the  residents  of  East  Germany,  by  contrast,  have  yet  to  deal  with  that  same  past.   Commenting  on  “the  poor  mayor  of  Furstenberg,”  who  had  said  that  his  city  would  be  captive  to  the  past,  Die  Zeit  said  he  was  only  articulating  “the  wish  of  so  many  of  his  countrymen,  their  de  sire  for  a  normal  life,  unburdened  by  the  past.”  But,  the  paper  said,  “if  the  historians’  feud  has  taught  us  anything,”  it  is  that  “one  can  not  expunge  the  crimes  of  the  other.  No  person  can  escape  the  formative  period  of  childhood.  No  nation  can  escape  the  dark  shadow  of  its  history.”

heading: Restoration lifts German trophy
article_text: .GMogiiGBOOD  f/v\irifVrn'5irfn  OirrFfPivv?  ISluuUllaJUll  Uyii)  jJuLiyy   A  NEGLECTED  Great  War  tro  phy  recently  got  a  new  lease  of  life  after  years  of  misuse  as  a  plaything  and  garbage  bin  in  a  Sydney  park.   After  restoration,  the  Krupp  naval  gun  was  given  a  new  home  at  the  National  Artillery  Museum  at  North  Head.  Maj  Craig  Youll,  DArty,  said  the  gun  was  one  of  26  captured  by  45  Bn  4  Div  AIF  during  WW1.  "The  rare  15cm  naval  gun  was  manu  factured  by  the  German  steel  giant  Krupp  at  the  turn  of  the  century  and  con-  :  verted  to  a  heavy  field  artillery  piece  early  in  the  war,"  Maj  Youll  said.  "They  simply  took  it  off  the  battle  ship  and  mounted  it  on  an  enormous  gun  carriage."  He  said  the  gun  was  stockpiled  at  Moorebank  with  other,  trophies  after  the  .  war  before  distribution  to  local  councils  for  display.   "In  1921  it  was  allocated  to  the  Woollahra  Council  and  given  pride  of  place  outside  its  chambers.  "For  some  reason  unknown  to  local  historians,  it  was  transferred  in  1930  to  the  School  of  Artillery,  then  located  at  South  Head."  He  said  the  gun  was  returned  to  Woollahra  Council  in  1957  and  placed  on  the  waterfront  in  Rose  Bay,  where  time  and  the  elements  took  their  toll.  "Like  so  many  of  these  old  memori  als  it  was  neglected,  becoming  just  .  another  thing  for  the  kids  to  play  on  in  the  park,,  its  history  forgotten  and  its  magnificent  barrel  a  receptacle  for  refuse.  "In  1994,  the  council  offered  the  gun  to  the  National  Artillery  Museum  and  with  the  kind  assistance  of  Transfield  Holdings  and  Croda  Paints,  the  old  gun  was  restored  to  something  that  even  old  Kaiser  Bill  would  have  been  proud  of."   What  a  big  load  of  Krupp  ...  the  restored  WW1  German  15cm  Krupp  naval  gun  captured  by  45  Bn  4  Div  AIF  and  is  now  on  display  with  at  the  National  Artillery  Museum.   Director  of  Artillery  Col  Paul  Retter  presents  a  certificate  of  appreciation  to  Frank  Borsini,  Director  of  T  ransfield  Holdings.  ;  /  —  :  —  -  :  :  \
snippet: A NEGLECTED Great War trophy recently got a new lease of life after years of misuse as a plaything and garbage bin in a Sydney park.

heading: Single German team 'Certain'
article_text: Single  German  team  Certain*   DRESDEN,  East  Germany:  West  German  coach  Franz  Beckenbauer  said  yesterday  he  was  convinced  there  would  be  a  single  German  team  in  the  1994  World  Cup.   Beckenbauer  said  he  would  have  no  hesitation  in  picking  East  Germans  Andreas  Thorn,  now  playing  for  Bayer  Levcrkusen  in  West  Germany,  and  Rico  Stei  neann  of  Karl  Marx  Stadt,  for  his  West  German  side.   He  was  speaking  after  captaining  a  united  German  XI  that  was  beaten  3-1  by  a  Rest  of  the  World  side  to  raise  money  for  the  reconstruction  of  Dresden  castle,  de  stroyed  by  allied  bombing  in  World  War  II.   His  former  World  Cup  rival  Bobby  Moore,  the  ex  England  captain,  led  the  opposition  which  included  Bob  by  Charlton  and  ex-Brazilian  international  Jairzinho  in  a  match  watched  by  38,000.   East  German  star  Hans-Jurgen  Kreische  put  the  Ger  mans  ahead  but  South  Korea's  Kun  Cha  Bum,  who  used  to  play  for  Bayer  Leverkusen,  scored  twice.  Former  French  international  Alain  Giressealso  scored.
snippet: DRESDEN, East Germany: West German coach Franz Beckenbauer said yesterday he was convinced there would be a single German team in the 1994 World Cup.

heading: Australians indict German industry
article_text: Australians  indict  German  industry   DAN  GOLDBERG   SOME  1500  Australians  —  an  esti  mated  two-thirds  of  whom  are  Jew  ish  Holocaust  survivors  —  launched  an  Australian  Class  Action  Suit  in  a   New  York  District  Court  on  April  10,  claiming  USD$lbillion  in  compensa  tion  from  German  industries  for  the  slave  labour  they  performed  during   World  WarH.   The  Australian  Class  Action  Suit,  which  accuses  263  German  industries  (including  corporate  giants  such  as  Volkswagen,  BMW,   Siemens,  Daimler-Chrysler,  Bayer  and  Krupp  among  others)  of  col  laborating  with  the  Nazis,  was  filed  under  the  US  “Alien  Torts  Claims  Act”  which  enables  non  US  residents  to  sue  anyone  who   does  business  in  the  US.   It  is,  however,  identical  to  the  American  Class  Action  Suit  filed  in   August  1998  which,  by  definition,  covers  all  members  of  that  “class”  regardless  of  their  contemporary   location.   In  an  effort  to  appease  the   American  Class  Action  Suit,  Ger  man  Chancellor  Schroeder  has  persuaded  18  of  the  country’s  largest  corporations  to  contribute  to  a  USD$3billion  victims’  compen  sation  fund,  preferring  a  speedy  settlement  to  court  litigation.   The  American  and  Australian   Class  Action  Suits  appear,  howev  er,  to  be  the  tip  of  the  iceberg.  A   Polish  suit  was  filed  last  week  and  an  Israeli  suit  is  imminent.   “On  April  28,  a  Hungarian  suit  will  be  filed,”  a  legal  representa   tive  for  the  Australian  claimants   Henry  Burstyner  informed  the  AJN.  “On  May  3,  a  Canadian  suit  will  be  filed;  on  May  5,  an  English  suit;  on  May  6,  a  French  suit  and  on  May  10  a  Russian  suit  will  be  filed  —  all  to  the  same  district  court  in  New  York.”   The  AJN  has  learned  that  the   team  of  lawyers  representing  all  the  various  suits  will  agree  to  consoli   date  the  national  suits  into  one  unit  ed  international  class  action  suit.

heading: German Army exhibit halted
article_text: German  Army  exhibit  halted   BERLIN:  A  controversial  exhibit  on  Hitler’s  army  will  not  come  to  New  York  next  month  because  of  charges  that  some  of  the  atroci  ties  depicted  in  the  exhibit  were  not  com  mitted  by  German  soldiers.   Last  week,  the  head  of  the  institute  that  mounted  the  exhibit  admitted  that  one  of  the  atrocities  covered  in  the  show  —  the  1941  murder  of  4500  Jews  in  a  Soviet  town  —  was  committed  by  Lithuanian  Nazis,  not  by  the  German  Army.   The  show  has  been  closed  amid  allega  tions  that  some  parts  of  the  exhibit  may  depict  victims  of  the  Soviet  secret  service.   The  exhibit,  which  is  meant  to  illustrate  the  role  that  ordinary  German  soldiers  played  in  the  Holocaust,  includes  photo  graphs,  letters  and  other  documents  from  World  War  II.  Opponents  claim  it  brands  all  veterans  of  the  wartime  German  Army,  the  Wehrmacht,  as  criminals  instead  of  honour  ing  the  vast  majority  for  serving  their  coun  try.   During  its  tour  of  Germany  and  Austria  during  the  past  four  years,  the  exhibit  has  generated  heated  protests  —  and,  in  some  cases,  violence.  At  almost  every  stop,  the  exhibit  has  attracted  neo-Nazis  who  handed  out  fliers  claiming  that  the  photos  were  fal  sified,  and  that  “our  grandfathers  were  not   criminals”.   Jan  Philipp  Reemstma,  head  of  the  Hamburg  Institute  for  Social  Research,  which  mounted  the  exhibit,  announced  the  delay  in  sending  it  to  New  York,  saying  it  will  take  researchers  at  least  three  months  to  answer  questions  recently  raised  about  some  of  the  photographs  in  The  War  of  Extermination:  Crimes  of  the  Wehrmacht  from   1941  to  1944.   Supporters  say  the  exhibit  has  raised  awareness  of  a  taboo  chapter  of  German  his  tory  because  it  proves  that  ordinary  German   soldiers,  and  not  only  the  Nazi  SS,  were  responsible  for  committing  atrocities  during   World  War  11.   Historian  Andreas  Nachama,  leader  of  Berlin’s  Jewish  community,  said  he  thought  the  exhibit  has  been  “overestimated  by  both  its  friends  and  enemies.  We  knew  there  were  many  historical  mistakes  in  it.”  Nachama,  the  former  director  of  the  Berlin  museum  Topography  of  Terror,  an  archive  and  exhib  it  located  at  the  site  of  the  Gestapo’s  former  headquarters.  “It  is  important  to  present  such  material  to  the  public.  But  you  have  to  be  very  careful,  especially  if  it  is  something  new  for  the  general  public.”   The  involvement  of  the  Wehrmacht  in  World  War  II  atrocities  has  long  been  known.  But  discussion  of  this  involvement  was  brought  to  the  fore  by  the  exhibit,  which  presented  evidence  of  these  acts  to  the  gen  eral  public.  More  than  800,000  visitors  in  Germany  and  Austria  have  seen  the  exhibit,  which  contains  1400  photos,  more  than  half  of  them  portraits.   Reemstma’s  announcement  that  the  show  would  close  came  after  an  appeal  by  a  leader  of  the  Christian  Democratic  Party,  Michael  Glos,  that  Foreign  Minister  Joschka  Fischer  “use  all  necessary  means”  to  stop  the  exhib  it  from  being  sent  to  New  York.  He  said  the  Foreign  Ministry  should  be  working  to  help  build  a  positive  image  of  Germany  abroad.  Glos  said  the  exhibit  would  only  heighten  prejudices  against  Germans  and  could  dam  age  the  good  relationship  between  the  United  States  and  Germany.   Reemstma  admitted  that  a  loss  of  credibil  ity  threatened  to  undermine  the  exhibit’s  thesis.  He  added  that  researchers  had  too  often  depended  on  archival  descriptions  of  photos.  But  he  denied  that  any  photos  had   been  falsified.  ita   JTA

heading: Distance hampers German push
article_text: istance  hampers  German  push   By  IAN  McPHEDRAN   Foreign  Affairs  Reporter   Moves  by  German  companies  to  use  Australia  as  a  regional  headquarters  will  be  dampened  by  distance  and  the  hierarchical  nature  of  their  head  offices,  ac  cording  to  the  German  Ambas  sador  in  Canberra,  Franz  Keil.   Last  week's  announcement  by  German  automotive  supplier  Hella  that,  it  planned  to  establish  a  re  gional  headquarters  in  Australia  was,  the  latest  in  a  series  of  moves  by  German  corporations  to  in  crease  their  stakes  in.  Australia  and  the  Asia-Pacific  region.   Hella,  which  supplies  all  Austra  lian  car-makers  with  light  and  sig  nals,  systems,  might  be  the  first  German  manufacturer  to  establish  a  regional  headquarters  in  Austra  lia,  but  German  investment  has  been  growing  steadily  from  SI.5  billioij  in  1986  to  $2.4  billion  last   year.   The  Industry  Minister,  Peter  Cook,  who  announced  the  move  by  Hella  from  Germany  last  week  said  .he  expected  Hella's  decision  to  establish  a  new  trend  for  German  companies  wanting  access  to  the  burge.oning  markets  of  Asia.   More  than  70  foreign  companies  have  established  regional  headquar  ters,  in  Australia  including  36  from  the  United  States,  20  from  Britain,  and.,  three  from  Sweden.   According  to  Dr  Keil,  who  re  tires  in  September,  the  Asia-Pacific   was  not  new  to  German  business,  but  there  was  a  growing  conscious  ness  in  the  boardrooms  of  Germa  ny  of  the  importance  and  dyna  mism;  of  the  region.   The  German  Government  launched  a  new  strategy  for.  the  Asia-Pacific  last  October  and  that  was  followed  up  by  ambassadors'  conferences  in  Bonn  in  January  and  in  Bangkok  in  April.   "This  is  part  of  a  concerted  ef  fort  to  intensify  our  efforts  in  the  Asia-Pacific  particularly  for  small  and  medium-sized  businesses,"  Dr  Keil  said.   He  said  the  springboard  theory  for  European  companies  to  use  Australia  as  a  base  into  Asia,  which  has  been  promoted  heavily  by  Senator  Cook,  had  some  good  points  including  language  and  in  frastructure.  However,  he  believes  Australia  suffers  the  tyranny  of  distance  when  companies  analyse  access  in  to  North  Asian  markets.   "It  is  9/2  hours  from  Sydney  to  Tokyo  and  only  lO'/i  from  Frank  furt  to  Tokyo.  There  are  many  good  arguments  in  favour  of  the  springboard  theory  particularly  for  businesses  targeting  niche  mar  kets,"  Dr  Keil  said.   Dr  Keil  cited  the  German-owned  Australian  engineering  firm,  Bauld  erstone  Hornibrook,  which  enabled  parent  company  Bilfingfer  and  Ber  ger  to  gain  a  foothold  in  the  Chi  nese  market  via  a  SI40  million   Baulderstone  Hornibrook  project.   THE  TOP  10  GERMAN  FIRMS  IN  AUSTRALIA   Company  Woriwrs  Robert  Bosch  1550  Daimler  Benz  1013  Westdeutsch  Landesbarik   (Thomas  Cook  Australia)....  980  Hoechst....:..  900  VDO.........  610  Deutsche  Bank   (Bain  and  Co)  600  •  Bayer  AG..„...  440  Degussa..;  340  BASF  300  Bilfinger  and  Berger   (Baulderstone  Hornibrook).  300   DIRECT  INVESTMENT  IN  AUSTRALIA   BASF   $Ab  United  States  35.0  United  Kingdom  25.7  Japan  17.4  Netherlands  4.2  Switzerland  2.8  Germany  2.4   0   BAULDERSTONE  HORNIBROOK   In  its  marketing  material,  the  Australian  Trade  Commission,  Austrade,  claims  that  Australia  is  ideally  located  as  a  regional  base,  being  in  the  Asian  time  zone  with  daily  non-stop  flights  throughout  the  region.   Dr  Keil  said  a  major  stumbling  block  for  German  companies  es   tablishing  regional  bases  in  Austra  lia  were  the  restrictions  placed  on  regional  offices  by  head  office  deci  sion-makers.  "Many  companies  cannot  delegate  power  away  from  the  head  office  in  Germany  and  that  is  one  of  the  major  complaints  we  hear  from  subsidiary  companies  based  here,"  he  said.   Germany  has  a  long-standing  re  lationship  with  ASEAN  via  the  European  Union-ASEAN  treaty  and  its  links  with  the  region  date  back  to  colonial  days  when  West  ern  Samoa  was  a  German  colony.   Dr  Keil  rejects  the  notion  that  Germany's  colonial  past  could  im  pact  badly  on  its  push  into  the  re  gion.  "I  was  in  Western  Samoa  re  cently  '  and  the  people  there  have  only  good  memories  of  the  Ger  man  colonial  times,"  he  said.   According  to  Dr  Keil,  the  Ger  man  Government  has  taken  seri  ously  the  claims  by  Prime  Minister  Paul  Keating  that  Australia's  push   into  Asia  was  not  a  zero  sum  game.'There  is  a  growing  con  sciousness  in  the  Australian  Gov  ernment  that  focusing  on  Asia  docs  not  mean  neglecting  Europe,"   he  said.   "The  recently  signed  treaty  be  tween  the  European  Union  and  the  ASEAN  Free  Trade  Area  creates  a  market  of  370  million  people  which  is  bigger  than  the-  North  American  Free  Trade  Area  and   vety  important  for  Australia."   Dr  Keil,  who  is  a  former  ambas  sador  at  large  for  Asia-Pacific  in  the  German  Foreign  Office  will  be  replaced  in  Canberra  by  Klaus  Geller,  head  of  the  Foreign  Minis  try's  Asia-Pacific  desk.   .  The  appointment  of  two  Asia  experts  to  Australia  plus  the  visit  by  German  President  Richard  Von  Weizsacker  last  year  are  evidence   of  the  renewed  commitment  on  the  part  of  the  Bonn  Government  to  Australia  and  the  region:   Apart  from  the  slight  hiccup  in  relations  when  a  women's  Aborigi  nal  dance  troupe  was  subjected  to  racism  at  a  German  hotel  earlier  this  year,  the  bilateral  relationship  is  in  great  shape.   Further  proof  of  Germany's  growing  interest  in  Australia  was  the  decision  by  Economics  Minister  Guentcr  Rexrodt  to  visit  Australia  next  year.  Mr  Rexrodt  told  Sena  tor  Cook  in  Bonn  last  week  that,  subject  to  the  Government  being  returned  in  October's  general  elec  tion,  he  would  visit  next  May  for  a  conference  of  Australian  and  German  chambers  of  commerce.   More  than  60  German  compa  nies  operate  in  Australia  and  Ger  many  is  the  fourth  largest  Europe  an  direct  investor  in  Australia.   Last  year's  figure  of  $2.4  billion  placed  it  behind  Britain  ($25.7  bil  lion),  the  Netherlands  ($4.2  billion)  and  Switzerland  ($2.8  billion).  In  vestment  was  divided  between  sev  eral  sectors  with  manufacturing,  chemicals,  mining  and  finance  ac  counting  for  the  lion's  share.   Some  of  the  German  players  in  Australia  are  Robert  Bosch,  with  1550  employees,  Daimler  Benz  (Mercedes  Benz  Australia)  with  1000,  chemical  giant  Hoechst  with  900  and  Westdeutsch  Landesbank  Girozentrale  (Thomas  Cook  Aus  tralia)  with  980.

heading: German donates to Wizo
article_text: I  German  donates  to  Wizo   Bonn:  AN  elderly  German  retired  state  employee  has  donated  a  million  marks  to  Wizo.  In  a  ceremony  at  the  Israeli  Con  sulate  in  Berlin,  84-year-  old  Gunther  Rutschke  explained  his  motive  for  the  donation,  which  is  equivalent  to  about  A$900,000:  “I  want  to  prove  that  there  are  other,  good  Germans,  who  really  care  about  what  happened  to  the  Jews.”  Rutschke,  who  donated  the  money  from  his  life  savings,  added  that  no  sum  can  compensate  the  Jews  for  their  sufferings  under  the  Third  Reich.  But  he  said  it  was  nevertheless  important  to  demonstrate  to  the  Jews  that  many  Germans  love  the  Jewish  people.

heading: German shame over bombing
article_text: German  shame  over  bombing   BONN:  Politicians  and.  pressure  groups  announced  demonstrations  and  vigils  as  Germany  reacted  in  shock  and  shame  yesterday  to  the  fire-bombing  of  a  syna  gogue  on  the  eve  of  the  Passover  festival.   Neo-Nazis  were  suspected  of  carrying  out'the  arson   attack,  which  was  believed  to  be  the  first  on  a  syna-.  gogue  since  the  Nazis  ransacked  and  burned  Jewish  shops  and  temples  in  the  1938  "Kristallnacht"  pro  gram,  in  the  early  hours  of  Friday.   The  petrol-bombing  of  the  synagogue  in  the  north  ern  port  of  Luebeck  prompted  shock  and  outrage  among  politicians,  religious  leaders  and  commentators.   "It  would  be  fatal  to  try  and  play  down  the  attack,  to  console  oneself  with  the  thought  that  no-one  was  hurt  and  the  damage  was  minimal,"  said  the  Frank  furter  Rundschau  newspaper.  "Any  attempt  to  shrug  it  off  would  leave  the  Holocaust  survivors,  with  their  jus  tifiable  fears,  alone  again."   Residents  of  Luebeck  held  an  all-night  vigil  in  the  charred  synagogue  building,  and  the  city  called  for  five  minutes  of  silence  before  noon,  accompanied  by  the   halting  of  traffic.   I   -  Rtutof  I
snippet: BONN: Politicians and pressure groups announced demonstrations and vigils as Germany reacted in shock and shame yesterday to the fire-bombing of a synagogue on the eve of the Passover festival.

heading: Envoy defends German stand
article_text: Envoy  defends   German  stand   Bernard  Freedman   GERMAN  ambassador  Dr  Franz  Keil  has  rejected  a  charge  that  the  German  government  lacks   the  will  and  determination  to  deal  with  racist  violence  in  east   ern  Germany.   He  said,  however,  that  mis  takes  had  occurred  with  the  police  in  Rostock  which  were  being  examined  to  ensure  they  did  not  happen  in  future.   Dr  Keil  was  responding  to  a  protest  from  Executive  Council  of  Australian  Jewry  president  Leslie  Caplan  about  the  German  government’s  failure  to  control   the  Rostock  racist  riots.   In  a  letter  to  Mr  Caplan,  Dr  Keil  said  he  respected  deeply  the  Jewish  community’s  concern  “even  if  the  riots  in  Rostock  had  no  antisemitic  connotation”.  He  had  conveyed  the  community’s  concern  to  the  German  govern   ment  in  Bonn.   Dr  Keil  said  post-war  federal  German  governments  had  tried  their  utmost  to  foster  reconcilia  tion  between  Jews  and  Germans  and  had  always  condemned  racist  agitation,  violence  and  xenophobia  which  were  punish  able  under  the  federal  penal   code.   All  German  authorities  took  these  offences  very  seriously  and  did  everything  possible  to  bring  perpetrators  to  justice.   “I  therefore  cannot  agree  with  your  assessment  that  there  was  a  lack  of  will  and  determina  tion  by  the  federal  government  to  control  the  situation  in  Ros  tock,  even  in  its  early  stages,”  Dr  Keil  told  Mr  Caplan.   A  document  accompanying   Dr  Keil’s  letter  blamed  condi  tions  in  the  former  German  Democratic  Republic  for  local  police  in  Rostock  being  insuffi  ciently  trained  and  equipped  to  deal  with  crowd  control,  riot  sit  uations  and  rioting  extremists.   It  said  law  enforcement  authorities  also  faced  the  prob  lem  that  those  perpetrating  the  violence  were  better  organised  and  had  verbal  support  from  some  people  in  the  local  popula   tion.   The  document  said  there   were  76  “mostly  very  small  and  locally  organised  neo-Nazi  par  ties  and  organisations  in  Ger  many  with  a  membership  num  bering  40,000.   While  the  number  of  mem  bers  was  decreasing,  the  willing  ness  of  activists  to  commit  acts   of  violence  was  increasing  and  offenders  were  getting  younger.  Rostock  police  were  now  arrest  ing  14  and  16  year  olds.   The  majority  of  those  com  mitting  acts  of  violence  were  “skinheads”,  of  whom  there  were  about  3000  in  the  eastern  states.  Under  the  previous  East  German  communist  government  they  had  considered  themselves  a  “National  Socialist  opposition”.   The  document  said  the  feder  al  German  government  had  recently  provided  DM20  million  ($A22  million)  for  an  “action  pro  gram  against  aggression  and  vio  lence”   This  involved  education  and  information  work  among  young  people,  many  of  whom  were  easy  targets  for  recruitment  by  vio  lent  groups  because  of  their  “political  and  social  disorienta  tion”.

heading: German Jews sound alarm
article_text: German  Jews  sound  alarm   DAVID  KANTOR   Bonn:  GERMANY’S  small  Jew  ish  community  has  sounded  an  alarm  over  the  escalation  of  neo  Nazi  violence,  especially  in  form  er  East  Germany.   Heinz  Galinski,  chairman  of  the  German  Jewish  community,  has  urged  Interior  Minister  Wolfgang  Schaeuble  to  enforce  the  bans  on  events  such  as  the  celebration  of  Hitler’s  birthday,  which  invariably  stir  violence,  or  a  vigil  in  Munich  several  weeks  ago  at  which  the  truth  of  the  Holocaust  was  publicly  denied.   About  150  neo-Nazi  youths  and  Skinheads  were  taken  into  tem  porary  .  custody  in  Dresden  on  Saturday  to  prevent  a  clash  with  anti-fascists  after  they  marched  through  the  city  to  mark  the  fuhrer’s  102nd  anniversary.  About  15  neo-Nazis  were  arrested  in  Ober  weser,  near  Kassel  in  central  Ger   many,  after  a  Hitler  party  that  damaged  shops  and  parked  cars.   In  Osnabruck,  in  the  north  state  of  Hanover,  neo-Nazi  activists  at  tacked  a  group  of  Kurds  who  were  on  a  hunger  strike  to  protest  the  Iraqi  massacre  of  their  people.  Some  Kurds  were  badly  beaten  by  the  time  police  arrived  and  their  tent  was  demolished.   In  Magdeburg,  in  the  centre  of  what  was  formerly  East  Germany,  dozens  of  neo-Nazi  hooligans  clashed  with  police  after  throwing  cans  and  assaulting  spectators  at  a  local  soccer  match.  Several  arrests  were  reported.  Incidents  involving  neo-Nazis  were  also  reported  in  Leipzig,  Cottbus  and  Birkenwerda  in  eastern  Germany.   Galinski  demanded  that  the  authorities  intervene  more  forceful  ly  when  right-wing  extremists  dis  play  Nazi  symbols  in  violation  of   the  law  and  spread  anti-semitic  propaganda.   In  Munich,  neo-Nazis  claimed  no  Jews  were  ever  killed  at  Ausch  witz  and  Treblinka.  How  can  Ger   many  subject  its  small  surviving  Jewish  community  to  such  outra  geous  expressions?  Galinski  asked.   The  Jewish  leader'had  urged  the  prime  minister  of  Saxony,  Kurt  Biedenkopf,  to  ban  the  Hitler  birthday  march  in  Dresden.  Dres  den  has  become  the  centre  of  neo  Nazi  activity,  which  spread  after  the  Communist  regime  was  ousted  from  East  Germany  in  1989.  In  re  cent  weeks,  visitors  from  Poland  have  been  attacked  in  eastern  Ger  many  after  the  country  abolished  visa  requirements  for  them.   Sociologists  have  blamed  the  emergence  of  right-wing  extremism  in  the  former  Communist-ruled  territory  on  unemployment,  poor  living  conditions  and  the  collapse  of  state  and  parental  authority.  (JTA)  ■

heading: Sister enjoys German food
article_text: Sister  enjoys  German  food   ST  Joseph's  School  Principal  Josephine  Dubiel  while  very  busy  with  her  work,  finds  time  to  enjoy  cooking  German  meals.  Sr  Josephine's  love  for  German  meals  stems  from  her  family  background.  Her  mother  was  German  and  her  father  was  Polish  and  emigrated  to  Australia  following  World  War  Two.  They  were  among  the  first  refugees  to  be  stationed  at  Woodside.  Sr  Josephine  said  she  lived  with  three  other  sisters,  at  St  Joseph's  convent  at  Port  Lincoln,  who  all  shared  the  cooking.  However  she  mainly  cooked  on  the  weekend  when  she  had  time  away  from  her  school  commitments.  She  admitted  to  being  a  sweet  tooth,  and  German  food  provided  a  wealth  of  delicious  tortes,  desserts  and  cakes.  Sr  Josephine  shares  some  of  her  favourite  recipes  with  Lifestyle  readers:  Pancake  soup  Ingredients  Prepare  your  favourite  beef  stock  Pancake  mixture  2  heaped  tablespoons  of  plain  flour  2  eggs  pinch  of  salt  milk  Method  Beat  this  mixture  until  it  is  a   smooth  and  thin  batter.  Cook  as  very  thin  pancakes,  and  then  roll  up  the  pancakes  and  cut  into  very  thin  slices  (so  it  looks  like  noodles).  Place  about  half  a  cup  of  the  pancake  noodles  into  a  soup  bowl  and  add  very  hot  stock.  Garnish  with  chopped  chives.  Stuffed  capsicums  (served  as  a  light  meal  or  as  accompaniment  to  meat)  Ingredients  large  capsicum  2  middle-sized  potatoes  almost  cooked  and  lightly  mashed  150  grams  shredded  Edam  or  tasty  cheese  1  onion  chopped  150  grams  of  bacon  or  ham  finely  chopped  2  eggs  100  grams  peas  (canned  or  slightly  cooked  if  frozen)  1  dessertspoon  of  plain  flour  salt  and  pepper  few  drops  of  tabasco  sauce  Method  Halve  the  capsicums,  remove  seeds  and  wash.  b  m  s  s  t  m  b   Combine  all  other  ingredients  and  fill  the  capsicum  with  the  mixture.  Place  in  a  Pyrex  dish,  add  about  250  ml  of  water  or  stock  and  bake  at  210  degrees  Celsius  for  30  to  40  minutes.  Cherry  cake  (Kirschkuchen)  Ingredients  80  grams  butter  80  grams  sugar  2  eggs  grated  lemon  rind  6  dessertspoons  of  milk  250  grams  of  self-raising  flour  melted  butter  drained  pitted  black  cherries  Method  Combine  butter  and  sugar.  Add  eggs  and  lemon.  Mix  with  flour  and  milk  alternately  to  make  a  dough.  Grease  a  baking  tray  (about  20  to  30  cm)  and  roll  out  the  dough  to  form  the  base.  Brush  over  with  melted  butter  and  spread  cherries  over  the  ase.  Bake  about  15  minutes  in  a  oderate  oven.  Topping  3  to  4  egg  whites  100  grams  of  sugar  or  caster  ugar  Beat  the  egg  whites  with  the  ugar  well  and  then  spread  over  he  cake.  Bake  a  further  10  to  15  inutes  until  the  topping  rowns.  d   •  St  Joseph's  School  Principal  Josephine  Dubiel  prepared  this  stuffed  capsicum  ish  in  advance  as  a  quick  and  easy  light  meal  which  only  needs  to  be  baked  and  is  then  ready  to  eat.
snippet: ST Joseph’s School Principal Josephine Dubiel while very busy with her work, finds time to enjoy cooking
